LEAD: The Bank Money Accounts table in Business Day yesterday misstated the yield for a six-month certificate of deposit at Marine Midland Bank.
It is 7.84 percent.

PRETORIA LEADERS LINKED TO KILLINGS
LEAD: A retired South African police captain who has said he commanded a ''hit squad'' that killed Government opponents says he has evidence that killings were authorized at the highest levels of the South Africa Government.


British Trade Gap Grows
LEAD: Britain said today that the country's foreign trade deficit more than doubled in January from December.
The deficit was $:1.88 billion, or $3.16 billion, compared with the revised $:817 million, or $1.37 billion, gap for December.
The Central Statistical Office attributed the size of the January gap, which was larger than had been expected, to a deficit in several items that were expected to show a small surplus.


Natural Gas Refueling Station Opens
LEAD: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company will open the first compressed natural gas refueling station available to the public on Thursday in Concord, Calif.


Abandoned Newborn Girl Dies
LEAD: A newborn baby girl died last night shortly after she was found in a garbage can in front of an apartment building in the Van Nest section of the Bronx, the police said.
The infant's faint cries were heard shortly after 5 P.M. by the building's landlord, said the police.
A neighbor helped the landlord lift the lid and pull out a duffel bag.


Upheaval in the East;   Lithuania Steps Up Drive to Leave Soviet Union
LEAD: The republic of Lithuania stepped up its campaign to leave the Soviet Union today, announcing a new round of parliamentary elections in concern that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will soon have stronger emergency powers to oppose secession.


24,000 Gallons of Oil Spill Off Bayonne
LEAD: More than 24,000 gallons of heating oil leaked from a hole in a barge here at the Constable Hook terminal of the Exxon Company this morning.
The leak spread gobs of oil into Upper New York Bay as far as Liberty Island, forcing officials to close the Kill van Kull between this city and Staten Island to marine traffic.

Upheaval in the East: The Germanys;   Kohl Takes Tentative Step On Polish Border Proposal
LEAD: Under pressure at home and abroad, Chancellor Helmut Kohl took a tentative step today toward meeting Poland's demands for a guarantee of its western border once Germany is reunited, but he again declined Warsaw's call for a provisional treaty.


Goodyear Resignation
LEAD: James K. DeVoe, the vice president for worldwide advertising at the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, resigned yesterday to become a principal in and the president of an advertising agency in Ohio.
Mr.
DeVoe, who previously held executive positions at BBDO and N. W. Ayer in New York and at RCA Consumer Electronics, would not disclose the name of the agency he was joining.

The Battle Of Bedtime: Children Won
LEAD: STEPHEN CECCHETTI, an economist who lives in Columbus, Ohio, says his 2-year-old son Daniel stays up every night until 10 or 10:30.
Mr.
Cecchetti would like Daniel to go to bed earlier, but he doesn't insist. ''We're not disciplined people,'' says Mr.
Cecchetti, whose wife, Ruth Charney, is a mathematician.


Tokyo Stocks Fall 2.2%, Ending a 2-Day Rally
LEAD: Rising interest rates and weakness in the yen abruptly reversed a two-day stock market rally and sent prices sharply lower here today.


Swedish Prices Up 3.2%
LEAD: Swedish consumer prices jumped 3.2 percent in January, the highest monthly increase in a decade, from four-tenths of a percent the previous month, the Central Bureau of Statistics said Tuesday.


Fannie Mae Buying Sears Mortgages
LEAD: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, announced yesterday that it had agreed to purchase over the next year about $2 billion in home mortgages orginated by the Sears Mortgage Corporation, a subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck &amp; Company.

Topics of The Times;   Tax Writeoffs in Ski Country
LEAD: The Federal tax code has long invited lawyers, doctors and other professionals to mix a little bit of work with a lot of play by allowing them to deduct most of the costs of attending an educational conference.
Not atypically, a recent medical seminar at a Colorado ski resort hotel featured four hours of lectures daily - all artfully scheduled before the lifts opened in the morning and after they closed in late afternoon.

CHRONCILE
LEAD: The Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington lost another curator yesterday, a defection that leaves the museum's four top positions empty.
FRANKLIN KELLY, a historian of American art who joined the Corcoran in December 1988 as curator of the permanent collection, will return to the National Gallery of Art next month as research curator of


Regiments of Flowers Protesting Winter's Iron Rule
LEAD: SPRING has been teasing for weeks.
It's particularly hard on gardeners tortured by a torrent of mail-order catalogues with pictures of perfect plants.
If sanity is to prevail through the latest blast of Arctic air, the antidote might be a pilgrimage to one of those annual extravaganzas called flower shows.


2 Sentenced in Haas Case
LEAD: Two prosecution witnesses in the stock manipulation case against the chairman of the Haas Securities Corporation were sentenced yesterday to prison terms.
The sentencings of Haas's former president, Stanley Aslanian Jr., and a stock promoter, Henry Lorin, came a day after the former chairman, Eugene Laff, was sentenced to five years in prison for manipulating stock prices.


Upheaval in the East;   How the Mutiny on 'Red October' Sub Really Happened
LEAD: The Government newspaper Izvestia has confirmed Western news reports of an attempted mutiny aboard a Soviet naval vessel in 1975 that Tom Clancy used as the basis of his bestseller, ''The Hunt for Red October.''


Difficulties In Filling Wall's Job
LEAD: The Treasury Department's struggles to find a replacement for M. Danny Wall as the nation's top Federal savings and loan regulator are such that it could be weeks, even months, before a permanent successor is named, Government officials and industry experts said today.


Twins Sign Candelaria
LEAD: The Minnesota Twins reached contract terms yesterday with the free agent left-hander John Candelaria, a 16-year veteran.

Receivership For Empire
LEAD: Federal banking regulators have placed Empire of America Federal Savings Bank in receivership and changed its name to Empire Federal Savings Bank of America.

LEAD: A qualified plan to allow revival of the family farm but maintain Communism's ban on private ownership of land was approved today by the Supreme Soviet and sent on to likely final approval in the Soviet Congress.


Judge Explains His Ruling in the Jogger Case
LEAD: In explaining a major decision he issued last week, the judge in the Central Park rape case said yesterday that the police were not required to give warnings against self-incrimination to every suspect they questioned on the night of the incident until they began to question them about their specific roles in the attack.

LEAD: Despite the wish of politicians in Bonn to speed up the monetary and economic union of East and West Germany, the president of the West German Bundesbank, Karl Otto Pohl, said today that it would take ''a few months, at the least,'' even after the East German elections on March 18.

LEAD: Rick Rhoden, the right-hander who won 28 games in two seasons with the Yankees, said he was retiring from baseball because of recurring back problems.

LEAD: Michael Feldman, the artistic director of the various St.
Luke's musical ensembles, studied with Vittorio Rieti, which is one explanation for the admirable St.
Luke's loyalty to that composer's music.
The loyalty has expressed itself in all-Rieti concerts by the St.
Luke's Chamber Ensemble every two or three years, the most recent being Tuesday night at Merkin Concert Hall.

Currents;   The Great OpportunityTo Sit in Your Own Lap
LEAD: PHILLIP GRACE's trompe l'oeil portrait chairs combine function and art.
If you commission your own portrait, you can sit in your own lap.


Peace Talks on Cambodia Break Down
LEAD: The latest peace talks on Cambodia broke down early this morning, with the rival Cambodian factions unable to agree on even a carefully worded communique that elided the central issue: a role for the United Nations in the administration of the country before new elections.


Fernandez and O'Connor Clash on Drug-Counseling Sites
LEAD: New York City Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez and John Cardinal O'Connor have come into conflict over where publicly financed drug counselors should work with parochial school students.


Frederick Peters, 81, Publishing Executive
LEAD: Frederick P. Peters, retired executive vice president of the Reinhold Publishing Company in Manhattan and a former professor of management, died of a ruptured aorta on Sunday at the Southwest Florida Regional Medical Center in Fort Myers.
He was 81 years old and lived in Naples, Fla., and Summit, N.J.

LEAD: DRENTTEL DOYLE PARTNERS, a design and advertising concern in Manhattan, has designed three watches that are both witty and slightly hard to read.
One shows the numbers on the rotary dial telephone, one the numbers on an oven dial and the third the numbers of subway trains.


Nicaragua, Victory U.S. Fair Play
LEAD: The Nicaraguan election has proved that open, honorable support for a democratic process is one of the most powerful foreign policy tools at Washington's disposal.
It is more effective than the sordid practice of using the Central Intelligence Agency to engineer coups and secretly finance political parties.

Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday about anti-abortion protesters who were fined for blocking abortion and family-planning clinics misidentified a lawyer for one plaintiff.
It was David Cole, not David Lerner, who represented the National Organization for Women.
Mr.
Cole is a lawyer with the Center for Constitutional Rights; David Lerner is a spokesman for the center.

LEAD: Carmine S. Bellino, a Congressional investigator for 30 years who was credited with a major role in bringing about the downfall of the teamster leaders James R. Hoffa and Dave Beck, died of prostate cancer on Tuesday at his home in Coconut Creek, Fla., where he had lived in retirement since 1983.
He was 84 years old.

LEAD: Prices of RJR Nabisco Inc.'s bonds dropped sharply yesterday in an otherwise steady ''junk bond'' market.

Review/Recital;   Love Songs For Tenor And Lute
LEAD: The program of love songs from 17th-century England and Italy presented by the English tenor Nigel Rogers and the American lutanist Paul O'Dette at Weill Recital Hall on Friday evening seemed a sort of work in progress.
After the Stagebill was printed, the performers substituted one Henry Lawes tune for another, split up and reordered a group of works by Sigismondo d'India and replaced a group of songs by Alessandro Grandi with a cantata by Antonio Cesti.

Close to Home
LEAD: TO get from where I am staying to where I am presumably working is a curious journey.
I am in a motel, the plain kind, the kind without a strip of paper across the toilet seat and complimentary shampoo and a bed that will tickle your back if you put money in the slot.
From the window in the shag-carpeted living room, I can see a little courtyard and rooms just like mine.

LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation extended its guaranteed rebate program through the end of March.

LEAD: Sales of existing homes declined 2.2 percent in January, as rising mortgage interest rates and the usual winter lull combined to reduce sales to their slowest pace since last summer, a real estate trade group said today.

New York's Patrol Officers to Go on Steady Shifts
LEAD: The New York City Police Department has reversed a longstanding policy and will begin assigning uniformed officers to steady shifts by September, the First Deputy Commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, said yesterday.

INSIDE
LEAD:
An Economic Improvement Is Revealed in Latest Data
The economy grew at an annual rate of nine-tenths of 1 percent in the fourth quarter last year.
The performance was stronger than initially estimated but still the weakest in any quarter since 1986.
Page D1.
5 Defect From Shamir Party
Five Likud members of the Israeli Parliament bolted to form a new opposition party, deepening Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's political problems.


Tests of Cockpit Radiation Show Levels Above a Federal Standard
LEAD: The first cockpit radiation measurements presented to an aviation health panel confirmed estimates by experts that some airline crew members receive more radiation than the limit set by health officials for pregnant women, panel members said here today.


Ex-Vice President at Orion Is Chief of Tri-Star Pictures
LEAD: Michael Medavoy, who began his Hollywood career in the mailroom at Universal Studios, has been named chairman of Tri-Star Pictures, with responsibility for developing, producing and marketing Tri-Star products, Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc., Tri-Star's parent, has announced.


Storm Stirs Fires on Corsica
LEAD: The Atlantic storm that has killed at least 53 people in northern Europe has reached the Mediterranean, turning small blazes on this island into major brush fires.
In Nancy, in eastern France, a motorist died when he was blown off an icy road late Tuesday.
Fifty-three deaths have been reported since the storm struck Monday: 17 in Britain, 12 in West Germany, 3 in East Germany, 11 in France, 5 in Belgium, 2 in Switzerland and 1 each in Ireland, Italy and the Netherlands.

LEAD: After years in the trenches of America's drug war, John C. Lawn, the Drug Enforcement Administration chief, is heading to a new turf: overseeing operations for the Yankees baseball organization.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Daphne Arnstein; Arts Group Founder In Harlem Was 78
LEAD: Daphne Barritt-Vane Arnstein, an arts patron who founded the Harlem Cultural Council and was a co-founder of the Jazzmobile, died of heart disease Saturday in Mount Sinai Hospital.
She was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Clerics Urge End to Lebanese Christian Strife
LEAD: The heads of Lebanon's 16 Christian denominations issued an impassioned appeal to warring factions today to stop their fierce fighting.

LEAD: On a recent warm evening, 14 candidates for the Ukrainian parliament gathered at a hall here to promote their programs to voters in this agricultural and industrial region.


N.F.L. and ESPN in Accord On New Cable TV Contract
LEAD: ESPN Inc. and the National Football League agreed yesterday on a new four-year contract that people close to the deal said would more than double the money that the N.F.L. now receives for broadcasts on sports cable television network.


Clemson Case Revised
LEAD: The National Collegiate Athletic Association dropped one of 14 charges of recruiting violations against Clemson's program and amended two others, university officials said yesterday.


Supreme Court Roundup;   Justices Uphold Property Searches Of Foreigners in Foreign Countries
LEAD: The Supreme Court ruled today that the Constitution's prohibition against unreasonable searches does not bar American law-enforcement agents who lack warrants from searching and seizing property owned by foreigners in foreign countries.

Residents of Covenant House Split on Its Future and Ritter
LEAD: On this they agreed: after decades of devoted, even life-saving work, Covenant House is suffering an unjust damage to its reputation.

Bruce Ritter's decision to leave the organization he founded, staff members and residents were divided on other questions.


Ex-Banker to Help U.S. in Marcos Case
LEAD: A former bank executive who was charged with helping Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos transfer $168 million from the Philippines to the United States pleaded guilty yesterday to mail fraud.


Soviet McDonald's Serves 30,000 Daily
LEAD: The first McDonald's restaurant in the Soviet Union is serving 30,000 people a day in Moscow, a company official said.
The company, based in Oak Brook, Ill., had originally predicted that the world's largest McDonald's would serve from 10,000 to 15,000 people a day.
Over all, McDonald's serves 22 million people daily in 11,000 restaurants in 52 countries.

Electronic Monitoring Doesn't HelpIn Premature Births, a Study Finds
LEAD: Electronic monitoring of the heart rate of premature infants during labor and delivery does not improve chances of survival or normal neurological development and may be linked to higher rates of cerebral palsy, a new study has found.


4 Senior Editors Resign In Protest at Pantheon
LEAD: Four of the five senior editors at Pantheon Books resigned yesterday in protest over the removal earlier this week of Andre Schiffrin, the publishing house's longtime managing director.

Nahum N. Glatzer Is Dead at 86; Wrote About Jewish Philosophy
LEAD: Nahum N. Glatzer, a scholar, an editor and the author of many works on literature and Jewish philosophy, died on Tuesday after several days in a coma in Tucson, Ariz., where he was spending the winter.
He was 86 years old and lived in Watertown, Mass.

Joel M. Tropper, Stage Manager, 46
LEAD: Joel M. Tropper, a stage manager, died of AIDS on Friday in Orlando, Fla.
He was 46 years old.
Mr.
Tropper was a member of Actors' Equity and a founding member and former chairman of the Stage Managers' Association.
He managed many Broadway shows, including ''Woman of the Year,'' ''Ain't Misbehavin','' ''Beatlemania,'' ''Porgy and Bess,'' ''Rags'' and ''Elvis.

Harley-Davidson Investor in Filing
LEAD: The Rochester investor Malcolm I. Glazer has recommended that Harley-Davidson Inc. spin off its Holiday Rambler Corporation unit and distribute the proceeds to shareholders.
Mr.
Glazer suggested in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that the division could be spun off as a public company, with the shares being distributed to holders.

LEAD: John M. Poindexter said in court papers filed today that he believed that Ronald Reagan's diaries while President accurately documented important Iran-contra events that Mr.
Reagan now says he has forgotten.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
HORSE RACING
Lost in Flight Wins by a Neck
Lost in Flight swung off the rail nearing the stretch, took the lead at the eighth pole and outlasted Dusty's Talc by a neck yesterday to win the $36,000 allowance feature at Aqueduct.
The winner, ridden by Mike Smith, covered a mile and 70 yards on a fast track in 1:44 for her second victory in four starts this season.

The station, which was part of the setting for the book ''Red Storm Rising,'' has 4,379 military personnel and 1,040 civilians.

XTRA Dissidents' Sale Commitment
LEAD: The independent shareholders' committee of the XTRA Corporation said it was committed to supporting a cash sale of the company that was in the best interests of shareholders. ''If management can commence a transaction that achieves this goal before the annual meeting, we pledge ourselves to its consummation,'' a committee spokesman said.

LEAD: The agent in charge of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration in New York City and a top undercover agent for it are leaving the D.E.A. with harsh words about Federal drug policy, saying that it is ill conceived and that the Government's operations abroad are futile.


Political Strife Threatens Himalayas Tourism
LEAD: The tourism industry in the state of Jammu and Kashmir, one of the best-known travel destinations in Asia for Himalayan treks and climbs and vacations in houseboats, is likely to be crippled this summer unless anti-India agitation eases.


Late Goal Beats Islanders
LEAD: It was an unusual rookie whose late goal beat the Islanders, 4-3, tonight and dropped them into third place in the Patrick Division.
Daniel Shank of the Red Wings scored with with 1 minute 31 seconds left, leaving the Islanders below .500 for the first time since Jan. 13 and extending their streak without a victory to seven games, a season high.

LEAD: The Lockheed Corporation, defending itself against a planned proxy fight by the Dallas financier Harold C. Simmons, said its board had passed a resolution affirming its opposition to the payment of ''greenmail.'' A proposal made on Monday by Mr.
Simmons, who owns 18.9 percent of Lockheed, would ban such payments on stock held less than two years.

Undermining the Undercount Remedy
LEAD: This year's census, which the Commerce Department says may be ''the best ever,'' could prove the worst in decades for big cities with many hard-to-count people.
And now Commerce is reneging on a promise to take a fresh, open-minded look at its methods.
It has proposed stiff guidelines that would doom the nation to another undercount of urban minorities.

LEAD: Because of malfunctions in The Times's newsroom computer network on Tuesday, the News Summary and several articles were omitted from some editions yesterday, or were mutilated.

The Times regrets the inconvenience to readers.

LEAD: Rescuers used hoes and shovels today to dig through thick mud and rock that swept across a Peruvian jungle village, killing at least 21 people.

Belial and Other Oddities Return in 'Basket Case 2'
''I understand your pain,'' the gray-haired psychiatrist called Granny Ruth says in a kind and comforting voice to the patient on her couch -the mutant severed half of a Siamese twin, a creature resembling a giant Mr.
Potato Head with gangly arms and blue eyes. ''But ripping the faces off people may not be in your best interest,'' she croons.
''Basket Case 2'' continues the story of Belial, who was once a growth sticking out from under his normal-looking brother's arm and is now a violence-prone individual carried around by his twin in a wicker basket.
As cheap horror spoofs go, this one isn't all bad.
Granny Ruth, known to the world as Dr.
Freak, has taken the twins into her menage of misfits, which includes a man with 27 noses, a creature with a frog's head, even a woman with the figure of a tree stump who turns out to be a perfect match for Belial.
These creatures actually look cheery, not fearsome.

LEAD: Women's History Month is being celebrated with a variety of events around New York City.
Here is a sampling of events this weekend.
For more information, consult the Women's History Month Calendar published by the New York City Commission on the Status of Women, 52 Chambers Street, Suite 207 (566-3832).

'Roger &amp; Me': Narrow, Simplistic, Wrong
LEAD: Many people were outraged that Michael Moore's documentary, ''Roger &amp; Me,'' was shut out in the Academy Award nominations.
I can't understand why.
The film mocks American culture brilliantly, but forfeits any claim to distinction by manipulating its audience to believe that General Motors abandoned Flint, Mich., in the pursuit of profits.

Robert J. Wood, 71, Ex-Chief Executive In Public Relations
LEAD: Robert J. Wood, former chairman and chief executive of the public relations agency of Carl Byoir &amp; Associates, died of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, on Wednesday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y.
He was 71 years old.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Shift by Dow Jones
LEAD: Dow Jones &amp; Company has assigned the $8 million advertising account for The Wall Street Journal to the J. Walter Thompson Company.
The previous agency was GSD&amp;M.
The other finalist for the account was Lord Einstein O'Neill &amp; Partners.

LEAD: When Sandy Lyle arrived at the Doral Ryder Open a year ago, he was at the top of the golf world.
But since he left, he has been in a paralyzing slump that has sometimes left him wondering if he will ever play well again.

He was 79 years old.

Pistons Stingy With the Bullets
The Detroit Pistons held the Washington Bullets to their lowest point total this season in a 99-85 victory last night in Landover, Md.
The victory was the 42d for Detroit, the first team in the league to guarantee itself a winning record this season.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Hot Town Of the 80's Loses Allure
LEAD: ADVERTISING creative people may leave their hearts in San Francisco, but many seem to be taking their resumes and portfolios out of town.


Out of This Nettle
LEAD: What happened in Nicaragua this week was not just a remarkable election.
It was a victory for a new approach to intractable conflicts, turning them from bloodshed to the democratic political process.


Shuttle Deploys Spy Satellite
LEAD: A $500 million spy satellite was deployed by the space shuttle's astronauts early today, space agency officials said.


Ex-Exile Emerges at Core of Chamorro Alliance
LEAD: When the Nicaraguan opposition held an enormous rally here before the election on Sunday, huge vertical banners waved with the names of the presidential candidate, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, and her running mate.
But a smaller set of signs advertised a third name: Alfredo Cesar Aguirre, the opposition's man behind the throne.


C.I.A. Says a Gorbachev Removal Is the Sole Threat to Soviet Change
LEAD: The Director of Central Intelligence said today that changes in the Soviet Union's political and economic structure had progressed so far that only the removal of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and a forced return to Stalinist-style government could reverse them.


SENATORS ACHIEVE ACCORD WITH BUSH ON CLEAN AIR BILL
LEAD: After weeks of negotiations in closed sessions, Senate leaders today diluted some provisions of their proposed clean air legislation to meet President Bush's demand for a less costly solution to the nation's pollution problems.

LEAD: More than 1,000 mourners mingled in sorrow and exuberance at a memorial service for Malcolm Forbes in St.
Bartholomew's Church on Park Avenue yesterday, and they included everybody from a former President and a movie star to Scots in kilts, motorcyclists in leather and Gallic players of the hunting horn who used to perform at Mr.


Heavy Trading In USAir Shares
LEAD: A report that Marvin Davis, the West Coast financier, had bought a stake in the USAir Group was cited for heavy trading in the airline's stock.
A spokesman for Mr.
Davis would not comment on the report in USA Today that he had acquired about a 5 percent stake.
USAir's stock closed at $31 yesterday, down $1, after trading as high as $33.75.


Money Fund Assets Fall
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 499 money market mutual funds decreased by $1.9 billion, to $388.79 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 153 institutional funds fell by $1.15 billion, to $91.54 billion.
The assets of the 245 general-purpose funds dropped by $151.5 million, to $132.40 billion.


Drexel Is Said to Owe Millions to Foreign Governments
LEAD: Many foreign governments and Puerto Rico are owed hundreds of millions of dollars as a result of the collapse of the parent of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., people at the firm and lawyers said yesterday.


Stocks End Higher for Fourth Day
LEAD: Stock prices rose yesterday for a fourth consecutive day, with the Dow Jones industrial average eking out a gain of only 8.34 points.
The Dow now stands at 2,635.59, having climbed more than 71 points so far this week.


Republicans' Duty to the Schools
LEAD: The success of New York City schools depends heavily on excellent teachers.
But recruiting and keeping them is hampered by the Board of Examiners, an agency that has outlived its usefulness.
The Republican State Senate refuses to abolish it.
If it fails to do so in this session, students, teachers and voters will know precisely whom to blame.


Corrections
LEAD: A report in ''At the Movies'' in Weekend last Friday about the film ''Mountains of the Moon'' quoted an actor who misidentified the people in one battle scene.
They were Somalis, not Maoris.


Prices of Treasury Issues Decline
LEAD: Prices of Treasury issues dipped yesterday in light trading, as dealers sold securities in the wake of a series of economic reports that were somewhat stronger than anticipated.


Japanese Fear Problems From a Hasty Meeting
LEAD: As Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu prepares to meet President Bush this weekend, Japanese officials say they are suddenly fearful that American demands for rapid action on trade issues could undermine the chances of Japanese concessions down the road.

LEAD: Fabia Drake, an actress whose career spanned 77 years with credits from the Shakespearean stage to television mini-series, died on Wednesday at her home.

Josephine Johnson, Nature Writer, Poet And Novelist, 79
LEAD: Josephine Johnson, a novelist and nature writer whose first novel, ''Now in November,'' won the 1935 Pulitzer Prize for fiction, died of pneumonia on Tuesday in Clearmont Mercy Hospital, Batavia, Ohio.
She was 79 years old and lived in Mount Carmel, Ohio.

LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, yesterday priced a $400 million issue of notes due in 1993 through Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company.

LEAD: Construction spending rose 1.8 percent in January, the biggest increase in more than a year, the Government said today.
Analysts said the warmest January on record caused the improvement.

Division III Atlantic Region playoffs.
The 100 points were a season high for Stockton, which led by 59-41 at halftime.

Dinkins's daughter.

Kalila was born at New Britain (Conn.) General Hospital.

For the Normally Clubby A.B.A., Sudden Rifts Over an Explosive Issue: Abortion
LEAD: In the past few years the American Bar Association has debated gay rights and private clubs, apartheid and AIDS discrimination.
But until two weeks ago it had never tackled perhaps the most divisive legal and social issue of them all: abortion.
Now, as the A.B.A. sifts the resulting wreckage, it is apparent why.

LEAD: Public-policy groups and the leaders of both houses of the State Legislature called today for a commission to suggest government-ethics reforms after questions were raised about the influence of lobbyists, businesses and campaign contibutors on legislators.

LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said today that it had reached a new labor agreement with the union representing 2,100 hourly workers at its plant in Hermosillo, Mexico.

LEAD: A Reserve Officer Training Corps hearing officer has recommended that the United States Army try to reclaim the scholarship money it gave to a R.O.T.C. member who is homosexual.


WORLD DRUG CROP UP SHARPLY IN 1989 DESPITE U.S. EFFORT
LEAD: The State Department reported today that global production of opium poppies, coca, marijuana and hashish soared in the last year.
This occurred despite President Bush's highly publicized effort to curtail drug supply and demand.

LEAD: Norman Blackburn, a writer and producer who worked in film, radio and television and whose movie credits included the Marx Brothers' ''Day at the Races'' and the ''Our Gang'' comedies, died on Feb. 21 after complications from hip surgery.
He was 86 years old.

LEAD: With a smile and a wave, Darryl Strawberry left the Smithers Center in Manhattan yesterday and headed off toward a court date today in California.

LEAD: When Orrin Hatch charged into the Senate in 1976, there was no ambiguity in the flint-hard agenda he advocated.
He soon established a reputation as a slashing, give-no-quarter conservative by filibustering to death labor law reform and fair housing bills.

LEAD: Reports of large supplies of gasoline prompted heavy selling of petroleum futures yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

LEAD: Eric Salmestrelli is an energetic boy with a sunshine smile that goes well with soft brown eyes that seem to know a lot for a 10-year-old.

LEAD: Two more workers at the Triborough Bridge fell ill yesterday of the mysterious ailment that struck 33 other bridge attendants a week ago.

LEAD: A spokesman for former President Ronald Reagan said today there was no basis for a report by the East German press agency Wednesday that Mr.
Reagan would speak at a political rally in East Berlin in support of a small grouping of liberal, centrist parties.

N.F.L. Is Expanding Playoffs And Revenue From Television
LEAD: The National Football League yesterday added two wild-card teams to its playoff format and in the process helped swell television revenue to an expected $30 million a team each year, an increase of $13 million a team.

Chronology of Seabrook: Plans, Protests, Building
LEAD:
1966: The Public Service Company of New Hampshire tentatively decides to build a nuclear power plant, among the first in New England, in Newington, N.H.
The Atomic Energy Commission says the site is too near Pease Air Force Base.
January 1972: The company decides to build twin reactors at Seabrook, at a cost of $973 million.

Prague: Neglected Hotbed of Modernism
LEAD: Beginning this weekend, three New York City institutions pay homage to Prague, the Czechoslovak capital that during the first half of this century turns out to have been no less an incubator of modern art than Paris or Moscow or Vienna.
Whether it was testing out the waters of new technologies, like film, or giving a distinctively Czechoslovak twist to movements in painting, photography and sculpture like Cubism and Surrealism, Prague turns out to have been a city where modernism was embraced with a remarkable combination of passion and panache.

Review/Pop;   Paris's Negresses Vertes
LEAD: Paris has taken on a new role as musical melting pot, a place where a French gloss and some cross-cultural pop hybridization can be added to gypsy, African, Brazilian or Algerian music.
Its latest emissaries, who performed Wednesday night at Woody's, are the Negresses Vertes, a group of eight men and two women who fuse an international assortment of folky styles into a newfangled kind of cabaret music.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Taxi and Model Change To Limited Circulation
LEAD: Family Media Inc., the magazine publishing company, announced yesterday that it was converting two of its ailing publications for women, Taxi and Model, from paid circulation to controlled-circulation magazines, beginning in the fall.


U.S. Turns Down MCI's Complaint
LEAD: A Federal appeals board rejected the MCI Communications Corporation's challenge to part of the multibillion-dollar Government contracts that have been awarded to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and U S Sprint.
Washington-based MCI's complaint involves changes in a contract to redesign and provide voice, data and video telecommunications networks, a project that could total $25 billion over 10 years.

LEAD: What, fight drugs at the source?

Restaurants
LEAD: Just a few years ago, La Caravelle was suffering an advanced case of culinary senescence, and it seemed destined for that big banquette-lined dining room in the sky where it would join former Manhattan luminaries like the Pavillon, the Colony and Luchow's.
A transfusion of new blood in the kitchen and the dining room kept the patient breathing, but many still believed the outlook was dim for this icon of a more decorous era.

Sale of F-16's Set
LEAD: Portugal will buy 20 General Dynamics Corporation F-16 warplanes from the United States in the next three years for $450 million, a military spokesman said.
A United States Embassy spokesman here said much of the cost would be met through grants under the Lajes Accord, which covers United States bases on Portugal's mid-Atlantic Azores Islands and military cooperation between the two NATO allies.

Market Place;   Fewer Companies Lifting Dividends
LEAD: THE economy may not be in a recession, but more and more companies are acting as though they think it may enter one.
They are doing that by forgoing dividend increases that might have been made in other years.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Cutty Sark Whisky Goes to Della Femina
LEAD: Della Femina, McNamee WCRS was awarded the Cutty Sark Scots Whisky account yesterday.
The brand's advertising had been handled by MacNamara, Clapp &amp; Klein.
But last month, the Scotch's distributor, Buckingham Wile U.S., was acquired by Hiram Walker-Allied Vintners, which gave exclusive domestic distribution rights for Cutty Sark to its W.A.


AIDS Panel Agrees On Sex Counseling Of Catholic Patients
LEAD: In an emotional debate in which one member likened John Cardinal O'Connor to Hitler, a state panel on AIDS policy agreed today that Roman Catholic nursing homes for AIDS patients should provide counseling on safer sex.


Exxon Unit Head Resigns
LEAD: The president of the Exxon Corporation's shipping subsidary, Frank Iarossi, announced yesterday that he was resigning to manage a standards-setting organization for the shipping trade.
Mr.
Iarossi, who is 53 years old, had been the head of Exxon Shipping Company since 1982.


TEXAS AIR ACCUSED ON EASTERN DEALS
LEAD: The court-appointed official supervising the bankruptcy case of Eastern Airlines concluded yesterday that Eastern had been improperly shortchanged by its parent company in various financial transactions.


Mel Hosansky, Editor, 64
LEAD: Mel Hosansky, editor in chief of Successful Meetings magazine, died of liver cancer on Wednesday at the Cabrini Hospice in Manhattan.
He was 64 years old and lived in Jamaica, Queens.


Tax Fraud Discussions
LEAD: The European Community and the United States plan talks next week to increase cooperation against tax fraud.
Officials said today that the European Community Tax Commissioner, Christiane Scrivener, would meet with top Bush Administration officials.


Review/Art;   Gallery of Unknowns In Brooklyn Exhibition
LEAD: TO discuss Czechoslovak art of the 20th century has long meant to speak about Frantisek Kupka or to say nothing at all.
Kupka's name and to a lesser extent the name of Otto Gutfreund have earned mention in most surveys of modern art, although neither has achieved anything like the recognition he deserves (especially Kupka, it should be added, whose experiments in abstraction, as a recent retrospective of the painter's work in Paris confirmed, were no less groundbreaking than Piet Mondrian's and Wassily


Colgate to Acquire Dental Gel Unit
LEAD: The Colgate-Palmolive Company agreed in principle to buy the dental therapeutic business of Scherer Healthcare Inc., a leader in the United States in gel products for dentists.
Colgate said the business would be run by its Colgate-Hoyt Laboratories.
Terms were not disclosed.


Du Pont to Build Complex in Spain
LEAD: E. I. du Pont de Nemours &amp; Company and the Spanish Government signed an agreement to invest $1 billion in the next 12 years to build a high-technology industrial complex in the northern region of Asturias.
Spain has agreed to put up $300 million for the complex, which is to employ 1,000 people in the hard-pressed region by 2001.


Binks Stake Sold
LEAD: Illinois Tool Works Inc., which on Feb. 20 made an unsolicited offer of $45 a share for the Binks Manufacturing Company, said its Ransburg Corporation subsidiary was selling some of its Binks holdings.
Binks, based in Franklin Park, Ill., had rejected Illinois Tools' offer.
Binks's stock closed today at $44.875, down 25 cents, on the American Stock Exchange.

Castro Asks Mandela to Visit
LEAD: President Fidel Castro today invited Nelson Mandela to visit Cuba, the Cuban news agency Prensa Latina reported.
Mr.
Mandela received the invitation from a senior Cuban diplomat in Lusaka, Zambia, where he has been holding talks with exiled leaders of the African National Congress.
Prensa Latina said Mr.


Greville Wynne, Spy for Britain In the Soviet Bloc, Is Dead at 71
LEAD: Greville Wynne, who spied on the Soviet Union for Britain in the cold war and who spent 18 months in a Moscow prison after being caught, died of throat cancer on Wednesday, hospital officials said today.
He was 71 years old.


Israel Devalues Shekel
LEAD: The Israeli shekel was devalued today by about 6 percent in an effort to aid the economy and curb inflation.
Israel's last devaluation was in June, when the shekel was devalued by 4.2 percent.
Finance Minister Shimon Peres also said the exchange rate would now be allowed to fluctuate as much as 5 percent daily, rather than the current 3 percent limit.


More Protests Of Pantheon Resignation
LEAD: The remaining senior editor at Pantheon Books resigned yesterday, following the departures of the four other senior editors in protest over the removal of Andre Schiffrin as managing director.


$66.7 Million Bonds By New York State
LEAD: The Dormitory Authority of the State of New York yesterday priced $66.7 million in revenue bonds through competitive bidding for the New York State Department of Health.


Corrections
LEAD: A chart in Business Day on Monday headed ''International Book Rights'' and showing the breakdown, by country, of the print rights sold for the novel ''Fade the Heat'' misidentified the source of the data.
It was the Virginia Barber Literary Agency.
The chart also omitted the figure for print rights sold in Norway, Sweden and Denmark.


No Rough Stuff Allowed
LEAD: Her coach, Don MacLeod, describes Vicky Sunohara as the Wayne Gretzky of women's hockey.
And who's to doubt him?


Michigan Star in Draft
LEAD: Leroy Hoard, the Michigan tailback who was voted the most valuable player in the 1989 Rose Bowl, will forgo his final year of college eligibility and enter the N.F.L. draft.


CHRONICLE
LEAD: In the movie version of ''The Bonfire of the Vanities,'' TOM HANKS will play Sherman McCoy, the philandering, self-absorbed bond trader whose ''Yale chin'' and prep-school background figure prominently in the TOM WOLFE best seller.
Mr.
Hanks visited Yale yesterday, soaking up information and atmosphere.

LEAD: Saying he wanted to end the longtime bitterness between himself and American Jews, the Black Muslim leader Louis Farrakhan has given interviews with two Washington newspapers this week in which he offered what he characterized as the correct version of his past statements perceived as anti-Semitic slurs.

LEAD: Very early in ''The Hunt for Red October,'' Marko Ramius (Sean Connery), the captain of a new, atomic-powered, top-of-the-line Soviet submarine named the Red October, barehandedly murders a fellow officer aboard ship.


Prepayment Lag Is Changing Mortgage Security Values
LEAD: A steady decline since 1986 in the rate of prepayments on single-family home mortgages is changing the relative values of mortgage securities, analysts at Salomon Brothers Inc. are saying.


TV Weekend;   A View of the Gory Horrors Of Mozambique's Civil War
LEAD: Even hardened followers of the nightly news may be shaken by ''Madness in Mozambique,'' which takes up most of tonight's edition of ''20/20.'' Tom Jarriel's report, at 10 P.M. on ABC, focuses on the youngest victims of a brutal, decadelong civil war in the poorest of the African states.
It tells of boys as young as 8 years old turned into killers, of 10-year-old girls raped repeatedly, of children forced to witness or even participate in the murder of their parents.


The Church, Charity and Condoms
LEAD: From the beginning of the AIDS epidemic, John Cardinal O'Connor and the Catholic Archdiocese of New York have led in selfless caring for the victims.
But AIDS activists are now demanding that public funds be withheld from the nursing home care the archdiocese proposes to give.
They argue the church's care may be ''judgmental'' and that it refuses to give instruction in preventive measures like the use of condoms.

LEAD: WHY has the Soviet economy failed to respond to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's five-year effort to revitalize it?
There is a long list of answers to that question, ranging from the macro and microeconomic to the political and cultural.


Personal Income and Spending Up
LEAD: Personal income rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in January despite a new tax bite from Social Security, the Government said today.


Commissioner Sees No Reason for Talks
LEAD: As the owners' lockout entered its third week, Commissioner Fay Vincent portrayed a bleak picture for baseball yesterday.
He said he saw no reason for negotiations in the labor dispute to resume because the union has indicated no willingness to negotiate and compromise.

LEAD: Lebanese Army troops loyal to the Christian commander, Gen.

Corrections
LEAD: A headline yesterday about international efforts to prevent another famine in East Africa referred incorrectly in some editions to one country involved.
It is Ethiopia, not Egypt. (The other is the Sudan.)

Except to Speedy Morris, who happens to coach the 13th-ranked Explorers.

LEAD: The Philadelphia Electric Company's stock closed at a 52-week low after two administrative law judges recommended a surprisingly small rate increase for a new nuclear plant.

It was the third-most-active issue on the New York Stock


Fate of Principals Splits Some Chicago Schools
LEAD: The decentralization of Chicago's school system, the nation's third largest, hit its first serious snag this week as several communities were divided over the dismissal of principals by parent-led councils.

Bush and Reagan: Cookies, A Chat and a Contretemps
LEAD: After nine years of complete affinity, George Bush finally confessed to a policy difference with Ronald Reagan.


Nautilus in Chapter 11
LEAD: Nautilus Sports-Medical Industries Inc., which makes Nautilus exercise equipment, filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.
In documents filed in Roanoke, Va., the company listed $38.6 million in liabilities and $27.3 million in assets.
The company was moved here in 1987 after it was purchased by Ward International Corp., owned by Dallas investor Travis Ward.

LEAD: David L. Morley's boss envies his job.
The chairman of the Nutrasweet Company, Robert B. Shapiro, regularly tells Mr.
Morley that he has one of the most exciting corporate jobs in the country.

Dollar Continues Advance, Helped by Economic News
LEAD: Lifted by reports showing strength in the United states economy and by economic uncertainty in Japan, the dollar continued to climb against most foreign currencies yesterday.


A Resurrected Ensemble Helps Nurture New Music
LEAD: Some celebrations are hard won.
Not long ago the National Orchestral Association had cause to wonder whether it would even reach its 60th anniversary this year, let alone feel like celebrating.
Founded in 1930 to offer advanced training to aspiring orchestral musicians, the association determined a few years ago that, with music schools increasingly providing this training themselves, it had to some extent outlived its usefulness and needed to redirect its resources if it hoped to continue making a genuine contribution to American musical life.


Bush to Nominate Lehtinen As U.S. Prosecutor in Florida
LEAD: The White House has announced that President Bush will nominate Dexter W. Lehtinen as United States Attorney for South Florida, a post he has held on an acting basis through nearly two years of controversy.


CBS News President Ends Rooney's Suspension
LEAD: After three weeks of persistent lobbying by senior executives of CBS News and its parent company, CBS Inc., Andy Rooney will return to ''60 Minutes'' on Sunday, CBS News announced yesterday, ending a three-month suspension two months early.


Cancellation in Europe
LEAD: The International League of American Football, scheduled to begin operations in Europe next month, canceled the season yesterday because of such problems as obtaining work permits for players.


Studies Find Flaws in Testing for Cholesterol
LEAD: Cholesterol tests are highly inaccurate up to one-fourth of the time and some widely available portable testing machines have unacceptably high error rates even under ideal laboratory conditions, two studies have reported.


New England Bank Signs Lending Pact
LEAD: The Bank of New England Corporation, which lost more than $1.1 billion last year, said yesterday that it had signed agreements with Federal banking regulators that describe in unusual detail how it will improve its lending procedures and seek to recover its financial health.

Manufacturing Decline Slows a Bit
LEAD: Despite increases in the level of new orders and exports, the manufacturing sector of the nation's economy remained in decline in February for the 10th consecutive month, the National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday.
But the decline was at a slower rate than in previous months.


Brazil Economics Post
LEAD: Brazil's President-elect today named Zelia Cardoso de Mello, a 36-year-old economist, as his economy minister.
Fernando Collor de Mello will take office as President on March 15, and she will help him execute plans to combat inflation, now running at more than 70 percent a month.
She has been Mr.
Collor's economic adviser since early last year and accompanied him on a recent tour of the United States, Japan and Europe.


Alfred L. Ferguson Jr., Executive, 85
LEAD: Alfred L. Ferguson Jr., an investment executive with the Wall Street securities firm of Dominick &amp; Dominick before his retirement in 1965, died of congestive heart failure on Wednesday at his home in Atlantic Highlands, N.J.
He was 85 years old.
Mr.
Ferguson, who was born in Manhattan, was a graduate of Yale and the Yale Law School.


In California, Bush Tries to Close Gap With Troubled G.O.P.
LEAD: On his second political foray into California in less than a month, President Bush cut a ribbon at a new prison today to show how tough Republicans are on crime, but he found a fast-growing state in political upheaval with a disoriented Republican Party.


Review/Concert;   A Retelling of the Legend Of Joan of Arc, in Russian
LEAD: There are certain all-but-forgotten operas whose credentials look so promising on paper that periodic attempts to revive them are not only inevitable but also justified, if only for curiosity's sake.
Tchaikovsky's ''Maid of Orleans,'' which Eve Queler's Opera Orchestra of New York performed in Russian at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening, falls into that interesting category.


Los Angeles Journal;   Catering Trucks: Selective Welcome?
LEAD: It is lunchtime, and Juan Saenz, budding fast-food mogul, is toiling in his catering truck.
Fingering a thick wad of $1 bills, he takes three orders for burritos and calls them out to his wife, Mari, furiously working the griddle.


Indian Troops Kill 29 Protesters In Secessionist Rally in Kashmir
LEAD: At least 29 people were killed and about 25 wounded today in Srinagar, capital of the state of Jammu and Kashmir, when Indian troops fired on pro-independence crowds, news reports said.

LEAD: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission voted today to give an operating license to the Seabrook nuclear reactor, the New Hampshire plant that many experts consider the most fought-over nuclear project in America.

LEAD: An article on Tuesday about a beach restoration project in Sea Bright, N.J., misstated the storm damage that the Corps of Engineers estimates the project would prevent.

CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;   With Car C.D. Players
LEAD: The best sound in a car comes from compact disks, but a C.D. player does not have to be installed in the dashboard to obtain it.
A personal portable player can be installed by hooking it up to a car radio or tape player and speakers.
Sony says a third of all C.D. portables are used this way.

Kaypro Files For Bankruptcy
LEAD: The Kaypro Corporation, whose all-in-one personal computer was once characterized as the Volkswagen Beetle of the high-tech industry, filed today for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.
The company established a market niche in the early days of personal computers with a reliable low-priced machine that included a screen, computer and software in a semi-portable unit.


No Headline
LEAD: Nine thousand communities, most of them isolated rural towns and farming hamlets, were jolted today by the near-collapse of their only public transit system after drivers struck the Greyhound bus system in a wage dispute.


Frederick Landis, 78, Former Customs Judge
LEAD: Frederick Landis, a former judge of the United States Customs Court, now the Court of International Trade, and former Chief Judge of the Indiana Supreme Court, died of intestinal cancer on Thursday at a nursing home in Carmel, Ind.
He was 78 years old and lived in Indianapolis and Scarsdale, N.Y.

Mobil to Pay State $500,000 On Greenpoint Kerosene Leak
LEAD: The Mobil Oil Corporation has agreed to pay New York State a $500,000 penalty and to undertake an investigation and cleanup effort in response to a leak of 50,000 gallons of kerosene on Feb. 3 at its Greenpoint terminal in Brooklyn, the State Environmental Conservation Department said yesterday.

Now, more than 30 years later, she has sold that painting, the only known nude study by the illustrator of homey America.

LEAD: A sharply divided bipartisan commission today recommended an $86.2-billion-a-year program to provide health insurance and long-term nursing care to every American who needs them.
But the panel could not recommend specific ways to raise the money.

LEAD: An offensive by Gen.
Michel Aoun's army in Christian-controlled East Beirut halted today after making little headway on the second day of brutal clashes with rival Christian militiamen.
As the offensive stalled, the head of the Maronite Catholic Church threatened to excommunicate the combatants.

LEAD: A measles epidemic at the University of Maine in Orono has caused a Division I hockey league, Hockey East, to relinquish Boston Garden as the site of its tournament next Friday and Sunday.

LEAD: The governing wing of the African National Congress elected Nelson Mandela deputy president of the organization today, and the group said it would move its headquarters to Johannesburg ''without delay.''

Reviews/Music;   An Exploration of Two Viennese Schools
LEAD: The current all-Viennese New York Philharmonic subscription program at Avery Fisher Hall looked promising in theory, but proved problematic in practice Thursday night.
The idea was to combine a chronological mini-survey of the music of Anton Webern, stretching from the late Romanticism of his student days to his full maturity, and then to reach back to the First Viennese School for Beethoven's ''Emperor'' Piano Concerto.

Topics of the Times;   007, Arrested
LEAD: James Bond is a master at narrow escapes from life-threatening traps laid by his villainous enemies.
It is perhaps less noticed that, no matter how fast he roars through mountain passes on winding two-lane highways, he also escapes traffic cops.
Sean Connery, the movies' original 007, isn't so lucky.

LEAD: In an unusual double-barreled assault, the central banks of West Germany and Japan intervened in foreign exchange markets yesterday to defend their currencies against a weeklong rally in the dollar.

Trump Sues, Too
LEAD: Donald Trump has thrown his lawsuit into the ring.
Claiming unlawful interference by the Mirage Hotel and Casino with his contractual right to present a rematch between James (Buster) Douglas and Mike Tyson in Atlantic City in June, Trump yesterday sued the Mirage and its owner, Steve Wynn, and the heavyweight champion and his manager, John Johnson.


Warnings on Chemical Hazards Are Upheld by California Court
LEAD: A California judge ruled today that food, drugs and cosmetics are not exempt from a law enacted by California voters aimed at warning consumers about products containing chemicals known to cause cancer or birth defects.

To Our Readers
LEAD: Because of transmission problems, several tables reflecting trading in options are not available.


Corrections
LEAD: An obituary in some editions on Sunday, reprinted in all copies on Monday, about the magazine publisher Malcolm S. Forbes included two names erroneously on a list of guests at his 70th-birthday party last year in Tangier, Morocco.
Donald J. Trump and the singer Julio Iglesias did not attend.


Patents: Hunt Goes On For a Better Mousetrap;   New Tracking Compound
LEAD: An attempt to develop a more child-proof rat poison comes from ICI Americas, a subsidiary of Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C.
The poison is a new form of tracking compound, a substance that gets into the fur of a rodent.

LEAD: At the peak of his gymnastics career, Felix Martinez of Cuba was left to consider the great what-if: what if his country had not boycotted the 1988 Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea, for political reasons?


Corrections

He is Melvyn Levitsky.

Tax Filings Up From '89
LEAD: The Internal Revenue Service said this week that it had processed 19.4 percent more returns this year through Feb. 23 than last year - 18.1 million compared with 15.1 million.
More than half the processed returns, 9.9 million, have produced refunds, up 20.3 percent from last year.
In the first half of the filing season, 31.9 million returns have been received by the I.R.S., about 30 percent of the total expected this year.


Scott Jarvis, Actor, 46
LEAD: Scott Jarvis, an actor and singer, died of AIDS on Monday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 48 years old.


Fats, Fads, Fasts, Fallacies
LEAD: The Federal Government felt moved this Lenten week to get up in the pulpit and urge its flock to discipline their diets.
It admonished every citizen above 2 years of age to eat less fat and more spinach.
The sermon is probably salubrious, but the sanctimony can be taken with a modicum of salt.


Panel Urges NTT Breakup
LEAD: A Government advisory council said today that the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Company should be split into three companies within five years.

Surgeon General Confirmed
LEAD: Dr.
Antonia Coello Novello was confirmed as Surgeon General by the Senate on Thursday.
A 45-year-old pediatrician and expert on AIDS in children, she is the first female and the first Hispanic Surgeon General.
She has been deputy director of the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, one of the National Institutes of Health.


Japan Reports Trade Deficit
LEAD: Japan reported a trade deficit today for the first time in six years, but economists said Tokyo is expected to return to a trade surplus soon.

Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday about a Federal clean air bill described a type of coal incorrectly in some copies.
It was high-sulfur coal that Senate leaders agreed to allow for a longer period at Western and Midwestern power plants.


Strawberry At Meeting
LEAD: Darryl Strawberry, the Mets outfielder who ended a 26-day treatment in an alcohol-rehabilitation program in New York on Thursday, appeared at the Los Angeles City Attorney's office here today to determine whether he will face misdemeanor charges stemming from a domestic dispute five weeks ago.


Flyers Trade Propp
LEAD: Stressing a need to acquire younger players, the Philadelphia Flyers yesterday traded 31-year-old Brian Propp, their third-leading career scorer with 849 points, to the Boston Bruins for a second-round selection in this year's National Hockey League draft.


More of Same for the Nets
LEAD: Michael Jordan and Scottie Pippen each scored 23 points last night for Chicago as the Bulls defeated the Nets, 112-91.

Boeing Raises Market Outlook
LEAD: The Boeing Company, the world's largest commercial plane maker, today sharply raised its 16-year jetliner market outlook, predicting demand of $626 billion through 2005.
The company also said it expects overall air traffic to grow about 5.5 percent annually through 2005.
That growth rate would constitute a near-doubling by 2000.

LEAD: Former Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the maverick liberal Republican who vowed not to make a comeback after he was defeated in a bitter re-election race in 1988, returned today from his self-imposed exile and said he would run for governor as an independent.

Review/Music;   Two Masters in the Making: Beethoven, 14, Mahler, 16
LEAD: The Lyric Piano Quartet presented an interesting program of relatively unfamiliar and sometimes distinctly unmasterly music by familiar masters at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday evening.
Beginning the concert with a work by a 14-year-old Beethoven (the Quartet in D, WoO 36, No. 2), and the second half with one by a 16-year-old Mahler (a movement for an unfinished Quartet in A minor), was an especially nice touch.


Bridge
LEAD: Invitational events limited to top-ranked players and offering large cash prizes are common in Europe but rare on this side of the Atlantic.
For many years the only example has been the Cavendish Club's annual charity event in Manhattan, but it was sincerely flattered by imitation in Toronto last weekend.


Bail Is Denied in 1946 Killing
LEAD: A Manhattan judge denied bail yesterday to a man who could face the death penalty in Florida in the killing of a Miami police officer 43 years ago.
The man, Leroy Strachan, 61 years old, was denied bail because it is inappropriate and premature, Justice George F. Roberts of State Supreme Court told Mr.


CHRONICLE
LEAD: ZSA ZSA GABOR has been slapped with a $10 million suit for slander, assault and emotional distress by PAUL KRAMER, the Beverly Hills police officer who arrested her last June.
Mr.
Kramer filed suit against Miss Gabor on Thursday in Los Angeles Superior Court.
On June 14, 1989, he stopped her because the license tags of her Rolls-Royce convertible had expired.

Bushes to Head Yearlong Fete
LEAD: Up With People, an international cultural and educational program for young people, yesterday named George and Barbara Bush honorary chairmen of its 25th anniversary celebration under the heading, ''Encouraging Understanding Worldwide.'' The announcement by J. Blanton Belk, founder and president of the organization, said the yearlong observance would open July 25 in Denver, where President Bush has been invited to deliver the keynote address.


Scraping By on Hope in Moscow
LEAD: For a person who has been going to Moscow since childhood, the allure of that paradoxical city never wanes.
But this time the strange juxtapositions seemed thrown into particularly stark relief by a series of random encounters that evoked childhood memories and underscored the startling reality of today.

Intermark Set To Add Triton
LEAD: Intermark Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire the outstanding shares of Triton Group Ltd., its 51.6 percent owned affiliate, in a stock swap deal worth $99.4 million, based on today's stock price.


For Specialty Ketchups, A Battle With the Giants
LEAD: In a market where a couple of giants have smothered the competition, a handful of entrepreneurs are trying to carve a niche for what they call gourmet ketchup.


Promises, Promises on Schools
LEAD: The nation's governors have committed themselves to a 10-year strategy to produce better schools and better students.
But their admirably lofty rhetoric tells more about where American education ought to be in 10 years than about how to get it there.

Upheaval in the East;   1980 Soviet Defector Emerges With Account of K.G.B. Plots
LEAD: The K.G.B. had two sources in the State Department during the 1970's who supplied details of American arms-control strategies and other policies, a former K.G.B. officer who has lived secretly in the United States since 1980 alleged today.


'Crowbar' Is Extended
LEAD: ''Crowbar,'' the experimental play by Mac Wellman presented by En Garde Arts at the Victory Theater on 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, has extended its run to March 25.
It had been scheduled to close on March 11.


Patents: Hunt Goes On For a Better Mousetrap;   A Maple Concentrate
LEAD: A simpler approach to bait shyness, using an artificial maple concentrate, has been developed by John P. Hollis of San Antonio.
Mr.
Hollis, the retired owner of a pest control service, said maple was one of the more persistently successful natural attractants he has encountered.
His artificial maple is a new composition consisting of saccharin and alcohol tinctures containing coffee, vanilla and extracts from several other plants.

LEAD: President Bush greeted Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan at this glittering desert spa this afternoon to start a weekend of talks aimed at preventing trade strife from undermining their countries' close political and economic ties.

McCaw-Lin Link
LEAD: McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. said it had won bank financing for its $3.4 billion merger with the Lin Broadcasting Corporation, bringing it a step closer to creating the nation's biggest cellular telephone company.
The $3 billion bank loan agreement was arranged by a syndicate of 43 commercial banks.


Advocate for the Suffering Takes Over as Head of Mental Health
LEAD: As a young Army psychiatrist in Vietnam in 1969, Dr.
Billy E. Jones listened to the torments of American soldiers who had been put in a stockade for various crimes during the war.
Later, when he was a civilian, his patients were people who, in addition to their own private anguish, suffered lives of poverty.

LEAD: This is, in the end, a tale of how this spinning planet both disappoints and affirms its bewildered passengers.
It is about South Africa and New York City, about a son and a mother.


Now for Election Groupies
LEAD: Compared with difficulties ahead, winning Nicaragua's election was the least of Violeta Chamorro's problems.
But the elections had to be the first step toward creating (not rebuilding - there never was a substantial foundation) a peaceful, democratic society with a functioning economy.


Dr. Charles Doan, 93, Retired Medical Dean
LEAD: Dr.
Charles Austin Doan, the retired dean of Ohio State University Medical School and a noted hematologist, died of arteriosclerosis on Feb. 13 at a nursing home in West Bloomfield, Mich.
He was 93 years old and until last month had lived in Columbus, Ohio.


Amplified Cello: From Purring To Caterwauling
LEAD: The line separating art music from new-age formulas can be very thin.
And in the case of Elise Tobin, an electro-acoustic cellist who performed at Dance Theater Workshop on Monday and Tuesday evenings, the two become virtually synonymous.

LEAD: As people sort through their financial records to get things in order for income-tax preparation, many wonder just how long they need to keep various papers.

LEAD: United States officials said today that they expect to conclude a new trade accord with the Soviet Union in time for a superpower summit meeting in June, a move that would end a 16-year dispute linking trade with Soviet emigration policy.

Review/Art;   Sculpture, But Not Strictly So
LEAD: The sculptor Barry Le Va came of age in the late 1960's and early 70's, a time of pervasive social unrest and intellectual questioning.
The civil rights movement was in high gear, the antiwar movement was gaining speed, women's rights and students' rights were both hotly debated issues and art was not exempt from the ferment.

Corrections
LEAD: A map on Jan. 21 locating museums in Jerusalem misidentified the street on which the Tax Museum is situated.

Princeton Reunion
LEAD: One is a United States Senator.
Another is the treasurer of the World Bank and another the president of the Baltimore Orioles.
There also are an architect, two attorneys, three investment executives, two presidents of self-owned companies and two educators.
Not too shabby a group.
Twenty-five years ago, they were not bad, either as they shocked the college basketball world by leading Princeton to its only N.C.A.A.

A SUNSET WORTH THE APPLAUSE
LEAD: Karen comes back from Florida, talking about Key West.
She hit the Overseas Highway, and 42 bridges later she was on Duval Street buying a palm frond hat.
She checked into a guesthouse called Big Ruby's, stuffed herself with conch fritters and got wasted away in Margaritaville.
There was music everywhere, blues and jazz and calypso, and what they call Conchtown.


In Bright, Soaring Colors, Japan's Handcrafted Kites
LEAD: NOWHERE in the world do kites occupy as important a place in national life as they do in Japan.
The Japanese both welcome in the new year and celebrate Boys' Day on May 5 by flying kites.
Local kite festivals that involve dramatic airborne battles are also a feature of many communities in the spring and summer months.

LEAD: Mrs.
Philip Chadwick Foster Smith of Bath and Freeport, Me., and James Hazlet Stevenson 3d of Philadelphia and Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gertrude Gouverneur Stevenson, to Kirk Robert Pickering, the son of the late Silas Wright Pickering 3d and the late Carol Kelly Pickering of Pittsburgh.


THE HUT WHERE TOLSTOY DIED
LEAD: Astapovo.
It is a tiny railroad station in western Russia, unmarked in any atlas I have seen.
There, in the stationmaster's humble little shack beside the tracks, a small iron bedstead was placed in the living room with, beside it, a bedside table with a lamp, a candle, matches and the sick man's notebook.


Philippine Hotel Seized By a Rebel Governor
LEAD: A suspended provincial governor backed by hundreds of armed men seized a hotel in the northern Philippines after a gunfight today, taking a general and several other people hostage, witnesses said.


Protester Slain in Kashmir by Police Gunfire
LEAD: The police killed a protester today in the old downtown area of Srinagar after 25 people came out of their homes in defiance of a curfew, witnesses said.
The police and airport officials said India sent hundreds of reinforcements to the Kashmir Valley after troops fired on Muslim protesters this week.


UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Soviet Union;   Soviet Union Opposition Hits Democracy Circuit for Votes
LEAD: At 2 A.M. today, Ilya I. Zaslavsky, political kingpin, was on the phone with his pollster.
A last-minute survey of the Oktobr district of Moscow showed the tide running against the Communist establishment and in favor of Mr.
Zaslavsky's slate in Sunday's local elections.

The Other Way
LEAD: AFTER years of watching in dismay as star Soviet athletes defected to the United States and other Western nations, Soviet athletic authorities seem to have turned the emigration tide.
Dale Mulholland, a 25-year old American Soccer League player who spent last season with the Orlando Lions, said he had signed a contract to become the first American to play with Locomotiv Moscow, one of 22 professional teams in the Soviet Union.

It's Italian, but With a California Accent
LEAD: PASTA VIOLA, a newcomer in Stony Brook, sounds like yet another strutter in Long Island's never-ending parade of Italian restaurants.
But take a second look; it is not the same old tarantella.
There isn't a Bolognese, Alfredo or carbonara in sight.
Insted, fasten your seatbelts for the likes of violet linguine, an amalgam of pasta, sauteed red cabbage, prosciutto and olive oil splashed with balsamic vinegar.

Shy Quarry in Warm Waters
LEAD: I have fished for bonefish on the virgin flats of Christmas Island.
I have stalked them in the shadows of the orchid-bedecked ruins of Mayan temples in the Yucatan.
Biscayne Bay in Florida is not nearly so remote but is equally pretty, its waters the prettiest light blue I have ever seen.
And the fish are really big.

Synopsis Of the Plight of the Handicapped
LEAD: Walter McCarthy's article on social skills for the retarded as the key to advancement from sheltered workshop to successful supported employment in the public sector was a well considered one, raising the questions we need to ask about how retarded children and young adults gain these skills.
The relationship with the job trainer, a coach who is eventually faded out as the retarded young adult becomes more able to do his/her job, is vital in training both the employee and the supervisor.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. My house was built in 1926, and the original banisters and newel posts had many coats of paint on them that I stripped off.
I found that the wood had been stained a dark color that I could not remove with alcohol, bleach and other chemicals.
I applied two coats of a pigmented shellac sealer, then two coats of acrylic latex and two coats of semi-gloss.

Food;   RALLYING ROUND THE TABLE
LEAD: THE WORDS ''FAMILY SUPPER'' CARRY with them an almost unutterable nostalgia, images and emotions of the past wrapped in the glow of better values.
The vision is fueled by Norman Rockwell paintings and television commercials for turkeys, long-distance telephone companies and insurance agencies.
The props are large linen napkins, grandparents, paneled dining rooms and vast tables loaded with roasted birds, homemade breads, jams and pickles and a ravishment of pies, cakes and cookies.

The Mysterious Router Explained
LEAD: DESPITE its usefulness, the router is a mysterious power tool to many amateurs, perhaps because its name does not describe its function.
A better name might be electric chisel, for a chisel is the hand tool whose operations the router duplicates most closely.

LEAD: Though Elizabeth Swados had wanted to write a musical based on the story of Jonah as long ago as 1972 - ''because I was so keen on what the inside of a whale would sound like'' - it wasn't until she came across Robert Nathan's short, poetic 1925 novel, ''Jonah,'' that she saw how to do it.
The novel, she said, ''made Jonah such a prophet for the 80's and 90's, so narcissistic, full of complaints, apathetic, unwilling to do anything for anyone because there wasn't enough in it for him.

MACEDONIA'S STONY STRENGTH
LEAD: On the hill above the old city of Ohrid, in southern Yugoslavia, is an overgrown park, half reclaimed by forest and crowned by the monumental, ruined fortress of Tsar Samuil, who during the 10th century created a Macedonian empire extending from the Danube to the Adriatic.
The park is full of ruins: crumbling walls, rusted swing sets, the roofless Sveti Pantelejmon, which, like so many Yugoslav churches, served as a mosque for much of its life.

Review/Rock;   Mischief by Jad Fair and Kramer
LEAD: Jad Fair and Kramer, who brought a six-piece band to Wetlands on Monday night, are kindred souls on rock's scruffy fringes.
Mr.
Fair, who has led the band Half Japanese since the late 1970's, is one of rock's last professional amateurs; he writes blunt, seemingly artless lyrics, sings them in a nasal whine and scratches out scraggly notes and chords from his guitar.

ALBANIA'S BYRONIC SHORE
LEAD: The southern coast of Albania is sometimes referred to as the Ionian Riviera.
In this case the term is not ambiguous.
There are no high-rise developments here, no casinos, no jet airports or trailer parks.
Polychrome limestone cliffs loom above the sparkling emerald water, grown with cedar, pine and myrtle.

NEWS SUMMARY


In the Sonoran Desert, The Bizarre Is the Rule
LEAD: IN 1922 a botanist named Godfrey Sykes happened upon a bizarre- looking tree in the Sonoran desert, which stretches from Baja California nearly to the eastern border of Arizona.
It resembled a 30-foot-tall upside-down green carrot with tiny, tiny branches. ''Ho, ho, a boojum,'' Mr.
Sykes said when he saw the unusual plant.


Ban on Plastics in Suffolk Is Overturned
LEAD: A pioneering law that banned the use of plastic food containers and grocery bags in Suffolk County on Long Island has been overturned by a state appeals court because the county did not prepare an environmental-impact statement.


THE ROOM WHERE FORSTER LIVED
LEAD: In Edinburgh, a scarred old double-runged wooden stool; in Jerusalem, lying folded on a stand-up desk, a pair of well-used reading glasses.
The tall stool (I have one just like it in my kitchen) and the scratched lenses (a dresser-drawerful of these!) are the most commonplace objects in the world - what is more familiar, what is more intimate?


Noriega Kin Leave Panama
LEAD: The family of the deposed Panamanian military leader, Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega, arrived today in Havana after being granted safe passage by the Panamanian Government, a Mexican news agency reported.
The agency said General Noriega's wife, three daughters and grandson would travel to the Dominican Republic, where they have been granted asylum and where the general's son-in-law is a citizen.

LEAD: Mathias B. Freese has penned an eloquent plea for a grade school Kulturkampf in ''Teachers Have No Chance to Give Their Best'' (Long Island Opinion, Jan. 21), and one which I heartily endorse.
I was one of Mr.
Freese's advanced 10th-grade English students five years ago, and I consider myself an antecedent to what he cites as a ''general diminishment in students'' over time.

LEAD: JOHN TURNER leaned back on a row of wooden bleachers in the Mabee Center at Phillips University and wiped the perspiration from his forehead.

Long Island Journal
LEAD:
The Balsa Ball Park


The Budd Company's Different Drum
LEAD: Composites combine the properties of two or more materials to accomplish tasks beyond the capabilities of homogeneous substances.
An early example was the addition of straw to bricks to resist breakage.
Currently, carbon-reinforced plastics produce lighter, stiffer golf clubs and tennis rackets, and designers are looking at exotic metal-ceramic combinations for high-performance aerospace applications.


WHAT DO YOU CALL AN AGING HOOPSTER?
LEAD: Erich Rupprecht delineates exactly the sort of savvy that's needed to compete against younger opponents (About Men: ''What Do You Call an Aging Hoopster?'' Feb. 4).
For me (age 44), the moment of ''wisdom'' came 10 or so years ago, when a windmilling, spread-eagled, college-age defender was left gasping when I threw a perfect bounce-pass between his legs to a teammate (older than I), cutting to a basket: two points for us and a Newtonian epiphany for me.

I'm a sick person getting well.'' The 27-year-old right fielder for the Mets flew here from Los Angeles and made his first public statement about his troubled times since he entered the Smithers Center in Manhattan on Feb.


New Yorkers, etc.
LEAD: The restaurant is half empty.
You arrive, with a reservation, and are shown to a table either at the back of the room or next to the kitchen door.
It's enough to make you wonder (never mind that it's enough to make you mad, as in furious) - why is this happening to you?
Do you not have the right kind of power profile?

The new Mountaineer, 22-year-old Natalie Tennant, said winning the honor was more a matter of showing school spirit than of overcoming a sex barrier.

LEAD: AMONG the 3,282 candidates running for the Moscow City Council in elections Sunday, Yuri A. Prokofiev may be the one with the most to lose.
Since November he has been the Communist Party chief of Moscow, and by most accounts his party's control of the Soviet capital is in some jeopardy.

LEAD: HE came up a free throw short of a chance to end his 34-year coaching career with his 600th victory, but the way Abe Lemons of Oklahoma City saw it after a 78-77 loss to Oklahoma Christian on Friday night, the close call was something of a relief.

LEAD: A HUMBLE gourd can assume many guises in Africa.
Calabashes, hard-skinned members of the squash family, have been transformed into fearsome masks, musical instruments and ceremonial vessels in many parts of the continent.
