An Eye-Opening 'King Lear,' With Sunglasses
LEAD: IF ''King Lear'' is unplayable - oft times, it has been so declared - then what seems like a recent inundation of stage and screen Lears may have a common cause.
That is to prove how Shakespeare's ''very foolish, fond old man'' who is ''every inch a king'' can be played any which way, and the play can happen anytime, anyplace or in limbo.


Rider Injured
LEAD: A leading horse show rider, Katie Monahan Prudent of Middlesburg, Va., was seriously injured Friday when she was thrown from her horse during the winter equestrian festival at the Palm Beach Polo Equestrian Club in Florida.
The 35-year-old Prudent, a three-time American Grand Prix Association rider of the year and a member of the 1986 world champion team, suffered head injuries when she fell after her mount tripped on a obstacle.

Mexico Train Crash Injures 60
LEAD: At least 60 people were injured, 15 of them seriously, when two trains collided near the southern Mexican city of Puebla, local officials and the Red Cross said today.

Teen-Age Affluence: An Empty World
LEAD: I feel that Roger Keizerstein in his article ''Teen-Agers and the Trap of Affluence'' (Jan. 21) misses the point of what is really missing in their affluent lives.
It is this very protection from life in the outside world that creates for them an empty nonworld.
Even more to their detriment is the fact that they've never been told that the end of homelessness, the reversal of environmental decay, the elimination of animal exploitation, all rest within their hands.

COMPANIES
A Three-Sided Battle Over the Exxon Oil Spill
United States of America v.
Exxon Corporation is looking more like United States of America v.
State of Alaska.
True, a Federal grand jury indicted Exxon last Tuesday on five criminal charges involving the Alaskan oil spill.
But Justice Department officials immediately began to leak word that they had a difficult case based on untested legal principles.

A BALKAN CAPITAL, AS IT OUGHT TO BE
LEAD: I have for many years been fascinated by Romania, and in particular by Bucharest.
It is a purely literary fascination.
It began when I read Olivia Manning's ''Balkan Trilogy,'' from whose pages there rose a seedy glamour, a whiff of alluring decadence that was irresistible.
Gradually it attained the status of a disreputable Mecca, something between Anthony Hope's Ruritania and Malcolm Bradbury's Slaka.

You Can't Be Too Thin in Economy Class
LEAD: IN economy class, the squeeze is on.
If you feel you are having a tougher time getting into your airplane seat than you used to, and if you find sitting there for a long time more trying, it is not your age or your bulk.
You are being packed in more snugly.
Instead of a seat that occupied 34 inches or even 36 along the aisle four years ago, you will probably now get a seat that takes up only 31 inches.

Al Bianchi made the right move.
The Knicks are not a player away from title contention.


Marx Left the Individual Out of His Equation
LEAD: To the Editor:


EXPLORING DEVONS'S SECRET GARDENS
LEAD: Traveling the 120 miles from London to Devon in March is to make the leap from winter to spring.
Thanks to the warm waters of the Gulf Stream, England's southwest peninsula begins to bloom weeks before the rest of the country has emerged from gray dampness and night frosts.
Wherever you go in Devon, the ocean is not far away, and its influence makes winter a gentle affair with minimal frost, sea mists and lots of rain.

Where Cork Cooks Stock Up
LEAD: THE Duke of Wellington's campaign was victualed out of Cork City.
With its deep natural harbor and adjacent farmlands, Cork was one of the great food centers and the butter capital of Europe in those days.
For the perishables that couldn't be shipped - the fresh harvest of Ireland's fields and waters - you had to go to the English Market in Cork City.


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. My house was built in 1926, and the original banisters and newel posts had many coats of paint on them that I stripped off.
I found that the wood had been stained a dark color that I could not remove with alcohol, bleach and other chemicals.
I applied two coats of a pigmented shellac sealer, then two coats of acrylic latex and two coats of semi-gloss.

What He Wanted From His Public Were Tears
LEAD: Jean-Baptiste Greuze (1725-1805) is the great whipping boy of 18th-century French art.
The name immediately evokes an image of a misty-eyed prepubescent girl, clad only in filmy gauze, her eyes rolled heavenward, her lips illicitly moist.
This is the Greuze beloved by the 19th century, the Greuze of the 4th Marquess of Hertford, who paid staggering sums for these ''fancy heads.


Currency;   The Dollar's European Rally
LEAD: Will the dollar continue the small rally it started last week against the West German mark and other European currencies?
The West German Bundesbank signaled its concern about the rally of almost three pfennigs by selling dollars in Frankfurt Friday. (See Friday closings for New York at right.) If it is really worried, it will do the same thing again this week.

Congenial Setting for Italian Fare
LEAD: CINZANO'S in Fairfield is a year-old restaurant that sends mixed signals to first-time visitors.
Outside the entrance are handsome, terra cotta pots, but to enter the restaurant, you have to pass through a mundane bar.
Once inside the restaurant proper, you are greeted by a stylish, semiformal decor of tapestry-backed banquettes and chairs, rose-colored carpeting, wood paneling and a back wall covered with an oil painting of a pastoral Italian scene, the front a wall of greenhouse-style glass windows.


Mutual Funds;   High Expenses: Sign of Weakness
LEAD: Mutual fund expenses are rising.
But are investors getting their money's worth?
In most cases, the answer is no.
A fund with a high average expense ratio - the fund's expenses as a percentage of average net assets - usually turns in a weak performance, said D. Tyler Jenks, director of research for Kanon Bloch Carre &amp; Company, mutual fund consultants based in Boston.

Tech Notes;   Bringing Diesel Up to Snuff Without Alternative Fuels
LEAD: The soot-belching city bus is headed for extinction as a result of stringent Federal emissions standards due to go into effect next year.
Buses in urban areas may now emit as much as 0.6 grams of black carbon particles per horsepower of the engine for each mile driven; that allowance will be cut to one-tenth of a gram next Jan.

For I.B.M. Users, Programs Abound for IBM
LEAD: An irony surrounds the bevy of tax-preparation computer programs on the market these days: Despite countless hours spent by program writers to distinguish their products from the competition, the programs for I.B.M. and compatible personal computers remain essentially alike.
As a result, a consumer would be wise to pick a program based on how easy it is to use, whether it offers adequate on-screen help and whether it can generate a finished tax return on the printer the consumer owns.

LEAD: Q. My house was built in 1926, and the original banisters and newel posts had many coats of paint on them that I stripped off.
I found that the wood had been stained a dark color that I could not remove with alcohol, bleach and other chemicals.
I applied two coats of a pigmented shellac sealer, then two coats of acrylic latex and two coats of semi-gloss.

LEAD: To help as many as 1,000 of their employees buy affordable homes, four New Jersey companies have joined a state agency there to underwrite mortgages in what may be the first such program in the country.
Dubbed HOPE, or Home Ownership for Performing Employees, the companies guarantee up to 20 percent of a home loan for selected employees, while the New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency underwrites the entire amount.

LEAD: For freelance artists and writers, whose yearly expenses and income are often unpredictable and irregular, staying on top of personal finances is essential for saving on taxes.


Campus Life: Rutgers;   University Softens On Some Aspects Of Hazing Policy
LEAD: Rutgers University administrators have backed away from several aspects of a policy affecting fraternity pledging at predominantly black fraternities and sororities.
But the most controversial dispute is yet to be resolved.


THE DRINK OF MILLIONS
LEAD: IT IS RAINING ON THE ASHOKAN RESERVOIR.
The rain ruffles the surface of the water, and a gray mist slinks off the Catskill Mountains.
Several months from now, this rain will emerge, 90 miles to the south, through innumerable New York City faucets and washing machines and fire hydrants.
The trip, made by billions of gallons of water every month, will be uneventful.

MONTANA: THE LAND BEFORE TIME
LEAD: As far as the eye can see, if you think about the expression, is more than a measure of distance.

LEAD: Despite the move toward tax simplification, people in certain situations have tax concerns that call for special attention.

WHERE EAST MEETS WEST - TO BOOGIE!
LEAD: Dynasty Hao is a restaurant that has recently opened in Tokyo.
Its interior has been designed to resemble a bare-beamed SoHo loft, and its sound system speaks riffy American jazz.
The food, however, is spicy Taiwanese: pork dumplings, sauteed pumpkin with garlic, minced chicken in lettuce.
The restaurant is the second of this name to be opened in Tokyo by Kiddieland, an upscale Japanese toy store.

CBS and Writers Near Pact
LEAD: The east and west coast branches of the Writers Guild of America reached an agreement with CBS Friday on a three-year contract that will run through 1992.
The contract covers 325 network television and radio employees in New York and Washington and employees at CBS-owned stations in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles.


The Garden as a Gate Into the Neighborhood
LEAD: HOW to become part of a neighborhood?
Buy a house with a garden.
Not a garden that's handed over to other people to care for - that destroys the whole purpose.
It's all right to have somebody cut the lawn and clip the hedge but the garden itself - the dirty earthy part, the part that gets under your nails and ruins your manicure - must be your baby.

PASTIMES: Stamps
LEAD: Se-tenants stand together.
These are groups of different stamps, perforated and printed on one sheet.
They are usually collected in blocks or strips without separating them.
Hobbyists in the United States will be most familiar with the sheets of the 50 state flags (1976), the 50 state birds and flowers (1982) and the 50 stamps picturing wildlife (1987).

THE COURT PHOTOGRAPHER OF BEBOP
LEAD: If the kingdom of bebop had a court photographer, it was surely Herman Leonard.
Among his sharply etched black-and-white studies are some of the most famous images of such musicians as Dizzy Gillespie, Charlie Parker, Fats Navarro and the others who spearheaded modern jazz during the 1940's and 50's.

REAL FOOD IN L.A.
LEAD: The average person's notion of food in Los Angeles is that it's supermodern, trendy and eclectic.
Like all cliches, this is largely true.
There's a place on Melrose that serves Tex-Mex dim sum, and a favorite kind of sushi, with avocado, is called California maki.
L.A., with its vista west to the Orient, its rich stew of immigrants, its diverse cultures, encourages strange mixtures and makes everything its own, while at the same time preserving individual flavors.


Reviews/Music;   Erotica Trio at the Y; This Debut Is Official
LEAD: The Eroica Trio, a chamber group that was formed at the Juilliard School in 1986, made its official debut Wednesday evening with an enjoyable program of Mozart, Schubert and Shostakovich at the 92d Street Y. The players - Erika Nickrenz, a pianist; Adela Pena, a violinist, and Sara Sant'Ambrogio, a cellist - are accomplished musicians with interpretive instincts that are solid and well matched.

WHEN A PREGNANT WOMAN DRINKS
LEAD: As a writer working on a guide to pregnancy, I am familiar with the dangers posed by alcohol.
Yet, I take issue with the way in which Elisabeth Rosenthal uncritically quotes Dr.
Claire D. Coles.
Dr.
Coles seems to regard even the slightest aberration in behavior as a likely symptom of the effect.
The fact that a month-old baby ''should be calm'' but isn't is used as evidence that the infant is suffering from the effects of prenatal substance abuse.

Fighting The War On Cigs
LEAD: The ad looks like this.
There is a woman.
She has great clothes, important earrings, big hair, some attitude.
There is a white box beneath the woman.
The box says, ''Smoking Causes Lung Cancer, Heart Disease, Emphysema, And May Complicate Pregnancy.'' The ad appears to be selling two things: sex and death.

Corruption and Corporate 'Perks'
LEAD: To the Editor If your section had less concern for corporations and more for their stockholders, ''Butlers and Crystal as Well as a View'' (Feb. 4) would have appeared on page 1 of The Times, and not on page 29 of your section.

HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECENT RELEASES: AND KEEP IN MIND
LEAD: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

Classical


At Its Best, Love Is Far From a Fairy Tale
LEAD: In fairy tales, love songs and most Hollywood movies, any boy-meets- girl story takes the long way around to proving the predictable; the neat trajectory of conventional romance always shows that Cinderella and the Prince, tomato and tomahto, Tracy and Hepburn were right for each other all along.
But in real life, who hasn't been an idiot in love, defying the odds to find the wrong person at the least convenient time to create an emotional mess?


Postpartum Problems, Then and Now
LEAD: Kathy Shaskan's article, ''Postpartum Syndrome: A Patient's View'' (Opinion page, Feb. 11), rang a discordant bell with me.
In the 1940's, I had four babies in seven years and was quite familiar with the subsequent depression of which the article speaks.


Saving to Retire? Tax Code Helps
LEAD: RETIREMENT can be the time to enjoy the fruits of a life's labor, or it can be a time of penny-pinching uncertainty.
To be sure it is the first, an understanding of the role tax laws play, both in saving for retirement and during retirement, is essential.


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. My house was built in 1926, and the original banisters and newel posts had many coats of paint on them that I stripped off.
I found that the wood had been stained a dark color that I could not remove with alcohol, bleach and other chemicals.
I applied two coats of a pigmented shellac sealer, then two coats of acrylic latex and two coats of semi-gloss.


America's Position in the Economic Race: What the Numbers Show and Conceal
LEAD: These are days of confirmation that the American economic system remains the model for those yearning to be rich.
But to some, this is a moment of irony: Even as the world learns to stop worrying and love Big Macs, the American economy seems to be losing its productive edge.
The nation is borrowing billions to cover expenses and to build high-tech toys like the stealth bomber, the theory goes, while everything from vocational education to computer-chip factories slides into obsolescence.


Playing for Bigger Stakes?
LEAD: THE Rev.
Jesse Jackson has used an Archimedean approach to politics - ''leverage,'' he calls it - to nudge the Democratic Party this way and that in recent years.
But Mr.
Jackson also wants to move the world, and for that, he has decided, the Mayor's office in Washington is not the place to stand.

LEAD: ''A CHORUS LINE,'' the hit musical that is to close this month after a record-breaking Broadway run of 15 years, in some ways is the ideal New York story, both in its own success and in the story it tells.
In it, 17 dancers try out for jobs in a show and, although almost all are destined to be losers, their up-and-down careers represent the mood of eternal hope that keeps attracting out-of-towners to New York.

Sasabe Journal;   A Tribe's Bitter Drug Lesson: Nothing Is Sacred
LEAD: From time immemorial, the Papago Indians have lived in the harsh desert here, roaming back and forth across what is today the United States-Mexico border.
But after fending off conquistadors, miners, ranchers, armies and other Indian tribes, the Papago now confront perhaps the most dangerous threat to their existence: the international drug trade.


Bridge
LEAD: One of the most prestigious positions in bridge journalism has a new occupant: Albert Dormer of London has succeeded Jeremy Flint, who died last November, as columnist for The Times of London, one of the world's most famous newspapers.


Jet Loses Air Pressure And Dives 25,000 Feet
LEAD: American Airlines Flight 40 from Los Angeles to New York suddenly lost cabin pressure and the pilots put it into a steep dive yesterday, dropping 25,000 feet in several minutes.
No one was injured, an airline official said, but passengers on board said they thought they were going to crash.

Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day on Friday about the Penrod Drilling Corporation misstated the extent of the company's ownership of offshore drilling rigs.
Penrod owns 39 modern drilling rigs, not 39 percent of the world's total.

Diamond Trade Gains
LEAD: Belgium's diamond trade, the world's biggest, posted a 25 percent increase in 1989.
The Diamond High Council said Friday that Belgium imported diamonds weighing a total of more than 129 million carats and worth 286.7 billion francs, or $8 billion, in 1989.
The council said export sales totaled 291.8 billion francs, or $8.15 billion.

Fixed Mortgages Down
LEAD: Fixed-rate home mortgages averaged 10.23 percent last week, down from 10.31 percent in the previous week, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.48 percent last week, up from 8.44 percent the week before.

Q.

Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day on Thursday about an interview with Karl Otto Pohl, president of West Germany's central bank, mistranslated a comment on the possible rate at which East German marks will be converted to West German marks under a unification of the two economies.
The quotation should have read, ''The better the rate is for the savers, the worse it will be for debtors,'' not creditors.

Moscow Computer Store
LEAD: The first store selling Western computers opened today in Moscow.
Most buyers are expected to be from Soviet research institutions and businesses that have access to hard currency. ''We expect to do a $10 million business in the first year.'' said Michael Tseytin, a Soviet emigre and the president of the franchise running the Computerland store near Moscow University.


Talking Business; with Ellis of Northeast Utilities;   The Lessons From Seabrook
LEAD: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission voted last week to give an operating license to the Seabrook nuclear plant after 20 years of controversy and protests and the bankruptcy of its major builder, the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, which owns 36 percent of the project.
William B. Ellis is the chairman and chief executive of Northeast Utilities, based in Berlin, Conn., which owns a 4 percent share of Seabrook and is expected to complete the purchase of Public Service soon.

Q. How do liquid crystal displays work?
A.
Liquid crystal displays, or LCD's, used in products like forehead thermometers and watches rely on a kind of matter that has characteristics of both a solid and a liquid, said Dr.
John L. Lewis, a chemist at the Liquid Crystal Institute at Kent State University, Kent,

Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day on Feb. 27 about the Forbes publishing enterprise used an erroneous figure for Fortune in the comparison of three magazines' North American circulation.
Fortune's figure through June 30 was 672,134, compared with 739,856 in North America for Forbes and 900,989 for Business Week.

Ambac Indemnity
LEAD: Citicorp announced yesterday that it was considering selling the Ambac Indemnity Corporation, a subsidiary of Citibank that insures interest and principal payments on municipal bonds.
The possibility of a sale, which has been previously suggested by banking analysts, is part of Citicorp's plans announced earlier this year to raise capital by selling some operations, the banking company said.


Congress Agency Sees Big Bush Budget Deficit
LEAD: The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office estimated today that if President Bush's proposed budget becomes law, the Government will spend $131 billion more than it takes in during the next fiscal year, far in excess of the legal limit of $64 billion.

Israel Devalues Shekel
LEAD: Israel cut the value of the shekel against the dollar by 1.6 percent today.
The shekel has been devalued by 4.2 percent against the dollar since last Wednesday.
The new rate is 2.0431 shekels to the dollar, and 2.1779 shekels to one unit of a basket of foreign currencies.
The Israeli central bank announced a 5.6 percent devaluation of the median rate against the dollar-dominated basket of currencies last Wednesday.

LEAD:
SLED-DOG RACING
Runyan Takes Lead in Alaska
A search was under way for a sled-dog team that may have been attacked by a moose yesterday, and Joe Runyan, the defending champion in the Iditarod Trail race in Alaska, blasted into the lead through heavy snow and wind.
Two bush pilots reported seeing a moose stomping sled dogs near Finger Lake, about 200 miles from the start of the race.

Clean Air, Common Sense
LEAD: President Bush got more than he asked for.
Environmentalists got less than they hoped for.
George Mitchell, the Senate majority leader, got as much as he bargained for.
Nobody in Washington is entirely happy with the compromise clean air bill worked out last week in the Senate.
But it may well mark the end of a decade of legislative paralysis, and in that case there's one sure winner: the breathing public.

Measuring Workplace Impairment
LEAD: A SIMPLE computer-based test to help employers tell whether workers in safety-related jobs are impaired by drugs, alcohol or other factors is starting to move from the laboratory to the workplace.
It could provide an unusual instance of a technical solution to a vexing social problem - in this case, screening out impaired workers without violating anyone's rights.


U.S. and China Resume Fulbright Program
LEAD: China has agreed to resume participation in the Fulbright program, but on a smaller scale than in recent years, the United States Embassy said today.


Budget Matters at the Crux Of Kennedy Center Talks
LEAD: James D. Wolfensohn, the New York investment banker who is being wooed to become chairman of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, has told the search committee that his acceptance of the job hinges on a commitment from Congress and the White House to help pay renovation expenses and some of the center's $15 million debt.


Penalties for Maryland
LEAD: The men's basketball program at Maryland was banned today from the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament in 1991 and 1992, prohibited from appearing on television next season and placed on three years' probation for major violations of N.C.A.A. rules.


Silicon Graphics And NKK in Deal
LEAD: Silicon Graphics Inc., a leading maker of computer work stations for processing three-dimensional images, said it was entering a strategic partnership with the NKK Corporation of Tokyo.
NKK, which is the second-largest steel company in Japan, will invest $35 million in newly issued Silicon Graphics convertible preferred stock.

Begin at the Beginning
LEAD: ''A COMPUTER is not some sort of supernatural, super-intelligent, all-mighty machine poised to take over the world.
A computer cannot think for itself; it can only follow instructions.
It is not capable of suddenly deciding that it would like to have an ice cream cone, or of feeling the desire to take a long vacation on some sunny island beach.

LEAD: The rating on about $2 billion of National Westminster Bank P.L.C. subordinated debt was lowered to AA+ from triple-A by the Standard &amp; Poor's Corporation, reflecting what the rating agency termed as changes in the bank's capital structure.


Campeau Unit Losses
LEAD: The troubled American retail operations of the Campeau Corporation posted substantial losses in the early stages of bankruptcy, court papers show.


In Texas, Candidate Makes Effort to End Drug-Use Question
LEAD: Trying to revive her faltering campaign for Texas governor, Ann Richards said today that she had not taken illegal drugs anytime in the past decade.
But she refused to say anything about her earlier life when, by her own admission, she was a heavy drinker.


I.B.M. Will Use Adobe's Technology
LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation said today that it would use technology from Adobe Systems Inc. for displaying and printing typefaces on virtually its entire line of computers and printers.

LEAD: Paleomagnetists have determined that the impact of the comet or asteroid that carved out the Bosumtwi crater in Ghana some 900,000 years ago was not responsible for a reversal of the Earth's magnetic field.

LEAD: The Cesar awards, the French equivalent of the Oscars, this year went mostly to ''Too Beautiful for You.'' Woolworth Outlay
LEAD: The Woolworth Corporation, owner of discount-, variety- and shoe-store chains, said it plans capital spending of about $325 million for the year ending Jan. 26, 1991, up from about $315 million in the year just ended.
It said the spending would be financed from internal sources.
Woolworth said it plans to open about 735 stores this year, with more than 90 percent to be specialty retailing units.


Bridge
LEAD: Perhaps the most confusing auction of the world team championships in Perth, Australia, last September occurred on the diagramed deal in a match between Colombia and Egypt.
East-West bid and raised spades, and then North-South did the same, playing in four spades redoubled.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS:Advertising;   Moves at Family Media
LEAD: If, as it promises, Family Media Inc. restarts Taxi and Model magazines in the fall as controlled-circulation publications, the company will do so with an almost entirely new staff.
Departing staff members at the magazines said several dozen people were dismissed last week.
Only Mary Peacock, Model's editor in chief, and Sharri Jurmain, Model's publisher, have been retained for the new magazines, said Eileen Koslow, Family Media's promotions director.

LEAD: Within days after an earthquake struck the San Francisco area on Oct. 17, killing 67 people, President Bush flew to the scene and Congress agreed to send more than $3 billion in emergency relief.
In the same city, 5,000 people have died of AIDS without any such dramatic Federal response.

LEAD: South African troops were ordered into Ciskei today to restore order after a wave of looting and destruction unleashed by a military coup Sunday in the nominally independent homeland.

LEAD: Covenant House officials said yesterday that the Rev.
Bruce Ritter set up a trust fund of nearly $1 million to benefit runaway youths but that part of the fund was used to make loans to two Covenant House board members.


Review/Theater;   Madness, Murder and Irrationality, in 'Woyzeck'
LEAD: Though ''Woyzeck'' was written in the 1830's, it is a seminal play of the 20th century, the first to articulate the alienation of modern man driven to madness by forces far beyond his control.
In a sequence of cumulative scenes, Buchner's play - based on a true story - follows the downward path of a barber who murders his mistress and suffers tragic consequences.


Prego Testifies She Is Feeling Better
LEAD: Dr.
Veronica Prego returned to the witness stand yesterday and told the jury in the two-month trial of her lawsuit that she was feeling better.

LEAD: Sunday's installment of ''60 Minutes'' on CBS - which included the return of Andy Rooney after a three-week suspension - exceeded the combined audience of ABC and NBC, according to preliminary ratings released yesterday by the A. C. Nielsen Company.

Rig Count Slips a Bit
LEAD: The number of working United States oil and gas rigs dipped by three this week, to a total of 894, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today.
The year-to-date count remains well ahead of the 1989 tally, however, when 761 rigs were working.
Traditionally, the rig count declines in the first quarter of the year.

LEAD: Facing a British political backlash to her plan for granting up to 225,000 Hong Kong residents full British citizenship, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is trying to persuade the United States and other Western nations to make similar offers to the people of Hong Kong.

Compaq Computer
LEAD: The Compaq Computer Corporation said it had made a small equity investment in Nexgen Microsystems, a company in San Jose, Calif., that is working on a clone of the Intel Corporation's 80386 microprocessor.
This is the microprocessor at the heart of most Compaq computers, and it is available only from Intel.


Key Official at Witco Gets Top-Level Position
LEAD: The Witco Corporation, a $1.6 billion specialty chemicals and petroleum company, yesterday named a new president and chief operating officer, Denis Andreuzzi, to succeed Thomas J. Bickett, who resigned last week for what the company said were personal reasons.


Pathe Contract To MGM/UA
LEAD: The MGM/UA Communications Company, pulled off the auction block in January, has reached a five-year deal to distribute films from the Pathe Communications Company, the companies said today.

Eastern Plan For Review
LEAD: The management of Eastern Air Lines said today that it would ask the United States Bankruptcy Court to review 12 transactions between Eastern and its parent company, the Texas Air Corporation.


Punch Account to Ayer
LEAD: The Proctor &amp; Gamble Company, which acquired Hawaiian Punch from Del Monte in January for $150 million, has assigned the advertising account for the beverage brand to Ayer, New York.
The brand has not been advertised much of late, as Del Monte had emphasized promotions.


Eating Well
LEAD: FINDING a diet book that is practical, safe and accurate is far more difficult than it should be, given the large number published each year, as difficult as finding that rich, luscious, nonfattening dessert.
Books promising instant success for losing weight or lowering cholesterol appear regularly on best-seller lists.


Factory Orders Fall By 5.4%
LEAD: Orders received by the nation's factories fell in January at the steepest rate in 15 years, the Commerce Department said today, reflecting a slump in the nation's manufacturing sector.


No Frothing, No Frothing, No Frothing
LEAD: We tacked the message on our refrigerator door when the baseball follies began two weeks ago.


Perrier to Return to U.S. Early Next Month
LEAD: Pulled off the market because of a contamination scare, Perrier sparkling water is returning - today in France and by early April in America.


President of Whitney Foresees New Emphasis on Scholarship
LEAD: Following the dismissal on Monday of Thomas N. Armstrong 3d, director of the Whitney Museum of American Art for 15 years, the museum's president, William S. Woodside, said yesterday that the Whitney's ''emphasis will be more heavily on scholarship than on quickie show-and-tell operations.''


Spy Plane Sets Speed Record, Then Retires
LEAD: One of America's premier spy planes, the SR-71 Blackbirds, had a final fling with the history books today, setting a transcontinental speed record before retiring to a museum home.


Gene L. Harmon, 62, Former Sears Executive
LEAD: Gene L. Harmon, retired vice president of corporate public affairs for Sears, Roebuck and Company, died of a heart attack Saturday while traveling from Palm Springs, Calif., to his home in Albuquerque, N.M.
He was 62 years old.


At the Nation's Table
LEAD: WHEN the doors open at Gira Polli in the North Beach section of San Francisco, the aroma of roasting chickens attracts the most preoccupied passers-by, many of whom decide not to pass by after all.

Labor Party Rejects Likud Terms for Palestinian Talks
LEAD: The Israeli Labor Party rejected Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's new terms for initiating talks with Palestinians today and gave his Likud party a day to change its mind if it hopes to keep their coalition Government intact.


Lukens Hires Outsider; Management Is Shifted
LEAD: Lukens Inc. announced a realignment of manufacturing and administrative responsibilities yesterday, coinciding with the naming of a president and chief operating officer at the Coatesville, Pa., company.


Changes at Intergroup Proposed by Centaur
LEAD: The Centaur Partners Group made two proposals yesterday that would ease its effort to win control of the board of National Intergroup Inc., the troubled Pittsburgh-based holding company with interests in drug distribution and steel.


Economic Scene;   Global Warming: China Perplex
LEAD: THE bad news, say Alan S. Manne of Stanford University and Richard G. Richels of the Electric Power Research Institute, is that it would probably cost Americans trillions of dollars to reduce their output of ''greenhouse effect'' carbon dioxide gas by as little as 20 percent.
The really bad news, the two economists say in a new, unpublished paper, is that a 20 percent cut would almost certainly be offset by increased emissions from poor countries.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Saturday about a $50 million gift from Walter H. Annenberg to the United Negro College Fund omitted a word in some copies from a reference to his gifts to the University of Pennsylvania.
He has given more than $300 million to the university's schools of communication and performing arts.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Feb. 24 about an agreement among television networks to create a single Election Day survey of voters leaving the polls misidentified a group formed in 1964 by ABC, CBS, NBC, The Associated Press and United Press International to gather vote totals for news organizations.
It is the News Election Service.


In Debut as Pro, Capriati Wins
LEAD: Her mother developed a stiff neck from nervous tension.
Her father's eyes were bloodshot after a sleepless night.
But Jennifer Capriati, the 13-year-old tennis phenomenon who finally made her professional debut this afternoon, experienced no debilitating jitters.


Citicorp Auction
LEAD: Interest rates were up modestly at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper yesterday.
It marked the third consecutive week that rates rose.
The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 8.1805 percent, up from 8.137 percent last week.
Citicorp said it also sold $50 million of 182-day paper at an average rate of 8.12 percent, up from 8.043 percent.


Norman E. Cash, 71, TV Ad Bureau Leader
LEAD: Norman E. Cash, a former president of the Television Bureau of Advertising, died of a heart attack on Saturday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla.
He was 71 years old.

Norway's War Souvenirs
LEAD: Two 10-ton anchors from the German cruiser Blucher, which sank on April 9, 1940, under torpedo and gun attack by Norwegian forces, have been salvaged from 230 feet of water in the Oslo Fjord, the newspaper Aftenposten reported Monday.
It said the anchors will be turned into memorials to mark the German attack on Norway 50 years ago.


Upheaval in the East;   SOVIETS APPROVE THE RIGHT TO OWN SMALL BUSINESSES
LEAD: The Soviet Parliament approved a property law today that gives private citizens the right to own small-scale factories and other businesses for the first time since the 1920's.

LEAD: For biting and scratching each other in a fight on Feb. 27, Dave Manson of the Chicago Black Hawks and Scott Stevens of the Washington Capitals were suspended for three games by the National Hockey League yesterday.
Manson, who was suspended for 13 games earlier this season, was also fined $500 by Brian O'Neill, the N.F.L.

Howe Let Into Minors
LEAD: Fay Vincent, the baseball commissioner, said yesterday that he would allow Steve Howe, the left-handed relief pitcher who was suspended from major league baseball four times from 1983 to 1988 for using illegal drugs, to play minor league baseball in 1990.
The commissioner added that Howe would continue to be barred from the big leagues until 1991.

LEAD: Friday night's hip-hop show at the Ritz was both bizarre and a self-affirming party.
The group Third Bass, which headlined the concert, is white in a genre overwhelmingly black; backed by a supportive, racially mixed audience, it crashed stereotypes.
And the audience coalesced in a show of real community.

CHRONICLE
LEAD: ALAN GREENSPAN, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, turned 64 years old yesterday.
To celebrate, he invited three other Washington figures with the same birthday to lunch in his private dining room at the Fed.
They were THOMAS S. FOLEY, the Speaker of the House, who is 61; WILLIAM H. WEBSTER, the Director of Central Intelligence, who is 66, and SENATOR CHRISTOPHER S.


Broadcast TV Revenue
LEAD: Broadcast television advertising revenue totaled $21.35 billion in 1989, up 3.6 percent from 1988, the Television Bureau of Advertising reported yesterday.
Network revenue fell two-tenths of a percent, to $9.56 billion.
Local television advertising rose 4.5 percent, to $5.08 billion, and spot television rose 2.3 percent, to $5.42 billion.


Guatemalan Says U.S. Is Unfair on Rights
LEAD: President Vinicio Cerezo, responding to the recall of the American Ambassador for consultations on the deteriorating human rights situation in Guatemala, attacked the move today as unfair and inconsistent.


Time Warner Plans to Start First Book Club for Children
LEAD: Lured by the fast-growing market for juvenile books, Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it would start the country's first book club for children, offering a monthly selection of reading for everyone from toddlers to young teen-agers.


2-Part Fannie Mae Offering Of Debentures Priced at Par
LEAD: A two-part financing by the Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, totaling $1.4 billion and consisting of an equal amount of five-year and 10-year debentures, was priced at par yesterday through various securities dealers.

Manila Court Frees Aquino Opponent on Bail
LEAD: Senator Juan Ponce Enrile had accommodated himself pretty well to the week he has spent in confinement on charges of complicity in the December coup against President Corazon C. Aquino.
He has spent that time in a two-room air-conditioned apartment, filled with friends, political supporters and a maid to keep things tidy.

LEAD: William J. Lovejoy got his start with the General Motors Acceptance Corporation repossessing cars in Brooklyn 28 years ago.
Yesterday, he was named president of the giant financing organization.


Corrections
LEAD: An entry in the Company Earnings listing of Business Day on Saturday about the Service Corporation International misstated the period of the company's 1988 results.
They were recorded for the full 12 months of 1988, ended Dec. 31, not for eight months.
The entry also misstated the period during which a gain of $2.9 million was recorded from a public offering.


Left at the Altar: Modern Tale of Woe
LEAD: BACK in the days of chaperones and curfews, of vigilant fathers and chaste brides, and of couples smooching on porch swings, engagements offered many a young man and woman the chance to get to know each other better and in greater privacy.
And more often than most people admitted, they didn't like what they found, and the engagement ended in tears, recriminations and sometimes a huge bill for a wedding never held.

LEAD: Anyone native to this southwestern French town can identify the lampposts and metal terraces near the railroad station where 99 local men were hanged by Nazi stormtroopers on June 9, 1944, in reprisal for the killings of 40 Germans by Resistance fighters.


G.M. to Decide On Electric Car
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said it would decide within two months whether to put a nonpolluting electric car into production.
The world's biggest car company outlined test results for its electric car at a news conference before the 60th Geneva International Motor Show, which opens Thursday.


Wet Feet and Triangle Trails
LEAD: A New Yorker, returned after a long absence to live in the city, was made aware by yesterday's snowstorm of a change that took place while he was away.
Nobody seems worried about dry feet.
Walking with eyes down against the wind-driven flakes, he did not see a single pair of old-fashioned rubbers and the only galoshes were on children being herded to school.

Mr.
Kugler, who is 49 years old, had run the government securities operations of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the collapsed brokerage firm.
He has worked in the securities industry for 30 years.

LEAD: Elders IXL Ltd., the Australian brewer, sold a 23 percent stake in Scottish &amp; Newcastle Breweries P.L.C. at a big loss last week.
Elders, which makes Foster's lager and controls the Courage chain of pubs in Britain, had hoped to become a leading European brewer after buying the Edinburgh-based company.

Postal Service Proposes Rate Increases
LEAD: The United States Postal Service today proposed an increase in all classes of mail that would raise the price of a first-class stamp to 30 cents and increase costs to businesses for second- and third-class mailings by billions of dollars a year.

Bennington Journal;   Is the Statehood Honeymoon Over?
LEAD: In 1791, Vermont patriots gathered here, voting to join the union as the 14th state.
Almost two centuries later, in a pristine clapboard church a few yards from the site where that historic decision was made, an assembly of Vermonters voted by a 2-to-1 margin to secede from the United States.

Microwave Cooking
LEAD: PEOPLE who own microwave ovens are often asked by friends, ''Do you use that thing much?'' Notice they do not even use the term ''cook.'' The answers will vary depending on how the owner uses the oven.
Some use it for everything because they like the coolness and easy cleanup as much as the speed, while others make only certain foods that are quicker or better when made in the microwave oven, including vegetables and fish.


Police Bullets Hit Detectives, Officials Say
LEAD: The bullets that wounded two detectives during an undercover drug deal in Manhattan on Monday came from their own guns or the gun of a third officer, high-ranking police officials said privately yesterday.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Feb. 1 about a protein secreted by tumor cells, with possible use in predicting the recurrence of breast cancer in women, misstated the affiliation of a researcher, Dr.
William McGuire.
A reader's inquiry this week disclosed that he is at the University of Texas Health Science Center in San Antonio, not in Houston.


Where to Get Straight Talk
LEAD: BOOKS about healthful eating generally are even more difficult to evaluate than diet books.
The single most important criterion for books about nutrition and healthful eating is that they are accurate.
And it often takes a professional to judge their accuracy.
These organizations have compiled lists of, or can provide suggestions on, safe and accurate diet and nutrition books.


Korea in Uranium Pact
LEAD: The South Korean Government approved a plan on Monday that would allow the state-owned Korea Electric Power Corporation to import enriched uranium from the Soviet Union for nuclear power plants, an official said.
The decision cleared the way for South Korea and the Soviet Union, which have no diplomatic relations, to begin cooperation in nuclear power.

In the real world of everyday opera such an ideal balance seldom occurs, but the synergy of disparate elements sometimes can produce exciting results.


Disarm Nicaragua
LEAD: It is not just a clash of wills but stubborn history that clouds the promise of Nicaragua's election.
The losing Sandinistas now growl that even in defeat they cannot hand over control of the armed forces and security police to a new government.
And despite Violeta Barrios de Chamorro's victory, contra rebels are scorning pleas to disband.

FIGURE SKATING
Soviet Couples Dominate Pairs
Three Soviet couples led the pairs competition of the world figure skating championships last night in Halifax, Nova Scotia.
Yekaterina Gordeyeva and Sergei Grinkov, the 1988 Olympic and defending world champions, won first place.
Natalya Mishkutenok and Artur Dmitriev were second.

Japan's Chip Market
LEAD: Foreign companies increased their share of Japan's semiconductor market to a record 12.9 percent in the fourth quarter of 1989, a Japanese official said today.
The figure is nine-tenths of a percentage point higher than the third quarter of 1989 and 2.3 points higher than the fourth quarter of 1988, the Ministry of Trade and Industry official said, quoting figures of World Semiconductor Trade Statistics, a private group.

LEAD: Thumbs are particularly useful for those who read bridge columns, since they make it easy to reproduce the realities of play when only half the cards are in view.

Mitsubishi and Daimler-Benz are negotiating a plan of ''intensive cooperation'' in automobile technology, aerospace, microelectronics and a number of service industries.
It may prove to be one of the most far-reaching industrial linkups ever and could pose an enormous competitive challenge for the U.S.

Washington Talk;   Supreme Court's Style: A Richness in Diversity
LEAD: If Supreme Court opinions were paintings, art critics would have trouble defining the Supreme Court style.
Sometimes the Court paints with broad strokes, splashing color across the canvas as boldly as any Abstract Expressionist.
Sometimes it draws delicately, the results as fragile and fine as a Persian miniature, precise as Pointillism, or filled with Renaissance shadings of light and shadow.

'Handmaid's Tale,' Adapted From Atwood Novel
''The Handmaid's Tale'' is that rare totalitarian fantasy in which the tyrants plant tulips and wear pearls.
The United States, now renamed Gilead, has become a male-controlled police state dedicated to the oppression of women, yet there are very few men in either Margaret Atwood's novel or Volker Schlondorff's film version.
The men are either roaming the corridors of power, fighting as soldiers called Angels, or (if they are nonwhite) relegated to far-flung colonies in badly polluted parts of the world.
So for the most part, it is only the women we see.
Women called Aunts, dressed in high heels and loose, demure brown outfits that would have been just right for office jobs in the days when women were still allowed to hold them, are now in charge of teaching moral pieties and laying down the law.
Women called Wives wear an overpowering shade of blue and preside over large houses in the suburbs.
Women called Marthas, in gray-green maids' uniforms, keep these houses running smoothly.
Women called Handmaids dress in red and have been robbed of all rights, reduced to only two basic functions: breeding babies (because pollution has rendered most other women barren) and buying groceries.


I.R.S. Issues Summonses to Defense Lawyers
LEAD: The Internal Revenue Service has served summonses on criminal defense lawyers around the country, demanding that they reveal the names of clients who paid large fees with cash, an official of the agency said today.

Liberals Starting a Journal As a Forum for New Ideas
LEAD: Nobody will accuse liberals of having led the political debate during the past decade or so.
Indeed, many liberals themselves acknowledge, a bit ruefully, that the ideas that made a difference in the 1970's and 80's came more often than not from conservatives.
But a small group of liberal writers and professors, many with national reputations, are starting a new journal, hoping it will become the focal point of a renewal.

LEAD: Kashmiri militants shot and killed an Indian policeman today and killed a Muslim they suspected of spying for New Delhi, the Governor of Jammu and Kashmir state said.

LEAD: Andre Agassi has decided not to play in the United States Davis Cup matches against Czechoslovakia, which begin March 30.
He said yesterday that he did not think he would be well prepared.
He will be replaced by Aaron Krickstein, ranked No. 6 in the world.
Agassi is No. 8.
Krickstein and Brad Gilbert will play singles against the Czechoslovaks, with Jim Pugh and Rick Leach playing doubles.

LEAD: The three al-Fayed brothers lied during their successful takeover in 1985 of the House of Fraser P.L.C., the owner of the famous London department store Harrods, the British Government said today.

LEAD: The Ford Motor Company announced a series of executive changes today that included an important promotion for William Clay Ford Jr., improving his chances of one day running the company that his great-grandfather founded 87 years ago.

LEAD: Plans to introduce legislation to end the tax deductibility of cigarette advertising in New York State and New York City will be announced today by Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis and Councilman Stanley Michels, both of Manhattan.


Suspected Spy Appeals His Ouster by State Dept.
LEAD: Felix S. Bloch, the State Department diplomat dismissed last month after being named as a suspected Soviet agent, has protested his dismissal and will be granted a hearing before an appeals panel, a Government official said today.

For Children, A Hurtless House
LEAD: Tucked away in a housing development on some once-verdant farmland in New Jersey stands a house that will make every parent feel guilty.
It is designed and decorated to be safe for children.


USX Stock Drops In a Bet on Icahn
LEAD: The stock of the USX Corporation fell sharply today as investors bet Carl C. Icahn would fail to notify the steel and energy giant by Thursday that he plans to wage a fight for control of the company at its annual meeting.
Shares of USX lost $1.375, to $35.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Mr.
Icahn, who owns about 13 percent of the Pittsburgh-based steel and energy giant, has threatened to raise his stake.


Ian Horvath Memorial
LEAD: A memorial service for Ian Horvath, a founder of the Cleveland Ballet and a former soloist with the Joffrey Ballet and American Ballet Theater, is to be held at 3:45 P.M. on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street.
Among those scheduled to perform at the service, which is free and open to the public, are the dancers Cynthia Gregory and Christopher Gillis.


Dow Slides 7.21 Points on Light Volume
LEAD: Stocks moved narrowly yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 7.21, to 2,669.59, in light volume, as traders marked time until tomorrow's key employment figures for February.
The numbers are expected to show continued weakness in the economy.


William Appleman Williams Dies; Gadfly of Foreign Policy Was 68
LEAD: William Appleman Williams, a historian known for his sharp critiques of American foreign policy, died of cancer Monday at Newport (Ore.) Community Hospital.
He was 68 years old and lived on the Oregon coast at Waldport.

The designer for the Fendi collection of fur and ready-to-wear was explaining his eclectic approach after his show Tuesday night.

LEAD: The Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam, Conn., will open its 28th season on April 18 with ''The Chocolate Soldier,'' a musical based on George Bernard Shaw's ''Arms and the Man.'' The season will also include ''Pal Joey,'' opening July 4, and ''Bells Are Ringing,'' opening Sept. 26.

Reviews/Music;   Nettle, Markham and Pianos
LEAD: David Nettle and Richard Markham, two British pianists who have been performing as a duo since 1979, made their New York debut on Monday evening at Merkin Concert Hall.
Their playing was finely integrated, and melodic lines frequently passed from one piano to the other without the slighest variation in timbre or dynamics.

Reviews/Music;   Borodin and the Soviet Style
LEAD: As the Soviet Union's barriers crumble, so certainly in time will one of the last remaining musical enclaves of idiosyncratic style.
The Soviet school has prospered perhaps by its isolation; and in the process, it has more or less ignored contemporary trends toward lighter, finer musical phrasing and attention to historical accuracy.

LEAD: In another sign that Iran's leadership may be reaching for a closer relationship with the West, the Teheran Government agreed today to let a United Nations official make a second visit to the country to investigate accusations of unlawful executions, torture and other serious human rights violations.

LEAD: China expressed deep concern tonight over political battles in Taiwan that are taking place in advance of the presidential election there later this month, and strongly condemned the governing Nationalist Party for ''creating political and social instability.''

LEAD: President Bush will announce a transportation policy on Thursday declaring that the nation's economy is ''at risk'' because of inadequate investment in public works projects, but seeking to minimize Federal subsidies for transportation.

LEAD: James Wilder, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers' career leader in rushing and pass reception yardage, signed with the Washington Redskins yesterday after being left unprotected on the Buccaneers' 37-man roster.

LEAD: The Knicks came to Philadelphia tonight to protect the Atlantic Division lead they had held since Nov. 18, when the National Basketball Association season was only 15 days old.

Pan Am Offers Refund Policy
LEAD: Pan American World Airways announced a new policy yesterday, promising a free flight to anyone with a valid complaint about service in first class on its flights between New York and San Francisco or Los Angeles and between Washington and Los Angeles.

LEAD: Gregg Olson, the 1989 American League Rookie of the Year, came to terms with the Baltimore Orioles yesterday on a one-year contract that will make him one of the highest-paid second-year players ever.


Ex-Rep. Diggs Back in Politics
LEAD: Charles Diggs Jr., who resigned as a Congressman from Michigan in 1980 after being convicted of taking payroll kickbacks, said today that he would run for the Maryland House of Delegates. ''My principal reason for running is to be in Annapolis during the reapportionment consideration in 1991 and '92,'' he said.


Businessland Chain to Offer Products of Compaq Again
LEAD: The Compaq Computer Corporation said today that Businessland Inc., a leading retailer of computers, would again carry its products in the United States.
Compaq withdrew its products from Businessland last April, complaining that the chain had struck preferential deals with Compaq's major competitors.

Then she found out what that victory meant for her.

LEAD: The trial of William Reedy, who is charged with driving Billy Martin's pickup truck while intoxicated when the former Yankee manager was killed in an accident on Christmas Day, has been delayed another 30 days.

LEAD: Arthur Fletcher, the newly appointed chairman of the Federal Civil Rights Commission, today underwent his second triple-bypass heart operation in less than six months.
Mr.
Fletcher, 65 years old, entered George Washington University Hospital on Monday after doctors concluded that previous bypass surgery ''didn't take,'' said Barbara Brooks, a commission spokeswoman.

Philadelphia Subway Crash Kills 3; 150 Are Hurt
LEAD: The last three cars of a six-car subway train derailed and crashed into steel pillars in a downtown tunnel during the morning rush hour today, killing three people and injuring about 150 others.
At least six of the injured were in critical condition, including those crushed when the steel pillars pierced their car.

LEAD: Gene therapy for human disease took a leap from the theoretical realms of the laboratory toward the real world of practicing medicine today.
A National Institutes of Health panel approved a proposal to treat children with a severe genetic disease by inserting new genes into their blood cells.

Charlotte Sitterly, 91; Devoted Career to Sunlight Studies
LEAD: Charlotte M. Sitterly, an astrophysicist whose analysis of sunlight first showed that the element technitium exists in nature, died of heart failure on Saturday at her home in Washington.
She was 91.
Dr.
Sitterly had devoted much of her career to the study of the sun's spectrum, including wavelengths that could not penetrate the atmosphere and were therefore observed from rockets.

LEAD: Selling cigarettes these days would seem to be a difficult, even doomed, art.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:
Off-Track Sliding Door
Q.We have a sliding door between our kitchen and dining room that slides back into a pocket inside the wall.
When the carpet people were ripping up our old carpet, a workman jerked the door and knocked the rear hanger wheel off the track at the top so that the door now hangs at an angle and we cannot pull it shut.

LEAD: King Fahd of Saudi Arabia donated $1 million to Nancy Reagan's anti-drug campaign in 1985 while the Reagan Administration was considering a request from his country to buy surveillance aircraft, a former White House official said Tuesday.

Antique Beds and Their Lookalikes
LEAD: ANYONE who wants an antique bed or bed frame knows the predicament.
The beds are rare and getting rarer, and when you can find one it is either unbearably rickety, too short and narrow, or requires bed linen of unusual proportions.
And it is nearly impossible to find an antique bed frame to fit a modern king-size bed.

Uruguay Acts on Deficit
LEAD: Uruguay raised fuel prices and utility charges Tuesday by up to 30 percent and proposed an increase in taxes to slash its budget deficit and cut inflation.

Reviews/Music;   Groan (127 Minutes) and Drone (Eternal)
LEAD: For two decades, the composer La Monte Young has been presenting grandiose, mystic concerts in which musicians groan away for hours accompanying a dense electronic drone, sitting in a dark, hieratic visual environment.
These events, which have been fairly infrequent in recent years, are called Dream Houses, and the collection of musicians - who over the years have included some of the brightest lights of ''downtown'' experimental music - is called the Theater of Eternal Music.

Banks' Profits Fell 35% in '89
LEAD: Profits at American banks fell 35 percent in 1989, to $16.3 billion, largely because bad loans sharply eroded earnings in the second half of the year, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today.


Corrections
LEAD: A chart in Science Times on Tuesday showing the 1989 population of bald eagles described the National Wildlife Federation's midwinter eagle survey incompletely and omitted or misstated figures for some states.
The survey includes migratory Canadian eagles and does not reflect the status of the nesting population of the lower 48 states; not all states are covered in the survey.

HOME REPAIR
LEAD: DOOR lock problems do not always require the removal or replacement of the entire knob and latch assembly.

Hydraulic Hose Broke Before Shuttle Landed
LEAD: A ruptured hose spilled five gallons of hydraulic fluid inside the space shuttle Atlantis and caused a brief drop in pressure just before it landed Sunday but the astronauts were never in danger, the space agency has disclosed.


Inquiry Begun Into Claim Of Child Abuse at Center
LEAD: The Brooklyn District Attorney is investigating claims that dozens of children were sexually molested at a now-closed unlicensed day-care center in Brooklyn last year, according to participants in the case.


UConn Coach Honored
LEAD: Jim Calhoun of the University of Connecticut was voted Big East coach of the year yesterday after his team finished the regular season with a 25-5 record and won a share of the league title with Syracuse.


Hotel Chains' Woes: Just Too Many Rooms
LEAD: Overbuilding, operating cost increases and stiffer competition among major hotel chains have turned the fast growth-and-earnings pace of the early 1980's into a crawl of consolidation and strains on profits, corporate executives and industry analysts say.
Many experts believe that it will take the industry years to overcome most of the problems and that shakeouts could affect some familiar hotel names.

Economic Scene;   The Denial Of the Obvious
LEAD: STEPHEN POTTER, the author of ''Gamesmanship'' and ''One-Upmanship,'' said an economist has two basic ploys.
The first, labeled Economic Approach A, is to cloak the obvious in ''a little wild incomprehensibility.'' Thus, Mr.
Potter's model economist, named Regil, would tell listeners that if they wanted to influence ''the general liquidity situation of banks and public,'' they had better not forget that the central bank's ''discretionary action on the cash basis took the shape of dealings in Treasury bills, the market rate of discount on which could and did fluctuate.

LEAD: A number of new faces have worked their way into the Metropolitan Opera's new production of ''Faust.'' LEAD: Thousands of anti-Government demonstrators across Haiti set up flaming tire barricades and burned cars today to protest the army's killing of a schoolgirl.

RJR Selling Units
LEAD: RJR Nabisco Inc. agreed to sell its Nabisco food businesses in New Zealand, Singapore, Malaysia and Hong Kong to Britannia Brands Ltd. for $180 million.

Annual sales of the divested companies total $190 million.

LEAD: Mayor David N. Dinkins, keeping a political promise, said yesterday that he would let the New York City Fire Department reopen Engine Company 41 in the South Bronx, a firehouse that Mayor Edward I. Koch closed last year, after a long, bitter fight, to save money.

LEAD: A committee at the Louisiana State University Medical Center concluded today that it should not stop researchers from firing pellets into the brains of anesthetized cats despite opposition from animal rights groups.
Researchers say their findings will help them learn how to return brain-injured soldiers to active duty.

Reviews/Theater;   Primal Emotions When Sex Runs Amok
LEAD: Erotic passion run amok is one of the hardest things to portray on the stage without its seeming either tinnily melodramatic or unintentionally funny.
If the Intar Stage 2's production of Ana Maria Simo's heavy-breathing drama, ''Going to New England,'' has moments that seem both shrill and silly, her play still deserves credit for trying to go below the surface of soap opera histrionics to get at the primal emotions that erupt when sexual feelings go out of control.

Review/Art;   Re-Creating a 1930 Show With Famous and Forgotten
LEAD: There are obvious weaknesses in ''Nineteen Americans,'' at the Forum Gallery, which is something of a re-creation of a 1930 show at the Museum of Modern Art -the museum's second show, and its first devoted to American art.
Some of the paintings are weak and anecdotal.
The packed installation in the smaller of the two gallery spaces looks like an art shop.

LEAD: A yearlong odyssey ended for Kurt Browning of Canada tonight as he successfully defended his men's title in the world figure skating championships, putting to rest concerns that he was squandering his talents, rather than improving them.

Review/Pop;   Gloria Estefan, Bilingually
LEAD: Early in her Madison Square Garden concert on Wednesday evening, Gloria Estefan asked how many people in the spoke Spanish, how many spoke English, and how many spoke both languages.
After all three categories were greeted with enthusiastic applause, the Cuban-American pop star expressed her delight and responded by singing a bilingual concert in which the choruses and occasionally the verses of many of the songs were split between the two languages.

LEAD: B. J. Welsh named her 2 1/2-year-old son after Dylan Thomas not because she wanted him to be a poet, but because she and her husband liked the sound of the name and its lyric evocation of the sea. ''Dylan means 'borne on the waves,' or just 'washed ashore,' '' she said, ''and he came to us from overseas, so it seemed really appropriate.

LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about executive changes at the Ford Motor Company misstated the age of William Clay Ford Jr.
He is 32.

Washington Bank Agrees to Be Sold
LEAD: The board of the Washington Bancorporation, the parent of the National Bank of Washington, agreed to sell the company to a group of investors for at least $134 million.

Reviews/Dance;   Woe, Woe and Again Woe: A Catalogue of Complaints
LEAD: Jeff McMahon is an intense and driven monologuist who moves with the elasticity of warm putty and the lightness of a leaf buffeted by changeable winds.
Mind and body are blended inextricably in ''Discontents,'' a new work presented on Thursday at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater.
The eveninglong piece is a tour de force of performing.


Money Fund Assets Rise
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 499 money market mutual funds increased by $2 billion, to $390.79 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 153 institutional funds increased by $212 million, to $91.75 billion.
The assets of the 245 general-purpose funds were up by $502.20 million, to $132.90 billion.

Campaign Finance Bill Clears First Hurdle of Many
LEAD: In the start of what is expected to be a lively partisan debate, a Senate committee today approved a Democratic bill that seeks to place limits on campaign spending by candidates for the Senate.


Management Realigned At Young &amp; Rubicam
LEAD: Young &amp; Rubicam Inc. announced a nearly complete management realignment yesterday.
Peter A. Georgescu, who had been president of Young &amp; Rubicam Advertising, was named president of Young &amp; Rubicam Inc., a title formerly held by the chairman and chief executive, Alexander Kroll.
Joseph E. DeDeo, formerly president of Young &amp; Rubicam Europe, was named president and chief executive of Y.&amp;R.


Haim S. Eliachar, 61, A Developer, Is Dead
LEAD: Haim S. Eliachar, a developer who was a founder and the first president of the American Sephardi Foundation, died of lung cancer on Tuesday at his home in Boston.
He was 61 years old and also had a home in Edgartown on Martha's Vineyard.


Palestinian Leader Is Opposing Arafat On Talks With Israel
LEAD: Coming out in open opposition to what he said was Yasir Arafat's policy of compromise, a Palestinian guerrilla leader called today for ''mobilizing all our energies'' to foil proposed Palestinian-Israeli talks under United States and Egyptian sponsorship.


Big TV Deals Will Be at Top of the Agenda When N.F.L. Owners Meet Sunday
LEAD: The National Football League owners hope to open their five-day annual meeting Sunday in Orlando, Fla., by endorsing new four-year television contracts that could nearly double their current annual television revenue of $17 million per club.

Douglas Plays Berg
LEAD: The pianist Barry Douglas is to play Mussorgsky's ''Pictures at an Exhibition,'' Alban Berg's Sonata (Op. 1) and the Tchaikovsky Sonata in G (Op. 37) at the 92d Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue, tomorrow evening at 8.
Mr.
Douglas, who is from Belfast, won the gold medal at the Tchaikovsky International Competition in Moscow in 1986.


WEEKENDER GUIDE
LEAD:
FRIDAY
ARABIAN DAYS


Armani: Classic and Sensual
LEAD: The fall and winter fashion shows here this week were a series of loopy turns, but Giorgio Armani, as usual in the past few years, set everything straight at the end.
Retailers seeking truth in fashion believed they found it with Armani's stark daytime clothes and his expanded range of evening styles.


Youth Held in Burning of Boy Called Thuggish but Lonely
LEAD: On the block where he lives, the accused youth is known as a bully with a vicious streak - a boy who taunted and beat smaller children, stole their lunch money and other property and sometimes whipped stray dogs into snarling fury and set them on one another for the fun of it.


Books of The Times;   Alice Munro's Stories Of Changes of the Heart
LEAD:
Friend of My Youth
By Alice Munro
273 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.


No More Lockout for No Strike? Players' Union Says No Way
LEAD: In a move the union rejected as a blatant public relations ploy, Commissioner Fay Vincent yesterday asked baseball's club owners to lift their three-week-old lockout of players from spring training camps if the players pledged not to strike during the 1990 season.


Review/Film;   Gross Encounters in Comical 'House Party'
LEAD: ''House Party,'' Reginald Hudlin's effervescent first feature, enters the life of its young hero, Kid (Christopher Reid), as if passing into another dimension of time and space.
The screen glows with ominous hot-white light, the way it does when the little girl in ''Poltergeist'' crosses over to the other side of her television screen.


Ernest McMahon, 79, Former Rutgers Dean
LEAD: Dr.
Ernest E. McMahon, an author, educator and a former dean at Rutgers University, died of cancer last Thursday at the William Hill Health Center in Easton, Md.
He was 79 years old and lived in St.
Michaels, Md.


Defense Tries to Tie Valdez Spill to Helmsman
LEAD: The Exxon Valdez ran aground on a jagged reef and spilled its cargo of oil because the helmsman failed to turn the ship as far as he had been ordered, an expert testified today on behalf of the tanker's skipper.


Gartner Makes Himself A Factor
LEAD: A week's worth of disconcerting trade rumors had been followed by 24 hours of nonstop interviews once the deal was done.
Mike Gartner then stepped onto a plane, got off and stepped into a locker room of the Rangers for the first time.
Twelve hours later, he boarded a bus, got in one brief skate and finally wound up in a hotel room here, hours from a game against the

Profit-Sharing Pay Is Lower at Ford
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said its 1989 profits would generate $166 million in profit-sharing payments, or about $1,025 for each employee, roughly one-third of last year's amount and the lowest payout since 1984.

Treasuries Mixed in Light Trading
LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities were mixed in light trading yesterday, as dealers reacted to comments by Manuel Johnson, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, by selling shorter-term issues and buying long-term bonds.


Patent Suit Becomes Trade Battle
LEAD: A Swiss machine-tool company won a victory today over a Japanese rival in a battle that has been marked by bare-knuckles practices rarely seen in multinational business.


Review/Music;   'Sound of Music' Takes On The Icons of a Heroic Past
LEAD: From its first Broadway performance in 1959, Rodgers and Hammerstein's sentimental ''Sound of Music'' has not ranked high among the cognoscenti, even the cognoscenti of musicals.
And it cannot be said that the New York City Opera's spring seasons of musicals at the cavernous New York State Theater, now in their fifth and apparently final year, have been greeted with universal acclaim, either.

Chronicle
LEAD: The French are fond of wearing and bestowing medals, and last night in New York they awarded the medal of Chevalier des Arts et Lettres to three New Yorkers: the artists ELLSWORTH KELLY and FRANK STELLA, and the chief dance critic of The New York Times, ANNA KISSELGOFF.


Mother Accuses Sperm Bank of a Mixup
LEAD: A 33-year-old woman has sued a Manhattan fertility clinic and a sperm bank, charging that they mistakenly substituted another man's sperm for her husband's.
The woman is white, as was her late husband; she said the donor is black.


From Co-op to Rental to Condo;   1927 Structure Is Converted in Newark
LEAD: When Mount Prospect Manor opened here in 1927, the city was going through a period of unbridled development.
Newark ranked 14th in the nation in industrial production, its population was approaching half a million and Newark Airport was under construction.

Review/Television;   Adventures in the Fight Against Drug Dealers
LEAD: While some shows are already turning to reruns, the commercial networks continue to bring on new candidates for the weekly ratings competitions.

Action is the main word in each case.


Putting a Sharper Edge On Traditional Blues
LEAD: While many performers think of blues as a purist's idiom that should remain true to its roots in the rural American South of the 1930's and 40's, Son Seals, the 48-year-old blues guitarist, is a proud synthesist.
From the beginning of his career, Mr.
Seals, who is to perform this weekend at the Village Gate, has worked to update blues with more contemporary styles.

John Harlan Jr., 71, Former U.S. Official
LEAD: John G. Harlan Jr., a retired executive vice president and director of the Engelhard Minerals and Chemical Corporation of Edison, N.J., and former Federal official, died of congestive heart failure on Monday at his home in Gloucester, Va.
He was 71 years old.


Bush Transportation Policy Assailed
LEAD: The Bush Administration's new transportation policy was sharply criticized today by many members of Congress and by state and local officials, most of whom disagreed with its shift from Federal spending toward local spending on mass transit and highways.


Margaret Eddy, 63, Pastor and Educator In East Harlem Posts
LEAD: The Rev.
Dr.
Margaret Ruth Eddy, a Congregationalist minister, an educator and a community leader in East Harlem for 40 years, died of cancer Wednesday at her home in Manhattan.
She was 63 years old.
In 1948, as a seminary student, Dr.
Eddy was a member of the group ministry that founded the East Harlem Protestant Parish, and she remained involved there until 1972.

LEAD: AFTER riding high much of last year, steel stocks have taken a fall in recent months, a result of tumbling steel prices, a downturn in orders from the automotive industry and general economic weakness.
But steel industry analysts and executives insist that the current state of affairs is temporary and that a rebound is coming by the second half.

LEAD: Fairchild Publications is expected to announce a reorganization of its magazine group today, with one segment for retailing and fashion magazines, another for industrial and electronic publications and a third for financial publications.
A person familiar with the changes said that they were being made to save money and to use the staffs more efficiently and that no big layoffs were expected.

Buddy (Arye Gross) is the middle brother, the peacemaker, the one who wears Bermuda shorts and loves a girl named Tammy.

Restaurants
LEAD: When the Nice Restaurant opened five years ago on East Broadway in Chinatown, it was among the first of a new wave of cavernous, glittery Hong Kong-style Cantonese restaurants in the area.
These are festive places to be sure.
On any evening at this two-level, 500-seat extravaganza, you might encounter sprawling tables of 10 or more family members celebrating a birthday, a gaggle of schoolchildren and their chaperones clattering in another corner, and even a mirthful wedding reception complete with choral singers accompanied by dozens of wine-glass percussionists.

LEAD: The Supreme Court has shed all pretense of neutral justice on the matter of Federal court relief for state prisoners, especially those on death row.
Not content with rejecting most death penalty appeals, a five-justice majority is now doing all it can to close the Federal courts even to inmates with meritorious legal claims.

LEAD: A human skull packed with some 125 radiation detectors was flown on the last two secret military space shuttle missions in an attempt to better understand the radiation hazards for astronauts, space agency experts said yesterday.

Art by Charles Saxon
LEAD: About 70 drawings and watercolors by Charles Saxon, whose cartoons appeared in The New Yorker for 35 years, are on view through June 29 in the Rare Book and Manuscript Library of the Butler Library at Columbia University, Broadway and 116th Street.
The exhibition is in observance of a gift from the artist's widow, Nancy, of 1,900 of his works.


Laser Radar May Help To Detect Wind Shear
LEAD: Researchers at Stanford University have patented a laser-based radar that they think could help airline pilots detect wind shear, the pockets of air turbulence blamed for some fatal plane crashes.


Zaccaro's Conviction Upheld
LEAD: The Vermont Supreme Court today upheld the drug conviction of John Zaccaro Jr., the son of Geraldine Ferraro, the Democratic candidate for Vice President in 1984.
In a unanimous decision, the court rejected claims by Mr.
Zaccaro's lawyers that his conviction in 1988 for selling cocaine should be reversed because the police operation in which he was arrested was conducted illegally and he was the victim of selective prosecution as a result of his mother's being well known.


CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost;   Credit Card Trade-Ups
LEAD: With the credit card market saturated, issuers of gold cards are pressing more affluent consumers to ''trade up'' because gold cards offer higher profits and lower risks.
It makes sense for holders of standard Visa cards or Mastercards to consider switching to gold because the rates and annual fees for these cards are on their way down and are either lower than or competitive with the lowest charges for standard cards.

33 Seized in Gambling Raids
LEAD: A $328 million betting ring was broken by a series of raids that resulted in 33 arrests, District Attorney Denis Dillon of Nassau County said today.
He said the betting ring operated out of neighborhood stores at 18 locations in Nassau County and in New York City.
Officers seized more than $150,000, along with gambling records, recording devices, cassettes and television sets in the raids.


U.S. Bars 3 Airline Pilots For Drinking and Flying
LEAD: All three members of a Northwest Airlines cockpit crew were under the influence of alcohol on a Midwestern flight Thursday, and their licenses have been revoked, the Federal Aviation Administration said today.

Coffee Exports Spurt
LEAD: World exports of coffee jumped by nearly 25 percent last year after international controls on sales were abolished in July, the International Coffee Organization said this week.
Exports to all destinations in the last half of 1989 totaled 39.6 million bags, compared with 31.9 million in the comparable period of 1988, the organization reported.

Its creative urges would dry up and the form would blow away.

Fernandez has moved at a speed that has startled even a city renowned for its fast pace.

LEAD: The sentencing of the GAF Corporation and one of its top executives on stock manipulation and other charges was postponed yesterday until March 30.

Abortion Curbs, Strictest in U.S., Win Idaho Vote
LEAD: The Idaho House today approved a bill that would give the state the nation's most restrictive abortion law and provide abortion opponents the test they want for a United States Supreme Court decision on the issue.


Mandela Ally Rebukes Pretoria
LEAD: Walter Sisulu, a leader of the African National Congress, denied today that the group was responsible for the growing unrest in South Africa and said that the white-dominated Government had caused the violence by its policy of apartheid.
