LEAD: Demonstrations aimed at bringing down this country's military ruler continued for the fifth day today as protesters marched and built flaming barricades to block main roads.


British Concern to Add American Home Unit
LEAD: The British consumer goods company Reckitt &amp; Colman P.L.C. agreed yesterday to acquire the household products division of American Home Products for $1.25 billion.


Cardinal Hayes Tops All Hallows for Title
LEAD: The last time Cardinal Hayes High School in the Bronx won a Catholic High Schools Athletic Association championship, there was one Germany and the United States was at war with it and most of the crowd of 3,300 packed into Fordham University to watch them win their second one last night were not even born.


Phone Venture In East Germany
LEAD: Alcatel, a French-American telecommunications company, announced plans for a big joint venture in East Germany to overhaul the country's dilapidated telephone network.
It said its West German subsidiary had signed an agreement with VEB Kombinat Nachrichtenelektronik of East Berlin to set up a jointly owned company that would eventually produce 900,000 high-technology digital telephone lines a year.

CHARLES H. MAYO 2D, the grandson of a founder of the Mayo Clinic, has been fined $4,000 by the Minnesota Board of Medical Examiners for failing to diagnose illnesses or injuries in four patients.

Burned Boy Undergoes Four Hours of Surgery
LEAD: David Aupont, the 12-year-old Brooklyn boy who was critically burned in an attack on Wednesday, underwent four hours of surgery yesterday, as doctors removed damaged skin from his arms and replaced it with healthy skin from his legs.


The Founder of Grove Press Tries to Buy Publisher Back
LEAD: Barney Rosset, who founded Grove Press in 1951 but was ousted after it was sold five years ago, is attempting to buy back the house with the help of four independent publishers.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about modified atmosphere packaging misstated a sales figure.
Sales of TomAHtoes increased to 650,000 cases in 1989 from 20,000 cases in 1983, when they were introduced by Natural Pak.


Jets Add a Receiver
LEAD: In yet another signing linked to their new coaching staff, the Jets yesterday signed Carl Parker, a free-agent wide receiver who played the last two seasons with Cincinnati, where the Jets' new head coach, Bruce Coslet, was the Bengals' offensive coordinator.

Frederick Evoy Kneip, Executive, 75
LEAD: Frederick Evoy Kneip, a retired executive in the paper products industry, died of cancer on Tuesday at the Lakeland (Fla.) Regional Medical Center.
He was 75 years old and lived in Lakeland.


Red Ransom Sidelined
LEAD: The list of leading Kentucky Derby prospects continued to shrink today when Red Ransom was found to have suffered a torn tendon sheath that will probably force him to miss the Triple Crown races.


Peter-Adolf Thiessen, Atomic Scientist, 90
LEAD: Peter-Adolf Thiessen, the East German scientist who was taken from the ruins of Nazi Germany to play a major role in developing the Soviet atom bomb, has died at the age of 90, the official A.D.N. press agency said today.
The agency said he died on Monday.

Elmer T. Klassen, Who Oversaw Postal Reorganization, Dies at 81
LEAD: Elmer T. Klassen, a former United States Postmaster General who rose from messenger to president of the American Can Corporation, died of congestive heart failure on Tuesday at a nursing home in Palm Harbor, Fla.
He was 81 years old and lived in Palm Harbor.

Baseball;   Strawberry Not Charged
LEAD: The Los Angeles City Attorney notified Darryl Strawberry today that no charges would be brought in connection with the family fight between the Mets' outfielder and his wife on Jan. 26.
But Strawberry will be required to continue his treatment for alcohol abuse and to write reports on his progress every other week for the next three months.

Pistons Cash In on Nets' Turnovers
LEAD: There was only one thing in tonight's game as spectacular as the way New Jersey manhandled Detroit for most of three quarters: the way the Nets fell apart in the last 13 minutes and lost to the Pistons, 99-95.


Hospitals Awaken to Staff AIDS Risk
LEAD: Almost a decade after the AIDS epidemic began to sweep the nation, hospitals are only slowly beginning to take steps to protect their own health care workers or to care for them if they are infected in the line of duty.


State Trooper Killed in Undercover Drug Operation is Buried in Upstate New York


Deal in Armory Seizure
LEAD: A sheriff who seized a National Guard armory here to house some prisoners when he ran out of space at his century-old jail last month has agreed to move to the state's suggested compromise site, a vacant armory in nearby Holyoke.
But the agreement, worked out between the state and Sheriff Michael Ashe of Hampden County, is opposed by Mayor Martin Dunn of Holyoke, who says his city will fight it in court.

Ron Wolin, 55, Dies; Sued Port Authority Over Ban on Leaflets
LEAD: Ron Wolin, an antiwar advocate who brought a class-action lawsuit in the 1960's that allowed the distribution of political and religious leaflets in bus terminals and other transportation centers and that led to the right to solicit contributions in such centers, died on Sunday at Cabrini Hospital.


Civilian Rate As Main Gauge
LEAD: The Labor Department statistics published today by The New York Times show the civilian unemployment rate as the primary gauge of the nation's labor market rather than the overall rate, whose base includes domestically stationed military personnel.

Thruway to Update Most Restaurants
LEAD: The New York State Thruway Authority has decided to replace nearly all its 27 restaurants on the superhighway between New York City and Buffalo.


Gathers's Family Plans To Sue, Attorney Says
LEAD: An attorney for the family of Hank Gathers said today that medical records showed that a reduction in Gathers's heart medicine had been requested by someone in the athletic department at Loyola Marymount University.

LEAD: John Ben Shepperd, a former Texas Attorney General who was active in state politics for decades, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Gladewater.
He was 74 years old and also had a home in Odessa, Tex.

Unemployment Remains Steady at 5.3%
LEAD: The economy generated many more jobs in February than analysts had expected, but the growth was not sufficient to affect the civilian unemployment rate.
It stood at 5.3 percent for the ninth straight month, the Labor Department reported today.


General Signal To Sell 3 Units
LEAD: The General Signal Corporation said it intends to divest itself of three units that supply telecommunications test equipment, transmission and network products, and data network diagnostic and control equipment.
The proceeds will be used to repay debt.


Give Coach V A Raise!
LEAD: Coach V is being bashed from pillar to post.
It's hard to pick up a newspaper these days without finding someone calling for everything from his resignation to his head.
What's the world coming to?


Capriati, Brisk and Brash, Stuns Sukova
LEAD: On one side of the net, the 13-year-old hugged the baseline and appeared unconcerned at finding herself under the spotlights in the quarterfinals of her first professional tournament.
On the other side, the player tacitly assigned a villain's role, Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia, all 6 feet 2 unsmiling inches of her, loomed like the giant from a fairy tale.


Pathe MGM/UA Payment
LEAD: The MGM/UA Communications Corporation said today that it had received $50 million from the Pathe Communications Corporation, the first installment in a $200 million down payment that Pathe must provide as part of its deal to acquire MGM/UA for $1.2 billion.

Upheaval in the East;   Fear of Bonn Invigorates East German Communists
LEAD: All but written off a few weeks ago, the humbled and shrunken Communist Party, restyled the Party of Democratic Socialism, has found a new voice as the champion of East Germans increasingly fearful of West Germany's overbearing political and economic embrace.


Jay Feigus Dies at 97; Played Contract Bridge
LEAD: Jay Feigus, a leading contract bridge player, died of heart failure on Thursday at his home in Middletown N.J.
He was 97 years old.


U.S. IS STEPPING UP EFFORTS TO SEIZE CARGOES OF DRUGS
LEAD: The Pentagon said today that it was beefing up efforts to intercept drug shipments by operating Awacs reconnaissance aircraft over the Caribbean and deploying a network of radar-carrying balloons across the southern United States.


No Met Opera Today, But Lots of Singing
LEAD: The Metropolitan Opera's matinee performance and radio broadcast today will be a concert instead of an opera, to continue the 50th-anniversary celebrations of Texaco's sponsorship of Saturday-afternoon live broadcasts from the house.
The program will be arias, duets and ensembles by artists including Francisco Araiza, Mariella Devia, Jerry Hadley, Thomas Hampson, Kurt Moll, James Morris, Paul Plishka, Ashley Putnam, Gino Quilico, Neil Shicoff, Dawn Upshaw and Carol


Using Microbes to Get More Oil From a Well
LEAD: Rebecca S. Bryant, a microbiologist in Bartlesville, Okla., obtained a patent this week for a method of using microbial organisms to get more oil out of a well.

Senate Unanimously Backs Dunne for Civil Rights Post
LEAD: The Senate today unanimously confirmed John R. Dunne as Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights, filling a 15-month-old vacancy at the Justice Department.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
N.B.A.
Drexler Lifts Portland
Clyde Drexler scored 12 of his 25 points in the fourth quarter and Jerome Kersey hit a key jump shot with 27 seconds left as the Portland Trail Blazers beat the 76ers, 104-100, last night in Philadelphia.
The Trail Blazers improved their road record to 16-14.


Offer Refunds, Condo Builder On L.I. Is Told
LEAD: The New York Attorney General's office has told a condominium developer to offer millions of dollars in refunds to people who made deposits because the developer concealed financial difficulties with the project.


Upheaval in the East;   MITTERRAND BACKS POLAND ON BORDER
LEAD: President Francois Mitterrand today endorsed Poland's demand that West Germany sign a treaty recognizing East Germany's postwar borders with Poland before the two Germanys are united.


Iranian Leader Mocks Bush Over Hoax
LEAD: President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran today described the United States as ''the biggest bully on earth,'' and he mocked President Bush for taking a telephone call from someone posing as Mr.
Rafsanjani.


Ban on Smoking in Airliners Doesn't Apply to the Cockpit
LEAD: Smoke-free air in the cabin of an airliner may be better for the health of passengers, but Federal officials have determined that it is safer to let the pilots keep smoking.


Stephen F. Austin Signs Ex-Tulane Coach
LEAD: Ned Fowler, who resigned as head coach at Tulane University in 1985 after the Green Wave was involved in a point-shaving scandal that led to the cancellation of varsity basketball for four years, has been hired to rebuild the program at Stephen F. Austin State, in Nacogdoches, Tex.
Stephen F. Austin won only 2 of 27 games this season.


Religion Notes
LEAD: Giving Gospels Away Just weeks after the Supreme Court ruled that materials distributed by religious organizations could be taxed, the Jehovah's Witnesses have stopped asking for contributions in exchange for their magazines, Bibles and other literature.


Your Money;   Knowing Rules On Charity Gifts
LEAD: Charitable donations provide one of the few tax deductions left largely intact in the huge overhaul of the nation's tax laws in recent years, an important consideration for the 85 percent of people who say they give.

Review/Music;   Del Tredici, in a New Work, Is Again Bucking the Trend
LEAD: David Del Tredici is a composer who likes to anticipate changes in musical fashion.
In the late 1960's, when Serialism and other forms of atonality were the accepted modes in the academic world, he began a series of works based on ''Alice in Wonderland'' in which comparatively simple tonal formulas, lush orchestrations and accessibility developed into a recognizable personal style.

Bonwit Stores To Be Sold
LEAD: The L. J. Hooker Corporation announced yesterday that it would sell 5 of the 16 Bonwit Teller stores, including the flagship store in Trump Tower in Manhattan, to the Pyramid Companies, a real estate development and investment company based in Syracuse, for an undisclosed amount of cash.

LEAD: Just off the Pan-American Highway, a desert lot here serves as a drive-in showroom for Peru's latest fashion in power pylons - pillboxes, electric fences and ''concrete pants.''

Seymour B. Wyler, 79, Antiques Store Owner
LEAD: Seymour B. Wyler, owner of S. Wyler Inc., an East Side antiques store specializing in English silver and porcelain, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness.
He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan and Palm Beach, Fla.

- Arnold Hiatt, chairman of Stride Rite, on workplace day care for children and the elderly. [8:4.]

Bridge
LEAD: There are few absolutes in bridge, and probably none at all in the area of opening leads.
Against a no-trump contract the textbooks advise leading the jack from jack-ten-nine and two small cards, although that is often wrong: It will block the suit when the partner has a doubleton honor.

Rizzoli Corporation New York and ALEXIS GREGORY, the owner of Vendome

G.M. Rejects District's Plea for $2 Million
LEAD: General Motors said today that it would not advance the Tarrytown School District $2 million, but that it wanted to help the district in any other way.


Bruce B. Benson, 68, A Professor of Physics
LEAD: Bruce B. Benson, professor of physics at Amherst College, died of respiratory failure on Wednesday at Cooley Dickenson Hospital in Northampton, Mass.
He was 68 years old and lived in Amherst, Mass.


CHRONICLE
LEAD: Asserting that he had been cheated of $8.5 million, BILL COSBY has charged MARY WALLER, his former business manager, with fraud and embezzlement.
Yesterday, Mr.
Cosby's lawyers requested an early start for Ms.
Waller's bankruptcy trial, saying they wanted to prevent her from depleting assets estimated at $10 million.


Europe Joblessness Dips
LEAD: The average unemployment rate in the 12 European Community nations dipped to 8.6 percent in January from 8.7 percent in December, the European Community statistics agency said today.
Unemployment was highest in Ireland, where 16.7 percent of the potential work force was out of work in January.


Judge Upholds AIDS Testing of Colorado Prisoners
LEAD: A Federal district judge has upheld a requirement that all Colorado prison inmates be tested for AIDS and that those testing positive be segregated from the rest of the prison population.

O'Connor Is Moving To Clear Up 'Mess' At Covenant House
LEAD: John Cardinal O'Connor called the tangled affairs of Covenant House a ''mess'' yesterday and said the Archdiocese of New York was acting to rescue the organization by helping it find a new interim president.


A Rauschenberg Exhibition Heralds Arts Union in Berlin
LEAD: Robert Rauschenberg, the American artist, advanced East and West German cultural unification by a giant step today through an exhibition in the historic Alte Museum.
For the first time, a major exhibition spanned the division of the city.


New Drumstick Said To Be Easier to Control
LEAD: David Hughlett, a professional drummer in Dallas, patented a drumstick this week that he said was faster, more powerful and easier to control than conventional sticks.


Germans Are Starting to Take Unity Into Their Own Hands
LEAD: The border of 1945 in this region is melting even before reunification.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the New Jersey Senate's approval of Gov.
Jim Florio's automobile-insurance plan misstated the vote.
It was 29 to 8.

Retirement Is Reported Near For North Korea's President
LEAD: Kim Il Sung, North Korea's ''Great Leader'' since 1948, will step down after his 78th birthday next month and hand day-to-day power to his son, a Japanese news agency reported today.


Woman in the News;   Head Nurse For Welfare
LEAD: Shortly after Barbara J. Sabol took a job as the top lieutenant to New York's Commissioner of Social Services in 1987, she put on blue jeans and a sweatshirt and paid an unannounced visit to a welfare office in midtown Manhattan.
She filled out an application and, like most others in the office, settled in for a long wait.


Artists, Accepting Federal Grants, Worry About Strings
LEAD: Grants are godsends for writers like Martha Collins, but she still had to think long and hard before accepting a $20,000 fellowship this year from the National Endowment for the Arts.


Review/Film;   Loot That Catches the Conscience of a Cop
LEAD: Frank Daly (Brian Dennehy), in ''The Last of the Finest,'' is a Los Angeles cop who could never be accused of being less than zealous about his job.
In fact, he's so dedicated that he keeps on working even after the job has been taken away.
Daly and three young proteges are suspended from their duties after a drug investigation turns murderous, but they stay with the case because they know they're on to something big.

Digital Offer Of Severance
LEAD: The Digital Equipment Corporation, trying to cope with a slumping computer industry and a weak New England economy, said today that it would soon offer a voluntary severance package to as many as 8,000 employees.


Chile's Civilian President-to-Be Acts to Calm Pinochet on Reprisals
LEAD: As he prepares to become Chile's first elected President since 1973, Patricio Aylwin has sought to calm Gen.
Augusto Pinochet's fears of prosecution for the political killings, disappearances and torture that took place under his rule.


Mordecai Gorelic, Theatrical Designer and Playwright, 90
LEAD: Mordecai (Max) Gorelik, a theatrical designer who also wrote, produced and directed plays, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Sarasota, Fla.
He was 90 years old.


3 Die in Collision of 2 Planes
LEAD: Two small planes collided and crashed into a residential neighborhood during rush hour today.
All three people in the two planes were killed, the authorities said.
The planes crashed into homes in this suburb of Fort Lauderdale suburb, but there were no reports of injuries to anyone on the ground.


East Germany's Military Chief Acknowledges 'Signs of Dissolution'
LEAD: The Defense Minister, Adm.
Theodor Hoffmann, conceded on Friday that ''signs of dissolution'' existed in the military, but said an overwhelming majority of his forces were carrying out their duties responsibly, particularly those linked to East Germany's obligations under the Warsaw Pact.


OLDER CHILDREN AND DIVORCE
LEAD: It seems to me that Barbara S. Cain's article ''Older Children and Divorce'' (Feb. 18) does not add anything new to that tired subject.
We all know that everyone suffers in a divorce.
However, everyone suffers growing up.
The young people mentioned in your article might have had different problems in nondivorcing families, but problems they would have had.


Hope G. Schefler and Glenn P. Taitz Are Married
LEAD: Hope Gabrielle Schefler and Glenn Preston Taitz were married last evening at the Pierre in New York by Rabbi Baruch Silverstein.

Magical Evening Ends a Little Dimly
LEAD: TThe omens seemed right tonight for the Islanders to end their dual streaks of 5 consecutive defeats and 11 games without a victory.


Leslie Mills Wed To Peter Santos
LEAD: Leslie Ann Mills and Peter Clark Santos were married yesterday at the Presbyterian Church in Mount Kisco, N.Y., by the Rev.
Douglas S. Phillips.
Mrs.
Santos is the daughter of R. Jeffries Mills Jr. of Chappaqua, N.Y., and the late Jo Ann Yow Mills.
Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs.
Peter Santos of Long Meadow, Mass.


Saving the Most On Europe Fares
LEAD: PAN AMERICAN'S Eurosaver fare from New York to London for travelers leaving May 31 is $535 round trip.
For those leaving the next day, it is $704.
Much of the difference is in the season: May 31 falls within shoulder season, and June 1 begins the high season (and is a weekend departure).


Finding Out If It Will Play In Peoria
LEAD: So how did they play in Enfield, Conn.?
To test a long-held belief in the video industry that outside of New York and Los Angeles the country doesn't want to watch foreign films, Orion Home Video deployed 24 of its best foreign titles (such as ''Babette's Feast'' and ''Manon of the Spring'') in 500 exurban stores, all of them in prosperous towns and many of them near universities.


Corrections
LEAD: A chart last Sunday under the headline ''National Output'' gave an incorrect value for the gross national products of several countries.
The numbers represented trillions of dollars, not billions.

REFORM MOVEMENT GROWS IN MONGOLIA
LEAD: The revolutionary changes in Eastern Europe appear to have swept eastward into Asia, with the Communist leadership in the remote nation of Mongolia preparing for a meeting on Monday that may lead to the ouster of its Politburo.


Review/Music;   Pianist Plays Rarity By Debussy
LEAD: James Barbagallo's thoughtful and elegant choice of music for his Alice Tully Hall piano recital on Thursday night pretty much reflected the thoughtfulness and elegance with which it was addressed.
Mr.
Barbagallo played four Debussy pieces -including one of the neglected masterpieces of the keyboard literature, ''Hommage a Rameau'' - Schumann's Second Sonata, ''Masks'' by Robert Muczynsky and three pieces by Chopin.


Co-op Crash: Just Fine With Me
LEAD: In the 80's, we were asked to feel sorry for the homeless.
In the 90's, we are asked to feel sorry for the people who share much of the blame for putting the homeless on the street.
I have in mind those who, through frenzied real-estate speculation, have sent the value of New York City apartments soaring and who are only now beginning to pay fair property taxes based on those outrageous levels.


Kimberli R. Cohn Plans May Bridal
LEAD: The engagement of Kimberli Rose Cohn to Dr.
Scott Higgins Bailey, a son of Dr. and Mrs.
Higgins D. Bailey of Bethesda, Md., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs.
Norman U. Cohn of Radnor, Pa.
A May wedding is planned.


Heart Transplant, Despite Fog
LEAD: A relay of troopers from two states rushed a heart to a 13-year-old transplant patient Friday after fog forced doctors to land at an airport 50 miles away.
Three doctors flying the heart from Tulsa, Okla., to Detroit had to land in Toledo, Ohio.


Notes From the Revolution
LEAD: The final days of 1989 brought with them the end of the Communist era.
The system that had proclaimed itself the future of the world was buried in the ashes of burning Romanian towns.
No doubt there will still be police and military relapses, no doubt various epigones of Communism will still tantalize with their baubles and sow dissension with their calumnies.


Cocaine Use Is Found By Motorman in Crash
LEAD: A motorman on the Philadelphia subway train that crashed Wednesday, killing 3 people and injuring 94, has been suspended because he had used cocaine the day of the accident, a transit agency spokesman said today.


Community Colleges Fear State Cuts
LEAD: ENROLLMENT for the current semester at Norwalk Community is 10 percent higher than last spring, one of the most dramatic increases in the school's history.
And with a planned move to new quarters on Richards Avenue that would more than double its space to 122,000 square feet, the college was looking forward to even more growth.


Comparing Prices at Duty-Free Shops
LEAD: WANDERING through duty-free shops to try on sleek Ebel watches, inhale seductive fragrances or admire the frosted curves of Lalique crystal has become as much a part of the itinerary for many travelers as lolling on pristine beaches or visiting landmark museums and temples.


Soviets and Hungary Agree on Troop Pullout
LEAD: The Soviet Union and Hungary signed an agreement today calling for all Soviet troops to be withdrawn from Hungarian territory by the middle of next year, Hungarian radio reported.


Clearing Adam Smith's Name
LEAD: To the Editor:


All About/Accountants;   Rivalries, Responsibilities and Some New Risks
LEAD: Forget about accountants being a mild-mannered bunch of milquetoasts.
When it comes to competing for clients, they are actually some of the most ruthless predators known to humankind.
As Barry R. Wallach, a tax expert with Arthur Andersen &amp; Company, boasted, ''I kind of view nonclients as clients being held in trust for us by the competition until we get there.


Explaining the 'No' In a 15-to-1 Vote
LEAD: At a special meeting of the County Board of Legislators on Feb. 13 the Board voted 15 to 1 for a budget amendment that restored over $14 million in spending [''Budget Impasse Comes to an End,'' Feb. 18] .
By doing so, the Board voted to reinstate more than 450 jobs that County Executive O'Rourke had threatened to terminate.

Death Penalty Ordered for Convicted Killer
LEAD: A man convicted in a murder that was cited by the group claiming responsibility for two deadly mail bombs was sentenced Friday to die in the electric chair.


Academic Repeaters
LEAD: Among the GTE Academic all-America men's basketball players named Friday were Alex Kessler of the University of Georgia and Philip Hutcheson of David Lipscomb College, both repeat first-team selections in the university and college divisions.


Fashion: On the Street;   When It's All Right To Be Two-Faced
LEAD: Take a jacket made of fake lamb's fur, line it with polka-dot dress silk, and what have you got?
An imaginative and versatile piece of clothing that has suddenly captured imaginations on both sides of the Atlantic.
The jacket, designed by Dolce &amp; Gabbana in Milan, Italy, is reversible, so it can look like a fur (actually a pile fabric that resembles caracul) with polka-dot cuffs, or a polka-dot jacket with fur cuffs and collar.


Style Makers;   Ozey Thorpe Clothing Designer
LEAD: As a teen-ager growing up in Washington, Ozey Thorpe remembers that it was not always easy finding men's clothing that complemented his 6-foot-6-inch frame. ''I used to tinker a lot with sewing machines as a kid,'' Mr.
Thorpe said. ''That way, I was able to do my own alterations.''


Seaford Is Divided On Library
LEAD: A PROPOSAL to build a new public library in Seaford has divided this South Shore community, but the issue may be resolved Wednesday, when Seaford residents will vote on a $4 million bond issue to finance construction of the building.


Course Record Broken By Youmadeyourpoint
LEAD: Youmadeyourpoint, perhaps the most improved horse in Florida this winter, outran a strong field and broke a course record while winning the $157,600 Gulfstream Breeders' Cup Handicap on the grass today at Gulfstream Park.


Cable TV Pact
LEAD: The National Football League completed its television package for its international venture yesterday, agreeing to a four-year contract with the USA cable network, which guarantees that all World League of American Football games involving United States teams will be shown in the United States.


Baseball Impasse: Locking Out for No. 1
LEAD: Why is baseball so consistently unable to reach collective bargaining agreements without a work stoppage?
Since 1972, a strike or a lockout has occurred each time the old contract expired.
The record of conflict stems partly from the need for the union to break down the system of paternalism and impediments to freedom in the players' labor market.


Managing;   Getting Women Down to the Site
LEAD: Robert E. Coker, the project superintendent at the paper plant expansion in this tiny town just outside Savannah, thinks Sheryl T. Hamlett is a terrific carpenter's helper.
She works hard, takes classes on her own time and never balks at working late or weekends.
She is, he said, ''one of the best workers we've got.


Large Steaks and the He-Man Look
LEAD: CAN an old-fashioned, throwback American steakhouse succeed at a time when cholesterol-conscious diners are discussing their HDL-LDL ratios more than their children's S.A.T. scores?


THE MUSICAL MYSTERY OF ST. JOAN
LEAD: What is it about Joan of Arc that frustrates the efforts of opera composers to bring her to life?
At least two dozen musical versions of this promising subject exist, but none has established itself in the repertory.
There is no Joan to compare even remotely with adored heroines like Mimi, Violetta, Tatiana or the many other mistreated women who lead vivid stage existences.

Donald Schapiro of New York.

STEAL THIS REVIEW
LEAD:
THE BEST OF ABBIE HOFFMAN.
Edited by Daniel Simon with Abbie Hoffman. (Four Walls Eight Windows, $21.95.) At the Chicago conspiracy trial 20 years ago, the judge gently scolded Tom Hayden: ''Fellows as smart as you could do awfully well under [the American]  system.'' Those words would have been lost on Abbie Hoffman, who remained, in his actions and, as this book shows, in his writings, incorrigibly and imaginatively subversive to the end.

LEAD: TO Louise Caputo, when the wind is just right, blowing in from the north, the noises fly through the sky like an airborne invasion.

Reap What You Sew
LEAD: I have taken over a basement room in which someone who lived here before had left a Ping-Pong table.
It is now my sewing room.
The table is just the right height for me, and I can spread out the fabric on its expanse of dark green when I cut out things.
It's quiet there.
I listen to the radio and work away, and a flat piece of cloth takes on shape as I work, grows breast-shaped curves and hips, gathers itself into a waistband, to which I have added an inch because I am fatter than I wish

'Holding the Line'
LEAD: To the Editor:


For Students, a Preview of What the Real World Holds
LEAD: LIFE was tough last week in Michael Rossi's sociology class at Hastings-on-Hudson High School.
Kevin Gannon and Ruchi Khurana discovered their son, Peter, had a hole in his heart and would need major surgery.
Bronwyn Fisher and Matt Bucko found their infant daughter, Jessica, dead of ''SIDS.''


A Brooklyn Man Is Charged With the Theft of 15 Torahs
LEAD: A Brooklyn man was charged with stealing 15 sacred Jewish scrolls from synagogues in New Jersey and Pennsylvania last month, the United States Attorney for New Jersey has announced.


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. The ceiling of our unheated basement is insulated with fiberglass that has an R-13 rating.
These fiberglass batts have a vapor barrier that faces the heated first floor above the basement.
The fiberglass now fills most of the space between the joists, but we want to add more insulation to this ceiling.


Pastimes;   Around the Garden
LEAD: For This Week: It is early to plant if the soil is too heavy to dig and rake.
Keep off the lawn if it is wet and soggy; allow the soil to dry thoroughly before using spreaders.
Turn seedlings growing indoors near window sills so they do not bend toward the light.
If seedlings are growing under lights do not forget to use half-rate, water-soluble fertilizer weekly.

Bakker's Former House Burns
LEAD: A fire Friday morning destroyed the sprawling lakeside house where Jim Bakker, the former television evangelist, once lived.
Officials searched the ruins, but no one was found, and the police said neighbors had told them no one had been there recently.


A May Wedding For Amy Conklin
LEAD: Lois Touhey of Albany has announced the engagement of her daughter Amy Conklin to James Rose, a son of Mr. and Mrs.
George Rose of Locust Valley, L.I.
A May wedding is planned.


Enter a New 'Phantom,' With Freudian Surprises
LEAD: Once again, The Phantom of the Opera has been sighted, according to reports from the capital.
Last fall, the masked figure in full evening regalia made a sudden appearance on the roof of the Paris Opera House.
Fortunately, he was cornered by the police and unmasked.


POSTINGS: 72 Units in 15 Buildings;   Hard by a 9-Hole Golf Course
LEAD: What will be one of the few housing developments in Westchester County adjacent to a nine-hole golf course is being built in the Village of Pleasantville.
Named the Country Club at Pleasantville, the project will contain 72 two-story town house units in a cluster of 15 buildings.
The units, the first of which is due to be finished late this summer, will have either two or three bedrooms and range from 2,400 to 3,400 square feet.


Votes in Congress
LEAD: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York
Senate
1.
Clean Air Act: Vote to amend the Clean Air Act to strike a provision that removes the existing authority of the Environmental Protection Agency and the states from regulating radioactive emissions at Nuclear Regulatory Commission centers, by making the commission the sole regulator.


Taking the Heat at American Express
LEAD: Once again, the heat is on the American Express Company and its chairman, James D. Robinson 3d.
Having been forced to rescue its brokerage subsidiary with a massive capital infusion, American Express is facing criticism for a series of missteps over the past decade.


Gene Therapy Moves A Step Closer to Reality
LEAD: WITH an anatomy consisting of no more than a glob of genetic material wrapped in a protective coat of protein, viruses exist on the boundary between the living and the dead.
Under a plan announced last week, these borderline creatures would be used as messengers to smuggle missing genes into the cells of children otherwise doomed by a devastating congenital disorder.

LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers.
Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.
Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036.
We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.


Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;   Spring Training for Beach Lovers at Coney Island
LEAD: The Coney Island of dreams and memories - the magical seaside Brooklyn playground of wondrous amusements and rides - is still a part of New York.


Spying For Hanoi
LEAD: It is early morning, Jan. 25, 1989, and the caravan - my ''60 Minutes'' camera crew and assorted hangers-on - is waiting at the Majestic Hotel in Ho Chi Minh City.
Huang Mai Huong, my guide-interpreter, is looking very smug. ''Miss Mai,'' as I call her, has been wedding shopping in Ho Chi Minh City, which to someone from Hanoi is the equivalent of Hong Kong or Bangkok.


Red Sox Sign Burks
LEAD: The Boston Red Sox yesterday completed their 40-player roster when Ellis Burks, the center fielder, accepted a hefty pay raise and Jody Reed, the shortstop, received a healthy salary increase with the renewal of his contract.
The Red Sox did not disclose financial terms, but Burks reportedly signed a one-year contract for $475,000 guaranteed, plus incentives based on games and plate appearances worth an additional $75,000.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs.
Ralph A. Sternick of Cranford, N.J., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter, Jane K. Sternick, and Patrick J. Hitchcock, a son of Mr. and Mrs.

Reviews/Music;   Tenor From South Africa Makes Met Opera Debut
LEAD: Deon van der Walt, a South African tenor, made an auspicious Metropolitan Opera debut Thursday night as Belmonte in Mozart's ''Entfuhrung aus dem Serail.'' Mr. van der Walt has sung the same role at the Salzburg Festival (a widely circulated televised production), the Royal Opera in London, the Bavarian State Opera in Munich and other prestigious theaters, and on Thursday one could hear and see why.

INTERNATIONAL ISSUE: The Taste of Three Cities;   London Gets Into the Act For After-Theater Dining
LEAD: LONDON, for all its reputation as a world capital, used to be an early closing town.
Few restaurants took orders after 9 o'clock and, as for late-night bars and cafes, you could pretty much forget anything public - or legal.
For theatergoers the alternatives were eat early or not at all.
All that has changed in the last few years.

CORRECTION
LEAD: The ''All About'' column on Feb. 25, discussing modems, misidentified a company listed among those dominant in that market.
It is Multi-Tech Systems Inc. of Mounds View, Minn., not the Acer America Corporation.

It was one of the first makers of cellular telephone modems, not the first.

LEAD: ''What did he know, and when did he know it?'' This now-famous question should be asked of Jim Valvano.
A major college basketball coach sets the tone for his players on the court with the tactics he teaches them.
He sets the tone for them off the court by his own behavior.
If Jim Valvano was not aware of his players' unlawful activities, he is guilty of incompetence.

Kirk Varnedoe Is In The Hot Seat As Moma's Boy
LEAD: One of the more curious objects at the Museum of Modern Art in New York sits on a long table in the fifth-floor office of Kirk Varnedoe.
It's a square white mat populated by what seem to be high-tech chessmen, or futuristic warriors in a space-age board game.
They are, actually, foam-core replicas of the museum's Brancusi sculptures, and they are giving Varnedoe, the museum's new director of painting and sculpture, a tough fight.

For Rudolf Bing at 88, Operatic Drama Lingers
LEAD: ''La Commedia e Finita - The comedy is over'': The final words of Leoncavallo's tragic opera ''I Pagliacci'' were the ones Sir Rudolf Bing chose on April 22, 1972, to ring down the curtain on his lordly and controversial 22-year tenure as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera.
A drama was indeed ending, but it was hardly the last that awaited Sir Rudolf, who could not have anticipated the quintessentially operatic tangle of tragedy and farce that lay ahead.

Look Who's Hooked on Drug Dollars
LEAD: Federal law now allows the Government to seize drug barons' wealth - mansions, yachts, sports cars - and give a share to local cops who may have helped with the prosecution.

LEAD: Every set of Olympic Games has its dominant figure.
In Rome in 1960 it was a boxer named Cassius Clay.

In Seoul in 1988 it was a runner named Ben Johnson skulking out of town.

LEAD: A state parks police officer in the Bronx was shot in the leg yesterday by a robbery suspect, the police said.

The police said three people had entered the police building in Roberto Clemente State Park at 1:30 P.M.

Men's Style;   Milan's Great Escape
LEAD: Standing shoulder to shoulder, their eyes shaded by Mountie hats, they looked like extras from a Nelson Eddy movie.
But these young men were models, costumed for winter by Valentino, one of Italy's reigning fashion designers.
And their cinematically scarlet jackets, lumberjack shirts and Hudson Bay blanket coats were not destined for the wilds but for some of the most exclusive men's shops in cities on several continents.


Unseating the Electrical Utilities' Monopoly
LEAD: Electric utilities have flourished in the United States during the last half-century by virtue of being monopolies.
But those monopolies are giving way to a new order as a growing number of small, independent power producers, and now joint ventures with the utilities themselves, enter the industry.

LEAD: Willy Brandt took the East Germany election campaign onto Polish soil today to assure Poland that most Germans do not question its right to live in areas that were German until 1945.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about states' revenue problems misstated New York's bond rating in some editions.
It is now ''very good.'' A chart with the article referred incorrectly to Vermont's budget and the estimated deficit.
Vermont is on a two-year budget cycle and is working to avoid a $90 million deficit for the fiscal years 1990 and 1991.

The Gossip Column
LEAD: The attitude about gossip these days reminds me of an attitude people had about sex 20 years ago.
It was called the sexual revolution, and it was as tiresome as can be.

SPIES &amp; THRILLERS
LEAD: The pompous new head of a British intelligence service sends a top deskman to make a tour of various installations and pep them up.
This is against all rules.
Top deskmen are not supposed to be in the field.
They know too much, and if they are captured and tortured, operatives may die and services may be compromised.

LEAD:
COMPANIES
The Great American Express Cut-Rate Buyback
Finally, the American Express Company has found a way to come out ahead at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption on Feb. 25 misidentified a building in East Berlin.
It was the Museum of German History, not the German State Opera House.
The caption also referred imprecisely to the tower in the background.
It is more commonly known as the Fernsehturm (television tower); the tower known as the Funkturm (radio tower) is in West Berlin.

LEAD: I've just finished reading the article about the outstanding James quilt collection [''County Couple's Quilts Chosen for Japan Tour,'' Feb. 18] .
As a quilt collector and enthusiast I was especially interested.
However, as a supremely satisfied client of Betsy Prokop, I can just imagine the frustration of potential quilt-owning clients, who will never be able to locate her through your article.

Idaho Says No
LEAD: In the indigo moment before the sun rises and the night is not yet gone, the vast lava plain that lies at the foot of the Lost River Range in eastern Idaho reveals itself - raw, empty, magnetic.
In July, the wind blows hot, and dust rakes the brush and fills the gullies.
In February, the sky turns deep blue, and blinding snow robes the western summits and chokes the craggy canyons.

LEAD: Many people think that laissez-faire capitalism will be a workable model for the redevelopment of the socialist economies of the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.
Western advisers have consistently pushed for the creation of markets, free pricing and currency systems and an economy built on private enterprises.

Safe Lifting Techniques
LEAD: EVEN an hour of home improvement activities involving lifting can cause a sore back or even an injury that lasts for days or longer.

Corrections
LEAD: A quotation in the front-page index last Sunday was misattributed.
It was the interviewer - not Yuri A. Prokofiev, the Moscow Communist Party chief - who noted that for Soviet politicians, ''to be a Communist is a minus, and to be a Communist Party functionary is a huge minus.''


Pastimes;   Chess
LEAD: In Boris Spassky's contract for the Linares International Tournament, which began Feb. 18 in Spain, one clause read that he must, ''not make any compromises before move 40.'' The tournament sponsor, Luis Rentero, did not want the former world champion to show up in body but not in spirit, aiming for quick draws, as he so often does.

Review/Music;   Violinist Gives Recital Using Instrument Made of Plastic
LEAD: In ''The Graduate,'' Dustin Hoffman's character, Ben, is given a single word of career advice by a friend of his parents: Plastics.
Presumably Ben ignored the suggestion, but by the time the film was made, in 1967, the Italian-born guitarist and instrument-maker Mario Maccaferri had proved the value of that advice, having made his fortune manufacturing plastic ukeleles, hangers, clothespins and tape cassettes.


Mixed Reviews
LEAD: Washington is not without literary tradition, of course, but when a member of Congress writes a book that somehow makes money, it is often suspected that something unseemly has transpired.
Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip, raised such suspicions about a book written by former House Speaker Jim Wright, who resigned last year after a House ethics panel found improprieties in connection with his book sales.

Back to Basics on Chicken
LEAD: THERE is a story, possibly apocryphal, of the novice cook who put a chicken in the oven to roast.
After about 20 minutes, a revolting stench began to fill the kitchen.
It turned out that this newcomer to the culinary arts did not know enough to remove the package of innards tucked inside the bird.

LEAD: A committee set up at Simon's Rock of Bard College has exonerated three professors accused by students of sexual harassment.

Screaming Won't Help
LEAD: ''I hear America singing,'' wrote Walt Whitman in the last century.
Today, he would have difficulty hearing himself think.
According to audiologists, 20 million Americans are exposed daily to persistent noise loud enough to cause hearing loss.
The racket also contributes to high blood pressure, peptic ulcers, aggression, poor reading, lack of consideration and, understandably, the urge to give up.

Others serve as purely neutral containers for it.

One space of the last type is surely the Great Hall at Cooper Union, where on Thursday night Patricia Cremins and Wyoming, her New York-based company, presented ''Landing With and Without the Map.

Correction
LEAD: An article in the Sports Section on Feb. 25 about the experiences of black players in the National Hockey League incorrectly described the professional level at which an incident involving Willie O'Ree, the first black player in the N.H.L., took place.
The incident, in which O'Ree said he became entangled with a group of fans who made racial remarks and grabbed at his jersey, occurred when O'Ree was playing for the Quebec Aces in the minor leagues, not in the N.H.L.

Quality Control for Health Care
LEAD: A painful back injury recently sent me to top medical specialists in Washington and New York.
One doctor rated the injury an 8 on a scale of 1 to 10 and recommended immediate surgery.
The other rated it a 2 and suggested plenty of rest and physical therapy.
I opted for the latter and am in fine physical shape today.


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. The ceiling of our unheated basement is insulated with fiberglass that has an R-13 rating.
These fiberglass batts have a vapor barrier that faces the heated first floor above the basement.
The fiberglass now fills most of the space between the joists, but we want to add more insulation to this ceiling.

LEAD: IN a crack-plagued Bronx neighborhood, public school students wear uniforms proudly.
At a Bedford-Stuyvesant high school ringed by poverty, students know to leave their gold jewelry and the removable gold jackets for their teeth at home.
And in a handful of New York City high schools, students routinely submit to metal-detector searches for weapons.

Music in Which Words Need Only Sound Poetic
LEAD: Empty-headed pop music usually comes in the form of sleek, high-tech disco or pounding, three-chord rock.
But the Church, an Australian quartet that has just released its seventh album, ''Gold Afternoon Fix'' (Arista AL-8579; all three formats) makes lightweight pop of a different sort.
Instead of disco's synthetic tracks and drum machines, or commercial rock's tired riffs and cliched baby-I-love-you lyrics, the Church combines 12-string guitar, bass and drums with dreamy images to make an elegant surface of sound.


INTERNATIONAL ISSUE: The Taste of Three Cities;   High Energy at Parisian Brasseries
LEAD: PARIS, we are endlessly assured, is no longer truly Paris but instead a city, like many others, in thrall to sheiks, Japanese conglomerates and fast-food operatives.
It is true that foreign investment has changed the character of certain of the city's arrondissements, and that the once classy Champs-Elysees now has a hectic, honky-tonk glow to it.

Barry in Baltimore.
LEAD: Irv Levinson and Vi Krichinsky grew up on Appleton Street in southwest Baltimore, where they met more than 50 years ago and, later, were married.
Today they're back for the first time in decades, along with Irv's younger brother Herb and a few cousins, and they can hardly believe what they see.
Lining Appleton are 1940's vintage Cadillacs, Buicks, Chevrolets and Hudsons.


Pay Cut Is Now a Seldom-Used Tool
LEAD: Rich Gedman, the Boston catcher who has forgotten how to hit, suffered the maximum 20 percent pay cut this year, his salary plummeting from $1.15 million to $920,000.
Life wasn't always so cruel to Gedman.
In 1988, he batted .231 and drove in 39 runs and got a raise, from $980,000 to $1.15 million.

Sandinistas Have Trouble Accepting the Fact of Defeat
LEAD: IN a single day of balloting last month, Nicaraguan voters tore the heart out of the Sandinista Government: its claim to represent the will of the Nicaraguan people.
The transformation was nothing Sandinista leaders had imagined last year when, to repair their international image, they accepted calls to hold free, closely supervised elections.

The Best Ways to Fight Drug and Alcohol Abuse
LEAD: The words are familiar: ''I didn't get up one morning and say, ''I think I'll become a drug addict,' the way someone decides to be a fireman or a doctor.
No one wants to become an addict.
But once I got sucked up into the drug habit, I didn't know how to stop.
I didn't know where to go for help.''

LEAD: It is down, down, down for the British pound, which has fallen more than nine cents, to $1.6160, in the last two weeks.

OLDER CHILDREN AND DIVORCE
LEAD: For years, my siblings and I struggled with our parents' marriage problems, trying to provide support and keep them together.
Finally, after seven years, they divorced and sold the family home.
Both remarried.
At my father's wedding, I gave a toast.
I said that his wedding day was the last day of a job for me - a job that I was happy to hand over to his new wife.

Safe Lifting Techniques
LEAD: EVEN an hour of home improvement activities involving lifting can cause a sore back or even an injury that lasts for days or longer.

LEAD: Classy Irene, unbeaten in five races, heads a field of nine 3-year-old fillies Sunday in the $50,000-added Magnolia Stakes at Oaklawn Park.


Wall Street;   End of the 'Event-Risk' Nightmare?
LEAD: Top-quality corporate bonds were among the first casualties of the takeover craze that defined the Drexel era on Wall Street.
With each new debt-laden deal, another set of corporate investors awoke to find that their bonds, blue-chip assets the night before, were suddenly on their way to the junk heap.

LEAD: If John Gotti is innocent, Jim Valvano is Mother Theresa.
NORMAN KLINE
Larchmont, N.Y.


After 9 Deaths, Ithaca Residents Wonder What Has Gone Wrong
LEAD: Tompkins County residents, who have long considered their area a pristine refuge from the world, are suddenly feeling that something has gone terribly wrong.


Laura Hill Is Married
LEAD: Laura S. Hill and Lyle G. Clark 3d, financial executives in New York, were married yesterday at the Marriott River Center in San Antonio by the Rev.
Nell Linebarger, a United Methodist minister and an aunt of the bride.
The bride, a daughter of Mrs.
Crawford Reeder and Edward Hill, both of San Antonio, will keep her name.


FICTION
LEAD:
IF I NEVER GET BACK.
By Darryl Brock. (Crown, $18.95.) Submitted for your approval: Sam Fowler, a frustrated crime-and-disaster reporter for The San Francisco Chronicle whose wife has left him for a television anchorman, boards a train in Cleveland after his father's funeral, collapses and wakes up in 1869, surrounded by the Cincinnati Red Stockings, just as they are about to begin their legendary 64-0 season.

A New London Theater Team Is Attracting Stars
LEAD: In the rapidly gentrifying area of north London known as Islington, age-old pubs with names like the Slug and Lettuce vie for patronage with newly glamorized restaurants.
Drunks inhabit the main thoroughfare, Upper Street, buttonholing for money the recently arrived yuppies, who are drawn to the area because of its proximity to London's financial center, the City.


Remedial School: Paying the Piper
LEAD: SUFFOLK Community College has a classroom shortage.
So much space is needed for remedial courses that the standard college departments are being squeezed into fewer rooms.


A New Concert Series Begins at Grace Church
LEAD: THE Grace Episcopal Church in White Plains is home to an endeavor known as Downtown Music at Grace. ''The charming Victorian architecture and fine acoustics of the church provide a warm, intimate setting for all types of music,'' said the group's music director, Timothy Lewis.


On Encouraging A Healthy Life Style
LEAD: In response to Robert Figlerski's essay, ''Encouraging a Healthy Life Style,'' R. S. McCord recommends ''eliminating the medical fringe.'' This response is simplistic and naive.
The health care system in this country is both complex and complicated.

Roger A. Johnson of Metuchen, N.J., was married yesterday to Eelco Dewitt Swaak, a son of Mr. and Mrs.
Reyer Swaak of Chatham, N.J.
The Rev.
Robin Capoor officiated at the Unitarian Fellowship in Morristown, N.J.


PACE CARS PULLED FROM NEW JERSEY
LEAD: The new Superintendent of the New Jersey State Police has abandoned the idea of using pace cars to try to slow down motorists.


U.S. Pressed to Pay for Boat People in Hong Kong
LEAD: Britain is pressing the Bush Administration to pay most of the cost of caring for the tens of thousands of Vietnamese boat people now being housed in its colony of Hong Kong, as well as for building a new refugee camp, possibly on Guam, diplomats and United Nations officials here say.


POSTINGS: A New Kind of Mortgage;   The Fannie Mae Two-Step
LEAD: One problem with long-term, fixed-rate mortgages is that most homeowners sell their houses long before their loans are repaid.
This, in turn, forces them to pay higher interest rates for the first years than with an adjustable-rate mortgage.
But if they have a short-term, adjustable-rate loan and decide not to move after all they usually must pay several thousand dollars in refinancing costs when obtaining a new mortgage, and sometimes face major increases in interest rates as well.

LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD:
THE SUN IN CAPRICORN.
By Paul Rosenblatt. (Watermark Press, 149 North Broadway, Wichita, Kan. 67202, $18.50.) Jonathan, a much beloved American who teaches literature and poetry in Rio de Janeiro, has been set up.
A guerrilla named Verlande has tricked him into a compromising situation and the innocent academic has become ''a temporary liability'' who must be sent stateside.

LEAD: ARGENTINA has become ridiculously cheap for travelers with dollars, and the elegant old mountain city of Cordoba is one of the greatest values.

Review/Dance;   Stressing the Athletic Side Of Choreographed Moves
LEAD: Elizabeth Streb is one of several choreographers who during the past two decades have based dances upon athletic or gymnastic movement.
Whereas some of them make gymnastics seem witty or fantastic, Ms.
Streb emphasizes effort for its own sake.
At their best, her works resemble vigorous games.
At their worst, they are displays of stress and strain.


Review/Concert;   Marimba Quartet and Calabash Women
LEAD: The Manhattan Marimba Quartet and Women of the Calabash opened a series called New Riffs at Town Hall on Tuesday night.
The idea of combining the two groups seemed odd.
The Marimba Quartet performs written works in the European classical tradition, dryly.
The Women of the Calabash celebrates the African diaspora with songs and percussion, sentimentally.


When Nature Became God, Art Changed
LEAD: In the heart of the sleepy village in ''The Starry Night'' is a Dutch church that van Gogh transposed to the south of France.
Its interior is black, its steeple as protective and forbidding as a lance.
Although the steeple is a lightning rod for the wave of light flowing across the pre-dawn sky, the church is untouched by the sea of energy and light bolting and spiraling through the cosmic night.


Campus Life: Irvine;   Six Are Arrested Protesting Policy On Gay Housing
LEAD: Six students were arrested last week at the University of California at Irvine in a demonstration protesting Chancellor Jack W. Peltason's refusal to permit gay and lesbian couples to live in family dormitories.
The demonstrators blocked an entrance to the administration building.


SATURDAY NIGHT
LEAD: You didn't mention the way in which many residents of New York City spend Saturday night.
For many of us, it is a time to stay away from the nightspots and the crowds that crowd in from suburbia.
It is a time to avoid the touring automobiles and roaming band of visitors.
During the week, the noise of the city has a certain rhythm, a sense of purpose that is somehow absent from the weekend ruckus.


Playing Hedda Gabler As an Untamed Beast
LEAD: GEORGE BERNARD SHAW described Hedda Gabler, the title character in Henrik Ibsen's play, as a woman with no ethical ideals, only romantic ones.
He said that she had imagination and an intense appetite for beauty, but no conscience, no convictions.


Boccherini Up Front
LEAD: In the 1950's heyday of the ''Baroque revival'' - how dim and distant that sounds, in this age of the early-music movement - the marketplace was flooded with integral ''i's'' and ''ini's.'' The long-playing record had just taken over the record business, and multidisk boxed sets proliferated of the complete concerti grossi of Vivaldi, Corelli, Albinoni, Galuppi, Torelli, Locatelli, Manfredini, Geminiani, Tartini and Boccherini.


Children Find a Human Head And Man Finds Legs Nearby
LEAD: Three children playing on a Bronx street yesterday made a grisly find: a round object wrapped in a cloth that turned out to be a human head, the police said.
The father of one of the children then found a plastic bag in a box nearby containing two legs.


Military's Power Over South Africa: The Lid Is Off
LEAD: SINCE F. W. de Klerk became President of South Africa six months ago, he has taken bold steps to turn away from the dead end of apartheid.
While he has been most visible in laying the groundwork for negotiations with the country's black majority, he has also been working in the mine field of white politics.


A Glimpse Behind The Bamboo Curtain
LEAD: AS the mists rise each morning, the calm and graceful Nam Khan River in northern Laos slowly takes shape, ornamented with saffron-robed Buddhist monks on the banks and naked children swimming in the middle, and destined a few hundred yards later to end its journey in the embrace of the larger, ever-churning Mekong River.


On Language;   Virile Women Target Tobacco Men
LEAD: My heart goes out to the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company.
Taken over in a leveraged buyout; junk bonds sinking; publicly blasted into dropping its plan to make a pitch to sell its products to blacks.
Nobody seems willing to walk a few steps, much less a mile, for a Camel.

Housing: 'The Writing Is on the Wall'
LEAD: After reading the two articles on housing in your Feb. 18 edition [''Housing Forum Presses Its Effort at Local Level'' and ''Union Housing Offer Attracts No Takers''] , I felt compelled to write in with my thoughts on that familiar Westchester oxymoron - ''affordable housing.''


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. The ceiling of our unheated basement is insulated with fiberglass that has an R-13 rating.
These fiberglass batts have a vapor barrier that faces the heated first floor above the basement.
The fiberglass now fills most of the space between the joists, but we want to add more insulation to this ceiling.


Pastimes;   Coins
LEAD: The value of paper money is just a chimera unless you can convince someone of its worth.
Today our conviction in the value of United States dollars is so high so that we accept them without a second thought although the bills are only redeemable in other bills or coins made of nearly worthless alloy.

Pan Am Shuttle to Offer Hourly Papers to Fliers
LEAD: All-news cable television and radio stations have obliged compulsive Americans to follow current events during midnight snacks, at the dinner table and even, for owners of waterproof radios, in the shower.
Now even the afternoon flight home from an out-of-town meeting, a quiet respite in the sky from the tumult of information below, may have its own hourly newspaper.

Panama's New Leader Fasts To Dramatize Need for Aid
LEAD: Nearly three months after American forces invaded Panama, the Panamanian economy is in ruins and $1 billion in emergency aid remains stalled in the United States Congress.
At the Metropolitan Cathedral here, President Guillermo Endara has devised an unusual but apt way to dramatize the plight of a country starved for money: he has gone on an indefinite hunger strike.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   WPP Profit Up 89.4%
LEAD: WPP Group P.L.C., the world's largest marketing communications conglomerate, said its 1989 profit after taxes rose 89.4 percent, to $66.1 million, or $1.19 a share, from $34.9 million, or 89 cents a share, in 1988.
Revenues increased 83.7 percent, to $1.64 billion, from $892.8 million in 1988.
The company said its improved performance was helped by the acquisition of the Ogilvy Group, whose operating margin increased, and to a continued rise in the operating margins of J.


On Economic Front, Changes Continue
LEAD: G.M.
Deal With East Germany.
The largest American auto maker tentatively agreed to a joint venture with the larger of East Germany's two car makers.
General Motors could invest as much as $600 million in the venture, which would make components and assemble cars at a factory near the West German border.


A Freer, but Shrinking, Market
LEAD: In Eastern Europe, Hungary is leading the way in shifting trade away from the Soviet Union and toward the West.
The abrupt about-face has jolted many Hungarian companies that grew fat and happy relying on the huge Soviet market.

LEAD: The Sultan of Brunei has denied that he played a role in the $1 billion takeover of House of Fraser P.L.C., the owner of the Harrods department stores, by the Fayed brothers in 1985.

Results Plus
LEAD:
Golf
Huston's First Victory: Mark Calcavecchia's late bid failed, and John Huston went on to win the Honda Classic yesterday in Coral Springs, Fla.
Huston, 28 years old, led throughout the final 18 holes and earned the first victory of his three-season PGA Tour career with a closing 71.
He won by a two-stroke margin over Calcavecchia with a 282 total, six under par on the windswept Tournament Players Course at Eagle Trace.

LEAD: Because of a computer malfunction, an article on Feb. 28 about a Supreme Court ruling on the treatment of mentally ill prisoners was scrambled in some copies.
The opening paragraph should have read, ''The Supreme Court ruled today that prison officials can treat mentally ill prisoners with antipsychotic drugs against their will without first receiving permission in a formal judicial hearing.

Girl, 2, Killed in Harlem Fire
LEAD: A fire swept through a Harlem apartment yesterday morning, killing a 2-year-old girl who was found dead in her crib, the police said.
The fire was contained in the top floor apartment at 301 West 152d Street.
The infant's five brothers and sisters; her mother, Yvette Adams, 26; and her grandmother, Nettie Adams, 53, managed to safely flee the building.

LEAD: Anti-Government demonstrators marched today through the capital and in Timisoara, the cradle of the December revolution, protesting what they said was the continued prevalence of Communists and the dreaded security police.

Two performers and creators, Takehisa Kosugi and Fast Forward (yes, that is his name), perambulated an open space before a small audience in bleacher seats and made music on a number of instruments, household objects and themselves.

Private Group Drafting Changes in Spy Laws
LEAD: Nine private citizens who advise the leaders of the Senate Intelligence Committee are drafting a proposal to change the Federal espionage laws, partly to strengthen the authority of investigators to search for spies, according to Government officials and private intelligence experts.


New Land Panel Has Trouble Gearing Up
LEAD: The way New York City governs land, perhaps its most precious commodity, is in quiet turmoil these days, with the Dinkins administration behind schedule in putting in place changes under the new City Charter and developers rushing to act on big projects before the system changes.


Estonian Congress Calls for a Republic
LEAD: In a major step toward achieving independence from the Soviet Union, a congress selected by a majority of Estonians living in Estonia today called on the United Nations and the Soviet Parliament to restore ''the free and independent republic of Estonia.''


Entrepreneurs in Czechoslovakia Await Law
LEAD: Martin Stepanek works at the Prague Zoo with large animals.
It is a good job, but his heart is really in snakes and crocodiles, he said as he waited to register with a newly formed association of entrepreneurs.
He would like to open his own pet shop.

Review/Concert;   Celebrating 50 Years of Opera on Saturdays
LEAD: The Metropolitan Opera began broadcasting its Saturday matinees to a national radio audience in 1931, but nearly called its series to a halt in 1939 when it had trouble finding a sponsor.
In 1940, Texaco began sponsoring the weekly broadcasts, and on Saturday afternoon, the Met and Texaco celebrated their half-century alliance with a gala concert that was, naturally, broadcast live.

The Mail Monopoly
LEAD: Does the price of mail really have to go up again?
Yes, and 30 cents for a first-class letter is still a bargain compared with prices in other countries.
But costlier service could also be better service.
The U.S.
Postal Service is, and acts like, a monopoly.
Competition is the answer.

Argentine Inflation Rate
LEAD: Living costs in Argentina rose more than 12,000 percent in the 12 months through the end of February, according to official figures released Friday.
The National Statistics Institute said the consumer price index rose 61.6 percent in February alone, compared with a 79.2 percent rise in January.
Prices rose 9.6 percent in February 1989.

American Airlines
LEAD: American Airlines Inc. said Monday it would add 39 domestic flights beginning next month, including two cross-country flights from Newark to Los Angeles.
American also exercised options to buy seven MD-11 jumbo jets from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.
The expansion also includes service at Stewart Airport in Newburgh, N.Y., and daily flights between Miami and both Newark and New York's Kennedy Airport - as well as new flights serving Dallas, Chicago and North Carolina.

A.T.&amp; T. and Olin
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it had signed a license agreement with the Olin Corporation and the chip-making consortium Sematech to let Olin use certain A.T.&amp; T. technology.
Under the agreement, A.T.&amp; T. will transfer to Stamford, Conn.-based Olin the process for developing a chemical compound, known as a resist, which can be used to make more powerful chips using narrower circuits that are needed as semiconductors become smaller.

LEAD: To the Editor:


William F. Raborn Is Dead at 84; Led Production of Polaris Missile
LEAD: William F. Raborn Jr., a retired Navy vice admiral who led the development of the Polaris nuclear missile in the 1950's and later headed the Central Intelligence Agency under President Lyndon B. Johnson, died of cardiac arrest on March 7 at his home in McLean, Va.
He was 84 years old.


Escort Price Raised
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said the average price of its 1991 Ford Escort car with popular options would be about 2.5 percent more than comparably equipped 1990 models.
Base prices for two-door, four-door and station wagon models will range from $7,565 to $11,063.
The new Escort, made at Ford's assembly plant in Wayne, Mich., will go on sale April 26.


Hope in Haiti. Yes, Haiti.
LEAD: It's easy to wring hands about Haiti, the hemisphere's poorest nation and one with virtually no democratic tradition.
In the 49 months since Jean-Claude Duvalier fell, four more governments have failed.
Gen.
Prosper Avril, the latest strongman, has now been prodded into exile.
The free elections first promised for 1987 have not been held.


Sales Spurt in Britain
LEAD: Britain said today that retail sales rose by 2.4 percent in February.
January's adjusted figure showed a fall of nine-tenths of a percent.
Participants in investment markets had expected a rise of three-tenths of 1 percent in February.


The Big Bailout    A special report.;   U.S. HAS TROUBLE COPING WITH ITS SAVINGS EMPIRE
LEAD: Seven months after President Bush signed into law the largest Federal bailout in history, savings and loan regulators are mired in bureaucratic bickering and frustrated by their inability to sell off hundreds of sick savings institutions quickly.


Finding of Overcharges Is Challenged by Nynex
LEAD: The Nynex Corporation, parent of New York Telephone and New England Telephone, yesterday challenged a finding by the Federal Communications Commission that the two companies overcharged consumers to pay inflated prices to another, unregulated Nynex subsidiary.


Luxembourg Watchdog
LEAD: The Government of Luxembourg plans to establish a stock market watchdog agency to deal with insider trading, a Finance Ministry official said today.
The planned bourse commissariat is part of draft legislation approved recently by the Government making insider trading a criminal offense, said the official, who asked not to be identified.

LEAD: President Bush's recent statement that in effect raised questions about Israel's claim to East Jerusalem has set off a dispute among some leaders of American Jewish organizations.

LEAD: The first large study of women and heart disease is being undertaken by the Johns Hopkins Medical Institutions and six other medical centers after decades of research devoted solely to heart disease in men.

LEAD: Former Mayor Abraham D. Beame, complaining of chest pains, was taken by ambulance to Bellevue Medical Center late last night for tests, hospital officials said.

Copper Miners Strike in Peru
LEAD: Workers in Peru's vital copper mining industry went on strike today for better pay, adding to a wave of labor unrest less than a month before presidential elections.
The walkout by workers at the Southern Peru Copper Corporation shut down the country's biggest copper mine, the Cuajone pit near the Chilean border, and its main copper smelter, a company spokesman said.

Review/Music;   Bernstein's Latest Thoughts on 2 of His Specialties
LEAD: The Vienna Philharmonic ended its five-concert residency at Carnegie Hall with a Sunday afternoon program devoted to Leonard Bernstein's latest thoughts on Mahler's orchestral songs and Sibelius's First Symphony.
The orchestra's ravishing sound, a joy on its own terms, was especially reassuring after the uneven Bruckner Ninth the ensemble unleashed on Friday evening.


Philippe Soupault, 92, A Surrealism Founder
LEAD: Philippe Soupault, a writer and poet who was one of the founders of Surrealism, died on Sunday at his home in Paris.
He was 92 years old.


New Jersey Court Voids 14th Death Sentence
LEAD: The State Supreme Court today reversed its 14th death sentence in a row.
The court ruled that there was insufficient evidence surrounding the confession of a man who had pleaded guilty to killing a pizzeria owner in Maplewood.

He was 69 years old and had been in failing health for some time.

LEAD: Overgrazing, inappropriate agriculture and even the use of off-road vehicles have long been linked to turning semi-arid grasslands into desert.

Review/Dance;   Oakland Ballet's 'Giselle'
LEAD: One of the most eloquent works of the 19th century, ''Giselle'' is also one of the most durable and adaptable of ballet's classics.

But because of its poignant scenario, it can be equally effective when danced by a small company on a small stage.

Quirky Britain in Fashion's Sea
LEAD: For an hour Sunday evening Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher chatted about fashion and seemed to be enjoying herself in the midst of turmoil here over taxes, economics and her leadership of the Conservative Party.
She wore a tailored dinner suit of plum-colored brocade with a long, slender skirt by Aquascutum as she moved among the 500 people, members of the British fashion industry and their guests, at a Government reception at Lancaster House.

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today described Lithuania's declaration of independence as ''alarming,'' but he gave no indication of what the Kremlin's next move would be.


Chip Maker Had Deficit In 3d Quarter
LEAD: After just a quarter of profitability, the National Semiconductor Corporation fell back into the red in its third fiscal quarter ended Feb. 25.
The company today attributed the $10.2 million loss to pricing pressures on electronically programmable read only memory chips, or Eproms, a typical seasonal sales slowdown and the annual two-week closing of its production operations for the holidays.


Labor Closer to Split With Likud
LEAD: As compromise efforts foundered, the Israeli Government moved closer to dissolution today when the Labor Party's governing body agreed to give Labor Cabinet ministers the power to end their coalition with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and his Likud party.


40 at Random House Critical of Pantheon
LEAD: Forty Random House editors and publishers issued a statement yesterday supporting Pantheon's ''high editorial standards'' but faulting Pantheon as not having practiced fiscal responsibility. ''There is no reason,'' the statement added, ''why Pantheon shouldn't live by the same fiscal rules as the rest of us at Random House and throughout the industry.

LEAD: A longtime corporate raider, Nortek Inc., was accused yesterday of lying to the Securities and Exchange Commission in a filing regarding its efforts to acquire another company.

Marquette is just happy to still be playing.

Results Plus
LEAD:
SLED-DOG RACING
Butcher and Runyan Close In
Susan Butcher, a three-time winner, and Joe Runyan, the defending champion, both gained on the leader, Lavon Barve, in the Iditarod Trail race yesterday as they pulled into the checkpoint at Unalakleet, Alaska.
Resting his dogs for only three and a half hours, Barve was about four hours ahead of Butcher and Runyan when they left Kaltag, the last checkpoint on the Yukon River, for the 90-mile run to Unalakleet.

LEAD: Lawrence K. Fish, who last week became chairman of the Bank of New England Corporation, said today that he plans to reduce the troubled holding company's work force, continue selling assets and possibly sell subsidiaries.


As Romanian Elections Near, Politics Looks for a Direction
LEAD: Romania's interim Parliament has had one thing in common with the United States Congress in recent days - delays.
It had set itself the task of voting on two new laws.
Instead, it debated politely, then postponed the vote until the following week.


Chronicle
LEAD: When MARILYN MONROE died in 1962, she left 75 percent of her estate to LEE STRASBERG, who had been her coach at the Actors' Studio, and 25 percent to DR.
MARIANNE KRIS, her psychiatrist.
Yesterday ANNA STRASBERG, Mr.
Strasberg's widow, lost her challenge to get control of that 25 percent of the estate.


Woman Killed as Ornate Ceiling Collapses in Ansonia Hotel Shop
LEAD: A once-ornate ceiling in a once-elegant Upper West Side hotel cracked and sent 4,000 pounds of plaster and concrete crashing down in a croissant shop there yesterday, killing one customer at the counter and injuring 16 other people in the store.

LEAD: Widening the picture of corruption in New York City's local school districts, two Brooklyn superintendents have told an investigative panel that they were pressured to hire relatives and friends of school board members.

Suited for Work
LEAD: Fashion in the office has taken a truly odd turn.
Sit at a typical in-office meeting and it's hard to miss.
The men, mostly, come without their jackets.
The women, to a woman, come with their jackets on.
Men show no compunction about displaying generous paunches.
Women hide their unbusiness-like chests and not-so-flat stomachs.

LEAD: *
Grand Metropolitan Food Sector, Minneapolis, a subsidiary of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., London, a food and retailing conglomerate, appointed Chris J. Chamberlain senior vice president for business development.
He replaces Gerard M. Murphy, who will work on strategic planning for Grand Metropolitan in London.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Feb. 26 about a ban on smoking on most domestic airline flights included an incorrect identification from The Associated Press for a Tobacco Institute spokesman.


Cigna Leaving 2 Businesses
LEAD: The Cigna Corporation, one of the nation's largest financial service concerns, is pulling out of the automobile and personal liability insurance businesses as part of its plan to become largely a commercial insurer, a company official said.


Upheaval in the East;   Lithuanian-Americans React With Joy After 50-Year Wait
LEAD: A party in Chicago for a local Lithuanian-language radio program on Sunday erupted into a more spontaneous celebration.
Just minutes earlier, Lithuania had proclaimed itself free of the Soviet Union.


President Criticizes Deficit Plan
LEAD: President Bush took issue today with the main elements of Representative Dan Rostenkowski's plan for cutting the deficit, those that would raise taxes and lower Social Security benefits.


Wine Talk
LEAD: WHEN President John F. Kennedy ordered United States embassies around the world to begin serving American wines, the know-it-alls shuddered and affected great sympathy for our poor diplomats and their hapless guests.


Maybe Lunkhead Park?
LEAD: Baltimore is building a new baseball park for the Orioles, and the big question is what to name it.
Some people want it called Babe Ruth Park, or Babe Ruth Stadium, or Babe Ruth Baseball Emporium, or anything else that has Babe Ruth in it.


Art by Charles Saxon
LEAD: About 70 drawings and watercolors by Charles Saxon, whose cartoons appeared in The New Yorker for 35 years, are on view through June 29 in the Rare Book and Manuscript Library of the Butler Library at Columbia University, Broadway and 116th Street.
The exhibition is in observance of a gift from the artist's widow, Nancy, of 1,900 of his works.


Brazil Returns 10 Tons of Arms Sent by Cuba for Castro's Security
LEAD: Brazil has sent back to Cuba a load of arms that arrived in Brasilia as part of Cuban security preparations for Fidel Castro's attendance at Brazil's presidential inauguration on Thursday, a newspaper and an official here said today.


Trial Opens on Suit Over a Senator's Suicide
LEAD: Opening arguments have been presented in a wrongful death lawsuit against the Government by the widow of Senator John P. East, who committed suicide in 1986.


Chronicle


About New York;   Lonely Crusade To Pay Tribute To the Dead
LEAD: This column will ramble a bit, but hold to a central theme. The theme is death.


Review/Music;   Celebrating a Birthday With Song
LEAD: Although most music lovers know the name of the Swiss composer Frank Martin, few in this country have heard much of his music.
And since Martin was an independent spirit who ranged widely in the slow development of his mature style, including a serious flirtation with serialism, fewer still have any distinct impression of his idiom.


Panel Votes Immunity for Ex-Aide to Pierce
LEAD: The House Government Operations Committee voted unanimously today to grant immunity to a onetime aide of the Reagan Administration's Housing Secretary, Samuel R. Pierce Jr., in exchange for new information about fraud and mismanagement at the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

LEAD:
