Devils Start Burke and He's Super
LEAD: The Devils ignored the tradition of staying with a hot goaltender in a stretch drive and it proved successful.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about health workers who become infected with the AIDS virus on the job referred incompletely to the case of Dr.
Hacib Aoun at John Hopkins University.
The university corroborated his account of having become infected in the course of his duties.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Y.&amp;R. Consolidation
LEAD: Young &amp; Rubicam has consolidated its promotional marketing offices under the name Cato Johnson Worldwide.
William A. Power was appointed chief executive of the subsidiary, and Jean Paul Lafaye was named president of worldwide operations.


Cinemas Blossoming In Manhattan
LEAD: THE collective message blaring from the marquees of all the new cinemas in New York might well be ''Movie Mania Grips Gotham.''


Asarco Fights Sale Of Freeport Unit
LEAD: Asarco Inc. challenged the proposed sale of the Freeport-McMoran Inc.'s gold mining subsidiary to South African-controlled Minorco S.A.
In a lawsuit filed in New York Supreme Court, Asarco said its interest in a joint venture with the Freeport-McMoran unit could be violated by the sale.


Jets Get Strength Coach
LEAD: The Jets, with a history of critical injuries that came at the wrong time, have upgraded the position of strength and conditioning coach to equal status with the assistant coaches.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Status Is Uncertain For Keye/Donna Team
LEAD: Keye/Donna/Pearlstein is negotiating to sell its small New York office to Della Femina, McNamee WCRS.
But Jay Taub and Tod Seisser, the creative team who run the operation, are still pondering their own future.


Burger King Resignation
LEAD: The Burger King Corporation, the struggling hamburger chain owned by Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., said yesterday that the president and chief operating officer of its American operation had resigned, effective immediately.


Lady Jaspers Aiming To Beat Long Odds
LEAD: Kathy Solano doesn't mind that at least one Las Vegas oddsmaker has made her Manhattan College basketball team a million-to-one shot to win the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's tournament.
The way she sees it, only 47 schools have been given a better chance.


Upheaval in the East;   Cash-Starved Parties Introduce Voters in Hungary to the Fund-Raiser
LEAD: Democracy has its price, as Hungary's new political parties are learning now that they must pay the bill for the posters, leaflets, 30-second television spots, lapel pins, cigarette lighters, helicopters, hot-air balloons and other props of this country's first full-fledged electoral campaign in 40 years.

One Dead as Gas Pipeline Explodes in Upstate New York


Banque Indosuez Adds Risk-Management Post
LEAD: Richard Sandor, a self-styled financial ''tinkerer'' who has created some of the futures market's most familiar interest-rate products, has been hired to organize a new risk-management unit for Banque Indosuez, the French merchant bank.


Blind Robbery Suspect Seized
LEAD: A blind man handed a threatening note to a bank teller Monday, collected $105 and then was arrested after he asked the teller to help him leave the building, the authorities said.
The 27-year-old suspect, Jeffery Lee Flournoy, was seized by officers who had been summoned by the manager of the Bank of America branch.


Walter Orr Roberts Is Dead at 74; Expert on Climate's Effect on Life
LEAD: Walter Orr Roberts, the founder of the National Center for Atmospheric Research, who was one of the first scientists to warn that technology was changing the earth's climate, died of cancer on Monday in Boulder, Colo.
He was 74 years old.


Expert Links Bite Mark on Body to Murder Suspect
LEAD: An expert in forensic dentistry said today that a bite mark on the body of Kelly Ann Tinyes, the Valley Stream teen-ager slain a year ago, was made by Robert Golub.


Home Loan Banks Offering Bonds
LEAD: The Office of Finance for the Federal Home Loan Banks system priced four bond issues totaling $2.58 billion at par through various securities dealers yesterday.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of a transcription error, an article on Monday about Lithuania's declaration of independence misidentified the new president of Lithuania in some editions, as did a picture caption in other copies.
He is Vytautas Landsbergis.
The article also misidentified the Communist Party ideology chief of Lithuania.


Bush Turns Down Bid To Help Negotiators
LEAD: Baseball's labor dispute lay dormant yesterday as negotiators chose not to meet and President Bush opted not to become involved.
The possibility of binding arbitration was raised and neither side rejected the idea outright, but the owners' labor spokesman said it would be ''a difficult sell'' for his side.


Retail Sales Decline 0.9% As Demand for Autos Slips
LEAD: Retail sales fell nine-tenths of a percent in February, their steepest fall in four months, the Government reported today.

Reviews/Music;   Blues at the Lone Star, Played, Shouted and Sung
LEAD: Blues revues, which flourished from the 1940's through the 60's, were roof-raising fun.
Competitive and exuberant affairs in which a slew of performers came out and took their turns at trying to win the audience, they offered listeners a wide variety of musical ideas and techniques.
Over the last several years, blues revues have been making a comeback, this time playing to the young, white blues audience, and in theory that's a good thing.

LEAD: There's an old yarn in academic circles about the state legislator who asked a college professor how much time he spent teaching.
The professor, who taught three courses, each for three hours a week, replied, ''Nine hours.''

LEAD: On a night of playoff-like warm weather, the Montreal Canadiens brought playoff-level discipline and playoff-style patience to their game with the Islanders at Nassau Coliseum.

She is Anita Contini.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Nabisco Brands Agrees To Settle Ad Charges
LEAD: Without admitting wrongdoing, Nabisco Brands has agreed to pay $135,000 in costs to settle charges by 10 state attorneys general that advertising campaigns for several of Nabisco's products misled consumers about the nutritional value of the foods.


ISRAELI COALITION DISSOLVES IN FIGHT OVER PEACE PLAN
LEAD: Israel's coalition Government collapsed today when Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir dismissed Finance Minister Shimon Peres, the leader of the Labor Party, prompting the rest of Labor's Cabinet ministers to resign.


Chrysler's Austria Mini-van Deal
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation announced a final agreement to manufacture its mini-vans in Austria.
The deal, which had been expected, creates a new joint venture company in which Chrysler and the Austrian manufacturer Steyr-Daimler-Puch Fahrzeugtecknik G.m.b.H. will each own 50 percent.

Nicaraguans on Both Sides Praise Embargo's End
LEAD: After five years of deepening economic hardship, much of it attributable to United States sanctions, Sandinista officials and opposition business leaders today applauded President Bush's decision to end the American embargo on trade with Nicaragua.

LEAD: A 21-year-old man who has admitted participating in the fatal attack in Bensonhurst last summer and who reneged on a pledge to cooperate with prosecutors was ordered held without bail yesterday on second-degree murder charges.


Peanut Butter at 100 Still Loves Jelly
LEAD: ENOUGH of this kid stuff.
Now that peanut butter is 100 years old, let's face facts and stop beating around the bush.
Isn't it time for peanut butter to grow up?
It is almost embarrassing to admit.
But this country is still serving most of its peanut butter with jelly when so many other parts of the world are using it subtly to enhance stews, thicken soups, or top grilled fish.


London Journal;   In Highgate Cemetery, Marx Is Safe on a Pedestal
LEAD: At the grave of Karl Marx, they come not to mourn Marxism but to ponder the flawed realities that sprang from its ideals, or to keep the faith, or perhaps even to bask in its new and somewhat paradoxical vogue.


Stieb's Option Renewed
LEAD: The Toronto Blue Jays yesterday exercised the 1990 option in the contract of their ace right-hander, Dave Stieb, for $1.6 million.
Under the terms of Stieb's contract, signed in March 1985, the team had until Thursday to renew his option for 1990 or buy out the contract for $800,000.

LEAD: The finish of last night's Knicks-Bulls game at Madison Square Garden centered around a 3-point shot attempt, which meant it resembled the finish of the game there between the same teams two months ago.


Corrections
LEAD: A chart on Saturday showing the civilian unemployment rate and the total rate misstated the total for February 1989.
It was 5.1 percent.


Lebanese Truce Breaks Down
LEAD: An 11-day cease-fire between warring Lebanese Christian factions began to fall apart today as loyalists of Gen.
Michel Aoun and Samir Geagea traded artillery shells and rockets in East Beirut and in the hills northeast of here.


Auto Dealerships Drop
LEAD: The number of new-car dealerships in the United States fell by 337 last year, a survey by Automotive News has found.
It was the largest decline since the early 1980's.
The weekly automotive trade journal said on Monday that on Jan. 1, there were 24,576 outlets, compared with 24,913 a year earlier, a decline of 1.4 percent.

LEAD: Two Brooklyn school superintendents said yesterday that their school boards had hired a total of 150 unneeded people to patrol cafeterias and perform clerical chores at a cost of almost $2 million a year.

LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply yesterday, pushed lower by stronger-than-expected February retail sales data and by reports that the West German Government has a plan to exchange West German marks on a one-to-one basis for the Ostmark, East Germany's currency, for savings.

'Invisible' British Deficit
LEAD: Britain recorded a deficit in its so-called invisible trade in the last three months of 1989, the Government said today.
It was the first quarterly deficit since such data were first collected in 1955.
Figures from the Central Statistical Office showed a gap of $:713 million ($1.14 billion) in the last quarter of 1989 for the category, which includes banking, insurance, shipping and tourism.

She is one of 10 women from the New York metropolitan area who have won world titles in the last decade.

Bonn Sets Mark Rate On Savings
LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany said today that East Germans would be able to exchange their personal savings at a one-to-one rate for West German marks, but that this rate would not apply to East German marks held by businesses or other institutions.


Hong Kong Bank Gains
LEAD: The Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation, regarded as the largest bank in Asia outside Japan, reported today that its earnings rose 11 percent in 1989.
Despite economic slowdowns in the bank's leading markets, the bank said its profits for the year rose to $4.77 billion (Hong Kong), or $612 million (United States), from $4.3 billion (Hong Kong) in 1988.


Rejuvenating Faded Flavor Of 1990's Food
LEAD: FOR 30 years, food producers have slowly been turning seasonal foods into foods for all seasons.
Asparagus time, salmon time and even raspberry time have become any time.
Today the idea of seasonal ingredients is as quaint as the image of Mom in a ruffled apron in the American kitchen.


Aid Hanoi on Boat People, U.N. Official Urges
LEAD: Faced with continuing United States opposition to the forced repatriation of boat people from Hong Kong to Vietnam, a leading United Nations official appealed today for a sharp increase in international aid to Vietnam.
The aim of the aid would be to stop the boat people from fleeing Vietnam in the first place.

LEAD: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the British food company, provided details today of its deal with Elders IXL Ltd. of Australia.
Under the agreement, Grand Met will sell most of its breweries to Elders, and the two companies will jointly operate about 5,000 pubs.

Now You Can Take On the Monster
LEAD: A group of Canadian designers has come up with a new style of video game that permits the player to climb directly into the action.
Using a video camera like those that look for shoplifters in stores, the system captures the user's movements and displays them instantaneously in the middle of the video game on the computer screen.


Upheaval in the East;   Unity Talks Begin Today
LEAD: The four World War II Allies and the two Germanys are to begin initial talks on Wednesday on returning the full sovereignty that the Germanys lost with the defeat of the Third Reich in 1945.


Guidelines Issued in Noriega Trial
LEAD: A Federal judge issued a sweeping order today on how lawyers in the drug-trafficking trial of General Manuel Antonio Noriega could handle classified information.


Australia's Ramtron Names Electronic Chip Unit Chief
LEAD: After careers at two major corporations, George J. Stathakis plans to try his hand at getting a start-up company up and running in the semiconductor industry.


Macy Lost $39 Million In Quarter
LEAD: Citing turmoil in the retail industry caused by severe price competition during the holidays, R. H. Macy &amp; Company yesterday reported a loss of $39 million in its second quarter.


Phillips to Offer Propane Gas for Vehicles
LEAD: In another sign of the effort by large energy companies to promote alternative fuels more aggressively, the Phillips Petroleum Company said today that it would market propane gas for taxis, buses and fleets of vehicles owned by private companies and government agencies in the Denver area.


Document Processor Appoints a Chairman
LEAD: Document Technologies Inc., a Palo Alto, Calif., company specializing in image processing products, named Dwight Ryan as chairman and chief executive yesterday.
Mr.
Ryan, 54 years old, is a 28-year veteran of the Xerox Corporation.


Gold Prices Decline Again; Some Expect Further Drop
LEAD: Gold futures dropped again yesterday, and analysts said the price could fall to $385 an ounce before enough buyers appear to offset the negative effects of the dollar's recent rise.


Now, No Haitians Can Donate Blood
LEAD: A Federal recommendation to exclude certain Haitians from blood donations as a safeguard against spreading AIDS has been expanded to all Haitians, and the change is being protested by Haitian organizations in New York City and Miami.


Washington Power System Prices $603 Million in Bonds
LEAD: The Washington Public Supply Power System tentatively priced $603 million in revenue bonds yesterday as part of its $2 billion refunding program for Nuclear Projects 1, 2 and 3, which issued debt when interest rates were higher.
This financing is a refunding for Projects 1 and 2.


Chief Picked For Comex
LEAD: The members of the Commodity Exchange in New York yesterday elected Martin Greenberg, a commodities firm executive and Comex member since 1976, to a two-year term as chairman of the board of governors of the exchange.


Edith F. Lynton, 70, Personnel Economist
LEAD: Edith F. Lynton, a government aide and an economist specializing in staffing problems, died of a heart attack on Monday after being stricken while on a flight from Fort Myers, Fla., to Newark International Airport.
She was 70 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Mamaroneck, N.Y.

Dolphins Sign Paige

LEAD: IN the kitchen of his weekend cottage in this northwest Connecticut village, James O'Shea, preparing an Irish meal for a group of friends, is fighting what he calls ''this amazing American idea of Irish food: that it's corned beef and cabbage and that's it.''

Another Greyhound Bus Is Hit by Gunfire
LEAD: A sniper opened fire yesterday on a Greyhound bus in Chicago in the seventh bus-shooting incident nationwide since drivers went on strike, officials said.
Neither the 13 passengers nor the driver were injured.

LEAD: President Bush called today for negotiations to end Mozambique's 10-year civil war.

Topics of The Times;   Detoxifying Households
LEAD: Child-resistant caps on containers have dramatically reduced fatalities, but the toll is still high.
About two million children a year ingest toxic household chemicals, accounting for tens of thousands of emergency room visits.


A.T.&amp;T.-Tandem Computer Venture
LEAD: Tandem Computers Inc. and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said they would jointly develop and market computer systems combining Tandem's ''fault tolerant'' designs and A.T.&amp; T.'s Unix operating system software.

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today rejected Lithuania's declaration of independence, calling the decision ''illegitimate and invalid,'' and he ruled out negotiations with the three Baltic republics on their quest for sovereign statehood.

Yields at Banks Are Mixed
LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were mixed for the week ended yesterday.


EDUCATION: About Education
LEAD: Even more tragic than the fate of students who drop out of school is that of half a million children who drop in irregularly or not at all.
They are not truants; they may not lack the desire to learn.
What they lack is a home from which to register as regulars for school.

Weights on Old Ceiling Are Blamed for Collapse
LEAD: The excessive weight of modern air-conditioning ducts, pipes and decorations suspended from a turn-of the-century plaster ceiling caused the ceiling collapse that killed one customer and injured 16 others on Monday in a croissant shop in a West Side hotel, New York City officials said yesterday.

LEAD: THE steep rise of the dollar and the tumble of the yen in global currency trading are contributing to a growing sense of crisis in the financial markets here.
Traders and investors say they see little prospect that monetary authorities can turn the situation around.

LEAD: President Bush yesterday announced a simple and appealing strategy to help Nicaragua and Panama meet their most desperate needs: national reconciliation and economic reconstruction.
He ended sanctions against Nicaragua.
And he urged Congress to approve an $800 million package for the two countries by April 8.

60-Minute Gourmet
LEAD: THE intermingling of French and Russian cuisines goes back at least to the time of Catherine the Great, when noble Russian families took great pride in employing French or Swiss chefs.
Lavish feasts usually began with a zakuska, an array of tidbits including caviar, herring, pates, cold fish, vegetables and breads, accompanied by vodka.


Critic's Notebook;   Ah, Those Americans Abroad, So Crassly Pursuing Culture
LEAD: ''I think this is the Pizza Hut where he wrote 'Troilus and Cressida,' '' said my theater-fanatic friend during a pre-matinee stroll in Stratford-on-Avon, England, a few summers ago.
We had already passed the McDonald's where, we imagined, Shakespeare had written ''Twelfth Night.'' (Or was it ''As You Like It'' at Burger King?) As we later wolfed down curry just in time to make the curtain at the Royal Shakespeare Company's evening performance of ''The Merchant of Venice,'' we concluded that we had finally found a Stratford restaurant the Bard might have missed.

LEAD: Oliver L. North today confirmed a long-suspected but hazy footnote to the Iran-contra affair: that officials of the Reagan Administration had considered sending Vice President George Bush as an emissary to Iran in early 1986.


Court Clears Aid For Bhopal Victims
LEAD: India's Supreme Court approved a Government plan to pay interim compensation of $12 a month to each of the 500,000 people living near the site of the 1984 Bhopal disaster.
The Supreme Court also ruled that the Government must pay $44 a month to 3,110 people disabled by the toxic gas leak.

Critic's Notebook;   TV News in the Schools: Which Channel, if Any?
LEAD: If more of America's schoolchildren knew the difference between Dan Quayle and Yasir Arafat, the competition between ''Channel One'' and ''CNN Newsroom'' would be moot.
Unfortunately, tests of teen-agers keep revealing prodigious ignorance of much of what is going on around them.
So the question becomes whether television can do anything to improve a painful condition; and, if so, whether either of the two daily news programs now being offered to schools may help in that job, and whether one is preferable to the other.


China's Tranquillity Is Seen as Only Skin Deep
LEAD: The Government assures foreigners that life in China has loosened up, but lately many Chinese are shaking their heads, whispering: ''Nei jin, wai song'' - ''tranquillity outside, repression within.''

Tales Told in Stars: Michelin Adds and Subtracts
LEAD: The 1990 Michelin Guide for France, published Monday, demoted Oustau de Baumaniere, one of the nation's longtime temples of gastronomy, from the top three-star rating to two stars.
Oustau de Baumaniere in Les Baux de Provence, opened by Raymond Thuilier in 1946, was first awarded Michelin's three-star rating in 1954.

LEAD: Maurice Saatchi said today that he and his brother, Charles, were cutting their $1 million salaries by 30 percent and that the other directors of the Saatchi &amp; Saatchi Company were taking 10 percent pay cuts.
But angry shareholders at the annual meeting here of the giant advertising and communications company said the cuts were not deep enough.

Gov.

LEAD: Nassau County announced a settlement with the United States Department of Justice today that will allow the county to begin hiring new police officers for the first time in three years.


Rangers' Nicholls Not Equal to His Boasts
LEAD: His intense anxiety in anticipation of the game had cost him a night's sleep, and now Bernie Nicholls, pale and perplexed, faced the prospect of losing another night's rest because of the acute embarrassment he felt in the wake of the game.


Salvador Rebels Say They'll Curb Raids
LEAD: Guerrilla leaders announced today that they would stop attacking most nonmilitary targets to pave the way for new peace talks with the Government.


President of Panama Ends His 13-Day Fast
LEAD: President Guillermo Endara of Panama today ended a 13-day fast begun as ''an act of commiseration with a suffering people'' and as a protest against his country's worsening economic situation.

Banks Shut By Brazil For 3 Days
LEAD: Brazil's central bank closed the nation's banks late today for the rest of the week until an emergency economic package is announced by President-elect Fernando Collor de Mello.


Harvard Doctor Named to Head Hospital Agency
LEAD: A 39-year-old physician with a background in community activity was appointed president of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation yesterday.
He immediately pledged to give top priority to improving health care for the poor.


Savings in Japan Rise
LEAD: Personal savings in Japan grew 11.2 percent in 1989, reaching a total of 700.08 trillion yen ($4.6 trillion) at the end of December, the Bank of Japan said on Tuesday.
It was the largest yearly increase since 1981, the report said.
Savings rose because of deregulation of interest rates on time deposits as well as larger company bonuses last year as Japan's economy boomed, the bank said.

Recycled Paper Spurs a New Debate: What Is It?
LEAD: The American paper industry has pledged to recycle 40 percent of its output by 1995 to reduce the amount of waste paper now being buried in landfills.
But the president of a company specializing in selling recycled paper said much of what the industry calls recycled paper was mill scrap that had never been used by the public.


Nomura Official Looks To Develop a Business
LEAD: After years of heading the futures desk at Kidder, Peabody &amp; Company, Joseph R. Schmuckler realized he was ready for new challenges.
It was getting increasingly difficult to make money in computerized program trading in domestic markets, where Mr.
Schmuckler made his reputation, and he felt he was ready for something more.


Higher Profits at Auction Concerns
LEAD: Sotheby's Holdings Inc. said today that its earnings for 1989 rose 82 percent from the period a year earlier, while another fine arts auction house, Christies International P.L.C., reported a 61 percent profit gain.

An industry executive said the account bills about $10 million.

Curtin Vocal Class
LEAD: The soprano Phyllis Curtin is to give a master class on vocal techniques at 3 P.M. on April 1 at the Turtle Bay Music School, 244 East 52d Street.
Ms.
Curtin, the dean of the School of the Arts at Boston University, will be working with the finalists of the Center for Contemporary Opera International Opera Singers Competition.


Company News;   Icahn Sets Campaign On USX
LEAD: Carl C. Icahn, who has proposed spinning off the steel business of the USX Corporation, said yesterday that he intended to conduct a vigorous campaign to win the votes of the company's institutional investors and other shareholders before the May 7 annual meeting.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Feb. 13 about reorganization plans by the American Jewish Committee referred incompletely to its intentions for a role in Western Europe and South America.
The human rights group has since said that while ending its formal staff structure along geographic boundaries, it will continue to pursue issues of concern to the Jewish community wherever they arise.


Stroh Brewery and Grey End Their Relationship
LEAD: The Stroh Brewery Company and Grey Advertising announced yesterday that they had ended their relationship. ''Due to reduced manpower and budgets'' at Stroh, the brewer said in a statement, ''we have been unable to agree upon terms with Grey.''


Jerome Schnur Dead; TV Producer Was 66
LEAD: Jerome Schnur, an award-winning director and producer of television shows, died of melanoma on Monday at Mt.
Sinai Hospital.
He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.


One Housing Agency Is To Run Another
LEAD: The Jersey City Housing Authority will be paid $100,000 by the Federal Government to try to repair and reorganize the embattled Passaic Housing Authority, officials said yesterday.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Friday about an experimental AIDS drug, compound Q, referred incorrectly to the drug and its manufacturer.
The drug is derived from a Chinese cucumber plant; it is not synthetic.
Genelabs, which makes the drug, is an independent company, not a subsidiary of Sandoz Pharmaceuticals.


Penn St. Defeats Marquette
LEAD: DeRon Hayes scored 4 of Penn State's final 5 points and grabbed an offensive rebound in the final minute that helped seal a 57-54 victory over Marquette in a first-round National Invitation Tournament game tonight.


Serrano and Molinari for Congress
LEAD: Voters will be filling two Congressional seats in a special election next Tuesday - one in the Bronx, another in a district that includes Staten Island and a piece of Brooklyn.
The winners serve only until the regularly scheduled general election in November, but whoever prevails next week will have the advantage.


Outlook on Peruvian Strike Sends Copper Up Sharply
LEAD: Copper futures prices climbed sharply yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York, reflecting a more optimistic economic outlook and concerns that a strike at Peru's largest copper company could last longer than a few days.

LEAD: IN 1987, a handful of friends decided to put together something that would be a historical document about the experiences of people suffering from AIDS.

CLOSE TO HOME
LEAD: THERE are places throughout this country where corporate America goes to die: warm places with golf courses and beaches and clubs whose members are, as they describe themselves, ''the kind of people who'd be comfortable here.'' The kind of people who'd be comfortable play bridge, have fond memories of alma mater and, if male, have a predilection for plaid golf pants.

LEAD: Darryl Strawberry has been ordered to pay $40,000 in back child-support payments, plus regular payments of $2,000 per month as a result of a paternity suit.

LEAD: House Democrats said today that they had reached a consensus to forgo deep cuts in military spending for the next fiscal year and to seek more dramatic reductions in spending for future years.

Review/Theater;   'Prelude to a Kiss,' a Fairy Tale Of Souls in Love and in Flight
LEAD: Peter, the ingenuous hero played by Alec Baldwin in ''Prelude to a Kiss,'' loves the sign at the roller coaster: ''Ride at Your Own Risk.'' It promises a journey into ''the wild blue'' in which anything can happen.
The same sign could be posted at ''Prelude to a Kiss,'' for Craig Lucas, the author of ''Reckless'' and ''Blue Window,'' has again written a play that propels the audience through hairpin emotional turns, some soaring heavenward and others plummeting toward earth, until one is deposited at the final curtain in a winded and teary yet exhilarating state of disorientation.

Chronicle
LEAD: In the hopes of settling the dust that has swirled around the NBC ''Today'' show, BRYANT GUMBEL has acknowledged his role in hurting his own program.
A year ago, Mr.
Gumbel wrote an interoffice memo criticizing several aspects of ''Today,'' of which he is a host.
After its contents became public, the show's ratings declined.


A New Assault On Brazil's Woes
LEAD: Harried by hyperinflation and mounting debts, a new young economic team takes office here Thursday carrying blueprints of free-market reforms designed to turn Brazil into an economic world power this decade.


Browns Sign Clayborn
LEAD: The Cleveland Browns yesterday signed Raymond Clayborn, a three-time Pro Bowl cornerback with the New England Patriots.
Clayborn, 35 years old, who has played for New England since beginning his pro career in 1977, was an unprotected free agent.
He has 36 career interceptions, seventh among active N.F.L.

LEAD: The pianist Kathryn Supove is to play a recital of contemporary piano music at Weill Recital Hall on March 29 at 8 P.M.
The program, titled ''The Exploding Piano,'' is to include Lukas Foss's ''Solo'' (1981), Frederic Rzewski's ''Winnsboro Cotton Mill Blues'' (1978), Giacinto Scelsi's ''Five Incantations'' (1953), and the New York premieres of works by Augusta Read Thomas and Randall Woolf.

Review/Music;   Oratorio by Elder Scarlatti On Abraham and His Sons
LEAD: History remembers Alessandro Scarlatti for the same wrong reasons as it does Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach.
The first is known as the father of a famous son (Domenico), the second as the son of a famous father (Johann Sebastian).
Yet from his musical stronghold in Naples, the elder Scarlatti dominated Italian opera in the latter half of the 17th century much as the younger Bach presided over Central Europe's transition from Baroque to Classical style about 75 years later.

HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: STAINED grout between ceramic tiles can generally be cleaned with a liquid grout cleaner available from tile stores or with acid applied by a professional tile setter.
But if the cement filler is cracked, crumbling or missing, it must be replaced.
Otherwise tiles can shift and break, or water can seep behind them and cause major damage.

Paris Sugar Market
LEAD: The Paris sugar market this week moved its operations across the exchange in a bid to revitalize futures trading.
The Paris futures exchange, Matif, moved the sugar trading floor 770 yards to the financial futures center, placing it next to the French Government bond pit, where Matif's most active contract is traded.


Loss for Prudential-Bache
LEAD: Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. had a net loss of $51 million in 1989, compared with earnings of $111 million in 1988, its parent company, the Prudential Insurance Company of America, reported yesterday.

Abraham Halkin, 86; Taught Jewish Culture
LEAD: Abraham S. Halkin, who taught Jewish literature, history and culture for nearly half a century before retiring from the Jewish Theological Seminary faculty in 1977, died on Friday in Jerusalem, where he lived.
He was 86 years old.

LEAD: Iraq said today it had executed a British-based journalist who was convicted last week of spying by an Iraqi revolutionary court.

LEAD: What's the prognosis for Israeli-Palestinian negotiations?
Very grim, with the collapse of the Likud-Labor coalition Government on Tuesday.
What's the remedy?
A new Israeli government, strong and united enough to pursue Israel's own plan for negotiating with the Palestinians.

LEAD: The Pathe Communications Company began its $20-a-share, $1.22 billion tender offer for the MGM/UA Communications Company.
Pathe was expected to release details of its financing but did not.
In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing in Washington, Pathe said only that it had received ''a non-binding'' oral commitment to provide up to $200 million for the purchase.

LEAD: Adults often complain that doctors do not take their headaches seriously.

Upheaval in the East;   Narrow Victory on Vote
LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev narrowly avoided being forced to face the first general election of his life today.


Jane McIntire Grigson, Food Writer, 61
LEAD: Jane McIntire Grigson, a British food writer, died of cancer on Monday at her home in Wiltshire, England.
She was 61 years old.


Greek Bank Faces Charges
LEAD: A leading Greek bank and 13 of its employees were indicted in Brooklyn yesterday on Federal charges of carrying out a money-laundering scheme that enabled clients to evade taxes on millions of dollars.

A Gallery Where Dogs Are Welcome
LEAD: WILLIAM SECORD opened his new paintings gallery on Feb. 10, to coincide with the Westminster Kennel Club's annual show, which is the sort of thing you do when you specialize in dog paintings.
His inaugural show, titled ''British Dog Painting, 1840-1940,'' which continues through March 31, includes 35 works that range in price from $3,500 to $34,000.


Arthur Mead Irwin Jr., Publishers' Representative, 72
LEAD: Arthur Mead Irwin Jr., the owner of Mead Irwin Associates, publishers' representatives, died of lung cancer on Tuesday at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y.
He was 72 years old.


Jury Finds Man Guilty In '79 Slaying of Boy
LEAD: Nearly 11 years after the body of a 13-year-old was found in Smithtown, a man was convicted of the slaying today.


Chairman of Robinson's
LEAD: Kenneth L. Wilkerson has been named chairman of the Robinson's department stores in Los Angeles, effective April 1, the May Department Stores Company said yesterday.
Mr.
Wilkerson will succeed Elden Rasmussen, who is retiring.
Mr.
Wilkerson is now chairman of the Famous-Barr store division in St.
Louis, which, like Robinson's, is owned by May.

Sidney Shenkman, Executive, 69
LEAD: Sidney Shenkman, chairman of Extebank, the United States subsidiary of Banco Exterior Group of Spain, died of a heart attack on Monday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 69 years old.


Earle Palmer Brown
LEAD: Earle Palmer Brown said its Atlanta office had added several of the staff members and clients set loose by the reduction of Tracy-Locke's Atlanta office.
Donald S. Morgan, the president of Tracy-Locke Atlanta, will take a still undetermined management position at Earle Palmer Brown, which said other staff moves were under negotiation.


Reuters Wins Court Ruling
LEAD: A Federal judge refused on Tuesday to order Reuters to continue a picture-exchange agreement with United Press International.
The judge said U.P.I. had not shown it would be irreparably harmed if the arrangement was discontinued.

''Baseball,'' the tour guide said.

LEAD: The fate of the Israeli Government and its peace initiative lies in the hands of a small, rigorously Orthodox religious party that won 1.5 percent of the vote in the last national elections.

Making Dead Land Live Again
LEAD: THE job is not quick and dirty.
It is slow and dirty.
And the time line is not measured in years or even decades.
For landscape architects and designers, the task of turning garbage into gardens - reclaiming landfills - means transforming a toxic mass into a livable place over time.

LEAD: Salomon Brothers Inc. is in final negotiations to purchase an asset management subsidiary of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., people involved in the talks said yesterday.


Talks on Satellites Stalled
LEAD: Talks between United States and Japanese negotiators have failed to make progress in trying to open Japan's markets to foreign space satellites, a Government trade official said today.


Rosamond Lehmann, 89, Writer Of Love, Betrayal and Rivalries
LEAD: Rosamond Lehmann, whose novels of love, betrayal and family rivalries were critically acclaimed, died in her home here on Monday, her family announced today.
She was 89 years old.


Child Labor Law Violators Sought in Nationwide Raids
LEAD: A 500-member Labor Department strike force fanned out across the country this week in an unannounced sweep of thousands of businesses, from fast-food restaurants to laundries, looking for violations of child labor laws.


Restaurants
LEAD: For several years so much attention has focused on Manhattan's downtown dining scene that one could forget there is anyplace to eat above 79th Street.
While it is true that most gastronomic tributaries flow south, it is reassuring to paddle upstream and find some places holding their own.

LEAD: It took 22 years and 10 trips to the National Invitation Tournament, but Fordham finally won another N.I.T. game last night.


Hand-Bell Concert: 100 Clappers Clapping
LEAD: THE pursuit of exotica is by now an unexotic commonplace of 20th-century musical culture.
Most such pursuits range out to third-world terrain, the more distant the better.
But it is perfectly possible to unearth exotica right in one's own backyard.
And the practitioners of these strange rites often turn out to be ordinary folk.

Review/Theater;   'Heart of a Dog,' a Parable On the Ills of Soviet Society
LEAD: Mikhail Bulgakov's novel ''Heart of a Dog'' is a malicious political parable on what the author envisioned as the inevitable corruption of a socialist state.
Written in 1925 (and unpublished in the Soviet Union until 1987), the book follows the rise and fall of a mongrel scientifically transformed into a man but unable to avoid the curse of atavism.


Knicks Expand on Loss Column
LEAD: The Knicks lost the first time they played the Hornets in Charlotte.
They did the same against the Heat the first time in Miami and the Magic in Orlando.


Commerce Secretary Issues Warning on Japan's Surplus
LEAD: After two days of meetings with Japanese Government officials, trading companies and political leaders, the United States Secretary of Commerce, Robert A. Mosbacher, warned today that Japan's trade surpluses had ''achieved a semipermanent status.''


I.B.M. Work Station Wins Test
LEAD: In recent years the upstart personal computer known as a work station has spoiled the minicomputer business by attaining comparable speed at far lower prices.
Now comes the first independent confirmation that a new work station from the International Business Machines Corporation can solve certain scientific problems faster than even one of the most powerful supercomputers.

Traffic Alert
LEAD: Because of the St.
Patrick's Day Parade tomorrow, a number of streets in Manhattan will be closed.
The parade begins at 11:30 A.M. at 44th Street and Fifth Avenue and heads north to 86th Street.
Streets will close at 10:30 A.M. and reopen around 2:30 P.M.

LEAD: Twenty-seven people have been indicted on charges that they dumped thousands of tons of solid and hazardous wastes from New York City in Monmouth and Ocean Counties, officials said.


At the Bar;   Warning (from lawmakers): Never judge a lawyer by his matchbook cover.
LEAD: Until now, perhaps the most maligned entrepreneurs in this city were its ''tin men,'' the fast-talking aluminum-siding salesmen depicted in a 1987 Barry Levinson movie of the same name.
But if some newly proposed legislation is enacted, the tin men may be displaced by lawyers.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Thompson Has Toys 'R' Us
LEAD: After a six-year split, Toys ''R'' Us has returned its advertising account to the J. Walter Thompson Company.
The creative director for the campaign will be Linda Kaplan, who is responsible for the company's catchy old theme song, ''I'm a Toys 'R' Us Kid.''


OPEC in Strong Position at Meeting
LEAD: OPEC oil ministers will start a meeting on Friday in which they will wrestle with how to play a strong hand: essentially whether to settle for oil prices at about $18 a barrel or to try to raise them.


Christie's Sculpture Expert Resigns After Bid on Statue
LEAD: The head of the sculpture department at Christie's London auction house resigned on Wednesday night after it was disclosed that he had tried to buy a statue that is now on the market for an estimated $11.2 million for about $5,200, a Christie's spokesman said.


Elmer L. Hann, 89, Shipbuilder Who Helped in Japan's Recovery
LEAD: Elmer L. Hann, an American shipbuilding executive who was instrumental in rebuilding Japan's industry after World War II, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at Kuakini Medical Center in Honolulu.
He was 89 years old.

Hispanic Agents Maintain Bias Persists in F.B.I.
LEAD: More than a year after a Federal court found widespread discrimination in the Federal Bureau of Investigation, tensions are growing among Hispanic agents who were at the center of the landmark lawsuit, and many say they are now the targets of retaliation by the bureau.

LEAD: In another move to scale back operations, Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its mutual fund and individual investment services division to Salomon Brothers Inc. for $28 million.

Economic Scene;   U.S. Lessons For Soviet Reform
LEAD: DESPITE Mikhail S. Gorbachev's high standing abroad and his unopposed election as the Soviet Union's first Executive President, his popularity appears to be sinking like a stone with his own people as a result of his failure to deliver on his economic promises.


No Testimony by Hazelwood
LEAD: Capt.
Joseph J. Hazelwood's defense lawyers rested today without calling him to the stand to give his own description of the Exxon Valdez grounding, which resulted in the nation's worst oil spill.
After presenting one rebuttal witness, the prosecution also rested.
Captain Hazelwood, from Huntington, L.I., is charged with one felony and three misdemeanor counts stemming from the spill of nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil into Prince William Sound in Alaska a year ago.


Review/Film;   A Deranged Yuppie With a Thing for His Lover's Gun
LEAD: Kathryn Bigelow's police thriller ''Blue Steel'' gets off to a brilliant start as it introduces the bright, eager rookie Megan Turner (Jamie Lee Curtis) and meticulously examines the tools of her trade.
With fetishistic fascination, Ms.
Bigelow inventories every feature of Megan's brand-new uniform and, at the police academy's graduation ceremony, captures the tears of hope and idealism in her eyes.

LEAD: Why does the hound not bark?


License Issued to Seabrook
LEAD: As expected, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission today signed a full-power operating license for the Seabrook nuclear power plant in New Hampshire.
The signing came one day after the plant's opponents, including the State of Massachusetts, failed to persuade a Federal appeals court to issue a stay blocking the license.


Brady Sees Bigger Role For S.E.C.
LEAD: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that the Administration was studying plans to enlarge the jurisdiction of the Securities and Exchange Commission that would strip at least some authority from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Dow Gains 7.88 Points; Volume Sags
LEAD: Stocks marked time yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 7.88, to 2,695.72, in the fourth day of light volume this week.
With interest rates on bonds remaining almost unchanged, traders had no clear sign of the way stocks might go.


Review/Film Festival;   Okinawan Folk Hero Fights The Good Hopeless Fight
LEAD: This year's New Directors/New Films festival begins this evening with Go Takemine's ''Untamagiru,'' a colorful, satiric but often obscure variation on what is said to be a famous Okinawan folk legend.
The film will be shown at the Museum of Modern Art at 6 P.M. and again at 3 P.M. on Sunday.

LEAD: Davidoff International, whose Havana cigars are among the most expensive and prestigious in the world, has formally ended relations with Cuba.

Investigators For Schools Are Criticized
LEAD: In a stinging report issued yesterday, the commission examining the New York City public school system said the work of the Board of Education's chief investigative arm was ''reminiscent of the Keystone Kops'' and deserved blame for much of the corruption and crime within the system.


After 17 Years, Panther Conviction Is Upset
LEAD: The conviction of a former leader of the Black Panther Party on attempted murder charges in the machine-gun attack on two New York City policemen in 1971 was reversed yesterday by a State Supreme Court justice.
He ordered a new trial.


Shell Oil Cleanup
LEAD: The Shell Oil Company, the nation's sixth-largest oil company, is planning to spend $7.5 billion in the next decade to clean up its operations, oil analysts said.
The amount would be one of the biggest environmental expenditure programs disclosed by a leading oil company.
Shell, a subsidiary of the world's largest commercial oil concern, Royal Dutch/Shell Group, plans to spend most of the money to revamp its seven oil refineries around the nation, analysts said.

LEAD: ''Macho Dancer'' wants to be a sexy homosexual film and to comment about social conditions in the Philippines at the same time.
But before long it's easy to discover the true interests of the director, Lino Brocka.


A Judicial Maverick Is Worn Down in Arkansas
LEAD: Since John Purtle left the Arkansas Supreme Court, its deliberations have gone far more smoothly.
His former colleagues can break for lunch sooner and wrap things up earlier in the afternoon.
Above all, there are fewer - far fewer - dissents.

LEAD: The bedrock legal principle of caveat emptor - ''let the buyer beware'' - applies just as much to ghosts as to shady Florida land deals, a judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday.

Terms were not disclosed.
J &amp; L said that it would keep its Pittsburgh headquarters and that the Paris-based Ugine would appoint a new board.

Corrections

Central City Chorus
LEAD: Charles Pilling will conduct the Central City Chorus in psalm settings and motets by Felix Mendelssohn and Johannes Brahms, and Mendelssohn's Organ Sonata No. 1, at 7 P.M. on Sunday at Central Presbyterian Church, 593 Park Avenue, at 64th Street.
The soloists are to be Elizabeth Pruett, soprano; Deborah Andrews, mezzo-soprano; Darrell Lauer, tenor; Richard Christopher, baritone, and Lawrence Maycher, organist.

Judge Medina Dies at 102

Reviews/Theater;   A Kaleidoscope of Language Onstage and on Video
LEAD: On one level, John Jesurun's ''Everything That Rises Must Converge'' is an incoherent play on the subject of language.
That fact alone says something about the difficulty of communication, which is at the root of Mr.
Jesurun's new work, a deeply layered multi-media theater piece that will leave audiences alternately fascinated and exhausted.


Orlando Joining the World League
LEAD: Orlando was awarded the first World League of American Football franchise today as the National Football League club owners concluded their five-day meeting here.


Review/Music;   Two French Church Organists in Recitals
LEAD: In France, the position of titular organist of a cathedral carries a kind of prestige that the closest American equivalent - a church organist post - does not quite equal.
The reasons are complex and culture-bound, but to a large extent the status of French church posts grows from the fact that so many of the organists who held them were also composers who left enduring repertories of organ works and liturgical settings.

Study Asks New Safeguards For Refugees Asking Asylum
LEAD: A new study by a public interest law group says that political considerations in the United States have undercut the humanitarian aims of the 1980 Refugee Act, and it calls for greater safeguards for those seeking asylum here.


A Drexel Brainchild Haunts 'Junk' Market
LEAD: A once-obscure bond, invented by Drexel Burnham Lambert to encourage financing for takeovers and leveraged buyouts, is now instead contributing to problems in the ''junk bond'' market.


Pepperell Acquires New Credit Lines
LEAD: West Point-Pepperell Inc. announced yesterday that it had established a new $1.2 billion credit facility with its major banks.
It includes a $550 million term loan and a revolving line of credit of up to $650 million.
They mature on Dec. 31, 1994.
Interest on both will be at 150 basis points more than the prime rate, and the interest rates will be automatically reduced if the company satisfies certain financial conditions.


Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday headed ''Philadelphia Journal,'' about a tourism campaign featuring Benjamin Franklin, gave an incorrect date for a funeral procession to commemorate his death.
It will be April 21; Franklin died April 17, 1790.

EFFORTS TO LIFT ERRANT SATELLITE
LEAD: Engineers tried to lift an errant $150 million communication satellite into a higher orbit today so it will not plunge back into the earth's atmosphere in the next few weeks.


Our Towns;   From Mean Turf To Green Lawns And Back Again
LEAD: It was Scott Fitzgerald who observed that the very rich are not like you and me - and not, as Hemingway retorted, because they have more money.
The same might be said of the very poor, and that, too, it is not merely a matter of money.


The First President
LEAD: Mikhail Gorbachev is not the father of his country but his election yesterday provokes contrast, and comparison, with the father of ours.
Mr.
Gorbachev, having already run the Soviet Union for five years, has now become its first full-fledged President. ''Prezident'' is the way some Russians transliterate the term, but the important difference between chief executives there and here is not one letter.

LEAD: Dr.
John Adrian Onderdonk Jr., chief of cardiology at the Chestnut Hill Hospital in Philadelphia, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Radnor, Pa.
He was 55 years old.

Man Charged in Killing Of Sister Over a Legacy
LEAD: The body of a woman found stuffed in a wooden crate last week at a bus stop on West End Avenue was identified yesterday as a Manhattan actress who the police said had been feuding with her brother over a family inheritance.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in Sports Pages on Tuesday about the funeral of Hank Gathers, the Loyola Marymount basketball player, misidentified the housing project where he grew up and the college for which his brother Derrick plays basketball.
Mr.
Gathers lived in the Raymond Rosen Projects in Philadelphia.
His brother plays for California State Polytechnic University, Pomona.

Guam Approves Bill Posing a Challenge To Abortion Ruling
LEAD: Nearly 9,000 miles from the Supreme Court, on the Pacific island of Guam, a territorial legislature has passed the most restrictive abortion legislation in the United States, a measure that explicitly challenges the constitutional right to abortion that was established in the landmark Roe v.
Wade case.


Review/Television;   Telling the Story of Monty Python, in 2 Episodes
LEAD: When the Monty Python troupe celebrated its 20th birthday last year, two documentaries were made by Tiger Television for the BBC for the occasion.
They are now being presented on the Showtime pay-cable channel under the very appropriate umbrella title ''20 Odd Years.'' The first part, produced by Mark Redhead, is ''Life of Python,'' a collection of interviews with the performers, whose recollections are illustrated with clips from their television shows and films.

LEAD: Holders of defaulted bonds of the Washington Public Power Supply System could receive as much as 32 cents on the dollar or as little as 10 cents under an agreement announced today by two groups sharing a $753 million settlement fund.

Review/Film;   Another Incarnation For 'Lord Of the Flies'
LEAD: William Golding's ''Lord of the Flies,'' long a fashionable novel with adolescent readers or others with a taste for broad allegory, is now a fashionable-looking film.
Shot in lavish color (unlike Peter Brook's much more stark black-and-white 1963 version), and so thoroughly Americanized that its characters bring with them the kind of light-sword used in ''Star Wars'' and make reference to the television show ''ALF,'' this ''Lord of the Flies'' features a cast of young actors seemingly chosen on the basis of lean physique and languid good looks.


Apple Expects Strong Results
LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. said today that financial results for its second fiscal quarter, which will end March 30, will be better than previously expected.


VATICAN RESUMING TIES WITH MOSCOW
LEAD: The Roman Catholic Church and the Soviet Union re-established permanent official contacts today in a move that was expected to lead to a papal trip to the Soviet Union.


Explosion in Rural Hamlet Raises Troubling Questions
LEAD: Robert Shaffer first thought the strange white cloud might be fog.
Then the ground shook.
The air exploded.
Flames flashed.
A few hours later, after the fires died and the smoke cleared, eight homes in this rural hamlet, 40 miles southwest of Albany, lay charred and in rubble.


Review/Art;   Extremes of Sculpture in 3 Bruce Nauman Shows
LEAD: For nearly a quarter of a century, Bruce Nauman has specialized in sculpture that is grating and challenging, that refuses to take maybe for an answer.
You may say yes, you may say no - you may say both in tandem.
But indifference to the artist's figurative fragments, or to his abrasive multi-media installations, or to the intimations of violence that run throughout his art, is not very likely.

Corrections
LEAD: An article by The Associated Press on Tuesday about a contract vote at the International Paper Company mill in Jay, Me., referred incorrectly to proceedings to remove the United Paperworkers International Union as bargaining agent for employees.
An employee, not the company, filed the petition with the National Labor Relations Board for decertification.


Rebels Said to Kill 19 in Peru
LEAD: Shining Path guerrillas shot and killed 19 peasants, nearly all of them women and children, in a small Andean hamlet where they had fled to escape rebel attacks in their own village, the police said today.
The reported massacre occurred late Tuesday in Pishupiaco, 60 miles southeast of Huancayo, a major trading center in the Andes 120 miles east of Lima.


2 Plays, $5, a Bargain
LEAD: At a time when theater ticket prices have reached $60, Playwrights Horizons is introducing a $5 ticket for two new productions at its second-floor Studio Theater at 416 West 42d Street.
This springtime bargain, called the New Theater Wing, begins with ''Subfertile,'' a comedy by Tom Mardirosian about an anxious man celebrating his 40th birthday with a museum dinosaur skeleton.

Church's Bomb Shelters to Be Inspected
LEAD: Local officials said today that they would begin making random inspections of bomb shelters owned by a church group whose members are ready to live underground because they fear an imminent nuclear attack.


Group Lifts Stake In Coles Myer
LEAD: An investment group led by Solomon Lew, the vice chairman of Coles Myer Ltd., has raised its stake in the Australian retailing concern to 21.7 percent from 17 percent.
The K Mart Corporation, the Troy, Mich., discount store chain, also controls 21 percent of the Coles Myer shares.
Coles Myer, Australia's largest retailer, operates K Mart stores in Australia and New Zealand.

Industries, its London-based parent.

LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds eased in very slow trading yesterday, as dealers took some profits after Wednesday's strong rally and awaited the release of new economic statistics.

The Editorial Notebook;   Just Wait Till 1990!
LEAD: President Bush's education goals for the year 2000 ring with all the certainty of old New Year's resolutions.
In 1983 President Reagan issued a set of goals that included reducing the high school dropout rate from 30 percent to 10, by 1990.
President Bush now calls for reducing the high school dropout rate from 30 percent to 10, by 2000.

LEAD: Two scientists here have developed a technique to identify genetic traits in livestock in advance, making it possible to plan with unheard-of precision the milk or meat production of animals before they are born.

LEAD: At the end of business today, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., whose parent filed for bankruptcy last month, will end its pricing service on more than 3,000 ''junk bonds,'' orphaning as many as 1,000 smaller issues in which other Wall Street dealers do not make markets.

Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 501 money market mutual funds increased by $60.3 million, to $390.77 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 154 institutional funds decreased by $789.5 million, to $91.01 billion.
The assets of the 245 general-purpose funds were up by $716.5 million, to $133.62 billion.

LEAD: The Xerox Corporation is offering $200 million in notes due in 2000 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

Drug Raid on Wall Street Bars
LEAD: Four bars in the Wall Street area were raided last night by plainclothes narcotic detectives who arrested 46 people on drug charges, the police said.


Lorraine Lester, Producer, 88
LEAD: Lorraine Lester, a producer who worked in theater, films and television, died after a heart attack on Wednesday in the Coronary Care Unit of the New Rochelle Medical Center.
She was 88 years old and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y.

Gansler Being Kept As U.S. Team's Coach
LEAD: Despite criticism from some players over his constant lineup juggling, Bob Gansler won a strong vote of confidence yesterday to retain his job as coach of the United States national soccer team.


Agency Votes to Sell Houses Owned by Savings Units
LEAD: The Oversight Board of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency managing the bailout of the nation's savings and loan industry, today approved its first program to sell the housing stock of failed savings institutions to low- and medium-income families.


Denying Pleas, Iraq Hangs British-Based Reporter
LEAD: Defying all calls for clemency, Iraq today hanged an Iranian-born British journalist it had convicted of espionage, in what Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher described as ''an act of barbarism deeply repugnant to all civilized people.''


Stuart MacClintock, Intelligence Aide, 70

He was 70 years old.

LEAD: Fifty-one years to the day after Hitler arrived here at the head of an occupying army, President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia today greeted the President of West Germany with a speech that equated anti-German feeling with anti-Semitism, and an offer to build a Europe free of recriminations.

Witness to Slaying Kills Assailant but Isn't Charged
LEAD: A man shot to death a killer fleeing a slaying at a shopping mall in the suburban town of Irving on Monday, the police said, but they have decided to not file charges against him.


Chronicle
LEAD: For two years JOHN F. KENNEDY JR. has worked on a program to provide additional training for people working with the handicapped.
Together with administrators at the City University of New York and health professionals, he helped develop Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities Studies, which started last month at the College of Staten Island.


Continental Air
LEAD: Continental Airlines, the Houston-based airline owned by the Texas Air Corporation, said it would add 100 daily flights, increasing its traffic by about 8 percent.
The company said the expansion, which is to begin on May 1, will include inauguration of service to four cities in the United States and three abroad and the addition of a series of late-night departures from its Houston hub.


Ruling Gives New Deduction To Thousands in New Jersey
LEAD: About 300,000 New Jerseyans who work in New York are entitled to a new deduction from their New Jersey taxes.

Soybean and Sugar Prices Rise on Rumor About Brazil
LEAD: Soybean and sugar futures prices rose sharply yesterday, partly reflecting fears that Brazil's new President will seek higher taxes and restrictions on exports of some of the country's principal commodities.

LEAD: After decades of paying their foreign obligations in full and on time, some Soviet companies are having difficulty making payments on contracts with Western suppliers, according to West German bankers and businessmen.


NBC Sues Columbia And Sony
LEAD: The National Broadcasting Company sued the Sony Corporation and its Columbia Pictures subsidiary today, charging that Columbia had sabotaged a joint venture with NBC to distribute home videos.

2d Raid on Late Flight in 2 Days Produces 53 More Illegal Aliens
LEAD: Federal immigration agents raided an Eastern Airlines flight today for the second time in two days and seized 53 more illegal aliens, including three Romanians, the authorities said.


American Airlines
LEAD: The AMR Corporation announced ambitious plans to spend $20.9 billion in the next five years to increase the size of its American Airlines fleet by about 50 percent, to 759 planes.
AMR's chairman, Robert L. Crandall, said in a speech on Wednesday to employees at American's maintenance center in Tulsa, Okla., that the plan depended on profits generated by the current fleet of 510 planes.

LEAD: The Soviet Parliament overwhelmingly rejected Lithuania's declaration of independence, but the resolution was stripped of vague threats of retaliation.

Threat Issued On Hostages
LEAD: A Muslim group holding three American professors hostage threatened today to kill them if the United States Government fails to meet its unspecified demands.


Maxwell Rejects Offer For Its Stake in Berlitz
LEAD: The Maxwell Communication Corporation said yesterday that it had rejected an offer for its 56 percent stake in Berlitz International Inc., the language services company that went public late last year.


Upheaval in the East;   Dissident Named Chief Of an East Berlin Party
LEAD: With the first free elections in this country only three days away, a conservative coalition allied with the West German Chancellor elected a longtime dissident as its leader today to replace a man who admitted he had been an undercover agent of the ousted Communist Government's secret police.


Oscar J. Youngberg, Accountant, 94
LEAD: Oscar J. Youngberg, a retired certified public accountant, died on Sunday at a nursing home in Huntington, L.I.
He was 94 years old and lived in Dix Hills, L.I.


CABINET IS OUSTED IN ISRAELI DISPUTE OVER PEACE TALKS
LEAD: The Israeli Parliament dissolved the Government today over Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's refusal to accept terms for starting Israeli-Palestinian peace talks that were suggested by the United States.


2d Lebow Brain Test
LEAD: A second brain biopsy is scheduled today at Mount Sinai Medical Center for Fred Lebow, the founder of the New York City Marathon and the New York Road Runners Club.


Hoechst to Buy A Carbide Business
LEAD: A subsidiary of the Union Carbide Corporation will sell a specialty chemical business to the Hoechst Celanese Corporation, a West German company, for an undisclosed price, officials said.
The Union Carbide Chemicals and Plastics Company said it had reached an agreement to sell its primary alcohol ethoxylates business.

LEAD: Women's History Month is being celebrated with a variety of events in New York City.
Here is a sampling of events this weekend.

Scientists Seem Nearer Their Dream for Hydrogen: Making It Metal
LEAD: Since 1935, scientists have dreamed of converting hydrogen into a metal with wonderful properties.
Now, physicists have reported here that they are a little closer to that elusive goal.


Drug Program Is Said to Curb Peer Pressure
LEAD: A drug prevention program that teaches high school students ways to resist social pressure can significantly curb marijuana and cigarette smoking, but not alcohol consumption, a three-year study by the Rand Corporation has found.


Bush to Streamline Advisory Panel on Intelligence
LEAD: President Bush will soon make major changes in his Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board, converting what has been a wide-ranging watchdog over the intelligence community into a far smaller panel of expert policy advisers, Administration officials said today.

The Cost of Fanaticism
LEAD: Nancy Klein of Long Island, 10 weeks pregnant, was severely injured in a car crash on Dec. 13, 1988.
For two months she was in a coma.
Doctors had little hope that she would come out of it, but they thought she might have a better chance if she had an abortion.
Her husband, Martin, told them to go ahead.

LEAD: rrNormally, at this time of year, we would all be fretting about one beloved baseball team or another trying to regroup amidst orange groves or cactus plants.

False-Alarm Apology
LEAD: Mike Abdenour, trainer for the Detroit Pistons, apologized to authorities in Auburn Hills, Mich., yesterday after pleading no contest in District Court to a misdemeanor charge stemming from a false emergency report.
Abdenour conceded having a call placed March 6 to the city's 911 emergency number to report that a Detroit player had collapsed during practice.


Review/Dance;   Reviving the Work of a Modern Pioneer
LEAD: The Third Annual Doris Humphrey Festival, which continues through Saturday night at the Pace Downtown Theater (Spruce and Gold Streets) allows dancegoers to see some rarely revived works by one of the pioneers of modern dance.
From the 1930's to the 50's, Miss Humphrey and Martha Graham were widely regarded as equally innovative choreographers.

The Instincts of Parenthood Become Part of Crack's Toll
LEAD: Crack can overwhelm one of the strongest forces in nature, the parental instinct, specialists in drug addiction say.
As a result, some of them say, the United States is giving birth to a new underclass of disadvantaged youth like none seen before.


Minister Resigns in India
LEAD: Deputy Prime Minister Devi Lal, one of India's most prominent political figures, resigned from Prime Minister V. P. Singh's administration today, threatening to split the ruling coalition.
Mr.
Lal, a peasant leader from the northern state of Haryana, did not give reasons for his resignation.
It followed a bitter campaign against him and his son, the Chief Minister of Haryana, by critics in the Singh Cabinet and the press.


Former National Security Aide Testifies Poindexter Distrusted Congress
LEAD: With the prosecution rapidly winding down its case against John M. Poindexter, a former aide to the National Security Council testified today that Mr.
Poindexter expressed his dislike and distrust of Congress as lawmakers were pressing him in 1986 to explain the White House role in aiding the Nicaraguan contras.

LEAD: The Control Data Corporation said today that its chairman, Robert M. Price, retired on Thursday but remains chairman of the company's board.

LEAD: An almost-silent film shot in the violent sandstorms of the Iranian desert, ''Water, Wind and Sand'' fulfills one purpose of the New Directors/New Films series: it is stylistically fresh and daring.
The story begins when an adolescent boy returns from working in a distant city and learns that his family has left its drought-stricken village.

Corrections

IRT Station to Take 2 1/2 Years
LEAD: The Transit Authority cut in half yesterday the schedule to rebuild the Intervale Avenue-163d Street station on the IRT White Plains Road line in the Bronx.
The board of the authority said the work would take two and a half years, instead of the estimated five years.
The stop has been closed since March 15, 1989, when a botched token robbery ended in a fire.

LEAD: Prices of coffee futures fell sharply yesterday on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York after the new President of Brazil announced sweeping economic changes.
Traders said the plan was likely to increase the sale of Brazilian coffee.

Studio-simulated song-and-dance extravaganzas made her a star although she never had performed her hits live.
Now, on her first tour as a headliner, she has to prove herself in real time.

LEAD: Dancers and athletes have often been described as embodying poetry in motion.
Now there may be music to go with the poetry.
The Yamaha Corporation of Japan, maker of electric pianos, has patented a musical instrument to be worn by performers that translates arm and hand motion into musical notes.

Vento, who had agreed to testify in exchange for immunity from prosecution, fled in December.

LEAD: The delinqency rate for home mortgages held steady in the final three months of 1989 after jumping sharply in the previous quarter, a trade group said this week.

British Jobless Rate Dips
LEAD: Britain's unemployment rate fell to 5.6 percent in February from 5.7 percent in the previous month, the Government reported this week.
The jobless rate stood at 6.8 percent a year ago, the Department of Employment said.
Without seasonal adjustment, the number of unemployed was 1.676 million in February, compared with a revised 1.687 million in January and 2.018 million in February 1989.


Mortgage Rates Are Up
LEAD: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 10.34 percent, up from 10.29 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.55 percent this week, up from 8.5 percent the week before.

Jazz That Speaks Latin, and Vice Versa
LEAD: Though jazz and Latin music have mingled regularly over the last century, their relationship has always been uneasy.
Despite their similar roots, their rhythms and sense of form are different, and from the 1940's on, their uses have separated.
Where Latin music, meant for dancing, is still essentially functional, jazz has long been content to use the vestiges of the dance impulse - riffs, swing - to keep the rhythms supple.

LEAD: In 1978, Air Wisconsin had a small fleet of aging, 19-passenger Swearingen Metro planes that shuttled most of its 397,000 riders that year to and from its hub in Appleton, Wis.
Just 12 years later, Air Wisconsin has become the nation's largest commuter airline.
Its turboprops and jets, with as many as 100 seats, carry more than two million passengers a year.

Down With Mass Culture

Livingstone
LEAD: To the Editor: In ''Ten Escapes to the Exotic'' (Travel, Dec. 24), Jane Perlez refers to David Livingstone as ''the English explorer.'' David Livingstone was born in Blantyre, Scotland, and should have, therefore, been referred to as a Scottish explorer.

Lake Bluff, Ill.

Fashion: On the Street;   Button-Down Set Is Loosening Up
LEAD: O.K., class, clear your desks; it's time for a quiz.
Today is March 18.
That means the season is: (A) winter, (B) spring, (C)summer or (D) all of the above.
The correct answer, as anyone who has been in New York City the last few days knows, is D. Those who are majoring in fashion appreciation also know that this is also called a transitional period, when the weather is a bit too warm for heavy winter wools but, most days at least, a little too brisk for lightweight clothes.


Time to Assess the Ravages of Winter
LEAD: DESPITE unusual spells of mild weather, part of it called the January thaw, this has been a rough winter for plants.
Gardeners who have been outside for their annual inspection may have been surprised to find that many of their plants, particularly the broadleaved evergreens, were burned.


Surgery for Driver
LEAD: A DAY after he crashed into a concrete barrier while testing a race car in West Palm Beach, Fla., Scott Pruett, the co-rookie of the year in the 1989 Indianapolis 500, was reported in fair condition yesterday at Methodist Hospital in Indianapolis, where he underwent surgery to repair multiple fractures of both legs.


Butterflies
LEAD: To the Editor: It was encouraging to read in ''A World of Butterflies in Florida'' (Travel, Jan. 28) that Coconut Creek visitors go home with information on the importance of native plants to native butterflies.
When preferred plants disappear, butterflies are at risk.
Adult butterflies sip nectar from many flowers - primarily yellow, orange, pink and purple ones - but the females require specific plants as host plants for their eggs and food for the caterpillars.


Digging In
LEAD: It could be that the de-Communization of Eastern Europe is naught but a Soviet ploy to lull the West into ill-defended complacency.
If so - and Elizabeth Clare Prophet believes it is - any Soviet invaders could be in for a surprise when they reach Paradise Valley, Mont.
There, Mrs.
Prophet, leader of the Church Universal and Triumphant, has assembled more than 2,000 of her followers and bade them prepare to sit out World War III in a huge complex of underground shelters on the church's 33,000-acre ranch.


NONFICTION
LEAD:
The quincentenary of Columbus's discovery of the New World is upon us, and Franco Cardini's EUROPE 1492: Portrait of a Continent Five Hundred Years Ago (Facts on File, $50) is disguised as a commemoration of that event.
More accurately, the book is a general treatment of European life at the end of the 15th century.


New Yorkers, etc.
LEAD: When Anne Meara was growing up on Long Island, she was convinced her family was like no other.
She had no intimate knowledge of other families, but she just knew that they and their beautifully modulated voices lived in perfect harmony in an atmosphere of sweet reason.
When she was a little older, she knew that romance wasn't romance unless there was background music and, in the distance, a sunset or some other bit of glorious nature.

Butterflies
LEAD: To the Editor: ''A World of Butterflies in Florida'' stirred happy memories of seeing butterflies last winter at Callaway Gardens in Georgia.
Seventy miles southwest of Atlanta, Callaway has the largest glass-enclosed butterfly house in the country.
Tropical vines and shrubs and cascading water plus computer climate control keep butterflies flying all year.

Review/Music;   Delafose's Traditional Zydeco Style
LEAD: John Delafose and the Eunice (La.) Playboys don't bother with any of zydeco's latest borrowings: no funk, no rock, no country-and-western, just the homegrown heritage of Cajun two-steps and waltzes tinctured with blues and rhythm-and-blues.
Wednesday night at Tramps, in the band's New York City debut, the closest thing he sang to a pop song was the Johnny Horton hit ''The Battle of New Orleans,'' from 1959.


China
LEAD: To the Editor: I read Carol Kramer's article ''China After Tiananmen Square'' (Travel, Feb. 18) with a mixture of fond memories and sadness.
Having completed a tour a few weeks before the Tiananmen incident, I relived our stay (and the guilt we felt when we first arrived) at the incredible Shanghai Hilton, our lovely hotel in Xian and the adventure of traveling on old Russian planes between cities.

Concert and Opera Arias (7)

Outdoors;   Deer Kill Down 6% In New York State
LEAD: Hunters in New York State killed 181,879 deer last fall, the state's Department of Environmental Conservation reported.
Although this was a 6 percent decrease from 1988, the number of bucks taken, 99,589, was a record high.
The previous record, set in 1987, was 97,595.

LEAD: What others discard - plastic six-pack rings and torn fishing line - Irene Neal gathers to make jewelry.

Forget Lions and Lambs, Try To Get Birds to Feed Together
LEAD: WHEN peace comes it will be ushered in on my bird feeder.
Certain political pundits, pondering peace, suggest that recent events in Eastern Europe presage an era of peace; soon the Messiah will ride through the Brandenburg Gate on a white donkey.
I know differently.
The age of peace will not arrive until the occupants of my bird feeder get their act together.

For an Off-Season Taste Treat, Roasted Tomatoes
LEAD: IF you yearn for the taste of tomatoes but are unimpressed by their quality at this time of year, try roasting them.
Ripe hothouse or hydroponically grown tomatoes taste wonderful when cooked this way.
They look a mess but they develop an intense flavor, sweet yet sharp, and almost carmelized.
They are good with almost any food that likes the flavor of tomato.


JULIA ROBERTS FACES A TEST OF CHARACTER
LEAD: In Garry Marshall's new romantic fantasy, a pretty woman is seen walking down the street, and she is indeed - as Roy Orbison sings - the kind you ''like to meet.'' But in this post-modern Cinderella story, with Shavian overtones and Los Angeles locales, the heroine happens to be a hooker.
And the man who would be her Prince is a mendacious corporate raider whose only regal trait is a passion for opera, specifically Verdi.


LINDA FAIRSTEIN VS. RAPE
LEAD: As the 1972-73 coordinator of the Rape Prevention Committee for NOW-NYC, I was pleased to read ''Linda Fairstein vs.
Rape'' (Feb. 25).
At the time of our campaign to have a rape unit established, the District Attorney's office operated on a rotation system.
Any woman brave enough to press charges against a rapist would be assigned to whatever lawyer was next in the rotation line.

Fashion;   The Urban (and Urbane) Spring Sandal
LEAD: This spring, women's sandals have been re-invented so that they can be worn to the office, and the platform shoe, an icon of the 40's, has returned.
What's common to both styles is the muted colors: peach, lemon, olive and creamy tomato.
This season, many of the freshest styles are also affordable, selling for less than $100.

LOVE AS A BURDEN, A CALLING AND, SOMETIMES, A CATHARSIS
LEAD: Centuries ago, an Irish poet, a woman whose name has been lost, wrote:
My love is no short year's sentence.
It is a grief lodged under the skin
Strength pushed beyond its bounds;
The four quarters of the world,
The highest point of heaven.
It is
A heart breaking or
Battle with a ghost,
Striving under water,
Outrunning the sky or
Courting an echo.

LEAD: A DESERT SCENE IN WHICH MILlions of dollars change hands under a tent seems better suited to an oil-rich sheikdom than an Arizona polo field called Horseworld.
Compounding the strangeness is that the commodity being bought and sold here is not the four-legged means of transportation of years gone by, but the machines that made them nearly obsolete - automobiles.

ALL ABOUT EVERYTHING IN JUST ONE COLUMN
LEAD: It must be some peculiar twist in the DNA that drives human beings toward extremes of every sort.
In politics, whole nations will periodically swing from soul-numbing repression to nearly chaotic freedom, or back again.
One school of rigorous poets finds in the 17 syllables of haiku the secret of the universe, while another believes truth is only revealed in random, half-conscious verbiage.
