Balloon Shorts Out 7,000
LEAD: An aluminum St.
Patrick's Day balloon floated into a substation this afternoon and caused a short-circuit that left more than 7,000 homes in Waterbury, Cheshire and Wolcott without power.
A Northeast Utilities spokesman said crews had to do extensive work before power was fully restored just before 4 p.m.


WARSAW ALLIANCE SPLIT ON GERMANY
LEAD: The Foreign Ministers of the Warsaw Pact, meeting here under new, democratic conditions, failed to agree today on whether a united Germany should be neutral or aligned with the West.
The Soviet Union was left alone in its rigid opposition to Germany's membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

&gt;More Than a Potato, A Lesson in Life
LEAD: LIKE many New Jerseyans, I have a vegetable garden out back.
I grow a half-dozen tomato plants, a few rows of beans, some zucchini - a vegetable smorgasbord.
I get a deep satisfaction from working the soil and making things grow.
And in raising a portion of our food organically, I enjoy the feeling that I am doing something worthwhile both for my family and for the environment.

THERE IS NOTHING LIKE THIS DAME
LEAD: MAGGIE SMITH - OR DAME MAGGIE SMITH, TO USE HER NEWLY ACQUIRED TITLE - approaches the Hyatt Carlton Tower hotel in Knightsbridge, showily twirling her left arm in the air.
A grand theatrical gesture from a star whose career has shown no shortage of them?
Perhaps, but this time, there's an element of triumph in the motion: the notorious arm whose injury partly caused the Broadway postponement of ''Lettice and Lovage'' for a year, is on the mend, and Maggie Smith wants to illustrate its recovery with a flourish.


Currency;   Going in Two Directions
LEAD:
It was a week of inaction, with mixed results for the dollar.
The head of the Bank of Japan returned from a trip to Europe but did not act to raise the country's official discount rate, a move that most analysts have been expecting and feel is necessary to support a very weak yen.
So the yen fell a little further against the dollar.

For an Off-Season Taste Treat, Roasted Tomatoes
LEAD: IF you yearn for the taste of tomatoes but are unimpressed by their quality at this time of year, try roasting them.
Ripe hothouse or hydroponically grown tomatoes taste wonderful when cooked this way.
They look a mess but they develop an intense flavor, sweet yet sharp, and almost carmelized.
They are good with almost any food that likes the flavor of tomato.

Teresa is so pure of heart and soul that it appears unreal.
We don't believe her career ever comes first; it is people who come first.
She has helped us and our son by giving him a bonus of life for the last three years.

Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   Simple Dish That's Ubiquitous in Coastal Mexico
LEAD: There are dozens of dishes all over Mexico, especially in the coastal areas, that are a variation on this theme: Fish with vegetables and chilies.
Many recipes call for baking the fish and cooking the potatoes separately, then combining them with the rest of the vegetables and cooking further.
But the results are equally flavorful if the fish is cooked right along with the vegetables, which saves time and pots.

Lynne Katsafouros Friedman - T-Shirt Artist
LEAD: A dog is a dog is a dog and a cat is a cat is a cat - to non-dog and non-cat people.
But to the enormous fraternity of pet owners, their cats and dogs are as beloved as children.
It's therefore no surprise that when Lynne Katsafouros Friedman appeared in public last year in a T-shirt with a hand-painted poodle on it, strangers approached, and when they discovered she had painted it herself, asked if she would do one for them.

Question Of the Week;   Will the Rangers' Deals Lead To the Cup?
LEAD: The Rangers will win the Stanley Cup (hopefully soon and hopefully often) when we have put together a strong organization from top to bottom which works hard and develops its player talent. ''Deals'' can be an important ingredient in achieving success, but ''deals'' are only one part of a number of factors needed to succeed.

New York Area's Population Growing, but Graying Faster
LEAD: The population of the New York region will increase only moderately but grow significantly older during the next three decades, according to new projections.


Pieces Missing From the Picture
LEAD: To the Editor:


Budapest's Grand Design
LEAD: IF each city has its niche in time, then the turn of the century is where Budapest naturally belongs.
It has the boulevards and the opera, the cafes and the trams, the public gardens and private villas.
And now, as another era and another century come to a close, it is showing signs of the same freneticism and languor, the same eagerness to do business and seek pleasure that characterized its golden age in 1900.


The Price of Lithuania
LEAD: To the Editor:


Prize-Winning Pianist Returning to Greenwich
LEAD: IN 1979, at the age of 11, the Korean-born pianist Ju Hee Suh made her debut with Zubin Mehta and the New York Philharmonic.
Five years later, she appeared with the Greenwich Symphony, and now barely into her 20's, the prize-winning performer is returning to Greenwich to play Rachmaninoff's Second Concerto.


THE CASE FOR GRAD SCHOOL
LEAD: In response to ''About Men: A Case For Grad School,'' by Mark McGurl (Feb. 18), I pity the writer for his self-deprecating reaction to the relative successes of his former girlfriends.
Life is strange, entropic for either sex, and we must fight the inclination to pit ourselves against our fellow humans and against the mentality that promotes such a limited understanding of other people.


THE NATION: S &amp; L Politics;   And Who Did What With the Money?
LEAD: THE Government has initiated scores of civil and criminal lawsuits against financiers whose savings and loan associations went bankrupt.
Some have been indicted, some have been acquitted and many have shifted their energies to other kinds of business.


Directors Walk a Fine Line
LEAD: To the Editor:


Starting to Mend
LEAD: THE Phoenix Suns guard Jeff Hornacek underwent successful arthroscopic surgery yesterday to remove torn cartilage in his left knee, the team announced.


Pan Am Flight 103: The West German Tie
LEAD: Two months before Pan Am Flight 103 crashed into the village of Lockerbie, Scotland, killing 270 people, the man who fashioned the bomb that destroyed it and other terrorists were seized in West Germany and almost immediately released, two writers say.
After the crash, they charge, the West Germans moved to conceal their errors from investigators.


Prague's Fine Vintage
LEAD: PRAGUE this spring has a supplementary reason for feeling like a city woken from a bad dream to a world full of promise and delight.
Its wine cellars are stocked with the 1989 vintage, one of those that almost sing with perfume.
The pale-gold glassfuls from the taps of its wine taverns have the rare quality of effortless excellence that harks back to the days before brand names and back-labels or indeed labels at all.

Paul J. Aronson.

Richard D. Leonard, a Unitarian minister, officiated.

Blossoms and Bullets
LEAD: There's a touch of spring in the air in New York City and something else, too: stray bullets.
One day last week, one struck Amy Rosen while she ate her lunch in Central Park.
That evening, another struck Loretta Rivera as she walked home from a pizza parlor in Brooklyn.
Dr.
Rosen, luckily, survived her chest wound.

LEAD: On his trip to southern Africa next week, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d will encourage Nelson Mandela to continue his campaign against apartheid and will also urge the black leader to abandon socialist economic principles, a senior State Department official says.

THE CASE FOR GRAD SCHOOL
LEAD: Last year I got a B.A. in philosophy.
Now I am waiting tables, writing, and taking pictures; it's a beginning.
I'm not sure what will come of it, but I do know that I won't spend my years parading other people's causes, not that it's not useful, it's that I've made other choices.
Nor will I wear $200 paisley ties, the usefulness of which I would call into question.

Pan Am 103: The High-Tech Terrorist
LEAD: AHMED JIBRIL, A PAUNCHY , avuncular man with a fondness for colorful sports clothes, was born in 1937, in the village of Yazur, near Jaffa, in what was then Palestine.
After the 1948 Arab-Israeli war, he left with his family and settled in Syria.
In Damascus, he attended the military college, becoming a demolition expert.


Cashing In
LEAD: Over the last few years in the entertainment industry, independent record companies have been selling like food during a famine.
Geffen Records, one last independents left on the shelf, has been the focus of a shopping war in recent months as much for the talents of its owner, David Geffen, as for its roster of artists, which includes Guns 'n' Roses, Aerosmith and Ricki Lee Jones.

LEAD: A terrorist group has claimed responsibility for the fatal crash of two United States helicopters and the bombing of a discotheque, and it threatened more attacks on Americans and United States property.
The group calls itself the December 20 Movement after the date of the American invasion of Panama.

POSTINGS: Joint South Jamaica Effort;   Luring Business
LEAD: To attract private investment to South Jamaica, Queens, New York State's Urban Development Corporation is teaming up with the Greater Jamaica Development Corporation to come up with benefits that companies might enjoy by moving their operations into that economically depressed neighborhood.
The two groups will spend $66,700 over the next eight months on outside consultants who will conduct a feasibility study to see if a seven-acre site at Liberty Avenue near Tuckerton Road could be used for food-processing companies.


A Collection of Sculpture Easy on the Eye, and on the Intellect
LEAD: A GOOD title being hard to find, the Gallery at Hastings-on-Hudson must be congratulated for '' 'Lite' Works,'' because the show of sculpture it identifies contains at most a couple of calories.
To put it another way, the art is as easy on the intellect as it is on the eye and mainly this is because the eight sculptors involved use materials that call for neither a vast studio space nor an arsenal of tools.

There are no official statistics.

LEAD: MEN.
YOU CAN TAKE them anywhere, but you can't dress them up.

LEAD: ''PRAGUE THE GOLDEN'' was always beautiful, but for the last 21 years the mood was sullen, brooding, resentful.

Pipeline to Open at Blast Site
LEAD: A pipeline that ruptured and allowed propane to leak and explode last week will be put back into service within a month, long before investigators know what caused the explosion that killed two people, officials said.
Officials at Texas Eastern Products Pipeline Company of Houston said the rebuilt pipeline will be tested by running water under high pressure through the line from Watkins Glen to Selkirk, where the pipeline ends.

It was completely acceptable for an interpreter to change instrumentation, notes or anything in the score, as long as what the performer felt was the message of the music was coming through.


What's Doing In: Warsaw
LEAD: Warsaw wears its woes more prominently than its wonders.
It seems at times to have more coal grit to coat its soulless apartment blocks than sunlight to bathe its golden Old Town.
But this year the city is wrapped in a sense of history being built day by day, which visitors can feel even behind unappealing facades.

LEAD: KILLEEN, TEX., IS HOME TO about 68,000 people and the Army base at Fort Hood.

On the bright side, however, is miniature golf, whose image in Killeen is undergoing state-of-the-art refurbishing.

Pastimes;   Around the Garden
LEAD: For This Week: This is a good week to use fertilizer, especially on woody plants and lawns.
But it is too early to remove winter protective mulches from garden borders, flower beds and younger plants; wait.
Prune roses when forsythia blooms.
Try sharp smelling spice or ground red pepper to discourage squirrels, mice, rabbits and other furry invaders from damaging flowers and plants.


China
LEAD: To the Editor: I was very distressed to see the article about China on Feb. 18.
We have been told that many people suffer unfairly when sanctions are applied, but now we understand that they have been very successful in helping to bring about the beginning of the end of apartheid in South Africa.

Should the Poor Get the Housing That Koch Built?
LEAD: A SINGULAR achievement of former Mayor Edward I. Koch's last term was the creation of a huge housing program, which has already produced about 3,500 new subsidized apartments in formerly abandoned buildings in New York City's poorest neighborhoods.
About 13,000 other apartments are under construction, and a total of 47,000 are to be renovated by the mid-1990's.

Review/Theater;   'Spare Parts,' and Baby Makes Four
LEAD: Lois and Jax, the embattled protagonists of Elizabeth Page's comedy ''Spare Parts,'' are a lesbian couple who decide, without really thinking ahead, to have a child.
As the play opens, Lois is making love with Henry, a young man she has picked up in a bar and gone home with for the sole purpose of insemination.


Seven City Hostelries
LEAD: WHEN Archduke Otto of Habsburg recently revisited Hungary on two separate occasions, he stayed at the Gellert Hotel on the west bank of the Danube River.
It was the newest and most sumptuous establishment in town when he was last in the country - in 1918, as a 5-year-old prince.
If, like the Archduke, you are the son of the last Emperor of Austria-Hungary, and if, furthermore, you are able to enchant Hungarians by your fluency in their language, as the 77-year-old Archduke and member of the European Parliament does, you can presumably pick your own hotel even on short notice.

But the Rangers will lose in the Wales Conference championship to either Buffalo or Montreal.

LEAD:
VERGING ON THE PERTINENT.
By Carol Emshwiller (Coffee House Press, Paper, $9.95.) When the aliens land, I hope Carol Emshwiller is around to explain what's up with Earth women these days.
She certainly knows how to take the Martian view of ordinary domestic life - how to get at the truth of things by rendering them strange.

POSTINGS: A Bid for Restoration;   The Kings Of Flatbush
LEAD: One of New York City's grand old moviehouses of the 1930's, the Loew's Kings Theater, or ''The Kings'' as it was more commonly called by the residents of Brooklyn's Flatbush neighborhood at that time, may be restored to its original flamboyancy if city officials have their way.
The city's Public Development Corporation is soliciting ideas about how best to use the theater, which has been dark for 12 years.

SHAPING A TRADITION
LEAD: Men's fashion moves forward not by leaps but by small steps, and changes are often imperceptible.
All the more reason to welcome the spring of 1990 as a season of real - and sometimes radical - shifts in style.
Conventional tailoring hasn't been scrapped so much as re-examined, with the emphasis on comfort, mobility and self-expression.


S &amp; L's: Big Money, Little Outcry
LEAD: BEFORE the decade is out, the Federal bailout of the savings and loan industry is expected to cost the Government more than $200 billion.
That is much more than the Government will spend on such critical social problems as preschool education, drug control and aid to the homeless.
It is more than will be spent on highways, air traffic control and pollution abatement.


Why Steinbeck's Okies Speak to Us Today
LEAD: The image of the dust bowl migration is imbedded in American consciousness, permanently linked to our memory of the Great Depression.
It was an epic event.
More than a million people, most of them dispossessed farm families, left the declining agricultural regions of Texas, Arkansas, Missouri and Oklahoma during the 1930's and moved west to California.

LEAD: MINOR wallboard damage - dents or small holes - is relatively easy to repair by smoothing spackling compound over the blemish and repainting the area.
But repairing large holes requires modest carpentry skills and sometimes ingenuity.

LEAD: PERHAPS it was my unexplained Easterner's fondness for the Midwest or had something to do with the approach of my 50th birthday, but as soon as I heard a friend's enthusiastic recounting of his marathon bicycle ride clear across Iowa I knew that this was something for me.

LEAD: WHEN New Jersey's first Federal prison opens its gates next month, officials say, it will be an example of enlightened penal philosophy - a structure without surrounding walls or guard towers.

China
LEAD: To the Editor: It seems ironic that China would attempt to exploit the art of the Buddhist religion (''Serene Haven of Buddhist Art,'' Travel, Jan. 14) after having so devastatingly destroyed much of the art of Tibet.
Unfortunately, suppression of the Tibetan people continues and we see no evidence that persecution has in any way lessened over the years.

THE INNER SANCTUMS OF THE NEWARK MUSEUM
LEAD: If there is any reward in architecture to staying the course, it is to be seen right here on Washington Street, where the Newark Museum has recently completed a $21 million reconstruction and expansion.
The architect the museum hired was Michael Graves - not the internationally famous Michael Graves of today, architect of Whitney Museum additions and Walt Disney World hotels, but the young and struggling Michael Graves of 1967, a faculty member at the Princeton University School of Architecture.

LEAD: Night after night, the games were dropped, the chances at points slipped away.

LEAD: Even though President Roh Tae Woo has formed an overwhelming legislative majority by merging two opposition parties into his ruling party, he was unable to break a deadlock on major bills in a special session of Parliament that ended this week.


Chavez Wins in Final Round
LEAD: Julio Cesar Chavez knocked out Meldrick Taylor in the final seconds of a spirited 12-round bout between junior welterweight champions here at the Hilton Hotel tonight, but it was a controversial ending.
Chavez was behind on two of the judges' cards at the time that Referee Richard Steele stopped the fight with just two seconds remaining.

NONFICTION
LEAD:
NIGHT AND FOG.
By Arne Brun Lie with Robby Robinson. (Norton, $18.95.) Half of ''Night and Fog'' is the story of the Norwegian Arne Brun Lie's year as a political prisoner of the occupying Nazi Government.
The other half is the story of how Mr.
Lie got up the nerve to talk about that year.
The two halves run alongside each other the length of the book and somehow never quite cohere.

LEAD: News organizations will have a hard time informing the public if they are routinely hauled into court to produce notes or unused television footage about a crime or accident that becomes the subject of court action.

Mortgage Delinquencies
LEAD: The delinquency rate for home mortgages held steady in the final three months of 1989 after jumping sharply in the previous quarter, a trade group said last week.
The group, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, said a seasonally adjusted 4.99 percent of mortgage payments on homes that house up to four families were late by 30 days or more.

LEAD: In a re-education camp during the Chinese Cultural Revolution, a guard asks a prisoner to identify the melody he's playing on a makeshift wind instrument.
The hapless man blurts out ''Mozart,'' then quickly saves himself by adding, ''It's a song called 'Mozart Dreams of Mao Zedong.' '' Though ''China, My Sorrow'' is not always so pointed or witty, it is a deft and oddly lighthearted tribute to the traditions and spirit of freedom that survived the Cultural

Review/Concert;   At Fisher, a Group From Beethoven's Hometown
LEAD: With the inexorable movement toward reunification of Germany, Bonn's days as a national capital appear to be numbered.
As the birthplace of Beethoven, however, the city retains an older, subtler distinction, which it continues to wear proudly despite the awkward fact that the composer high-tailed it permanently to the headier musical atmosphere of Vienna at the age of 21.

LEAD: AS 1989 ended and the new year began, Sharedata Inc. was struggling to survive after the loss of the only profitable products it ever had, computer game versions of the popular television shows ''Wheel of Fortune'' and ''Jeopardy.'' Insiders were funneling in cash, and the company was paying interest rates of up to 30 percent to keep the doors open.

How to Find Minority Teachers
LEAD: Eight of every 10 New York City public school students are from minority groups while 7 of every 10 teachers and principals are white.
Should there be somewhat closer correlation?
Surely yes.
That's the goal of a comprehensive affirmative action plan for hiring and promoting more minority employees now under consideration by the Board of Education.

Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''I voted in genuine secrecy.
No one told me in advance how to vote, and I have no fear of immediate reprisals tommorrow at work for voting the way I wanted.
In my heart, I feel as if I just voted for the first time.''
-Christoph Schoppe,
a cattle rancher in

The geographic location he explained by pointing south and saying, ''The Comoros and then away, away, South Africa.

British Growth Rate Off
LEAD: British economic growth was cut in half last year, according to official figures released Friday.
Gross domestic product, which measures goods and services produced, grew by 2.3 percent last year, compared with a 4.6 percent increase in 1988.
The increase last year was slightly above a forecast of 2 percent by the Chancellor of the Exchequer, John Major, in November.

LEAD: When Sir Michael Tippett, modeling his oratorio ''A Child of Our Time'' (1941) after Bach's Passions, sought a contemporary counterpart of the Lutheran chorale, universal for the age in significance and appeal, he found it in the American black spiritual.

LEAD: A group of conservative parties, led by the Christian Democrats and actively supported by Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, scored a surprising victory on Sunday in the first free election in East Germany.
The eastern Germans had not freely cast their ballots since Hitler abolished the Weimar Republic after coming to power in 1933.

LEAD: In Melbourne, Australia, in the mid-1950's there was a rabbit blight.

Nobel Prize Money Increased
LEAD: The money awarded to Nobel Prize recipients is being raised to $653,000 from $489,000, the head of the Nobel Foundation was quoted as saying today.
The foundation is hoping to return the ultimate value of the award to what it was worth in 1901, when it was created by Alfred Nobel, said the official, Stig Ramel.


Walter S. Mack, Who Made Pepsi The No. 2 Cola Maker, Dies at 94
LEAD: Walter S. Mack, the former president of Pepsi-Cola who made it the nation's No. 2 cola drink in the early 1940's, died of heart disease yesterday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 94 years old.

LEAD: The chairman of the Senate Budget Committee called today for a $20 billion cut in military spending for next year, $5 billion deeper than one he suggested only two weeks ago and nearly twice the size of the cut the Bush Administration has indicated it will now accept.


Flooding in Alabama Leaves 3,700 Homeless
LEAD: Two days of flooding across southern Alabama have left at least 3,700 people homeless and killed nine others, and this town remained a muddy pond today after its levee failed.

Mr. Kohl's Divisive Appeal for Unity
LEAD: Voting in their first free election since 1932, East Germans commendably turned out en masse to register their desire for a quick, sharp break with their Communist past.
They threw their support behind right-of-center parties backed by West Germany's Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, who held out hope that rapid unification soon would bring economic prosperity.

LEAD: An almost intact baby mammoth, frozen for at least 12,000 years, has been found in Western Siberia, scientists have reported.

LEAD: Dealers in Treasury securities took some profits yesterday following the rally on Friday, but overall prices were narrowly mixed in sluggish trading as traders awaited reports due this morning on consumer prices and the merchandise trade deficit.

LEAD: Some environmental and safety officials say the recent rash of oil spills and accidents at petrochemical plants may be traceable to financial pressures on the petroleum industry in the 1980's that led companies to reduce skilled technicians and put an emphasis on cost cutting rather than flawless performance.

Norwegian Union Raises
LEAD: Norway's main union organization agreed last week to a basic 4 percent pay increase in 1990 as a result of central wage negotiations.
The deal was in line with the Government's aim to keep wage increases at or below the rate of inflation.
When talks opened a week ago, the Norwegian Federation of Trade Unions initially demanded an increase of up to 5 percent for its 350,000 members.

Coca-Cola Report On Profit Margins
LEAD: The Coca-Cola Company's profit margins widened last year in every region of the world except the home base in the United States, the company said in a report to shareholders.
Coke's operating profits as a percentage of sales in the slow-growing American market eased to 11.6 percent in 1989, from 11.8 percent the previous year, the report said.

A.T.&amp; T. Discounts On Long Distance
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it would offer a long-distance plan that would give customers the chance to save money on out-of-state calls.
Customers of the plan, called Select Saver, will pay $1.90 a month, plus low per-minute prices on all calls dialed directly to the area code of their choice.


Manhattan Legislator To Lead Schools Panel
LEAD: A heated internal battle over the selection of a new head of the influential Assembly Education Committee has concluded with the selection of Angelo Del Toro, a Manhattan Democrat, legislative officials said today.


Chronicle
LEAD: STIRLING MOSS, the former British race-car driver who won 222 races, including 16 Grand Prix events, suffered a broken thigh when he was hit by a car while riding his motor scooter in London yesterday.
It may take six months for the 60-year-old former champion to recover from the injury.
Mr.
Moss, whose career began in 1950, said he was driving at 20 miles an hour, on a trip to the market to buy coriander.

Dragon Introduces Voice 'Typewriter'
LEAD: A Massachusetts technology company introduced what it said was the first commercially viable ''typewriter'' that operates by human speech instead of touch.
Dragon Systems Inc. in Newton said its Dragon Dictate had a basic vocabulary of 30,000 words, with an 80,000-word dictionary built in as a backup, and could print out more than 40 words a minute when operated by an experienced user.


MORE SOUTHERNERS ARE FLEEING FLOODS
LEAD: Flood waters forced more people to flee their homes in Georgia and Florida yesterday and more than 150 National Guard troops patrolled Elba, Ala., where a levee gave way Saturday, flooding the town.

Poindexter's Reassurance on Aid Ban Is Recalled
LEAD: The former chairman of the House Intelligence Committee testified today the Reagan White House assured him in 1985 and 1986 that the National Security Council was obeying a Congressional ban on aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.


Saint Laurent Enters Hospital to Rest
LEAD: Yves Saint Laurent entered the American Hospital in Neuilly-sur-Seine on Saturday afternoon and will not be at his fashion show on Wednesday for the first time since he opened his house in 1962.
His physician, Dr.
Michael Prendeville, said the designer had suffered a major nervous collapse and had been advised to rest for several weeks.


The City's Diplomat
LEAD: The job of running New York City's ''foreign ministry,'' the liaison office to the United Nations, would challenge the most experienced diplomat.
It involves everything from helping U.N. delegates cope with New York's difficult housing market to resolving sensitive matters of diplomatic immunity.

LEAD: The entertainment company Really Useful Group P.L.C. said the Australian financier Robert Holmes a Court had bought a 4.18 percent stake, threatening the plan of the British composer Andrew Lloyd Webber to take the company private.
Mr.
Lloyd Webber is offering 233 pence, or $3.75, a share, for the stock.

Bailout Cost Seen Rising
LEAD: Financing for the bailout of the savings and loan industry will be at least $30 billion and possibly as much as $162 billion short of the amount needed, a Congressional report said today Legislation enacted in August provided $50 billion to close or sell failed savings associations through 1992.
But $48 billion of that will be needed to cover losses at the 383 institutions seized by the Government through March 5, said the report, which was submitted by Representative Bruce F.


Poland to Get U.S. Corn
LEAD: Poland will get United States corn instead of butter as initially announced under President Bush's $100 million food-aid package, the Agriculture Department said today.
F.
Paul Dickerson, general sales manager of the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said 173,225 metric tons of surplus corn would be donated to Poland instead of the 10,000 tons of butter originally specified.

The move will eliminate certain ''nonstrategic product lines and reduction of excess manufacturing capacity,'' the company said.

Phones Ringing (Eerily?) For Nyack Spook Home
LEAD: The phones have been ringing at real-estate offices in Rockland County.
A patient in a psychiatric hospital called.
So did a para-psychologist from Florida.
And so did the Amazing Kreskin, all the way from his hotel room in Atlantic City.


John D. Niles, 55, Dies; Partner in a Law Firm
LEAD: John Denison Niles, a partner in the law firm of Debevoise &amp; Plimpton in Manhattan , died of pancreatic failure, a complication of AIDS, yesterday at New York University Hospital.
He was 55 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Rig Count Falls in Week
LEAD: The number of working United States oil and gas rigs declined by 15 last week, to a total of 908, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today.
The decrease conforms to previous first quarters when the count generally was in decline, said Ike Kerridge Jr., an economist at Baker Hughes.
The count remains well ahead of the 1989 tally at this period.


Whitman To Focus on Food, Bottling
LEAD: The Whitman Corporation announced today that it planned to sharpen its focus on food and soft drinks by selling the Hussmann Corporation, a food-service equipment maker.
Whitman's board said the proceeds would be used to reduce the company's $1.8 billion debt and to pursue soft drink bottling or food industry acquisitions.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on the Media Business page yesterday about advance sales of television advertising misidentified the network that is developing a comedy series based on the film ''Big.'' It is CBS.

Susan Johnson, most recently at Ogilvy &amp; Mather, will join Lowe Marschalk as executive vice president and creative services director, and will coordinate such functions as print production, traffic flow and proofreading.

Review/Ballet;   San Francisco 'Sleeping Beauty' Underlines Russian Influences
LEAD: ''The Sleeping Beauty'' is a century old this year, and the San Francisco Ballet has both celebrated its anniversary and given itself a whopping present of a box-office success with a dazzling new version of the grandest 19th-century ballet created by Tchaikovsky and Marius Petipa.


Players Are Back and Eager to Play
LEAD: On the first day of baseball's belated spring training, after four weeks of warmth and sunshine and cool afternoon breezes, a half-dozen Yankee players gathered up their bats and gloves, walked slowly across the infield grass and began to work out.
Then it rained and thundered.
The rain did not stop until late in the day, until after the players had taken batting practice, had thrown a little, and then packed and left.


Perkin-Elmer Sells One Chip Unit
LEAD: The Perkin-Elmer Corporation yesterday took the first step toward spinning off its troubled semiconductor business by selling its electron-beam-technology division.
The buyer is a management team backed by six United States corporations, including I.B.M. and Perkin-Elmer itself.

Nanette Guilford, Met Opera Singer, Voice Teacher, 86
LEAD: Nanette Guilford, a soprano who sang at the Metropolitan Opera from 1923 to 1932, died of an intestinal infection on Saturday at St.
Vincent's Hospital.
She was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $200 million in floating-rate notes due March 23, 1995, through two co-managers, Morgan Stanley &amp; Company and Smith Barney, Harris Upham &amp; Company.

LEAD: Many doctors treating Medicaid patients in New York's poorest communities are incompetent or dishonest and sometimes do more harm than good for the ill, a Congressional panel was told today.

A Lucrative Crime Grows Into a Costly Epidemic
LEAD: The theft at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston on Sunday is the largest and latest in what art experts and law enforcement authorities are calling an epidemic of art thefts.
Spurred by soaring art prices and the increasing resourcefulness of thieves, art theft now ranks as one of the most lucrative forms of crime, they say.

Corrections
LEAD: An obituary yesterday about Terry Quimby, a former advertising executive in the fashion industry, misidentified a surviving daughter.
She is Elizabeth Timberman, not Pimberman.
The obituary also misstated the day of her death.
It was Saturday, not Friday.

Biologists Identify 'Impresario' of Life In Vitamin A
LEAD: The question of how a single fertilized egg blossoms into a complete human infant is one of the magnificent puzzles of biology, and scientists are just beginning to pinpoint the key genes and molecules that direct the intricate unfolding.
But in a rush of new experiments, researchers have made the surprising discovery that one of those crucial impresario molecules of life is not some exotic or arcane compound, but retinoic acid, a familiar derivative of vitamin A.

LEAD: Under heavy pressure from the turmoil in the stock market and a weak yen, the Bank of Japan ended weeks of speculation by announcing here at midday that it was raising its official discount rate a steep one percentage point, to 5.25 percent, its highest level since 1981.

LEAD: Prices of soybean futures rose sharply today on the Chicago Board of Trade amid talk of lower-than-expected Brazilian soybean yields and diminishing fears that Brazil's economic reforms will lead to a flood of soybean marketings.

Nike Profit Rises 29.3%
LEAD: The athletic shoe and apparel giant Nike Inc. said today that its profit for its third fiscal quarter climbed 29.3 percent from a year earlier as its revenue jumped 24.4 percent.
Nike said its profit totaled $63.1 million, or $1.67 a share, for its quarter ended Feb. 28, up from $48.8 million, or $1.30 a share, a year earlier.

Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption on Feb. 18, about a speech by Deng Xiaoping to the committee drafting laws to govern Hong Kong after China takes control, misidentified the man at the right.
A reader's letter, delayed in delivery, points out that he was Ji Dengkui, a former Deputy Foreign Minister, not Prime Minister Li Peng.


Throw Out The First Microwave
LEAD: In taking so long to agree on their labor treaty, the club owners and the players have invented microwave baseball.
Put the pitchers and the hitters in spring training for less than three weeks, set the timer for only two weeks of exhibition games, then hope their arms and bats are heated properly by April 9 when the season starts.


Talking Business; with Blaydon of Amos Tuck;   Easing the Cost Of M.B.A. Degree
LEAD: After seven years as dean of the Amos Tuck Graduate School of Business at Dartmouth College, Colin C. Blaydon announced recently that he would step down to write and consult.
A nationally recognized expert on corporate governance, Professor Blaydon is also interested in the future of management education.

Albatross Wanders Far Afield
LEAD: By attaching radio beacons to wandering albatrosses and monitoring them by satellite, French researchers have found that circular foraging flights by the birds sometimes exceed 9,300 miles, more than eight times the distance that had been assumed.
In some cases they cover 560 miles a day.

Lucie County Sports Complex cheered anyway.
Several minutes later, when HoJo strolled out of the batting cage, the fans applauded.

LEAD: THE latest round of trade negotiations between the United States and Japan is provoking rancor but few results.

Miss Snyder should know: for 12 years she has been teaching the art of English tea service throughout the state.

Sports People: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;   Illinois Player in Draft
LEAD: Jeff George, the Illinois quarterback, announced yesterday in Champaign, Ill., that he would forgo his final year of college eligibility to enter the National Football League draft.
College juniors must declare their intentions to the N.F.L. by tomorrow.
The 6-4, 216-pound George completed 474 of 789 passes in two years with the Illini, and his 5,189 passing yards placed him third among all Illinois quarterbacks.


Islanders' Loss Puts Rangers in Playoffs

LEAD: Jury selection began today in the trial of John Emil List on murder charges filed against him more than 18 years ago after the bodies of his wife, three children and mother were found in their Westfield home.
All had been shot.

Mobil Sells Unit
LEAD: The Mobil Corporation agreed to sell its Italian subsidiary, Mobil Oil Italiana S.p.A. to an affiliate of the state-owned Kuwait Petroleum Corporation for about $300 million.
Mobil Oil Italiana owns a refinery in Naples, an aromatics plant and about 2,000 service stations.
Mobil said the sale did not include its Mobil Chemical Company unit in Italy.


Credit Card Issue By MNC Financial
LEAD: MNC Financial Inc., a Baltimore-based bank holding company and one of the three largest issuers of credit card securities, yesterday priced a $500 million issue of these types of securities through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.


Census Peers Into Corners to Count Homeless
LEAD: Working through the night, census takers peered into the shadows of underpasses and derelict buildings and canvassed shelters, bus stations and doorways yesterday and today in the Government's first attempt to count the nation's most elusive group: the homeless.


VENEZUELA AGREES TO DEBT PROPOSAL
LEAD: Giving a lift to the Bush Administration's debt policy, Venezuela and its bankers announced agreement yesterday on the basic terms of a plan for debt reduction and new loans.


6 Hurt at British Oil Refinery
LEAD: An explosion and fire struck a major oil refinery early today, injuring six workers, the authorities said.
Firefighters brought the blaze under control at the Shell chemical processing plant at Stanlow about 10 miles from Liverpool, a spokesman for Shell U.K.
Ltd., said.
Ten people were in the plant at the time of the blast, and six were injured, including one person with serious burns, the BBC reported.

LEAD: The Atlantic magazine, combining a desire to report the rise in corporate philanthropy over the last decade and to increase advertising revenues, will publish an annual supplement called ''Private Profit Public Gain,'' which will be distributed with its September issue.

Power Fails Briefly At Nuclear Station; No Danger Is Seen
LEAD: A truck accident caused a failure of electrical power at the Plant Vogtle nuclear station in this eastern Georgia town today, but the resulting brief emergency did not affect the plant's safety, the Georgia Power Company said.


Metropolitan Diary
LEAD:
SPRING FASHIONS: NEW YORK
Once spring
lasted long enough
to be a real season
with its own coat
of navy blue.
That first sighting
equaled a splurge
of daffodils.
Spring came serenely
in stages of dress code.
Now it unfolds
haphazardly in maybe
two weeks of surprises -
forgetful of white gloves.

Time Limit Is Upheld For Suit in Tax Case
LEAD: The Supreme Court ruled today that a taxpayer may not sue for a refund of an erroneous Federal tax payment after the time limit for filing such suits has expired, even if the Government is to blame for the overpayment.

Robert E. Bondy, 94, Social Work Executive
LEAD: Robert Earl Bondy, a social worker who was a former executive director of the National Social Welfare Assembly, died of a stroke on Saturday at University Hospital in Tampa, Fla.
He was 94 years old and lived in Tampa.


Growing Use of Electricity Raises Questions on Supply
LEAD: Electricity use, up by 50 percent since the first oil crisis, in 1973, will continue to grow strongly in the next few decades, far outpacing the increase in non-electric energy, experts attending a conference at George Washington University here said today.


Treasury Bond Prices Up Sharply
LEAD: Treasury bond prices moved sharply higher in a volatile session yesterday, as traders gave more weight to rumors of significant Japanese purchases of zero-coupon Treasury bonds than to economic reports that suggested inflation was still a problem.


The Search for a Cleaner Way to Make Steel
LEAD: For years, steel industry executives have voiced a need for a way to produce steel without using air-polluting ovens that convert coal into the fuel known as coke to heat the blast furnaces.
But the issue has taken on new urgency now that Senate leaders and the White House have agreed, in clean-air legislation, to retain a deadline of 1995 for steelmakers to install stringent anti-pollution technology.


Tiny Primate, Feared Extinct, Is Discovered in a Rain Forest
LEAD: In a leech-infested rain forest in Madagascar, a West German biologist has found a long-lost, tree-dwelling relative of humans and apes, an event described as one of the most important rediscoveries of a mammal in a decade.

LEAD: It was a battle of the sexes in the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship here Monday night, and the women were winning most of the skirmishes.


Move Expected On Valvano
LEAD: A decision on the fate of Jim Valvano, the North Carolina State basketball coach, might be announced in the next day or two, according to a published report.


Trade Deficit Widened by Oil Imports
LEAD: The trade deficit widened to $9.3 billion in January as oil imports surged to refill stocks depleted during December's record cold, the Commerce Department reported today.
In December, the trade deficit totaled a revised $7.7 billion.


The Shape of Cabs to Come
LEAD: The Chevrolet Caprice, the boxy foot soldier for the New York City taxicab fleet and the nation's police departments, is getting a makeover.
The 1991 model, which is now on sale and will roll into fleet service this fall, is styled with aerodynamic curves more in keeping with the latest automotive fashion.


Review/Theater;   Revisiting the Humor of Smoking and Cholesterol
LEAD: Bad habits aren't what they used to be, and neither is ''Bad Habits,'' the twin bill of one-act plays by Terrence McNally that has been given a catch-as-catch-can revival by the Manhattan Theater Club.
In the distant year of 1974, when ''Bad Habits'' made its hilarious New York debut, the characters' vices of chain smoking, high-cholesterol gluttony, martini guzzling and sexual adventurism were regarded more as amusingly naughty acts of rebellion, however self-destructive, than as one-way tickets to the grave.


Mature Sanders Wins National Championship
LEAD: Summer Sanders won her first national swimming championship tonight.
But even that, she said, was not the best thing that had ever happened to her.


Auctioneers Underwrite Reward In Art Theft
LEAD: The Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum announced today that it would offer a $1 million reward for information leading to the recovery of the 12 masterpieces stolen from the museum on Sunday in what is believed to be the largest art theft in history.

Ames Suspends Annual Dividend
LEAD: Ames Department Stores Inc., which expects to post its first annual loss, suspended its annual 10-cents-a-share common stock dividend.
Ames's directors said the dividend would not be paid until the company became profitable.
Ames paid a quarterly dividend of 2 1/2 cents on Thursday.

FINANCE BRIEFS
LEAD:
Debt


Wine Talk
LEAD: A TASTING of vintage port is an experience in sensual overload.
Superficially, there is no difference between a port tasting and a red wine tasting; substantively, nothing is the same.
The richness, the power, the nuances of the ports are considerably harder to appreciate, and articulate, than those of the red wines.


Cardinal Accepts Discord on Abortion
LEAD: Joseph Cardinal Bernardin, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Chicago, said today that public officials, whether Catholic or not, who believe that abortion is wrong were obliged to pursue policies reflecting this moral conviction.
But he said there was room for legitimate disagreement on what that would mean in actual political practice.


New Generations Bring New Vision To Food Business
LEAD: THE food business in America came of age over the last decade.
In some families involved in the industry, members of a younger generation were also coming of age.
Today many of them are in charge.

LEAD: A convoy of 12 relief trucks crossed military lines in northern Ethiopia today to begin an operation aimed at feeding a million starving peasants in rebel-held areas.

Devils Stay Off Balance And Stumble to Flyers

Limousine 'Dumping'
LEAD: The Commerce Department issued a final ruling today that imported stretch limousines from Canada were being sold at less than fair value on the American market.
The ruling paved the way for possible anti-dumping duties on the cars.
If the United States International Trade Commission finds that the cars have injured American producers, duties of about 5 percent would be imposed to compensate.


Corrections
LEAD: Articles from March 8 through March 19 about a Brooklyn boy who was set afire gave an incorrect rendering of his surname initially provided by the family.
A family lawyer now says the name was changed from Aupont to Opont when the family of the boy, David Opont, came to the United States from Haiti.


The Behemoth and the Boson
LEAD: The price of the United States' latest atom-smasher has just jumped a little - from $5.9 billion to $8 billion - and the designs aren't even completed.
Before it leaps again, there's time for second thoughts.
This dinosaur of a machine may crush more fruitful kinds of physical research.


Reading Test Scores for New York City Schools
LEAD: Following are the rankings of New York City's 619 public elementary and 180 junior high schools released yesterday by the Board of Education.
The rankings are based on the percentage of students scoring at or above grade level on reading tests given in May 1989.


Retail Group Post Expected
LEAD: John J. Schultz, the former president and chief executive of B. Altman &amp; Company, is expected to be named president of the National Retail Federation's store services division, formerly known as the National Retail Merchants Association, retailing executives said yesterday.


Angola Sees Gain in a Free Namibia
LEAD: The President of Angola says independence for Namibia will give a military advantage to his Government in its long-running war with rightist rebels.


Upheaval in the East;   The Romanian Revolution Over, It's Back to Old Hatreds in Transylvania
LEAD: More than two months after a revolution that briefly united them, the Hungarians and the Romanians who live together in what is now Romanian Transylvania are once again locked in a centuries-old rivalry that is reviving nationalist fervor on both sides.


Frederick R. Clark, 73, Lawyer and a Banker
LEAD: Frederick R. Clark, a lawyer, banker and former chairman of the New York Power Authority, died of heart failure on Monday at Naples Community Hospital in Florida.
He was 73 years old and lived in Loudonville, N.Y., and in Naples.


Scheduling Problem Is Nearly Solved
LEAD: Major league officials, player representatives and CBS executives spent yesterday grappling with the calendar, trying to find a way to reschedule at least some of the six games that had to be scratched from the opening week of the season without unduly disturbing the network's fall programming plans.


National Meatless Day Attracts Only Scant Support
LEAD: NOT everyone noticed, but the sixth annual Great American Meatout was held yesterday, a one-day boycott of meat sponsored by the Farm Animal Reform Movement, a national advocacy group opposed to ''factory farming'' and in favor of vegeterian diets.

LEAD: The Rangers yesterday announced that they had agreed in principle to a contract with Rick Bennett, the highly regarded 22-year-old left wing from Providence College.

AAR Corp., Elk Grove Village, Ill., a maker of aviation products, said its AAR Financial Services unit had leased two Boeing 727-200 aircraft to Key Airways, a unit of World Corp.
Terms were not disclosed.

LEAD: This was supposed to be a down year for the haughty Atlantic Coast Conference, a fact apparently reflected in the unusually low seedings given its teams in the 1990 National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament.

LEAD: Evaluating schools in this country has always been a political battlefield.


Lawyer Asserts Boy Slain by an Officer Was Trying to Flee
LEAD: A lawyer for the family of a 14-year-old robbery suspect killed by a police officer in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn on Jan. 31 charged yesterday that the boy was running away from the officer when he was shot in the back of the head.

Upheaval in the East;   U.S., in Sharper Tone, Is Worried By Soviets' Pressure on Lithuania
LEAD: The White House sharpened the tenor of its statements on Lithuania today, saying an increase in the Kremlin's political pressure against the republic's independence movement was ''cause for concern.'' The Bush Administration called on Moscow to open immediate talks on self-determination with the Lithuanian Government.


Jersey City Biddy Team Loses
LEAD: The Jersey City Biddy basketball champions were eliminated from the national Biddy championships in New Orleans yesterday, but got an extra day to tour the city.
The state Biddy champs came back from a 16-point deficit to tie the game at 65, before losing 67-65 to Gary, Ind. ''They went down fighting,'' said Gary Greenberg, operations director of the Boys Club, which sponsors the team for 12- and 13-year-olds.

LEAD: Valentino clipped a couple of decades off the age of his clothes by the simple expedient of puffing out his skirts.

Reviews/Film Festival;   A Finnish Version of Small-Town Frustration and Violence
LEAD: When a mother locks her drunken, violent middle-aged son in the barn toward the end of ''Plainlands,'' it is the only positive action a woman takes in this Finnish film that suggests machismo can be translated into any language and culture.
The first feature by Pekka Parikka, an established television director, is a familiar story about aimlessness and barely suppressed violence born of small-town frustration.

LEAD: AN unusual warm spell in the East has seen an early run of the migratory shad, one of the season's great delicacies.
Preparing shad and its rich, distinctive roe is a seasonal ritual dating back to the American Indians.
Shad season runs for about five months along the Atlantic coast, beginning in the St.

Maloney-Evans, this slushy Sunday at Sugarbush's Mount Ellen Ski Area is her first outing on Alpine skis in nearly 20 years, and she admits to having had her doubts.

Real Estate;   Development Aids Cultural Institutions
LEAD: LAND development that spins off benefits for cultural institutions has a long history in New York City, going back at least as far as 1890, when commercial space was built into the Mercantile Library on Manhattan's Astor Place to help repay its construction costs.

N.B.A.
Schrempf Leads Pacers Past Heat
Detlef Schrempf scored 20 of his career-high 29 points in the first half last night as the visiting Indiana Pacers took a big lead early and ended a five-game losing streak with a 112-98 victory over the Miami Heat.
Six of Schrempf's 14 second-quarter points came during a 12-2 surge that made the score 48-27.


Avoiding Fire in Lithuania
LEAD: The last thing Soviet and Lithuanian leaders should want is a showdown over Lithuanian independence.
But that's exactly where they seem to be heading, as Soviet planes buzz Vilnius, the capital, and the leaders there continue to insist that Lithuania is already a separate state.

LEAD: More than 6,000 students and thousands of onlookers gathered in a city park today to demand greater democracy, and there were reports that the President would convene a national conference to discuss the pace of political change on the island.

LEAD: The Security Pacific Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent to acquire Santa Clarita National Bank for $52.5 million worth of Security Pacific common stock.


Marcos Art Sale Discussed
LEAD: The chairman of Sotheby Holdings Inc., A. Alfred Taubman, and the president of the auction house, Michael L. Ainsley, are in Manila, meeting with President Corazon Aquino of the Philippines to discuss the possibility of auctioning $100 million worth of art and jewelry collected by Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos, Sotheby's confirmed yesterday.

LEAD: The Outboard Marine Corporation reached an agreement in principle with the Grumman Corporation, based in Bethpage, L.I., to acquire assets of its Grumman Boats division.
The unit makes aluminum recreational boats, including canoes.
The terms were not disclosed.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about Kentucky Fried Chicken and rival chains misidentified the parent company of El Pollo Loco, a fast-food chain.
It is TW Holdings Inc., a publicly traded holding company based in Spartanburg, S.C.

LEAD: BRADLEY OGDEN, the chef who pioneered new-wave Americana at Campton Place Hotel in San Francisco, recently moved across the Golden Gate Bridge and reopened the historic Lark Creek Inn.
Nestled in Larkspur, a picture-postcard Victorian town in Marin County, the sprawling inn was built as a private home in 1888 and still has plenty of country charm.

Eastern Europe Loan Agency
LEAD: A plan to create an international lending agency to aid the recovery of Eastern Europe may be completed by July, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today ''There is a sense of urgency among our European colleagues,'' Mr.
Brady told a Senate Appropriations subcommittee, ''to get this job done'' by the time the economic summit meeting is held July 9-11 in Houston.

LEAD: SOMEDAY I hope to visit Santiago de Compostela, in northwestern Spain.
This historic city, at the end of a famous medieval pilgrimage route, houses the shrine of St.
James the Apostle.
It fascinates me because the route is marked by the emblem of St.
James, scallop shells.

LEAD: United States trade negotiators have been hammering away for years to open Japanese markets, yet many American companies, even giants like Citibank, the nation's largest bank, find Japan a daunting challenge.
They have discovered that the real problem is not so much governmental or cultural barriers, but that doing business here is too costly and competitive to justify a major effort.

He was 46 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Asea Brown Boveri Inc., the American electrical engineering giant formed when ABB Asea Brown Boveri Ltd. of Switzerland acquired Combustion Engineering Inc. in January, said yesterday that Gerhard Schulmeyer had been named president and chief executive officer.


Miniscribe Corp. Receives 3 Offers
LEAD: The Miniscribe Corporation, the financially troubled computer disk drive maker, has received three preliminary bids, its chairman, Richard Rifenburgh, said.
He said the company expects formal offers later this week.
Mr.
Rifenburgh would not disclose the bidders or their offers, but he said he was optimistic a deal could be reached.


Fannie Mae Prices 6-Month Security
LEAD: The Federal National Mortgage Association yesterday priced its first ever six-month debenture through its regular sales group of securities dealers.


Peres Chosen to Try to Form Israeli Cabinet
LEAD: President Chaim Herzog chose Shimon Peres, the Labor Party leader, this evening to take on the difficult job of trying to form a new Government.
The President urged Mr.
Peres to complete the task as soon as possible.


Stocks Fall in Brisk Trading; Dow Off 16.89
LEAD: Stocks fell in brisk trading yesterday after twice trying to stage an advance, with the Dow Jones industrial average breaking through 2,768 at one point before falling back sharply.


Tiny Primate, Feared Extinct, Is Found in Forest
LEAD: In a leech-infested rain forest in Madagascar, a West German biologist has found a long-lost, tree-dwelling relative of humans and apes, an event described as one of the most important rediscoveries of a mammal in a decade.


'Cat and the Fiddle' In a Concert Version
LEAD: A concert version of Jerome Kern's ''Cat and the Fiddle'' is to be presented in six performances starting on April 18 at 8 P.M. at Weill Recital Hall.
With original orchestrations, this is believed to be the first New York revival of the show since it opened on Broadway in 1932.


Central Banks' Intervention Fails to Halt Soaring Dollar
LEAD: The dollar soared higher in heavy trading yesterday, helped by profit taking in West German marks and in the Japanese yen.

Review/Television;   Tom Brokaw Looks At the Hollywood of Today
LEAD: How many movie biggies can be accommodated on a pinhead of a documentary?
That seems to have been the challenge of ''The New Hollywood'' the NBC Special tonight at 10.
Starting with the much advertised fact that the movie business is controlled by huge conglomerates and dedicated to smash hits, Tom Brokaw goes around asking hot producers, agents, directors and actors how they feel about the pressure to come up with blockbusters.


Eating Well
LEAD: MICROWAVE ovens have not been high on anyone's list of important safety concerns for several years now.
Fears that small children will be exposed to low levels of radiation escaping from poorly sealed doors seem to have died down.


The Avant-Garde Think Bodysuit First
LEAD: Think of spandex exercise clothes: tights and a leotard, or a one-piece bodysuit.
That's where it all starts.
Then add layers.
A parka or a T-shirt, an abbreviated sweater or a chiffon dress.
If you're feeling fairly sedate, you might wear a long tailored jacket.
You might even pull on a skirt, but it must be either micro-mini or nearly ankle-length.


Rep. Savage Claims Victory in Illinois
LEAD: Representative Gus Savage has claimed victory in the Democratic primary for nomination to a sixth term in Chicago's Second Congressional District after an unexpectedly strong challenge from a relative newcomer.


Debris From Secret Satellite Is Burning Up, Pentagon Says
LEAD: Debris from a secret American spy satellite has begun falling from space and burning up from the heat of re-entering the atmosphere, the Pentagon said today.


Geffen Starts A New Label
LEAD: David Geffen, who last week agreed to sell Geffen Records to MCA Inc. for $550 million in stock, said today that he had started a new record label that would focus on developing new artists.

O'Neill Decides He Won't Run For a Third Term in Connecticut
LEAD: Gov.
William A. O'Neill said today that he would not seek a third full term in office, citing the ''political realities'' facing him and saying he had no taste for the negative campaign tactics he believed necessary to win re-election.

LEAD: AFTER scrutinizing five disparate agencies for seven weeks, Continental Airlines yesterday appointed Wells, Rich, Greene, an agency built on airline advertising, to handle its nearly $50 million account.


Corrections
LEAD: An article by Reuters in Business Day yesterday misstated the position of the Securities and Exchange Commission chairman, Richard C. Breeden, on jurisdiction over stock index futures.
He has not demanded the power to regulate stock index futures; he has said there is an urgent need to resolve jurisdictional disputes over stock index products but has not made specific recommendations.

Capucine, 57, Dies; French-Born Actress In Films of the 60's
LEAD: Capucine, the patrician French actress who starred in international movies of the 1960's like ''The Pink Panther'' and ''What's New, Pussycat?,'' was killed on Saturday in a fall from her eighth-floor apartment in Lausanne, Switzerland.
She was 57 years old.


Budget Plan For Britain
LEAD: Amid growing criticism of its management of the economy, the British Government today presented a cautious budget, which is aimed at fighting inflation partly by encouraging Britons to save and by raising taxes on tobacco, alcohol and gasoline.


Fleurian Beats Fog-Bound Becker
LEAD: While Boris Becker gave too convincing an imitation of a noontime somnambulist, Jean Fleurian, an eccentric Parisian wearing his last pair of sneakers and shorts too new, too large and held up by a safety pin, was wide awake.


Precious Metal Prices Fall, With Gold Leading the Way
LEAD: Precious metal prices plunged yesterday as the dollar advanced against most leading foreign currencies.
A sharp rise in Japanese interest rates also made platinum, gold and silver more expensive to buy in that nation, which has become a major consumer as well as dealer in precious metals.


Founder May Take Gulfstream Public
LEAD: The Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation, which was sold on Monday to an investor group headed by its founder, Allen Paulson, will probably be taken public again in a few years to enhance the investors' profits, Mr.
Paulson said.


Burmese Military Is Forcing Mass Migration From Cities
LEAD: At least 500,000 Burmese are being forced to move from Myanmar's cities to new, ill-prepared outlying towns where malaria and hepatitis are rampant, diplomats say.


Upheaval in the East;   BONN WILL CUT AID TO EAST GERMANS WHO MOVE TO WEST
LEAD: Moving to stem the migration of East Germans to West Germany, the Bonn Government decided today to put an end to special reception centers and most benefits for East German resettlers on July 1.


Sports People: BASEBALL;   Shoulder Injury Forces Krukow to Retire
LEAD: Because of his continuing shoulder problems, Mike Krukow, the San Francisco Giants' only 20-game winning pitcher in the last 17 years, announced his retirement from basball yesterday.
Krukow, 38 years old, became a free agent last October after a torn rotator cuff injury that ended his season in June.

World Trade Grew in 1989
LEAD: International trade volume could slow slightly this year, with inflation and rising interest rates in industrialized nations hampering expansion, the world's main trade forum reported today.


Browns' Risien Retires
LEAD: Cody Risien, a right tackle with the Cleveland Browns for 11 seasons, announced yesterday that he was retiring because of family responsibilities and a string of injuries and operations.
Risien was a seventh-round draft pick in 1979 out of Texas A&amp;M and played in 146 games for Cleveland, 140 as a starter.


F.C.C. Chief Urges Accord In Networks-Studios Fight
LEAD: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission warned the television networks and Hollywood producers yesterday that if they cannot negotiate an agreement in their dispute over program distribution, the commission will begin a full-blown rule-making proceeding.


Corrections
LEAD: A report in About New York yesterday on an audition of heroic tenors by the foundation established by Lauritz Melchior misstated the age of the music patron Alice Tully.

EXECUTIVE CHANGES
LEAD: *
AM International, Chicago, a maker of products for the graphics industry, appointed Steven F. Kaplan senior vice president for finance and corporate strategy.
He replaces John H. Shuey, who resigned, as the company's chief financial officer.


February Deficit Grows
LEAD: The Federal budget deficit totaled $36.42 billion last month, 30.1 percent higher than the $27.87 billion imbalance in February 1989, the Treasury Department reported today.
Receipts totaled $65.17 billion in February, up 5.3 percent from the same month last year.
But expenditures amounted to $101.58 billion, a 13.2 percent increase over February 1989.


Dow Falls 10.81 After an Early Rally Fails
LEAD: Stock prices gave way to profit taking yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average sliding 10.81 points, to 2,727.93.
The Dow fell back sharply after a brief early-morning spurt to 2,751.


Upheaval in the East;   Moscow Victors Act to Promote Freer Markets
LEAD: Having soundly defeated the Communist Party at the polls, the democratic insurgents taking over the Moscow City Council plan to name Gavriil K. Popov, an outspoken congressional deputy and economist, as the new Mayor in an attempt to make a free-market showcase of the capital.


Texas Billionaires Victorious on Hog Farm
LEAD: The Bass brothers, a family of Texas billionaires, were victorious on Tuesday when voters in Weld County rejected a proposal that would have required a huge hog farm to build a $10 million plant to treat manure.
The vote was 14,706 to 6,334.


Architects Recognize 17 Projects
LEAD: A round house designed with a crafts collection in mind and a pair of two-story lofts that now resemble ''a building within a building'' were among the entries cited as the best and most creative work of New York architects in a competition sponsored by the American Institute of Architects.


U.S. and Japanese to Meet on Trade
LEAD: Administration officials said today that a meeting Friday between Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and his Japanese counterpart is intended to head off major trade disputes this summer and to consider moves to check the recent fall of the yen.


Dog Got a Bad Bite? Try Orthodontia
LEAD: WHEN the veterinarian says it's time for the dog's dental checkup, certain questions inevitably arise: Does a dog get cavities?
Does a dog need to brush every night?
Does a dog need to floss?
Does a dog need braces?
The answers are no, yes, no and sometimes.
Dentistry for animals is the fastest-growing branch of veterinary medicine.

LEAD: Dr.
Michael Merson, a 44-year-old American, was named today as acting director of the World Health Organization's program to fight AIDS.
He succeeds Dr.
Jonathan Mann, who resigned last week in a dispute with the head of the agency, Dr.
Hiroshi Nakajima.


Philharmonic Season to Open Sept. 12
LEAD: Leonard Bernstein is to conduct three subscription series for the New York Philharmonic in December as part of the orchestra's 1990-91 season, with his newest composition, ''Arias and Barcarolles,'' and the Mendelssohn oratorio ''Elijah'' among the works to be performed.
The season is Zubin Mehta's last as music director; he is to lead 39 concerts.

LEAD: ''MEN are said to be happiest when shopping in hardware stores,'' said the New York jewelry designer Alex Streeter.

LEAD: In the first clear evidence that subtle abnormalities in brain structure are associated with schizophrenia, scientists have found differences in brain anatomy between identical twins, one with the disorder and the other normal.

LEAD: The Soviet Union has withdrawn all its military advisers from the battle zones in Ethiopia's civil wars, the Soviet Ambassador to the Sudan said today.

Masterpieces: Not Usually Vulnerable or Very Vulnerable Indeed
LEAD: The theft of 12 masterworks from the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston on Sunday may be the biggest art theft in history, but it is hardly unique.
Enough stolen masterpieces are still ''out there,'' art professionals and police specialists say, to fill a museum.

NEW STROKE VALUE FOUND FOR ASPIRIN
LEAD: Daily doses of aspirin or another blood-thinning drug dramatically reduce the risk of stroke from a heartbeat irregularity that affects more than a million Americans, researchers said today.

He was 78 years old.

LEAD: North Carolina State's board of trustees, stunned by new information regarding the academic performance of Jim Valvano's basketball players, has directed its attorney to seek the coach's resignation, a newspaper reported.

BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Black &amp; Decker Corp., Towson, Md., a maker of power tools, said it had issued 2.5 million common shares to the 401(k) employee savings plan of its Emhart Corp. subsidiary for $47 million.


Corrections
LEAD: A front-page picture caption in some copies yesterday, about a census taker interviewing a homeless man at a church in Manhattan, misidentified the church.
It was St.
Paul's Chapel at Broadway and Fulton Street.


Cannell to Buy Ohio Station
LEAD: Cannell Communications Inc. said on Tuesday that it would acquire WUAB-TV in Cleveland from the Gaylord Broadcasting Company.
Terms of the deal were not disclosed.


Western Union's Debts May Force Bankruptcy
LEAD: The Western Union Corporation, plagued by huge debt payments, said yesterday in a filing that it may be forced to seek bankruptcy protection.The 139-year-old company that pioneered global business communications with its telegraph and telex services mentioned the possibility in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.


Notebook;   Despite Her Legal Blindness, Dual Holes-in-One
LEAD: A 74-year-old legally blind woman made holes-in-one on the same hole on consecutive days this week.
Her achievement is believed to be the first occasion that the feat has been accomplished by a person with serious vision impairment.


Nuclear Plant Shuts Down
LEAD: Oregon's only nuclear generating plant ceased operating Tuesday after a monitor of the steam flow between the reactor and the turbines was discovered to be incorrectly set.
The Trojan plant, about 35 miles northwest of Portland, was to have been shut anyway at midnight Tuesday for three months of maintenance work.


Review/Theater;   Turner and Durning in 'Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'
It takes nothing away from Kathleen Turner's radiant Maggie in ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'' to say that Broadway's gripping new production of Tennessee Williams's 1955 play will be most remembered for Charles Durning's Big Daddy.
The actor's portrayal of a 65-year-old Mississippi plantation owner in festering extremis is an indelible hybrid of red-neck cutup and aristocratic tragedian, of grasping capitalist and loving patriarch.


Brown Appoints Panel to Review Gun Guidelines
LEAD: Saying that New York City faces ''an unprecedented level of violence,'' Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown yesterday appointed a committee to review guidelines on when officers are to fire their guns.


More on Cousy
LEAD: Bob Cousy, the star guard for the Boston Celtics in the 1950's and early 1960's, who resigned last month as president of the Basketball Hall of Fame in Springfield, Mass., reportedly quit because of his displeasure with the way the hall handled its recent election of players.
The Worcester (Mass.) Telegram and Gazette reported yesterday that Cousy quit because the executive committee ordered a new vote after none of the 16 nominees for admission received the 18 votes required from the 24-man honors committee.


Metro Datelines;   Swan Killing Plan Pressed by Agency
LEAD: Although many people are opposed, Connecticut wildlife officials still intend to reduce the state's mute swan population by invading the birds' nests and shaking their eggs.


Dinkins Names Labor Mediator To New Position
LEAD: Signaling his intention to give City Hall a more active role in labor issues, Mayor David N. Dinkins announced yesterday the appointment of a new chief labor negotiator and gave him an expanded mandate to get involved in private-sector labor disputes.

LEAD: A former Chilean Air Force chief, an original member of the military junta that seized power in 1973, was shot and seriously wounded today.

LEAD: When Fred G. Currey acquired Greyhound three years ago, he was convinced there was only one way for the dominant national bus line to survive against the airlines and their discount fares.

Bamboo Coaxed to Flower in Lab; Global Impact on the Crop Is Seen
LEAD: In a significant advance for the cultivation of one of the world's most important timber and fodder crops, scientists say they have coaxed bamboo plants to flower in the laboratory, a feat never before managed.
Bamboo in the field can take more than a century to flower and produce seeds.


Uncovered Short Sales Set Record on Big Board
LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose by 64.7 million shares, or almost 12 percent, in the month ended March 15, to a record level.
Short interest is the number of shares sold short by investors and not yet covered.

Review/Recital;   Christa Ludwig Takes On Schubert's Raw Despair
LEAD: Anyone who listens carefully to Schubert's ''Winterreise'' can understand why the question used to arise whether this painful study of a disintegrating human personality should be performed in public.
Written in the composer's dying months, the 24-song cycle is almost clinical in its depiction of a mind ravaged by abandoned hopes, delusions and loss of contact with society.

LEAD: SCORESBY has become the fifth-largest brand of Scotch in America - without advertising.
Scoresby Scotch has grown into the largest brand in California, indeed the Western United States -without advertising.
While sales of domestic Scotch declined by 4.6 percent last year, Scoresby's sales grew by more than 11 percent - without advertising.

A.T.&amp;T. Raises Quarterly Dividend
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said its board had raised the company's quarterly dividend to 33 cents from 30 cents.
The dividend increase was the first for A.T.&amp;T. since the Bell System was broken up in 1984.
The giant telecommunications company said the increase reflects its confidence that 1990 ''will be another year of revenue and profit growth.

Poindexter's need for the material.


The Privilege of Secrecy
LEAD: Executive privilege, the right claimed by a President to withhold information from Congress or the courts, is mentioned neither in the Constitution nor in the constitutional debates of the nation's founders.


List Will Use Insanity Defense, Judge Says
LEAD: John E. List will argue he is innocent of fatally shooting his family 18 years ago because of his mental condition at the time, the judge presiding over his trial said today.

Upheaval in the East;   Lithuanian Soldiers Are Outcasts in Soviet Army
LEAD: Virginijus Vitkauskas came to the Lithuanian government's Commission on Military Service this morning, his right eye swollen and purple and his upper teeth punched out.
He was the victim, he said, of soldiers in his unit, who said they would teach the young Lithuanian what they thought of his republic's drive for independence.


NAMIBIA STRESSES A MIXED ECONOMY
LEAD: As Namibia celebrated its first day of independence today, President Sam Nujoma proclaimed his Government's commitment to a mixed economy and invited foreign investors to come and help break the country's dependence on South Africa.


Martin's Widow Files an Action
LEAD: Billy Martin's widow has filed a notice of claim charging the town of Fenton, N.Y., with negligence in her husband's death in a motor-vehicle accident Dec. 25.

She was 87 years old.


Mobil Expansion
LEAD: The Mobil Corporation said it would expand its largest United States refinery, which is in Beaumont, Tex., at a cost of $300 million.
The expansion, which is scheduled to begin in the third quarter of this year, will increase the plant's capacity to 325,000 barrels of crude oil a day from the current 285,000 barrels.

LEAD: The New York City Conflicts of Interest Board ruled yesterday that Mayor David N. Dinkins may participate in a vote today by the Board of Estimate on land-use matters involving cable-television franchises in Manhattan.
The vote concerns whether cables now under the streets may remain there.

Review/Theater;   McCowen Returns in 'St. Mark's Gospel'
LEAD: Alec McCowen's ''St.
Mark's Gospel'' is a performance as revelation.
Without theatrics, he tells the story of Christ as recounted by Mark.
Though Mr.
McCowen has given this solo performance innumerable times in the last two decades, his actor's art has kept his delivery extraordinarily fresh.
The story is told every time as if for the first time.

LEAD: The Hungarian airline has suspended flights carrying Soviet emigrants to Israel, the official press agency said today.

Close to Home
LEAD: I had imagined my arrival, that I'd come in the door and call out something ridiculous like ''Honey, I'm home.'' First I'd hear the tinkle of the bell I had hung around her neck during the last year.
Then out she'd step from wherever she was hiding and walk, unsteady on her paws, toward the object of her constant affections.


Maze of Shops for Adventurous in Paris
LEAD: You can always spend your francs at Hermes or Christian Lacroix on the chic Faubourg St.-Honore or check out the new Emporio Armani on the Place Vendome, where a sweat shirt costs $100.
But an adventurous shopper might have more fun exploring the Marais, the old Jewish quarter of Paris in the Third Arrondissement, where fashionable boutiques are sprouting among kosher food stores, Moroccan pastry shops, art galleries, cafes and tranquil parks.

LEAD: Spring is here, the season of birds and bees, flowers and trees and wheeze and sneeze for millions of Americans with seasonal allergies.
When the runny nose and itchy eyes become sufficiently annoying, most will reach for one of the dozens of over-the-counter or prescription drugs that promise relief from allergy symptoms.

LEAD: Army tanks and troops separated rival, taunting crowds of Romanians and ethnic Hungarians today in a Transylvania city where three people were killed and 300 hurt in fighting on Tuesday night between mobs wielding iron bars, scythes and pitchforks, witnesses said.

LEAD: In an acknowledgment of Canada's emerging role as one of the world's leading havens for concealing illegal narcotics profits, the Canadian Government has shifted policy and proposed the adoption of a law requiring banks and other financial institutions to maintain records of large cash transactions.

Clean Air Compromise Survives Another Attack
LEAD: Senate leaders turned back another major challenge to their agreement with the White House on clean air legislation today as the Senate defeated an amendment to strengthen the ability of the Federal Government to clean up urban smog.
The vote was 53 to 46.
It now appears that the Senate-Administration compromise legislation, reached after a month of intense closed door negotiations, is likely be upheld by the full Senate despite strong opposition by environmentalists and their allies.


Lebow Treated For Brain Cancer
LEAD: Fred Lebow, the director of the New York City Marathon and the president of the New York Road Runners Club, was told yesterday that he has brain cancer.
Lebow, who was to begin radiation treatments immediately, underwent extensive testing after being admitted to Mount Sinai Medical Center on Feb. 14 with a growth in his skull that was detected by a neurological examination.
