Upheaval in the East;   400 Albanians Hospitalized
LEAD: More than 400 ethnic Albanian teen-agers were hospitalized today in Podujevo, a town in ethnically divided Kosovo Province, with signs of poisoning, officials reported.
Official Radio Belgrade said about 4,000 ethnic Albanians gathered in the streets of Podujevo upon hearing the news.
Some of them beat up Serbs and Montenegrins, accusing them of poisoning classrooms of Albanian pupils.

763 Burmese Houses Gutted
LEAD: A fire burned down 763 houses and left almost 4,000 people homeless in the Myanmar capital of Yangon, according to a report today.
It took three hours to control the blaze, said the report from the country formerly known as Burma.
According to the report, the fire began Tuesday in a house and quickly spread.

Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 505 money market mutual funds increased by $199 million, to $391.23 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 156 institutional funds increased by $530.9 million, to $91.88 billion.
The assets of the 247 general-purpose funds were down $968.9 million, to $132.57 billion.

LEAD: Eastern Airlines said yesterday that it had reached an interim agreement calling for wage and benefit cuts by members of its pilots' union, but that the cost savings would be less than half the amount needed to allow the airline to emerge from bankruptcy court protection.


'Le Roman de Fauvel'
LEAD: The Waverly Consort will present ''Le Roman de Fauvel'' at Kathryn Bache Miller Theater at Columbia University, Broadway at 116th Street, tonight and tomorrow night at 8 o'clock and Sunday at 3 P.M..
The work, which comes from an anonymous 14th-century French manuscript that is in the Bibliotheque Nationale in Paris, is a fable about a donkey, Fauvel, and has been part of the Waverly Consort's repertory since 1976.

They rushed shots.
They did not rebound or play the kind of defense that had rattled Texas.
They rushed shots.
They made sloppy passes, did not get back on defense and ran into foul trouble.

LEAD: Since the early 1980's, the territory between painting and photography has been defined by the difference between unique, handmade originals and images that are photo-mechanically reproduced.
But such a distinction is not so sharp as it first appears.
As the work of an artist like Andy Warhol makes clear, the seemingly distinct domains of originals and reproductions can be made to overlap.

Limits on Assault Rifles Voted
LEAD: A House subcommittee voted Wednesday to restrict the sale and possession of assault rifles made in the United States and to require a minimum sentence of 10 years for a person carrying one while committing a crime.
President Bush banned the importing of the semi-automatic rifles last year.
The bill approved Wednesday by the House Judiciary Subcommittee on Crime would require the Administration to extend the ban to domestic-made versions that the President determines have no sporting purpose.

LEAD: Several thousand students withdrew peacefully this morning from a public square in the capital, ending the largest student demonstration here in 40 years, after they discussed their demands Wednesday night with President Lee Teng-hui.

LEAD: One of the strengths of ''War, Resistance and Politics: Dusseldorf Artists 1910-1945,'' at the Jewish Museum, is that it sheds light on Dusseldorf as an avant-garde center.
Before World War I, the art in the city was largely identified with its traditional art academy.
After the war, artists there began to engage the social and political situation of their country, and that engagement has now itself become a tradition at the

LEAD: New York City transit officials today cleared the first of two hurdles to installing automated fare collection on subways and buses.

Pop/Jazz;   Tomorrow's Stars Today In Brooklyn's Small Clubs
LEAD: What makes Brooklyn clubs so nice is similar to what makes the borough itself pleasant: smaller crowds, less pressure and more variety than in Manhattan.
While the level of talent is not as high as in Manhattan, that is not always the point.
Brooklyn clubs, if one can make generalizations at all, are good places for novice musicians and artists to learn about stagecraft, to experiment without the fear of failing in front of high-paying audiences.


Time Warner Adviser Named Chief of Unit
LEAD: Robert W. Pittman, the young executive who brought to the world the MTV music video network and the Morton Downey Jr. show, among other efforts, was named president and chief executive of Time Warner Enterprises, the business and strategic development unit of Time Warner Inc., yesterday.


At Last, a Child Care Bill?
LEAD: Congress has a chance now to pass vital legislation long stalled by territorial battles in the House of Representatives.
It can enact a bill that will make it possible for the working poor to get decent child care for their children - and complement two Administration initiatives that will put more money in the pockets of the poor.


New Shops With an Emphasis on the Edible
LEAD: Rather than being concentrated in one area, Brooklyn's food shops are scattered about the borough like raisins in a Lenten hot-cross bun.
Here is a sampling of some fairly recent newcomers to Brooklyn's eclectic gastronomic scene.


USX to Sell Off Art
LEAD: The USX Corporation plans to auction 64 works of art from its collection this spring, said Christie's auction house, which will handle the sale.
A spokeswoman for Christie's said the collection is expected to sell for $3.5 million to $5 million.
The auction house said the art includes Impressionist and other 19th-century and 20th-century works.


New Kennedy Center Head Likely to Be Named Today
LEAD: James D. Wolfensohn, an investment banker, arts patron and amateur cellist, is expected to be named on Friday to succeed Ralph P. Davidson as chairman of the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, a member of the center's board said today.
The 43-member board is to meet at noon.


John Jardine, Football Coach, 54
LEAD: John Jardine, who coached the Wisconsin football team from 1970 through 1977, died of heart failure today at the University of Wisconsin Hospital.
He was 54 years old.


Brooklyn Teen-Ager Is Charged in Assaults
LEAD: A 14-year-old Brooklyn boy was arrested early yesterday and charged in a series of sexual assaults of five girls ranging in age from 9 years old to 17, the police said.

LEAD: The wild, winding road to the Final Four, already filled with upsets and spine-tingling finishes, took a crazy and controversial turn tonight.
Georgia Tech, a team that has specialized in heroic comebacks and last gasp victories this season, outdid itself tonight in defeating top-seeded Michigan State, 81-80, in overtime.

LEAD: The day after New York City bulldozed a statue built by East Harlem children, city officials promised yesterday to restore it.

LEAD: The game for New York City scholastic bragging rights was played 200 miles upstate at the Civic Center tonight in one semifinal of the New York State Federation of Secondary Schools Athletic Associations Class A tournament.

LEAD: Just two weeks after the National Football League completed a television agreement that will guarantee each team an average of $32 million a year for the next four years, two teams began to pass on the big bucks to their star players.


Maryland Legislature Halts an Abortion Move
LEAD: A committee of the Maryland House of Delegates voted tonight to reject a package of two bills on abortion that the State Senate passed early today after an eight-day filibuster.


Mongolia, Too, Ends Communist Monopoly
LEAD: Mongolia's Communist legislators formally abolished their party's monopoly on power today and approved elections with more than one candidate.
But the election law was drafted before recent democracy protests and does not mention a role for opposition parties, officials said.


Pine Valley, L.I., Fades Into Pine Valley, R.I.P.
LEAD: This village has been called many things in its two years of life: a developer's dream, an experiment in self-determination, a joke.
Now call it defunct.


With Bulbs, Light and Price Are the Key Considerations
LEAD: Consumers who think they can spot the bargains and the pitfalls in the supermarket aisles should pay close attention in the light bulb section, a part of the store where choices are multiplying, where common terms don't mean what people think they do, and the important measure, light, is almost always overlooked.


Doubling the Guarantee on a Computer
LEAD: Here is a tip for people buying a home computer: Charge it on either a gold Visa or a gold Mastercard.
Simply by using one of the bank cards, your computer's guarantee will be doubled, up to an additional year.
That may not be the case if you pay for the system using American Express.


Review/Opera;   New 'Don Giovanni,' From Zeffirelli
LEAD: The Metropolitan Opera's new ''Don Giovanni,'' its first staging of Mozart's Olympian tragicomedy since the celebrated Eugene Berman production more than 30 years ago, is beautiful to look at.
That can come as no surprise: the director and set designer is Franco Zeffirelli, who always brings to opera a painter's vivid sensitivity to colors and an obsessive need to splash his ideas on large canvases.


Federal Proposal Would Require Van Services for Disabled Who Can't Use Buses
LEAD: In a move welcomed by advocates for the disabled, the Bush Administration has proposed that operators of federally aided bus lines be required to provide door-to-door service in specialized vans for disabled people who do not benefit from wheelchair lifts and other special devices on buses.


Hewlett-Packard In Scottish Closing
LEAD: The Hewlett-Packard Company will close its plant in Livingston, Scotland, and move its operations to three other sites.
The plant repairs computer boards and assembles work stations.
Its 240 workers will be offered jobs elsewhere with the company.
The computer, electronics and instruments company acquired the Livingston plant when it bought Apollo Computer Inc.

LEAD: The Texas investor Harold C. Simmons said on Thursday that he would probably sell about $1 billion worth of assets in the Lockheed Corporation's technology and electronics services businesses if he wins control of the company.
He said no final decision would be made until after a review of the company's financial records.

LEAD: President Bush said today that he opposed statehood for the District of Columbia, the subject of renewed debate in this troubled, heavily Democratic city.

LEAD: A lawyer who in 1988 pressed regulators to refrain from seizing a failing savings and loan was given a $49,000 no-bid consulting contract last year to advise a Federal agency involved in the bailout of the savings industry.

LEAD: Reducing the amount of fat in the diet is more important than changing the kinds of fat consumed in preventing obstructive lesions in the heart arteries, researchers said yesterday.

LEAD: While the big-time ''programs'' are competing to reach the Final Four of college basketball, one school has already won its national championship.

Perrier in Talks With Cadbury
LEAD: The French drink company Source Perrier S.A. said it was discussing the sale of its soft drink business to Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. of Britain.
Perrier's soft drink brands include Oasis and Bali orange squashes, Pschitt sodas and Gini lemonade.
Perrier's mineral water business is not included in the soft drink segment.

LEAD: Rik Smits had 30 points and 14 rebounds tonight as the Indiana Pacers handed the Nets their 22d consecutive road loss and ninth succcessive defeat over all in a 125-109 decision.


News Summary
LEAD:
International
3-6
Soviet tanks passed through Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital, in the strongest attempt to intimidate the republic.
Tanks and trucks carrying 1,500 soldiers rumbled past an all-night session of the Parliament.
Page 1
The U.S. closely watched the activity in Lithuania amid mounting concerns in the Administration that Moscow may be considering harsher military action in the republic.


Search Is Halted for 9 Lost in Bering Sea After Trawler Sinks
LEAD: The Coast Guard suspended its search for nine men today after concluding that they had drowned when their fishing trawler capsized and sank in the frigid Bering Sea.


F.T.C. Reviews Genentech Deal
LEAD: The Federal Trade Commission has requested more information for its antitrust review of the proposed acquisition of a majority of Genentech Inc. by Roche Holding Ltd., the two companies said today.
Jack Murphy, a spokesman for Genentech, said it was too early to tell whether the additional Federal review would delay the completion of the transaction.


Fixed Mortgages Drop
LEAD: Fixed-rate home mortgages are now averaging 10.26 percent, down from 10.34 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.56 percent this week, up from 8.55 percent the week before.


Patents;   Insecticides That Are Safe For Humans
LEAD: Researchers at a California company won two patents this week involving insecticides derived from bacteria that they said do not harm humans.


Government Approves Novel Drug To Treat Immune System Disease
LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration approved a novel type of drug yesterday for the treatment of a rare genetic disease that devastates the immune system.


New Credit Card From A.T.&amp;T. Due
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company will announce on Monday that it is starting its own credit card, people familiar with the company's plans said.
A.T.&amp;T. scheduled a news conference at its Manhattan headquarters.
The company will introduce a new card combining the billing of A.T.&amp;T. credit-card calls with the billing of meals, hotel rooms and other goods and services, the sources said.


Soviets to Curb Jews' Flights to Israel
LEAD: The Soviet Union has announced that it will severely limit flights to Israel for emigrating Soviet Jews, and Yitzhak Shamir, the interim Prime Minister, held urgent meetings today to find a way to counter the Soviet decision.


Recourse for Shoddy Work
LEAD: For several months, William Drozdal waited for a contractor to finish the front of his house after parts of it were ripped off during a renovation project.
But after reading a newspaper article, Mr.
Drozdal, an accountant in Rochdale, Mass., learned that he, too, had been ''ripped off,'' as he put it.


List of Japan Goals Cited
LEAD: The United States Government has given Japan a list of more than 200 suggested policy changes aimed at eliminating barriers faced by foreign companies operating in Japan, a news report said today.


Cocoa Pact Extension
LEAD: The world's largest cocoa-producing countries agreed today to support a two-year extension of the International Cocoa Agreement, with all provisions on price supports frozen for the period, a spokesman for the producers said.


10-Day Vehicle Sales Off 9.5% As Season Gets a Slow Start
LEAD: The automobile industry's important spring selling season has started poorly.
Sales of domestically made cars and light trucks in mid-March were down by 9.5 percent from a year ago, with all of the Big Three companies reporting declines today.

LEAD: Col.
Jack Knowles (Roy Scheider) is the sort of guy who, upon hearing that three bullies stole his young son's bicycle in the schoolyard, wonders why the boy couldn't hang on to it; after all, there were only three of them.
This kind of attitude made him a hero in Vietnam, but since then he has been a belligerent misfit.

CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;   With Automobile Loans
LEAD: If you are trying to finance a new automobile with a five-year loan, you may find it more difficult to get one these days.
Banks, finance companies and other lenders are trying to discourage such long-term financing in many ways, including offering fewer of those loans to car buyers, charging higher interest rates and tightening the eligibility standards for applicants.

LEAD: Miffed at not having a say in the revised regular-season schedule, major league umpires said today that they would protest by not working spring training games.

LEAD: Continuing its buying binge, the Crown Cork and Seal Company agreed today to buy the food and beverage metal canning units of the Continental Can Company in a purchase that will make Crown the nation's biggest maker of metal packaging.

LEAD: The official murder of a British freelance journalist, Farzad Bazoft, in Baghdad put the spotlight on Iraq for a few days.
It should stay there.
Torture, summary execution, flagrant violation of the most basic human rights have not been wiped out, and Iraq remains one of the world's worst offenders.

LEAD: Maybe the Knicks should put Patrick Ewing out on the floor alone and let him play one on five.

LEAD: A rebound in dealers' orders for automobiles pushed orders for durable goods up by 3.3 percent last month, the Government said today, but the recovery after January's record plunge offered little hope that manufacturing was pulling out of its slump.

LEAD: David Singer, a professor of economics, died of cancer on Tuesday at the home of a friend, Sheila Steckel, in Manhattan.

LEAD: In Bertolt Brecht's first play, ''Baal,'' written when he was 20 years old, the protagonist is a poet who leads a life of ''sensational immorality.'' LEAD: A new disagreement between American and French scientists has erupted over their competing claims to have discovered the AIDS virus, with the leader of the French research group urging the head of the United States team to admit that he was mistaken.


Patient 76ers to Retire Chamberlain's No. 13
LEAD: Wilt Chamberlain, the second-leading career scorer in National Basketball Association history with 31,419 points over 14 seasons, has seen his jersey number, 13, retired by the Los Angeles Lakers, for whom he played his six final seasons, ending in 1973.
Now the Philadelphia 76ers, with whom he played three and a half seasons in the mid-1960's, would like to honor their home-grown 7-foot-1-inch hero, too.

LEAD: Yasir Arafat says the Palestine Liberation Organization has asked the Soviet Union to adopt specific measures to slow the emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel.


Bolivians Kill Trafficker's Son
LEAD: The son of one of Bolivia's biggest drug traffickers has been killed in a gun battle with the police, television reports said.
The dead man, Roberto Suarez Levy, was killed on Thursday night after the police surrounded his house in this southern Bolivian town.
His father, Roberto Suarez Gomez, is serving a 15-year prison term for producing and selling cocaine.

Soviet Georgian Troupe
LEAD: The Rustavi Company, a Georgian folk music and dance troupe from the Soviet Union, is to make its American debut at 8 P.M. on April 5 at the Beacon Theater, Broadway at 74th Street.
The 60-member group plans six performances, the last on April 8.
Tickets are $20 to $35 at the box office and Ticketron outlets.


Food Delivery Test By General Mills
LEAD: General Mills Inc. has begun an experimental business delivering casual food like chicken wings, roast chicken and sandwiches to customers ordering by telephone.
Called Bringer's, the service is provided to people who live in southwest Minneapolis and parts of suburban Edina, Richfield and Bloomington.


Dow Up Slightly for Day, but Falls in Week
LEAD: Stocks rose slightly yesterday after the rebound in Tokyo, with the Dow Jones industrial average advancing 8.56 points, to 2,704.28, in slow trading.


Mr. Bush's 'Big Tent' for Art
LEAD: That he has a passion for country-and-Western music is all that most Americans know about President Bush's esthetic leanings.
This week, however, they found out something more, and better.
In opposing Senator Jesse Helms's proposals to hamstring the National Endowment for the Arts, Mr.
Bush proved himself to be a friend to all artists.


Patents;   Synthetic Bag Starts A Bagpipe Dispute
LEAD: W. L. Gore &amp; Associates Inc. is making angry noises about bagpipes.
The Newark, Del., company makes Gore-Tex, the breathable, waterproof fabric, and last year patented a synthetic bag to replace the traditional animal skins used on Scottish bagpipes.

CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost;   Fixing Your Makeup
LEAD:
Has your makeup outlasted its shelf life?
Makeup that sits in a drawer or handbag exposed to atmospheric and temperature changes can break down.
Ingredients in cosmetics, like those in food, can separate or turn rancid.
And each application introduces dirt and oil, though this can be mitigated by using clean brushes and applicators.

Review/Pop;   With the Dense Band, Texture Is Melody
LEAD: David Moss's Dense Band dispenses noisy free improvisation in handy, accessible form - song-length pieces with a beat.
The Dense Band, which performed on Monday night at the Knitting Factory, is built around Mr.
Moss's talents as a drummer and a free-form vocalist.
Whether or not he is sitting at his drum kit - which includes a steel drum, an electronic drum pad and various crumpled cymbals as well as ordinary trap drums - he can pour out syllables, meaningless or not.

Corrections
LEAD: An obituary on March 10 about Ron Wolin, an antiwar advocate who brought a successful lawsuit to permit the distribution of political and religious leaflets in publicly owned transportation terminals, misstated later decisions on the issue.
Unlike transportation terminals, privately owned shopping centers in New York and nearly all other states are still permitted to limit leaflet distribution and solicitation.


Patents;   New Rods Said to Cut Danger of Lightning
LEAD: Two Florida inventors won patent approval this week on a class of lightning rods shaped like feather dusters.
The advantage of the rods, they say, is that they dissipate far more of the ground's static electricity and sharply reduce the chances of being struck by lightning.

LEAD: The Soviet Union has announced that it will severely limit flights to Israel for emigrating Soviet Jews, and Yitzhak Shamir, the interim Prime Minister, held urgent meetings to find a way to counteract the Soviet decision.

On AIDS, Compassion and Confusion
LEAD: The surge of deaths among patients taking an experimental new AIDS drug, DDI, does not necessarily mean the drug is to blame.
AIDS activists have brought about changes in the traditional methods of testing drugs.
The new methods represent a compassionate response to AIDS sufferers.
They also risk confusion.

Question of the Week;   Should College Athletes Be Paid?
LEAD: Absolutely not.
College is not an institution where athletes should be paid.
They should pay attention to getting good grades and completing school.
If it gets that far, why not pay high school athletes?
This way by the time they reach college, they can be well off within four years, or less.

JAILHOUSE BLUES: THE BALLAD OF THE MARIN COUNTY JAIL
LEAD: It is like a vast stucco spaceship, set gracefully into the brown hills just north of San Francisco, and it stands as Frank Lloyd Wright's crowning achievement on the West Coast as surely as the Guggenheim Museum culminates his career on the East Coast.
The building is the Marin County Civic Center, a combination office building, courthouse and library, and it was conceived not only as an adventurous piece of architecture but also as a visionary piece of planning: a unified governmental center for a growing suburban region.

We have become so used to this circular activity that in talented hands it can pass for creativity or even genius.

LEAD: MY husband, John, and I and two of our sons, Ian, who's 23, and Kit, who's 20, recently returned from two weeks spent investigating a canyon.

LEAD: Why does one listen to old recordings, especially to very old ones with their surface noise and low-end reproduction of sound?

Question of the Week;   Should College Athletes Be Paid?
LEAD: College athletes are already paid.
They live in preferred accommodations called athletic dorms.
They eat at special restaurants called training tables.
They get weekend trips - staying at five-star hotels, when motels are available to provide the same basic services.
They are provided with great seats at all their games, tickets that are often scalped.

LEAD: To the Editor:


When It Counts, Kohl Shows, He Cannot Be Counted Out
LEAD: CHANCELLOR HELMUT KOHL customarily reaches his maximum heft at this time of year, just before his annual Eastertime course of weight reduction.

This year it looks like pure gold: Mr.
Kohl stands at the peak of his career, and if things keep going his way, by this time next year he could be the first chancellor of a reunited Germany.

Pastimes;   Around the Garden
LEAD: For This Week: Prune rose of Sharon, large-flowered hydrangea, buddleia and other shrubs that will flower on this year's growth.
Apply general garden fertilizer to trees and shrubs; wait to uncover perennials.
Use a spading fork to turn the compost pile.
Prune roses.
Rake up winter debris from the lawn and use a calibrated spreader to apply lime and fertilizer.

Question of the Week;   Should College Athletes Be Paid?
LEAD: Idealistically, no.
They are amateurs and should be treated as such.
Realistically, yes, they should be paid.
Perhaps a weekly or monthly stipend determined by the National Collegiate Athletic Association's board for the particular sport in question.
DONNY GANNON
Astoria, Queens

LEAD: ARTHUR WALLACE, a smarmy divorce lawyer, is railing about the decline of the nuclear family.

Review/Music;   A John Coltrane Disciple
LEAD: Near the end of his first set on Monday at the Bottom Line, the English saxophonist Courtney Pine silenced his backup trio and performed a tour de force.
Using circular breathing to play nonstop, he reeled off hyperfast arpeggios, John Coltrane's ''sheets of sound'' technique, to create a thick, pulsating, slowly changing drone that went on and on - at first stubbornly, then with its own unearthly timing.

QUOTATION OF THE DAY
LEAD: ''I come from a small Midwestern town, and this only happened in places like Los Angeles or Dallas or New York or Chicago.
I was from Iowa.
I had never given it a thought.
But now I'm going to do my damnedest to keep it from happening to another woman.''
- Nancy Ziegenmeyer
of Grinnell, Iowa,
speaking of rape.


WATER GONE, BUT SHOCK LINGERS
LEAD: There are still people in Elba, Ala., who remember March 14, 1929, when flood waters from the Pea River inundated the small southeastern Alabama community, almost wiping it off the map.
But once the 3.2-mile-long levee surrounding the town was built in 1938, no one ever expected to see that kind of devastation again.

Review/Theater;   Woman's Many Lives In 'El Eterno Femenino'
LEAD: Rosario Castellanos took the title of her play ''El Eterno Femenino'' from Goethe, but nothing else. ''The eternal feminine leads us on,'' the German poet says at the end of ''Faust.'' To the Mexican novelist and poet, this famous tag line was obviously something of a joke, perhaps a bitter one, and her dark comedy supplies a feminist corrective to women's history.

POSTINGS: Nyack Condos;   20 Units, 5 Shops Downtown
LEAD: ''It's going to be very artsy-craftsy,'' is the way John H. Lese describes a condominium project he has started in the center of the Hudson River village of Nyack, N.Y.
The 20 two-story town houses and five shops are in four Victorian-style buildings that Mr.
Lese says are being designed with projecting bays, wide board fascias and trim, and clapboard and brick finishes to ape some of the village's older buildings.

NONFICTION
LEAD:
GREAT PLAINS PATCHWORK: A Memoir.
By Marilyn Coffey. (Iowa State University, $21.95.) The novelist Marilyn Coffey has put together an entertaining, insightful collection of stories, combining fact and legend, about her beloved central plains between the mid-1880's and the late 1950's. ''Like a speck on the eastern horizon appears a wagon loaded with Coffeys,'' who in 1885 migrated west to the Great Plains from Illinois.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about Namibia misstated the starting date of the war of independence there.
The war, which ended in 1989, began in 1966, not 1986.

LEAD: The life of Ernest Hemingway has been chronicled, celebrated and analyzed so exhaustively that its scenes now constitute the elements of a myth, the periodic retracing of which has become a kind of pilgrimage (or gravy train) taken by writers and readers alike.

Hotchner, the author of ''Papa Hemingway,'' a classic of Hemingway hagiography, has hit the trail again and served up in HEMINGWAY AND HIS WORLD (Vendome Press, $45) an encyclopedic buffet, full of fascinating rare photos of


A Concern With Painting the Unpaintable
LEAD: All of Gerhard Richter's work can be seen as a struggle with ideology.
He has moved back and forth between abstract and figurative styles, and between small hazy photorealist still lifes and landscapes and large gestural abstractions so physical that they seem to take over their room.
He has consistently tried to make art that is provocative and pleasing without advancing any one program or theory.


Seaside Retreat Offers a Respite From Life's Dizzying Pace
LEAD: THE road leading into the Mercy Center in Madison hugs a stretch of woods that taper out to the sea.
Nearby, in an open parcel, stands an old greenhouse, several sand-colored buildings and a towering 18-room mansion built in the 1940's by W. T. Grant, the dime-store magnate.
The house was built of brick and California redwood.

The Modernist Who Dared to Be a Romantic
LEAD: One could argue that modernism, for all its art-for-art's-sake veneer, is at heart Romantic.
Painters like Piet Mondrian, sculptors like Constantin Brancusi and photographers like Alfred Stieglitz all wanted to get to a spiritual dimension with their pared-down forms, and they relied on inner sensibility as their means of discovery.

Mutual Funds;   A Good Day for Bottom Fishing
LEAD: Skittish investors should stay out of today's ''junk bond'' market.
But conditions are ideal for ''bottom fishers,'' the hardy souls with a strong tolerance for risk who scout for bargains in the ruins.
And, according to Thomas J. Herzfeld, a Miami-based investment adviser, closed-end funds are the best bargains in today's junk market.

The produce of the jungles in South America is feeding what the article refers to as ''the nation's immense, insatiable habit.


COLLEGE BASKETBALL: Midwest Regional;   Arkansas Pulls Free Of Texas at the Line
LEAD: For all the high-flying rebounds and wondrous shots that Arkansas and Texas tossed at each other here this afternoon, the finish came down to one of basketball's most elementary phases: free throws.
Hit or miss.
Arkansas missed plenty in the waning minutes, but the Razorbacks' Ron Huery made two crucial ones with 16 seconds left to lift Arkansas to an 88-85 victory and the Midwest Regional championship before 16,143 in Reunion Arena.


THE MAN WITH THE GOLDEN SWING
LEAD: ON A MILD, LATE-JANUARY DAY, WHILE his fellow professionals scramble toward a weekend payday on the Monterey Peninsula some 3,000 miles away, Curtis Strange is back home on the range, hard at practice.
With monotonous regularity, Strange, a lanky, prematurely gray-haired 35-year-old, slaps golf ball after golf ball into the slight Virginia breeze.

SURVIVING HISTORY
LEAD: I DISCOVERED NATALIA Ginzburg in 1971.
I was in Florence; my friend and I, having just graduated from college, were doing the contemporary version of the grand tour: a trip around Europe carrying backpacks, hitchhiking, staying in cheap pensiones.
I decided that I should buy an Italian book; I went into a bookstore and my eye fell on Natalia Ginzburg's Le piccole virtu.

Lenin Is Alive and Well and Reporting From Lithuania
LEAD: AMID the feast of information and candor set forth by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, it is worth pointing out that the spectral figure of agitprop - the weary old Bolshevik specialist in manipulating information - still holds a high place at the table of glasnost.
In the war of nerves between the Kremlin and the breakaway republic of Lithuania, Soviet Government dominance of most information channels has been on display with a pervasiveness that Lenin first dreamed of.

Correction
LEAD: An article last week about people involved in savings and loan failures included erroneous statements about Thomas M. Gaubert, the former head of the Independent American Savings and Loan Association of Dallas.
Mr.
Gaubert has not been sued in a civil case by the Government.
In an agreement with regulators, he was banned from the savings industry in 1986 because of dealings with an Iowa savings institution that led to large losses, not because of the failure of his own institution.

SANDINISTA SWIMS AGAINST THE TIDE
LEAD: If Sandinista militants doubted the political orthodoxy of a comrade named Herty Lewites Rodriguez, they got their proof on election day.
While other Sandinista candidates were crushed in the national balloting on Feb. 25, Mr.
Lewites turned this tidy village into a something of an electoral miracle, leading his hometown Sandinista ticket to victory by a margin of 24 percentage points.

ABOUT NEW JERSEY
LEAD: IT is just after 9 A.M. on a Friday in the middle of the month.
Many of the stiff plastic chairs at the Essex County welfare office on Rector Street in Newark are already filled with women and babies, grandmothers, lunch bags and, here and there, a few men.
Phones ring and ring unanswered, and from behind the long counter a woman calls for the next client.

California Bankers No Longer Fear Outsiders
LEAD: For years, California bankers have been bracing for the second California gold rush.
Come next January, banks from other states can expand into the state's huge and lucrative market.
And bankers in the state have feared that New York giants like Citicorp, Chase and Chemical would swoop in and buy large California banks, creating continent-spanning empires.

T.'' ''is guiding the marriage of video and film technology.'' Mr.
Daviau's statement reflects the fact that nowadays movies are seen far more frequently on the home television screen than in the theater.

LEAD: One of the biggest attractions of the pop music world is following the spins of its wheel of fortune and watching where the golden arrow comes to rest.
Each month brings a surprise or two, but when a deserving artist like Bonnie Raitt is suddenly, unexpectedly rewarded, one's fascination in the whole hit-making process becomes rekindled.

Question of the Week;   Should College Athletes Be Paid?
LEAD: A successful sports program can be a university's foremost attraction when it comes to recruiting students, not just athletes but eggheads such as myself.
While at the University of North Carolina, I carried out my plan to have a double major: English and basketball attendance.
Student athletes are a useful commodity, they bring exposure and revenue to colleges.


Enforcement of Guam Abortion Law Is Barred
LEAD: A Federal district judge here has temporarily blocked enforcement of a new Guam law that is the most restrictive abortion statute in any American jurisdiction.


Pastimes;   Chess
LEAD: Gary Kasparov did not have an easy time in the Linares International Tournament in Spain, which ended Feb. 24.
For the moment he has given up the Gruenfeld Defense, which he used with reasonable success against Anatoly Karpov in their last two title matches.
A good guess is that he does not want everyone he meets to be educated in its niceties as a result of seeing his Karpov games.

IN AJU thimble, that will be the most provocative story from the American fall fashion market.

Review/Dance;   Observations on Life's Abrasiveness
LEAD: No one could accuse Donald Byrd of timidity.
From the start of his choreographic career in the mid-1970's, Mr.
Byrd has taken on complex issues including prejudice, the effects of negative reviews on artists, the AIDS crisis and life seen as an evening in a disco.
His choreographic voice - and electric presence - are both velvety and intensely abrasive.


Easter in Naples: Mangia Bene!
LEAD: THE FOOD OF NAPLES, LIKE THEJU city itself, is at its most exuberant at Easter when this ancient town shakes off the torpor induced by Lent and the gray damp of a Mediterranean winter.
Neapolitan cooks are brimming with vitality, turning out feasts with gusto.
But the food at Easter feasts throughout the city is far from the pizza and spaghetti with red sauce that most Americans associate with Naples.

Small World
LEAD: Sometimes science is served best by unscientific methods.
For years researchers wondered if the hairy-eared dwarf lemur still existed; they had never seen one alive.
Last week it was reported that the animal, the second smallest primate (the mouse lemur is smaller in dry seasons), was alive and well in a Madagascar rain forest.

Sports of The Times;   Ryan Would Strike Out Asterisks
LEAD: In the fallout from baseball's labor dispute, one temporary rule threatens the sanctity of its statistics.
Ordinarily a starting pitcher must complete at least five innings in order to be eligible for a victory.
But for the first 14 days of the season that opens on April 9, three innings will be enough.

Question of the Week;   Should College Athletes Be Paid?
LEAD: The question is not whether the college athlete should be paid; he (or she) is paid now, in an approved, legitimate, and generous way.
At Notre Dame for example, each of the 19 incoming football scholarship freshmen receive a yearly benefit (tuition, room, board) having an approximate value of $15,000.


Question of the Week;   Should College Athletes Be Paid?
LEAD: Yes, pay college basketball players!
Rename Division I the N.C.A.B.A. (with B for basketball) and continue the championship format as it exists now, recognizing it for what it truly is: a revenue-producing business with paid athletes whose primary interest is athletics, who are representing the college during their contracted four-year tenure.

U.S. Taking Watchful Attitude
LEAD: The United States has made it clear to the Soviet Union that using force in Lithuania would harm Soviet-American relations but is still accepting Moscow's assurances that no such action will be taken, Brent Scowcroft, President Bush's national security adviser, said today in an interview.
Other Administration officials said there were signs of heightened Soviet military activity in the Baltic republics but no indication of an impending crackdown.

Lifestyle: Outing;   Tokens, Please, For a Ride
LEAD: Since ancient times, cities have arisen out of transportation routes.
New York City was no different: today's metropolis emerged from a prosperous port, but it emanated also from the metropolis below.
Its streets cling to the massive transportation network beneath them.
A visit to the New York Transit Museum in Brooklyn offers a chance to explore the workings of that network at leisure.

Business Diary/March 18-23
LEAD:
INTERNATIONAL
The Tokyo stock market has caught New York on the way down.
An investor who bought Japanese stocks on Sept. 4, 1987 would now be no better off than one who bought American stocks the same day.
A 6.9 percent drop in the Nikkei average last week, to 30,372.16, left the total value of Tokyo's stocks slightly lower than New York's.

All About/Composite Materials;   Light and Tough, New Materials Head for the Mass Marketing Stage
LEAD: From the outside, today's automobiles still appear to be nearly all steel.
But about 8 percent of their weight consists of composites -strong, light combinations of complementary substances.
Bumpers, doors, body panels and station wagon tailgates are all commonly made from these materials.
Ten years ago, the composite content was less than 2 percent; by the year 2000, some producers of composites contend, their materials will predominate.

DANCE VIEW
LEAD: It's not necessarily survival of the fittest in the dance world; it may only be survival of the luckiest.
When a production vanishes from a repertory, no one can predict if it will be gone for a season or for all eternity.
Shockingly few creations of the past were notated when they were new.
Even in our own age of film, videotape and crusading notation societies, numerous dances still go unrecorded.

Japanese Rice in Its Many Guises
LEAD: A DARKLY gleaming lidded lacquer bowl is set before the diner.
He (or she) mumbles ''Itadakimasu'' (I receive), lifts the lid and sets it aside.
The glossy white grains carefully mounded within give off a sweet fragrance.
Chopsticks are raised and plunged into the steaming rice.
The meal begins.

Congratulations Are Not Enough
LEAD: To the Editor:


Man Killed by Subway Train
LEAD: A man was run over and decapitated by a subway train in lower Manhattan early yesterday morning, a transit official said.
The driver of a Manhattan-bound L train saw the man on the roadbed as the train was pulling into the First Avenue station in Manhattan at 2 A.M., a Transit Authority spokesman said.


QUESTIONS, QUESTIONS
LEAD: Will Dave Winfield, Kirk Gibson and Dwight Gooden be ready for the start of the season?
Are Carlos Baerga, Eric Anthony and Ben McDonald ready to take their places as major league starters?
Do Gary Carter, Dan Quisenberry and Bill Buckner have enough left to warrant being given jobs?
Can Rick Aguilera adjust to a pivotal new role?

SHARK TANK
Greed, Politics, and the Collapse of Finley Kumble,
One of America's Largest Law Firms.
By Kim Isaac Eisler.

BUSH'S CABINET: WHO'S UP, WHO'S DOWN
LEAD: At the first informal meeting of the Bush Cabinet, in Blair House a week before the Inauguration, George Bush pulled a handwritten list out of his pocket and read what he called ''The Marching Orders.''


A Paragon of Civility?
LEAD: To the Editor:


School Takeover: Gentle Words, Tough Action
LEAD: FIVE months into the nation's first complete state takeover of a public school system, Dr.
Elena J. Scambio, the state-appointed Superintendent in Jersey City, is trying to combine the big stick with a soft touch as she seeks to lift the city's educational system from the morass it has floundered in for years.


A Trip Down Memory Lane in Baldwin
LEAD: RAAY-NOR'S CABIN sits on the south side of Sunrise Highway in Baldwin, a nostalgic reminder of the past.
This time capsule of a restaurant, which opened in 1949, shows little evidence of the culinary changes of the last 40 years.


Campus Life: Vanderbilt;   400 Students Join 3-Week Program On Eating Smart
LEAD: Some 400 Vanderbilt University undergraduates are on a three-week regimen of low-fat, low-sodium and high-fiber foods intended to make them healthier and wiser - and perhaps a trifle wealthier, too.


The Menu Puts On Its Spring Garb
LEAD: THE weather has felt like spring on and off for weeks but now it's official.
And like the wardrobe and the garden, it's time for the menu to change Springtime calls for asparagus, artichokes, shad, soft-shell crabs, your own newly created salads, new potatoes, fresh herbs, scallions and light soups, stews and pasta dishes.


Ah, Symplocarpus Foetidus
LEAD: In a season of premature cherry blossoms and untimely tulips, one all-American plant is giving no ground to this headlong spring - symplocarpus foetidus, less elegantly known as skunk cabbage.
After poking its tip out of half-frozen soil, it waited to open its burnished green and purple sheaths and now, right on schedule, is sprouting the big leaves, which, when stepped on, smell terrible.


More on Mexico's Debt
LEAD: The complex nature of the debt agreement negotiated between Mexico and its creditor banks last month has led to some confusion regarding its implications for Mexico's economy.


Tennis in Italy
LEAD: To the Editor: What you told F. W. B. of Boseman, Mont., about finding tennis courts in Italy (Q &amp; A, March 11) was all well and good; tennis clubs are listed in the telephone directory.
But there is another, quite simple way to find out if a hotel or resort has a tennis court: look for the symbol (crossed tennis racquets) in the Michelin red guide to Italy.


Corrections
LEAD: The article ''Adding Up the Costs of Changes at the Top'' in the same issue misidentified the creator of the film ''Railroad Turnbridge.'' It is the work of Richard Serra.


Focus Turns To Those Behind The Camera
LEAD: Except in obscure publications, cinematographers never get credit for the look of a movie.
It's not that directors deliberately usurp the praise.
But parceling out credit is so complicated that the director becomes the winner by default.


Governor Urges Great Leap and Volunteers to Go First
LEAD: THE Governor of New Jersey has come came up with an alternative to tiptoeing around tax increases: jump in with both feet, to the tune of $2 billion; and while you're at it, overhaul the tax system, wipe out a $580 million deficit and redistribute wealth all at the same time.


New Piece Added To Puzzle on Perez
LEAD: On the fifth day of a gentle spring, with the Yankees working under a warm sun and George Steinbrenner observing from the dugout, the mystery of the missing pitcher took another strange twist.


On South Africa, U.S. Redefines Its Role for a Time of Transition
LEAD: LISTENING to Nelson Mandela chastising Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d last week for deciding to meet with President F. W. de Klerk, it was easy to wonder whether anything had really changed in the debate over American policy toward South Africa.


Nancy Ellen Haar and A. F. Buffa Are Married
LEAD: Nancy Ellen Haar, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs.
Laurence M. Haar of Port Washington, L.I., was married last evening to Anthony Francis Buffa, a son of Betty M. Buffa of Grosse Pointe Park, Mich., and the late Sebastian A. Buffa.
Rabbi Ramie Arian officiated at the Columns in Manhattan.

Kurt Ransenberg of Skokie, Ill.

Short-Form Films Bolster Long-Range Objectives
LEAD: Television viewers this week will have a chance to see three short, offbeat movies that are the results of a project designed to nurture a fresh crop of directors eager to try their hand at feature-length films.
Presented under the umbrella title ''Triple Play,'' the package will be shown on PBS's American Playhouse series Wednesday at 9 P.M.


Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   Lentils That Don't Linger in the Pot
LEAD: Dried beans, peas and lentils are the trend-setting foods of the 90's, appearing on menus where nutrition and taste meet.
One big drawback is that they take so long to cook.
An alternative is canned beans, and as canned foods go they are among the best.
And while lentils do not come in cans, they do come in more than one color.


Burke Produces As Devils Win
LEAD: The Devils got into sync at the Spectrum this afternoon and ended a losing streak at two games with a 5-2 triumph over the Flyers.


Serious Times, Trivial Politics
LEAD: News flash: The Kennedy Library at Harvard University, to encourage better leadership, will bestow its first Profile in Courage Award this year on a public official who follows his conscience instead of the opinion polls.


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. We inherited some walnut furniture that has a considerable amount of carving.
We would like to strip off the old finish down to the original wood.
We called for professional estimates, but found the cost quite high, and so we would like to do the stripping ourselves.
Can you offer some pointers?

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about corporate health and fitness programs misstated the number of workers participating at the American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.
It is 97,000, not 70,000.

NO LONG-TERM PLAN ON MILITARY SAVING
LEAD: At a time when receding Soviet military power suggests that hundreds of billions of dollars will be cut from the Pentagon budget in this decade, the Bush Administration and Congress are so absorbed in the politics of the moment that neither has begun to develop a strategy for using the money.

LEAD: Phoebe Neville often suggests an oracular priestess in her dances, and when she literally plays with fire by tossing a fireball from one gloved hand to another in her solo ''Memory,'' she again seems to possess a magic power.

Jesse Jackson's 'Stunning Victory'
LEAD: To the Editor:


Death Overseas: After Cairo Fire
LEAD: WHAT happens when a family member dies abroad?
Events after the deaths of Marver and Sheva Bernstein, two of the four Americans who were among the 17 people who died in the Heliopolis Sheraton fire in Cairo March 1, offer a case study of how the State Department responds to such incidents overseas and provide insights that people hope they will never need.


Visitors to Vilnius Glimpse Their Parents' Past
LEAD: When the lights flickered out in President Vytautas Landsbergis's office one evening this week, Carla Gruodis feared Moscow was at work again, turning up the psychological pressure on the Lithuanian President and his rebellious Government.


Review/Theater;   'The Nature of Things'
LEAD: ''I'm a wild animal; no one can tame me,'' says David Cale, expressing his outsider's vision of the world.
There is something undomesticated, almost anti-theatrical about this performance artist.
Those unfamiliar with his work might wonder if he had just wandered on stage from the audience.
Because the sky is blue, he asks if he is breathing blue air - and he contemplates what birds are thinking about as they fly, leaving the suggestion that thinking might be antithetical to flying.


THE AUTHOR FROM CALCUTTA
LEAD:
SATYAJIT RAY: The Inner Eye.
By Andrew Robinson. (University of California, $29.95.) Film buffs will be fascinated by ''Satyajit Ray,'' a study of India's most widely acclaimed director.
Born into a gifted Calcutta family in 1921, Mr.
Ray shot his first movie, ''Pather Panchali,'' with amateur actors and no script; its budget was so minuscule that at one point the director had to pawn his wife's jewelry to buy lunch for his crew.


SCHUYLERVILLE STANDS STILL;
LEAD: A FEW YEARS AGO I BOUGHT AN OLD house in a village named Schuylerville, 30 miles north of Albany, on the Hudson River.
I'd gotten priced out of the rental market in nearby Saratoga Springs, which was awash with prosperity and tourists, and Schuylerville was full of real estate ''bargains.'' Nestled beneath steep hills running down to the riverbank, it was a sad-looking town, clearly fallen on hard times.


Question of the Week;   Should College Athletes Be Paid?
LEAD: All college athletes in revenue-producing sports should be paid.
To ease the burden on smaller, less affluent programs, the N.C.A.A. should set aside money from all tournament revenue and provide participants their shares.
All athletes would be paid equally, using minimum wage as a guideline, just as if their extracurricular activity were a part-time campus job.


Elizabeth P. Guest, 79, A Patron of the Arts
LEAD: Elizabeth Polk Guest, a patron of classical music in New York and Washington, died of a heart attack on Friday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.
She was 79 years old and lived in Islesboro, Maine, and Front Royal, Va.

THE DRINK OF MILLIONS
LEAD: Before reading ''The Drink of Millions'' I would have assumed that Joseph Conway, head of the Bureau of Water Supply, had at least an inkling that it is important to conserve water.
Isn't his agency responsible for all those ''Don't Drip New York Dry'' posters I see in public restrooms and on the subway?

LEAD: To the Editor:


Campus Life: Harvard;   Conservatives Start Magazine To Preach 'Truth'
LEAD: Frustrated by what they call a moral wasteland on campus, politically conservative Harvard students have founded a magazine that they say preaches the ''absolute truth'' on issues like abortion, homosexuality and affirmative action.


Alvin R. Jennings, 85, Managed 'Big 8' Firm
LEAD: Alvin R. Jennings, a former managing partner of Coopers &amp; Lybrand and a past president of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, died of a stroke on March 14 in Miami, where he lived in retirement.
He was 85 years old.


Evening Hours;   The Guests Sang For Their Supper
LEAD: Franco Zeffirelli's production of ''Don Giovanni'' made its debut on Thursday at the Metropolitan Opera, the 13th new production underwritten by Sybil Harrington, the Texas philanthropist.
Carroll and Milton Petrie gave the opening-night party, and the guests applauded the principals as they arrived at the champagne supper.


Richard R. Wins by a Nose
LEAD: Richard R. regained the lead from For Really in the final stride of a stretchlong duel to win the $110,800 Bay Shore Stakes by a long nose yesterday at Aqueduct.


Fashion;   Easter Isn't Just for the Bunny Rabbit
LEAD: Tradition holds sway again on the bunny trail, with ruffles and lace for girls and nautical themes for boys this Easter, perhaps because the holiday offers a rare chance to get the children into dress-up clothes.


Style Makers;   Alviero Martini, Graphic Designer
LEAD: It's a safe bet that when Alviero Martini arrived at Kennedy International Airport from Italy recently, he had more bags than any other traveler.
He was carrying dozens of samples of his new luggage collection, and you might say it stopped traffic. ''Everyone wanted to know where I got it,'' he reported with glee.


WHEN BRITISH JUSTICE FAILED
LEAD: Kevin Toolis's article helped to rectify the slander against four blameless individuals.
The author, however, may have overlooked the most sobering aspect of the case: was it bigotry - or racism - that triggered the illegal and excessive response of the authorities?


Now, Slyly, Comes The Yuppie Devil
LEAD: When Mephistopheles shows up wearing a gold Rolex he's truly a creature for our age.
Meet the yuppie devil: relaxed, assured, the very model of casual elegance even if he has no visible means of support.
He loves risks, particularly if they're being taken by others.
He loves comfort, especially comfort of the high-tech, high-gloss kind.


What About Me?
LEAD: To the Editor:


'Weapon' Test: Rentals Boom, Sales Pop
LEAD: A month ago in this space a question was posed: Would ''Lethal Weapon 2,'' Warner's smash-hit cop thriller released on Feb. 8 at $24.98, sell as well as or better than it rents?
Furthermore, would a movie rated R sell in a family-oriented market?
And would it sell after the Christmas season - in years past, the prime time for selling videos?


Searching for Quality Medical Care
LEAD: To the Editor:


Tech Notes;   Using Lasers to Repair a Cornea
LEAD: A two-year-old company, Phoenix Lasers Systems Inc., in San Francisco, has applied laser techniques developed for the military to ophthalmic surgery.
The new system combines a low-energy blue-green laser with a computer workstation.
The system is employed in the surgical technique called refractive keraplasty, which is used to alter the shape of the cornea to repair vision impairments, including near- and far-sightedness and glaucoma.


Ethnic Unrest Continues in Romania The Government has retracted accusations that Hungary fueled tensions that led to the rioting. (Reuters)


STARK CYCLADIC FIGURES HAUNT CONTEMPORARY COLLECTORS
LEAD: Travelers to Greece more than a century ago returned to other European countries with the eyeless, mouthless Cycladic idols that historians at the time described as primitive, even ugly.
Today these 5,000-year-old white marble figures - most of which depict women with their arms folded flat against their chests - are among the most prized of ancient artifacts and are viewed by many curators, historians and collectors as, in Picasso's words, ''magical objects.


Colorful Needlepoint That Reflects Brazil
LEAD: LIKE much of Brazil's heritage, the tradition of Brazilian needlepoint comes from its Portuguese past.
The stitches found in intricate needlepoint tapestries or rugs have been developed from the Portuguese Arraiolos stitch, named after a small town in Portugal.


Unsticking a Window
LEAD: WHEN spring presents the opportunity to open a home to the outdoors, owners of double-hung windows often find them stuck tight.
Sometimes, the cause is paint applied during a winter remodeling; most of the time, the cause is swelling of wooden window parts because of moisture.


Campus Life: Carnegie-Mellon;   Using Balloons To Bring Attention To Women's Place
LEAD: Orange balloons wandered around Carnegie-Mellon University's Pittsburgh campus this month, signaling the celebration of International Women's Day.
The balloons, provided by the Carnegie-Mellon Women's Center, were distributed to passers-by - female passers-by that is.
Men who wanted balloons were refused.


Knick Playoff Tickets
LEAD: With the Knicks apparently headed for the playoffs, the team has announced details of a postcard lottery to allocate tickets to home games.


Nicaragua Rivals Praise Contra Move to Disband
LEAD: All sides in Nicaragua's long civil conflict today hailed the contras' agreement on Friday to disband their army, apparently eliminating the most important obstacle to a peaceful transfer of power on April 25 between the Sandinistas and the newly elected government.


Freud, Though a Genius, Was Also Human;   Nothing Has Improved
LEAD: To the Editor:


Men, Women and China
LEAD: To the Editor:


Softer Line
LEAD: Roman Catholic leaders have been talking as if being a little bit against abortion is like being a little bit pregnant.
But Joseph Cardinal Bernardin of Chicago says reasonable minds, or at least politicians' minds, can differ on the subject.
Even while Catholic officeholders are more or less obligated to oppose abortion, he said, they should not have to fear punishment for disagreeing on how to do that.


THE AGING HOOPSTER
LEAD: I am responding to Darren Kazimir's letter analyzing the basketball skills of those ''older guys'' (About Men: ''What Do You Call an Aging Hoopster,'' by Erich Rupprecht, Feb. 4).
As the wife of a 41-year-old die-hard lunch-hour basketball player, I see my husband as a competitive sportsman with a fervor for basketball bordering on a religious experience.


Loss of State Subsidies Threatens 3 Bus Lines
LEAD: THREE small bus lines, serving 7,000 riders a month in the Danbury, Middletown and Windham areas, could stop running as early as June 30, unless the state agrees to pay about $238,000 a year in subsidies to keep them going.


Realist Finds 'Bright Clear Sadness' in Skies and Shadows
LEAD: A PAINTER in the 1950's was, for all practical purposes, better Red than Realist, and the situation didn't improve much with the advent of the New Realism known as Pop.
Indeed, it seems now this movement did as much as Abstract Expressionism to make representation the self-conscious undertaking it is.

Outdoors;   Disagreement on Striped Bass
LEAD: There is considerable disagreement among biologists and anglers over whether Atlantic coast stocks of Atlantic striped bass have recovered sufficiently to allow more harvesting by sport and commercial interests in the coming season.

A Sculptor in Wood Joins Two Painters for Blue Hill Show
LEAD: AT the Blue Hill Cultural Center here, it is spring.
The Canada geese, without which no such center is complete, are stomping around the lake and the equally predictable Henry Moore bronze figure, a splash of verdigris in a taupe landscape, seems ready to join them.


Gunsel
LEAD: To the Editor: Regarding the derivation of ''gunsel'' (Letters on Travel, Jan. 21), the word does indeed derive from the old middle-high German word Gansel (little goose).
It is used to describe young, if empty-headed, girls.
With that meaning, the word is still used in Bavaria, Austria and the German-speaking section of


Data Bank/March 25, 1990


Troubling Doubles in 'Jekyll and Hyde'
LEAD: WATCH out for a spate of ''Jekyll and Hydes.'' No fewer than three musical adaptations of the 1886 Robert Louis Stevenson classic are going around.
Another, a Ridiculous Theatrical Company production, which is in a class by itself and may be the most sensible approach of all, has just closed in New York.


Question of the Week;   Should College Athletes Be Paid?
LEAD: As I sit here writing my check to pay another installment of my student loan, my heart bleeds for today's student athletes.
Having their dorm rooms, tuition and books paid for isn't enough.
The universities now need to pay them some spending money on the side.

Review/Dance;   Somber Choreography In Morningside Festival
LEAD: The fifth annual Morningside Dance Festival got off to a briskly produced start on Tuesday at the Theater of the Riverside Church.
The weeklong festival, presented by the Department of the Arts in Education at Teachers College of Columbia University, opened with eight works that stressed the virtues of solid craft and literate themes.


Flying With Film
LEAD: To the Editor: I recently shepherded 100 rolls of 35-millimeter film across more than 25,000 miles of the Far East where our worst enemies were a series of high-powered X-ray machines and a handful of inquisitive baggage examiners.
Some machines carried the false assurance: ''X-Ray Safe,'' and every examiner politely and firmly said, ''This machine will not damage your film.

Fiscal Bureaucracy in Japan Loses Credibility
LEAD: By engineering Japan's miraculous economic recovery after the war, steering the shaken economy deftly through the oil crises of the 1970's and then stabilizing the nation's financial markets quickly after the United States stock market collapsed in October 1987, Japan's economic policy makers won an international reputation for unparalleled management ability.

A Bad Bill Where a Fix Would Do
LEAD: An impartial auditor examines the books of a corporate pension plan and determines that it is overfunded.
Money, therefore, can be withdrawn without jeopardizing promised payments to current or future retirees.
So the corporate managers remove the excess money and give it to shareholders.

Inquiries Held Blocking Aid In Crime Cases
LEAD: Thousands of crime victims who may be entitled to compensation for their suffering are not receiving it because the New York State board that awards benefits conducts inadequate investigations, a state legislative panel has concluded.


Reviews/Music;   A French Orchestra Visits With Maazel at the Helm
LEAD: In a long and varied career, the American conductor Lorin Maazel has worn many hats, and in recent years he has doffed several of them.
The next one will be the music directorship of the Orchestre National de France, a title he assumed in 1988 after becoming principal guest conductor in 1977.
He now plans to leave the orchestra next year.

Reviews/Music;   Proof That Conductors Do Make a Difference
LEAD: Anyone who doubts that conductors can change the sound of an orchestra and do it on short notice should have gone to Avery Fisher Hall a week ago and then again on Thursday night.
In successive weeks, Zdenek Macal and Christof Perick have filled in at the New York Philharmonic for the scheduled conductor, Klaus Tennstedt.


Two Opposition Parties Leading in Hungary's Voting
LEAD: Early returns today in Hungary's first free parliamentary elections in more than four decades showed two leading opposition parties in a neck-and-neck race for first place.

LEAD: When the final horn sounded and Arkansas had beaten Texas for a berth in the Final Four, Nolan Richardson's thoughts were elsewhere.

Adweek Units to Shut
LEAD: The advertising trade magazine Adweek is ending publication of Ad Day, its daily news update, and Winners, its bi-monthly creative magazine.
Ad Day, which is two years old, is closing immediately.
The April-May issue of Winners will be its last.
Adweek said it made the moves to devote its resources to its core weeklies, Adweek and Adweek's Marketing Week.

Agassi Cruises Past Edberg
LEAD: The new, improved Andre Agassi, the one with the nearly monochromatic hair and kaleidoscopic shot array, played mistake-free tennis in three of four sets this afternoon to humble Stefan Edberg of Sweden, 6-1, 6-4, 0-6, 6-2, in the final of the Lipton International Players Championships.


Surplus Worries Maple Syrup Trade
LEAD: Bumper crops of maple sugar have created a huge surplus in Quebec, which supplies 70 percent of the world market.
And that has left smaller American producers in Maine, Vermont, New Hampshire, Michigan, Ohio, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin worried about lower prices.

On the Run While Afloat
LEAD: The AquaJogger, which is made of a foam material, fits securely around the waist by adjusting a strap of rubberized elastic webbing.
The product is not a flotation device.
Rather, it is a waist belt designed to give you the buoyancy to exercise freely.
With your legs and arms suspended in water, you are able to simulate any activity that might be part of a fitness routine on land.

Interim Pact At Eastern
LEAD: The leaders of the pilots' union at Eastern Airlines recommended yesterday that its members accept a temporary contract under which wages would be cut by 25 percent, but the matter was sent to the pilots for ratification.


Step Up (and Down) To Sharper Workouts
LEAD: SOME health-club classes in the Atlanta area involve more than hand weights, a water bottle and a sweat towel for aerobic workouts.
Exercisers find they need another prop: a low bench for stepping up and down in a choreographed routine set to music.
They call their program step training.

LEAD: The head of legal affairs for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York was named the acting president of Covenant House, and an Upper West Side pastor was made his deputy, John Cardinal O'Connor announced yesterday.


Jails Being Jammed Faster Than Being Built, U.S. Finds
LEAD: Municipal and county jails grew more crowded from 1983 to 1988 because construction failed to keep pace with a 54 percent increase in prisoners, the Justice Department reported today.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
N.B.A.
Heat 105, Bucks 102: Sherman Douglas hit a jumper from the free-throw line with 7.5 seconds left and slapped away a Milwaukee pass at the 1.3-second mark to lift Miami to victory over the Bucks last night in Miami.
The triumph snapped the Heat's losing streak at five games and gave the second-year franchise (16-54) more victories than it had last season.


Fiat Widens Soviet Deal
LEAD: Fiat S.p.A. has agreed to expand its joint auto venture with the Soviet Union to include the manufacture of engines and transmissions for the entire projected annual production of cars at the Yelabuga plant outside Moscow, a Fiat spokesman said last week.
Fiat will roughly triple the number of engines and parts to be made at the plant, the spokesman said on Friday.

The Editorial Notebook;   For Police: A $76 Million Question
LEAD: What's the price of lost public trust?
According to one New York City jury, it's $76 million.
The panel awarded that to two Brooklyn men it found to have been callously abused by police.
The case, coming at a time of heightened concern about rising violence, including police shootings of suspects, underlines the desirability of having civilians oversee law enforcement.

Atwater Leaves the Hospital
LEAD: Lee Atwater, the Republican national chairman, was released from George Washington University Hospital today after physicians adjusted the medication he is taking for a brain tumor, an aide said.
The 39-year-old Mr.
Atwater took radiation treatment at the hospital Saturday.
A small, nonmalignant tumor was discovered this month on the right side of his brain after he collapsed as he was making a speech.

Business Scene;   Global Strategies Vs. National Ties
LEAD: FOR many American manufacturers, putting factories abroad - going global - is a top priority.
They are learning to be as much at home in Europe and Asia as they are in the United States, and in the process they are redefining the meaning of ''home country.'' Having one is still important, it seems, but not in the old sense of the phrase.

LEAD: Armenians shot residents and set fire to houses in three villages in western Azerbaijan over the weekend, burning a family of five to death and killing two others, officials reported today.


2 Shot Dead in Manhattan
LEAD: Two men were shot to death on a street in Manhattan's West Side last evening in an apparently drug related dispute, the police said.
The incident occurred at 6:45 P.M. in front of 200 West 109th Street, said Sgt.
Edward Burns, a police spokesman.
He said that no weapons were found at the scene and that there were no known witnesses to the shootings.

38 Illegals Detained in Ohio
LEAD: Police stopped a rental truck near here Saturday and found 38 illegal aliens hiding inside.
The aliens, all men, were sent back to Mexico by airplane.
The police in Cleveland were lead to the truck by a report from a resident in Chardon, 24 miles northeast of Cleveland, who said that it had appeared in the village early Saturday with men acting suspiciously.

The Century's Worst Fires
LEAD: Following are some of the worst building fires, in terms of lives lost, in the United States and its possessions since 1900.
Dec. 30, 1903, Iroquois Theater, Chicago, 602 dead
Nov. 28, 1942, Cocoanut Grove Nightclub, Boston, 491 dead
April 21, 1930, penitentiary, Columbus, Ohio, 320 dead
April 23, 1940, dance hall, Natchez, Miss., 198 dead
March 4, 1908, school, Collinwood, Ohio, 176 dead

Titles in Succession
Q.
City College of New York is the only college basketball team to win both the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament and the National Invitation Tournament in the same year, 1950.
Has any school ever won each tournament in successive years?
A.
It hasn't happened since the tournaments began doing business a year apart in 1938, when the first N.I.T.

Market Place;   The Pressures On Drug Stocks
LEAD: THE robust earnings growth that polished the attractiveness of drug stocks in the 1980's owed much to aggressive increases in drug prices.
But pressures to restrain prices are building and that may at least partly explain why pharmaceutical stocks have slipped.
This year, pharmaceuticals trail the market by about 5 percent.

LEAD: Oil companies bid $589.5 million last week for the right to drill in United States waters in the Gulf of Mexico, the biggest total in five years and a sign that the industry is recovering.

LEAD: Jerome Ford stared at the photographs spread on the table at Public School 67 in the Bronx yesterday.
He recognized five faces: his wife's three brothers, a teen-age niece and a cousin.
He realized what the photographs meant: the five had been trapped when an illegal social club was transformed from an oasis of dancing and drinking into an inferno.

Bridge
LEAD: The Spring National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League began its final day here today with the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship the main topic of discussion.
A team led by Dan Morse of Houston and comprising John Sutherlin of San Francisco, Tom Sanders of Nashville, Bill Pollack of Englewood, N.J., Mike Kamil of Bergenfield, N.J., and Ron Gerard of White Plains won a convincing victory Friday night.

LEAD: New orders for American-made machine tools in February fell by 3.4 percent from January, the third consecutive monthly decline.
The drop reflected a slowing of the economy and a stagnancy in the automobile industry.

Britain's Inflation Eases
LEAD: Britain's annual inflation rate fell to 7.5 percent in February from 7.7 percent in January, but the rate is expected to move higher in coming months, the Government said Friday.
The retail price index rose sixth-tenths of 1 percent in February from January, the Central Statistical Office said.
It said the March figures would probably be raised by increases in mortgage rates and in excise duties announced in the new budget.

Shandwick Ranked as Largest Firm
LEAD: Shandwick P.L.C. has become the largest public relations firm in the annual listing compiled by O'Dwyer's Directory of Public Relations Firms.
Net fees collected by the London-based firm rose by 48 percent in 1989, to $180 million, enabling it to leap over Hill &amp; Knowlton, whose fees totaled $164 million in 1989, and Burson-Marsteller, which collected $159.9 million.

LEAD: The Philips Display Components Company said it would build a $100 million color-television picture-tube plant in Saline, Mich.

Plans call for the production of a million 27-inch color-television picture tubes a year.

Patient's Marrow Emerges as Key Cancer Tool
LEAD: DOCTORS have long suspected that colossal doses of chemotherapy and radiation could triumph over a number of otherwise fatal cancers.
The only hitch was that doses large enough to overcome the tumor frequently killed the patient as well, generally by destroying the bone marrow, the body's crucial factory for making cells for the blood and immune system.

LEAD: Squeaky-clean, cheerful and bursting with energy, New Kids on the Block earned the nonstop screams that greeted them tonight at the Brendan Byrne Arena.

LEAD: An analyst who refused to retract negative comments about the financial prospects of Donald J. Trump's Taj Mahal casino has been dismissed by his Philadelphia brokerage firm.

Japan to U.S.: Tighten Up. U.S. to Japan: Loosen Up.
LEAD: Japan has a few ideas how President Bush can move quickly to tighten up the American economy.
To start with, he should strictly limit every American to just a couple of credit cards.
Then he should build a network of bullet trains across America, impose a stiff gasoline tax and get rid of low-interest car loans, all to get gas-guzzlers off the road.


BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:
THE ECONOMY
The savings industry had its worst year ever in 1989, with losses soaring to $19.2 billion, regulators said.
Although a record loss had been expected, the amount surprised experts.
Indeed, losses from operations for 485 troubled institutions amounted to $2.6 billion in the fourth quarter, equivalent to a taxpayer loss of $29 million a day as long as the institutions stayed open in that period.


Vance Elected to Board
LEAD: David Vance, vice president of racing operations for the Edward J. DeBartolo Corporation, has been elected to the board of trustees of the New York Racing Association, which operates Aqueduct, Belmont Park and Saratoga.
Vance, whose election must be approved by the New York State Racing and Wagering Board, will continue to work for DeBartolo, who owns Louisiana Downs in Bossier City, La., Thistledown near Cleveland and Remington Park in Oklahoma City.


Gold Falls As Mideast Sales Jump
LEAD: Gold prices plunged yesterday in New York in near-panic selling on reports of unexpectedly large sales by Middle Eastern interests.
Statisticians at the Commodity Exchange in New York said the decline of more than $23 an ounce was the biggest one-day drop since Feb. 28, 1983, when bullion plunged by $42.50, to $400.50.


Review/Music;   Style for Period Instruments
LEAD: Searchers for appropriate 18th-century style on period instruments still stumble over the more mundane problems of playing the right notes, playing them in tune and doing both with confidence.
Sergiu Luca, in his violin-keyboard concert with John Gibbons at Weill Recital Hall on Friday, spent the evening as a model illustrator of how things were approached ''back then'' - with straightened, husky-sounding violin tone, with vibrato used as emphasis and accent rather than as blanket tone color, and with small subdivisions of phrase carved from longer melodic arcs.


Quicksand For Banks
LEAD: Bankers knew their problems with real estate loans were mounting, but Federal examiners now suggest that the problems are far more serious than the bankers have admitted.

John Dexter, 64, English Director Of Both Theater and Opera, Dies
LEAD: John Dexter, a leading English director of theater and opera, died of heart failure in a London hospital on Friday.
He was 64 years old.
Mr.
Dexter, who won two Tony Awards, was known for the sweep of his directorial imagination with contemporary plays as well as with classics.
One of a corps of directors who in the late 1950's and early 60's led the Royal Court Theater into the arena of new and venturesome plays, he was closely identified with the early work of Arnold Wesker.

The New South Africa?
LEAD: One model being considered by the Government for a constitutional settlement in South Africa calls for a two-chamber parliament.
One house would be elected on the basis of one person one vote, without regard to race.
The other would represent racial groups and perhaps geographical regions.


Lotus Is Shipping 1-2-3-G Software
LEAD: The Lotus Development Corporation said it had begun shipping a version of its popular 1-2-3 computer spreadsheet program for I.B.M.'s newest personal-computer operating system.
The 1-2-3-G software is designed for OS-2 and Presentation Manager.
OS-2 is the operating system for the most up-to-date personal computers made by the International Business Machines Corporation.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
N.B.A.
Nets' Losing Streak Grows to 11
Armon Gilliam scored 13 consecutive second-period points last night and the Charlotte Hornets went on to hand the Nets a team-record 24th consecutive road loss, 97-83.
The Nets' loss was their 11th in a row and their 30th in 33 games.
Gilliam, who finished with 28 points and 11 rebounds, scored the first 13 points in a 16-1 Charlotte run early in the second quarter as the Hornets went from a 4-point deficit to an 11-point lead.

Rig Count Down Again
LEAD: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States dropped last week by another 15, to a total of 893, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today.
The decline was attributed to seasonal factors.
But the count so far this year remains well ahead of the 1989 tally, when 766 rigs were working, Baker Hughes said.

Fluids May Aid Response Of Controls
LEAD: ENGINEERS at the University of Michigan are experimenting with inexpensive liquids that, in response to high electric fields, can change from the consistency of water to peanut butter in a fraction of a second.
These electro-rheological fluids are the focus of efforts to develop simpler, faster mechanical controls for cars, airplanes and submarines.

Theodore S. Cart, 91, Founder of 2 Concerns
LEAD: Theodore S. Cart, founder of two companies in Trenton, died on Sunday at his home in Lake Wales, Fla.
He was 91 years old.
Mr.
Cart founded the Pocono Rubber Cloth Company, manufacturer of material for automobile tops, in 1920.
Five years later he organized Atlantic Products, which manufactured luggage and sporting goods, as a division of Pocono.

Fennel, a vital ingredient in the summery cuisine of Provence, is used in all sorts of salads, soups and stews.
