Review/Television;   New Host and New Technology, But a Familiar Oscar Show
LEAD: Advice to Oscar the Diplomat: stay home.
The effort to make this year's Academy Awards show an international media miracle led to nothing but headaches.
Beyond opening up whole new worlds of triple feedback (from a malfunctioning microphone in Moscow) and global indiscretion (''Don't Cry for Me, Argentina'' was not the ideal musical lead-in for the show's Buenos Aires segment), the scheme to connect Hollywood with these and other capitals fell flat.


Cobb Eyes N.F.L.
LEAD: Six more underclassmen, including the running back Reggie Cobb of Tennessee, have been cleared for the N.F.L. draft, bringing to 28 the number of non-seniors who will be included in the April 22 selections.
Cobb, who was suspended from his college team last fall after failing a drug test for the third time, was one of four running backs in the group approved since last Friday, the cutoff date for applying.

Not-So-Crazy Talk From Japan
LEAD: Just who do the Japanese think they are?
Tokyo's negotiators and Washington's have been talking jargon to each other for seven months about ''structural impediments'' to trade.
Now the Japanese have found a way to show America how it feels to be patronized.

LEAD: The USLife Corporation, a major life insurance holding company, said yesterday that it had named William A. Simpson, a California insurance executive, as president.
The company already has a president, and it appears that there will be two.

LEAD: Much of the basketball talk in New York for the last 16 days had centered on the Knicks' six-game losing streak: how it happened, why it happened and would it ever end.

Toys 'R' Us Japan Bid
LEAD: In a case seen as a challenge to barriers against entering the Japanese market, the Japanese Government has agreed to consider a United States toy company's move to open a store in the country, officials said today.
Toys ''R'' Us Inc. has announced plans to open a 53,800-square-foot discount store in Niigata, 160 miles northwest of Tokyo.

LEAD: Lionel Simmons, who accumulated 3,217 points - the third-highest total in National College Athletic Association Division I history - and grabbed 1,429 rebounds during a four-year career at La Salle University, yesterday was named the 16th recipient of the Eastman Award.

Rival Christian Forces in Lebanon Continue to Clash Artillery exchanges flared in the highlands of Kesrouan province, 20 miles northeast of Beirut, and sniper fire was traded in East Beirut. Three soldiers were wounded in car bombing near a base controlled by General Aoun.   In a Christian controlled area outside the capital, children played on the remnants of a destroyed tank. (Reuters)


Norwest Bank Deal Is Cleared by Fed
LEAD: The Norwest Corporation said it had received Federal Reserve approval to acquire the First Interstate Corporation of Wisconsin, and it expects to close the deal about May 1.
Under the agreement, First Interstate will become Norwest-Wisconsin.


U.S. Praises Poland's Plans To Fly Soviet Jews to Israel
LEAD: The United States praised Poland today for agreeing to fly Soviet Jews to Israel and deplored the decision of the Hungarian airline, Malev, to stop flights in the face of threats of terrorism.


Oscars Off in Ratings
LEAD: The Academy Awards ceremony, broadcast from 9 P.M. to 12:35 A.M. on Monday by ABC, drew its smallest audience in three years.
The program had a 27.9 rating, the A. C. Nielsen Company said, and was seen by 48 percent of the television audience.
ABC estimated that 70 million people watched at least part of the program.


Rates Rise At Citicorp
LEAD: Interest rates rose at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper yesterday for the second consecutive week.


Moscow Worries About Effect of Nationalist Tensions on Army
LEAD: The crackdown on military deserters in Lithuania reflects growing Soviet concern over the cohesion of the Soviet Army in the face of ethnic tensions and draft evasion in several non-Russian republics, American officials and military experts said today.


John L. Morkovsky; Catholic Bishop, 80
LEAD: Bishop John L. Morkovsky, retired head of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Galveston-Houston, died of a stroke on Saturday.
He was 80 years old.
Bishop Morkovsky led the diocese from June 1963 until his retirement in 1985.

LEAD: Representatives of the Sandinista leadership today recognized the right of President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro to exercise full authority over the country's Sandinista-dominated army and security forces.

LEAD: William Thomas Scott, assistant to the president of the United Federation of Teachers and a former deputy city comptroller who played an important role in rescuing the city from its fiscal crisis in the 1970's, died of a heart attack on Monday at a friend's house in Tarpon Springs, Fla.
He was 71 years old.

Ford Cutting Jobs At British Factory
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said it would eliminate nearly 3,000 jobs at one of its British car assembly plants.

LEAD: A first-time film director is making a movie about disgruntled marines on the island of Guam.
Naturally he is shooting it on location - on a farm outside Schenectady.
Wildly over budget, he hopes to recoup his fortunes with a dramatic final scene, but, as the cameras roll, three cows amble into the picture, adding a jarringly bucolic note to the battlefield.

LEAD: Edward Cristy Welsh, an educator and economist who played a leading role in developing the nation's space program, died of a stroke on Sunday at the Charter House nursing home in Silver Spring, Md.

LEAD:
N.B.A.
Trail Blazers Rout the Lakers
Kevin Duckworth scored 11 of his 22 points in a 41-point Portland third-quarter outburst as the Trail Blazers rolled to a 130-111 home-court victory over the Lakers.
Los Angeles played most of the game without Magic Johnson, who sprained his right ankle midway through the second quarter and did not return.

LEAD: Dr.
Michel Mirowski, the principal developer of a device that controls sometimes fatal irregular heartbeats, died of cancer on Monday at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore.
He was 65 years old and lived in Owings Mills, Md.


Review/Music;   The Cambridge Singers In Their New York Debut
LEAD: Judging a book by its cover, warns the old saw, may not be the wisest way to select reading matter.
To apply the same folk wisdom to music, a live concert by an artist or an ensemble known only from its recordings should be approached with a caution verging on skepticism.
Uncomfortably often, it is technology, not practice, that makes perfect.


Mayor's Car Used in Getaway
LEAD: An inmate who walked out of the Nesaygo County Jail during a jail church service Sunday night and made his getaway in the Mayor's car surrendered today, the authorities said.
The 25-year-old inmate, Dean Dilts, who was awaiting sentencing for armed robbery, walked six blocks and stole a 1977 Buick from Mayor Russell Gilbert's driveway, the police said.

LEAD:
June 6, 1985: Alex DiLorenzo 3d buys the site for $885,000.

LEAD: Cher wasn't there.
Viewers can always depend on Cher's dress, or undress, to cheer up an Academy Awards show.
The vulgar opening musical number wasn't there, either.
Viewers could always depend on it for at least two days of coffee break conversation. (''Would you believe . . .?'') Last year's female fashion statement - prom queen run amok - had subsided into a certain cool minimalism, though there were still enough beads and sequins, plunges and slithers to memorialize Mae West.

LEAD: ''I hear what you never heard/I see what you never saw,'' Ryuichi Sakamoto and Nicky Holland sang on Thursday night at the Ritz.
They could have been singing about Mr.
Sakamoto's band, a coalition of performers from five continents that included the Senegalese singer Youssou N'Dour, a trio of singers and sanshin (lute) players from Okinawa, the singer and guitarist Arto Lindsay from New York and other performers from the United States, Brazil and Britain.

But he noted that the melons and vegetables didn't amount to much next to the profits from his main crop, tobacco.

Dinkins Bill Would Close Clubs Immediately
LEAD: Reacting to the fire that killed 87 people in an illegal Bronx social club on Sunday, the Dinkins administration has drafted legislation to allow New York City to padlock immediately any eating or drinking place ordered closed for violating fire or safety codes.


Suspect Wrote About Killing Family in '71
LEAD: Before fleeing 18 years ago for the life of a fugitive, John E. List wrote a letter to his pastor in which he told how and why he had just killed his wife, his three children and his mother in their house in Westfield, N.J.
Today a judge admitted that letter as evidence in his murder trial and released the text.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an obituary last Thursday about Princess Safiyeh Firouz, a member of a deposed Iranian royal family, misidentified her late husband.
He was Prince Mohammed Hussein Mirza Firouz.
The article also misstated the historical role of her husband's grandfather, Mozaffar ud-Din

British Rules on Stocks
LEAD: The Department of Trade and Industry today announced tougher requirements for the disclosure of stock purchases, making it more difficult for buyers to build up secret stakes in publicly held companies.
Starting in June, stock buyers will have to disclose to the companies the purchases of stakes of 3 percent or more, compared with the previous 5 percent or more.

LEAD: The trustee for the bankrupt Delaware &amp; Hudson Railway Company has been given less than two more weeks to find a buyer for the freight carrier or face the liquidation of the nation's oldest continually operated railroad.
United States Bankruptcy Judge Helen Balick granted a request on Tuesday from the trustee, Francis Dicello, for an extension to continue operating the road while a buyer is sought.

Percy Beard, Olympic Hurdler, 82
LEAD: Percy Beard, a silver medalist in the 110-meter hurdles in the 1932 Olympic Games at Los Angeles and the coach of the track team at the University of Florida from 1936 to 1964, died Tuesday in Gainesville, Fla., after a long illness.
He was 82 years old.
Mr.
Beard, who set five world records in hurdles events from 1931 to 1934, was a seven-time Amateur Athletic Union champion hurdler.


Basketball;   Nets End Slump Against Knicks
LEAD: The Knicks got a shocking reminder tonight that their deep-rooted problems have not been solved.
They had one of their poorest first-half performances of the season, falling behind by 18 points to the Nets, a team that had lost 11 consecutive games.
And in the process, the Knicks were badly outrebounded, badly outplayed, and badly outhustled by a team that has much less at stake than they do.

LEAD: JEANNE BARRETT says that her parents have been fighting for as long as she can remember.

Last fall Ms.
Barrett, her sister and two brothers, all in their 20's, decided to confront their parents about the fighting and the effect it was having on everyone in the family.

CLOSE TO HOME
LEAD: FRIENDS stayed in my apartment while I was away, homeless people.
They arrived with about 13 suitcases and duffels and departed without a shopping-bagful of dishes.
I am keeping the dishes for the duration, which is to say until my friends are settled down.
They have been wandering about town for 18 months.

LEAD: The Hungarian state airline will resume flights of Soviet Jews to Israel that were suspended last week after the carrier received threats from Arab fundamentalists, the state press agency reported today.

Retail Group President
LEAD: As expected, John J. Schultz has been named president of the National Retail Federation's retail services division in New York, effective Sunday.
He succeeds James R. Williams, who is resigning to become a consultant.
Mr.
Schultz was most recently president and chief executive of the B. Altman &amp; Company chain of department stores.

Ford to Shut Plant
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said it would shut its assembly plant in Lorain, Ohio, next week, idling about 2,700 hourly workers.
The closing results from slow sales of the Thunderbird and Cougar models assembled at the plant, which was also closed for four of the first six weeks of 1990.
A market analyst at Ford said that sales of full-sized specialty cars like Thunderbird and Cougar ''have been considerably weaker this year than the car market in general.


Israeli Army Drops Ban on Press Group Run by Palestinians
LEAD: The Israeli Army lifted a ban on a Palestinian news agency today, two years after the authorities shut it down by military order.

For the Courts, the Question of Liability
LEAD: Families of those killed in the Bronx social club fire on Sunday intend to file hundreds of millions of dollars in civil lawsuits against the property owner and the landlord of the building where 87 people died, lawyers said yesterday.


Dollar Gains Against Yen, But Falls in Other Trading
LEAD: The dollar rose sharply yesterday against the Japanese yen despite reports of intervention by the Federal Reserve, but it fell against all other major currencies in light, trendless trading.


De Benedetti Is Questioned
LEAD: The financier Carlo de Benedetti was questioned on Tuesday for six hours by a judge about his 65 days as a vice president of Banco Ambrosiano, the bank whose failure in 1982 was at the center of an Italian scandal.
At the end of the questioning, Mr. de Benedetti told reporters he was ''serene and satisfied'' because he was able to tell the magistrate ''the total honesty of my behavior.

Waiting List Dissolves
LEAD: East Germans used to wait up to 15 years to get behind the wheel of a Trabant, but they can now have a new auto in 24 hours.
A reporter for the youth newspaper Junge Welt, who tested claims that a Trabant could now be had as easily as a Volkswagen in a West German showroom, said he had successfully ordered one by telephone for pickup the next day.

- Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo With all due respect to Governor Cuomo, usually an articulate public man, I don't mind the mistake (about New York's budget gap) as much as the use of that most pervasive of contemporary cliches - ''behind us,'' supposedly meaning ''in the past'' and usually suggesting ''forgiven and forgotten.

Record Companies to Put Warnings on the Raw
LEAD: The major record companies have agreed to place a uniform warning label under the disposable wrapping of recordings whose lyrics may offend some listeners.
The labels, which will read ''Explicit Lyrics - Parental Advisory,'' are to be uniformly applied on albums, cassettes and CD packages, making it easier for consumers to identify such recordings.

LEAD: Apple Bancorp Inc. said its board would carefully consider a $38-a-share tender offer by Stanley Stahl for all its shares and make its recommendation by April 10.
The company said it would ask shareholders to postpone their decision on the bid until the board decided whether to accept or reject the offer.

Sony Disks in U.S.
LEAD: A division of the Sony Corporation has begun making laser disks in the United States at a plant in Terre Haute, Ind.
The new source of the disks, which are based on the same distortion-free digital technique as audio compact disks, could ease a bottleneck that has slowed the growth of the technology, which provides higher-quality pictures and sound than movies on videocassette tape.

Lung Chin, 84, Is Dead; Leader in Chinatown
LEAD: Lung Chin, a merchant and community leader in Chinatown for more than 60 years, died of cancer on Tuesday at St.
Vincent's Hospital.
He was 84 years old and had lived at 37 Mott Street since 1915, several months after emigrating from China.


Review/Music;   Soprano Takes Up Berlioz's Gauntlet
LEAD: ''Les Nuits d'Ete,'' Berlioz's setting of six moody poems by Theophile Gautier, is generally performed by sopranos or mezzos nowadays, though the cycle does not lie comfortably for any single voice type.
Barbara Hendricks, who took on the work in company with the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening, was therefore fairly typical among recent interpreters in that her voice seemed wrong for the music's demands much of the time.

LEAD: Once again, and for the second time in a year, the United States has allowed Communist governments to dictate American foreign policy.


GTE Debentures
LEAD: The GTE Corporation yesterday priced $250 million in 30-year debentures through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.
Underwriters gave the issue, which has a maturity of April 1, 2020, a 9 7/8 percent coupon and priced it at 98.441 to yield 10.04 percent, or about 155 basis points more than the Treasury's 30-year issue.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:
Removing Water Spots
Q.The finish of our teakwood dining table has water spots or rings left by wet glasses.
Is there some way I can remove these marks?
A.Water marks can usually be removed by rubbing over the white rings with some toothpaste, preferably a brand with ''extra whitener.


The Last Word in Recycling
LEAD: New York City's Sanitation Department collects 17,000 tons of residential trash and garbage a day, and recycles about 700.
Under a city law that took effect last summer, the amount recycled is to reach 4,000 tons by 1994.
The department is tackling its huge task one neighborhood at a time, gradually educating New Yorkers to bundle their newspapers, magazines and corrugated cardboard once a week in stacks no more than 18 inches high and tied with ''sturdy twine.

The Mood Is Ethnic, The Style Is Classic
LEAD: GEORGE STAVROPOULOS does not have to go far to tune into the ethnic craze that is surfacing in many fashion centers.
All he has to do is turn to his own heritage, since he was a couturier in his native Greece before he set up shop in New York in the 1960's.
His heritage is classic, and nothing has been developed to best the drapery on ancient statuary.

Bronx School Official Jailed
LEAD: The former president of Community School Board 9 in the High Bridge section of the Bronx was sentenced yesterday to six months in jail for taking kickbacks and gifts from school-supply vendors, the Bronx district attorney announced.
The former official, Curtis Johnson, 60 years old, of 1350 Washington Avenue, was also sentenced to 4 1/2 years' probation and eight hours of community service a week while on probation.

Newmark &amp; Lewis And Brick Church
LEAD: Newmark &amp; Lewis Inc., a leading regional retailer of appliances and electronics, agreed to acquire substantially all the retailing assets of Brick Church Appliances Inc., a New Jersey appliance and electronics chain, as well as a 220,000-square-foot warehouse and office building.
The purchase price is $7.8 million in cash and the assumption of certain liabilities.

LEAD: ''I sew front pockets,'' Filena Craft says of her work at the Reltoc Manufacturing Company here, where she is among 100 workers who make men's cotton pants.
Ms.
Craft, who is 27 years old, earns the Federal minimum wage of $3.35 an hour and takes less than $100 a week home to the trailer where she lives with her two young daughters.

LEAD: Cray Research Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire Supertek Computers Inc. for an undisclosed amount of cash.
Supertek, a privately held company based in Santa Clara, Calif., manufactures a mini-supercomputer compatible with Cray's machines.
Cray said the purchase would accelerate its entry in the mini-super market.

Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''We don't spurn the accident victim who didn't wear a seat belt.
We don't reject the cancer patient who didn't quit smoking cigarettes.
We try to love them and care for them and comfort them.
We do not fire them.
We don't evict them.
We don't cancel their insurance.''
- President Bush, talking about AIDS.


Money Fund Assets Off
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 506 money market mutual funds decreased by $522.1 million, to $391.62 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 158 institutional funds decreased by $603.7 million, to $91.39 billion.
The assets of the 246 general-purpose funds were up by $495.6 million, to $133.87 billion.

In what amounts to an admission of guilt, politicians of both parties concede that they've let the state get deeply into debt, and want to borrow enough to retire all or part of an accumulated deficit that's reached nearly $5 billion - a record high.

Review/Pop;   Rickie Lee Jones Mingles Past and Present, Time and Ego
LEAD: Rickie Lee Jones gets away with enough quirks to sink half a dozen other singer-songwriters.
She sings, most of the time, in a mewling voice, slurring her words in phrases that seem all but oblivious to the beat.
Her songs drift and ramble, in languid vamps that are always on the verge of dissolution; her lyrics do not shy away from childishness or melodrama as she sings about the utopian power of love.

LEAD: Sister Carol Brody, director of the Weekend College at Marymount College in Tarrytown, N.Y., died on Tuesday at the Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx after a brief illness.
She was 58 years old and lived at the college.

LEAD: Poland is preparing for free elections for a completely reorganized local government that Solidarity supporters hope will break the grip of the Communist Party bureaucracy throughout the country.

Sephardic Jews Mark 500th Anniversary
LEAD: The Sephardic Jews are already observing the 500th anniversary of their expulsion from Spain, an event that began in 1492, just as Columbus was sailing on his epochal voyage.

Plattsburgh Gets Probation
LEAD: The ice hockey program at SUNY-Plattsburgh, a Division III school, has been put on probation for two years for rules violations that the National Collegiate Athletic Association said included having athletes live at the homes of boosters.

LEAD: Kevin Rooney, who earned millions of dollars as Mike Tyson's trainer before Tyson dismissed him in 1988, has filed for bankruptcy protection after one of his homes was seized.

LEAD: Consumers feel more optimistic about future business prospects than they did last month but less positive about current business conditions, a survey released on Wednesday has found.


Isidore Adler, 73, Dies of Cancer; Chemist of the Moon's Dark Side
LEAD: Isidore Adler, a scientist, educator and researcher who was among the first to map the chemical composition of the back of the moon, died of cancer on Monday at Holy Cross Hospital in Silver Spring, Md.
He was 73 years old and lived in Silver Spring.

Former Principal Draws Probation in Drug Case
LEAD: Matthew Barnwell, the former Bronx elementary school principal whose arrest set off an investigation of corruption in New York City school boards, was sentenced yesterday to three years' probation, drug rehabilitation and 150 hours of community service for his conviction of cocaine possession.

It was a game of muscle-flexing, of establishing a foundation in case the teams meet in the Patrick Division final of the National Hockey League playoffs.

King Stirs Animosity In Douglas Hometown
LEAD: In 1492, Columbus discovered America.
Last week the city of Columbus, Ohio, discovered the fight promoter, Don King.
It's a toss-up which was more of a revelation.


150 at Jails Call In Ill; Cause Is Undetermined
LEAD: An unusually large number of captains in the New York City jail system - at least seven or eight times the average number - called in sick yesterday, the Department of Correction said.
There was no immediate explanation for the reported illnesses and the union that represents the captains said it had not sanctioned any job action.

Fire in the Bronx;   Victim's Mother Said to Sue
LEAD: A $510 million lawsuit was filed yesterday on behalf of the mother of a victim of the Bronx social club fire, a lawyer for the mother said.
The suit is on behalf of Jennie Mae Danzler, the mother of Natalie Danzler, who died in the blaze, said the lawyer, Harry Lipsig.
He said the suit names the Happy Land Social Club; Clarendon Place Corporation, the property's owner; Little Peach Realty, which leased the property; Elena Colon, wife of the late club owner Elias Colon, and Julio Gonzalez, who is accused of setting the fire.


Winfield Finally Bats in a Game
LEAD: It was nothing much to speak of: Dave Winfield popped up, grounded out, walked and hit into a force play.
When he got back to the Yankee clubhouse, he was covered with dirt and perspiration and still looking for a hit but - as he has said often this spring - he was glad to be back.

Drug Tests Suspend 2
LEAD: Antonio McKay, world indoor 400-meter champion last year and a gold medalist in the 1988 Olympic Games, and Trevor Black, a long jumper from Jamaica, have been suspended by The Athletics Congress for three months because they tested positive for substances commonly found in over-the-counter medications, the athletics organization said yesterday.


Chronicle
LEAD: PEN, the writers' and editors' society, will honor two writers in absentia at its annual benefit on Wednesday at Roseland in New York.
They are BEI DAO, a leading Chinese poet and the founder of Today, a literary journal banned in China, and JACK MAPANJE, a Malawian poet.

Schools Faulted in Audit on Fire Safety
LEAD: Most New York City public schools are not adequately protecting their children and staffs against the possibility of fire, the State Comptroller's office said yesterday after its auditors found numerous schools with empty fire extinguishers, clogged sprinklers and missing exit signs.


New York Court Says Defendants Can't Reject Jurors Based on Race
LEAD: New York's highest court today became the first in any state to rule that lawyers for criminal defendants cannot dismiss prospective jurors because of their race.
In issuing the unanimous decision, the court also upheld the manslaughter convictions of three young men in the Howard Beach racial attack case.


Spinning Stories Metaphorically: Dances From Life
LEAD: DANCE is an inherently metaphoric art.
Two very different worlds are suggested by the mere presence of a single person or of two on an empty stage space.
As much can be suggested about a human emotion in a moment's turn of a body or lifting of an arm as in long pages of philosophy.

LEAD: LITHUANIA'S struggle for independence from the Soviet Union has virtually blotted out from public attention President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's decision earlier this month to accept the advice of his liberal advisers and move rapidly to establish the basis for a market economy.
A set of decrees is expected shortly from the Government on paving the way.


Review/Photography;   Hybrids by Larry Johnson Stretch Language to Its Limits
LEAD: That words are as much representations as pictures - in a way, they are pictures - has been a subject of interest to artists as diverse as Jenny Holzer, Barbara Kruger, Bruce Nauman and Ed Ruscha.
Compared to their work, Larry Johnson's images of short paragraphs of text are less theatrical, but perhaps because they are unvarnished photographs, they seem even more disembodied and confounding.


Black Enrollment in College Up After Long Decline, U.S. Says
LEAD: Reversing years of decline, enrollment of black students at colleges and universities in the United States increased from 1986 to 1988, particularly in private institutions, according to new figures compiled by the United States Department of Education.

LEAD: Johnny Neun, one of only nine major league players to execute an unassisted triple play, died of pancreatic cancer Wednesday at Union Memorial Hospital.

LEAD: *
Burlington Industries, Greensboro, N.C., a subsidiary of Burlington Holdings Inc., New York, announced the resignation of Richard Altman, president of its Burlington Knitted Fabrics division.
Frank S. Greenberg, chairman and chief executive of Burlington Industries, will assume Mr.
Altman's responsibilities.

LEAD: The three Kentucky Derby preps tomorrow might better be called Derby-prep preps.
Each is a warm-up for a more significant prep race under similar conditions next month that is likely to draw the same cast.


SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
LEAD:
Music From Hungary Muzsikas, Church of St.
Ann and the Holy Trinity, 157 Montague Street, at Clinton Street, Brooklyn Heights (718-858-2424).
Muzsikas plays slightly updated Hungarian folk songs that are ready to join a European Community.
The pungent harmonies, angular leaps and vertiginous slides that fascinated Bela Bartok and the impassioned sound of the Hungarian fiddle are still in the music, and some of the songs still spiral up to galvanizing peaks.

LEAD: Continental Airlines has settled a $336 million lawsuit against United Airlines that charged United with unfair competition in the use of its computerized reservations system.

TV Weekend;   Open Season on Husbands as Comedy Stars Return
LEAD: Two of television's most successful comedy actresses are returning to the grind of a weekly schedule.
Jean Stapleton, for years the dizzy but shrewd mate to Archie Bunker on ''All in the Family,'' can be seen tonight at 9 o'clock on CBS's ''Bagdad Cafe,'' based on the 1988 Percy Adlon movie.
Her co-star is Whoopi Goldberg.

New Incentives Offered by Ford
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company fattened cash rebates and lowered interest rates on some company-financed loans on six car and truck lines.
The car maker's current incentives will extend through April 30 to try to move some of its slow-selling models before the 1991 versions appear.


Nasdaq Would End Trades in Most Penny Stocks
LEAD: The Nasdaq over-the-counter market, responding to a crackdown on ''penny stocks'' by regulators, proposed new rules today that would end trading in most stocks worth less than a dollar.
The rules would scratch hundreds of penny stocks from the 4,910 issues now traded on the Nasdaq.

Industries P.L.C., according to executives close to Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., which is handling the sale.

Review/Art;   The Burden of Isolation, In Baselitz 'Hero' Paintings
LEAD: The West German painter Georg Baselitz gained fame in the United States in the early 1980's for his strident paintings of inverted figures, canvases whose loony arbitrariness abstracted the world by simply turning it on its head.
Generally grouped into the Neo-Expressionist category, his paintings earned a mixed response; to no extent did Mr.


Imetal to Merge With Copperweld
LEAD: Imetal S.A., a French industrial holding company, and the Copperweld Corporation said they had agreed to merge.
Under the agreement, each outstanding Copperweld share will be converted into the right to receive $17 in cash.
Imetal, based in Paris, owns almost 5.8 million shares, or about 65.2 percent, of Copperweld's common stock.


G.M. Is Backed On Plant Closing
LEAD: An arbitrator ruled that the General Motors Corporation was within its rights under a labor contract with the United Automobile Workers union in 1988 when it closed an assembly plant in Pontiac, Mich., that produced the Pontiac Fiero.
But the subject of plant closings and job security will probably be a primary issue when Big Three and union negotiators begin bargaining for a new contract later this year.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about money market funds misidentified the distributor of Evergreen Tax-Exempt Fund.
It is the Evergreen Asset Management Corporation.


First Chicago Profit Outlook
LEAD: The First Chicago Corporation, parent of the First National Bank of Chicago, said today that troubled real estate loans will cause a drop of about 50 percent in first-quarter earnings compared with the 1989 period.
In last year's first quarter, First Chicago earned $120 million, or $1.72 a share.


Weekends at Dusk, a New Met Museum
LEAD: LAST fall, when the Metropolitan Museum of Art announced plans to stay open late on Friday and Saturday evenings instead of Tuesdays, it seemed that another well-established tradition was being needlessly tinkered with; it wasn't broken, so why fix it?
How could a museum hope to compete for attention on weekend evenings, hours already so flooded with entertainment options?

Review/Art;   The Independent Works of an Insider's Outsider
LEAD: Since the sculptor Alain Kirili moved to New York from Paris in 1977, he has been keeping his own counsel and thinking his own way.
He has praised the ecumenism of Barnett Newman and the struggle of David Smith against what Mr.
Kirili calls ''American Puritanism.'' He has expressed his ''passion for femininity and grace'' and a voluptuous French ease.


Bush, in First Address on AIDS, Backs a Bill to Protect Its Victims
LEAD: In his first address on AIDS since he took office, President Bush appealed today for compassion toward people infected with the AIDS virus and expressed support for a bill that would outlaw discrimination against people with AIDS and other diseases.

Mets Make Their First Roster Cuts of Spring
LEAD: The job market on the Mets took a pair of plunges today when three roster slots were eliminated and 10 rookies were demoted as victims of the mean arithmetic of baseball's short spring.


House, 265-145, Votes to Widen Day Care Programs in the Nation
LEAD: The House of Representatives today passed a bill that would both expand day care programs and provide more money to programs that already exist.


Sharpton Set Up Fraud, Prosecutor Tells Jurors
LEAD: The Rev.
Al Sharpton was portrayed yesterday by a state prosecutor as the mastermind of an ''ugly fraud'' who used a phantom charity in Brooklyn to steal more than $250,000 to promote his entertainment business interests and to satisfy his ''hunger for money.''


Lamenting Larks
LEAD: Starting Sunday, little kids can stay out longer, big kids and adults can get home from work before the street lights go on and householders can save a few pennies on the electric bill.
It's the beginning of daylight saving time, an idea for energy-saving that originated in Britain in 1907 and, since the energy crisis of the 1970's, starts in this country on the first Sunday of April.


Review/Film;   Nonstop Action in 'Mutant Ninja Turtles'
LEAD: The difference between ''Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles'' the live-action film and ''Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles'' the animated television show can be measured in whiskers, matted fur, beady eyes and desiccated paws.
These belong to Splinter, the wise old rodent who is the mentor of the four title characters, a debonair fellow in the animated version and a thoroughly disgusting one here.


Pretoria Names Delegation for Talks With Rebels
LEAD: The South African Government announced today that virtually its full leadership would turn out to meet the African National Congress at talks scheduled for April 11.


Market Place;   Investors Shifting To Stock Funds
LEAD: AS the stock market scored choppy gains in March, small investors continued the trend of buying stock mutual funds that was begun in February, fund managers said yesterday.
In January, for the first time in seven months, more investments had been withdrawn from such funds than were put in.

LEAD: Knight-Ridder Inc. has named a publisher for Philadelphia Newspapers Inc., which publishes The Philadelphia Inquirer and The Philadelphia Daily News, ending the present structure of management by a three-member team that had included the editors of the two papers.

LEAD: While tennis players generally agree that the Davis Cup is unlike any other event they play, especially for its nationalism, team format and connection to what is now 90 years of history, matches rarely feature each country's best players.

Cecil D. Andrus, today offered the first hint that he might veto a restrictive abortion bill passed by the Idaho Legislature last week.

Kohl Urges Poland to Admit Past 'Injustice'
LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany urged Poland today to acknowledge that it inflicted ''an injustice'' on Germans who came under Polish rule after World War II.

LEAD: William Olsten, a pioneer in the temporary-employment business, is stepping down as chief executive of the Olsten Corporation at age 70, but plans to remain active as chairman.

LEAD: Authorities today arrested a retired Deputy Interior Minister who ran a camp in northern Bulgaria in which hundreds of prisoners may have been killed during Todor Zhivkov's Government.

Karl Brown, 93, Hollywood Pioneer In Cinematography
LEAD: Karl Brown, a pioneering Hollywood cinematographer who worked on D. W. Griffith's 1915 silent film epic, ''The Birth of a Nation,'' and wrote several screenplays, died Sunday at the Motion Picture and Television Hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif.
He was 93 years old.

Jefferson Smurfit In Recycling Deal
LEAD: The Jefferson Smurfit Group P.L.C. agreed to buy a Southern California newsprint recycling mill from the Giant Group Ltd. for $95 million plus $25 million later if Jefferson Smurfit decides to expand the mill within several years.
The mill, the Golden State Newsprint Company in Pomona, Calif., also operates 10 recycling centers.

Broker Case Is Settled
LEAD: Howard A. Rubin, a former head mortgage bond securities trader at Merrill Lynch Goverment Securities Inc., settled Federal disciplinary charges today that he had failed to keep accurate books and records about certain sales of mortgage-backed securities in April 1987.


New Pact for Welsh
LEAD: George Welsh, the most successful coach in University of Virginia football history, has signed a new, eight-year contract that gives him the option of moving into athletic administration, Jim Copeland, athletic director, said yesterday in Charlottesville.


Belgium Eases Its Abortion Law
LEAD: Overcoming 17 years of opposition by Christian Democratic parties, the Belgian Parliament approved a law this afternoon that would allow abortions in the first 12 weeks of pregnancy for women ''in a state of distress.''


4-Way Tie For Lead In Tradition
LEAD: The anticipated Duel in the Desert between Jack Nicklaus and Lee Trevino was closer to the Bust in the Dust at the first round of the Tradition tournament here today.


Knicks Miss the Big Shot and the Big Rebound
LEAD: The Knicks finally got Michael Jordan to miss a key shot in overtime tonight, but then they missed the rebound.
Stacey King, the Bulls' rookie power forward, left alone underneath after Kenny Walker left him to help stop Jordan, grabbed the ball and put it in with 12.9 seconds left to give Chicago a 107-106 victory here at Chicago Stadium.

U.S.-Japan Telecommunications Accord
LEAD: The United States and Japan agreed on a telecommunications accord today that is expected to open the Japanese market further, and tonight they were nearing an accord on increasing sales of American satellites to Japan.


Court Bars Moving Trial in Killing of 5
LEAD: The State Supreme Court yesterday rejected requests by John E. List to move his murder trial out of Union County to prevent publicity from influencing the jurors.

Maxwell Stewart, 89, Editor and Economist
LEAD: Maxwell S. Stewart, a retired editor, author and economist, died on Tuesday at his home in Sun City Center, Fla.
He was 89 years old and also had a residence in Annandale, N.J.


Coach's Intensity Brings Success To Duke Team
LEAD: When he was a young man, Mike Krzyzewski considered abandoning his family name for something less conspicuous, something easier to spell and pronounce.
His father, for instance, had switched to Kross.


Wave of Light Injuries Washes Over Mets
LEAD: The first wave of light casualties struck the Mets today when Darryl Strawberry, Gregg Jefferies, Tim Teufel and Tom O'Malley came down with minor injuries that will cost them playing time in an already short spring-training season.


Queens Murder Suspect Seized by Miami Police
LEAD: A fugitive on the Federal Bureau of Investigation's 10 most-wanted list who was sought in the attempted murder of two police officers was arrested yesterday in Miami, the police said.


New Xerox Copier
LEAD: The Xerox Corporation introduced a new copier that can ''phone home'' for help when it senses a problem developing.
The Xerox 5065, a mid-volume copier that produces 62 copies a minute, is the first Xerox copier to offer a built-in ''remote interactive communications'' system, which continuously checks the copier's performance and alerts a central computer when it notices a potential problem, a Xerox spokesman said.


Sports People: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;   Willard Moves Up
LEAD: Ralph Willard, who served as an assistant to Coach Rick Pitino for two seasons with the Knicks and this season at the University of Kentucky, became his own boss on Thursday when he was appointed head coach at Western Kentucky University.
On his 44th birthday, Willard became Western Kentucky's ninth coach, replacing Murray Arnold, who resigned after four seasons with the Hilltoppers.


New Move By Federated
LEAD: Federated Stores Inc., the American parent of Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores, said yesterday in Cincinnati that it was filing for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code to facilitate the reorganization of both Federated and Allied.


Japan Sobered by Recent Stock Slide
LEAD: As prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange shuddered and plunged last week, the switchboards at the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation lighted up with shareholders expressing amazement, shock and disbelief: This was not supposed to happen, they all said.

LEAD: When Barbara DeMaria, a teacher at Public School 92, learned yesterday that Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez had dispatched trustees to take over the fiscal and personnel affairs of Community School Board 17, her first thought was for the children: Maybe now there would be enough money for supplies, for security guards and for a recently eliminated reading program.

Patents;   Weight-Lifting Devices For Wheelchair-Users
LEAD: The manufacturer of Nautilus exercise equipment has patented a line of weight-lifting machines for people who use wheelchairs.
But the company is so fearful about lawsuits stemming from possible injuries that it may never market them.


CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost;   Outdoor Furniture
LEAD: With spring come new materials, styles and patterns for outdoor furniture.
Consider durability, maintenance and design when you make a purchase, and remember to choose seating materials that withstand the weather in your area.
Vinyl straps are easy to clean and will last a long time.
Textilene, a polyester fabric used for outdoor cushions, is cool to sit on and resists sun damage but can stain.

The first word is that it seems to be a good deal for many consumers.

LEAD: Orders to factories for manufactured goods in February bounced back 1.8 percent from January, when they had their steepest plunge in 16 years, the Government said today.

LEAD: Eight relatives of victims of the Bronx social club fire whose immigration status is unclear have received special permission from the Immigration and Naturalization Service to return to Honduras to bury their dead.

LEAD: Auburn handed top-ranked Louisiana Tech its first defeat in 33 games and knocked out the Lady Techsters, 81-69, tonight in the semifinals of the women's National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament.

LEAD: A Federal judge has lifted a restraining order that blocked the sale of the Mr.
Donut chain to its biggest competitor, Dunkin' Donuts.

Donut franchise owners could pursue their lawsuit to block the sale on antitrust allegations, but he said the franchise owners had failed to prove they would suffer irreparable harm while they pursued their lawsuit.

LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, in an apparent softening of United States opposition to Israeli settlements in Arab East Jerusalem, has said that Jews have the right to live in all parts of the city.

Sports People: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;   Bowden Signs Contract
LEAD: Bobby Bowden of Florida State signed a ''lifetime'' contract Thursday that makes him one of the highest-paid coaches in the United States.
Bowden, who has run the football program at Florida State for 14 years (his record is 122-40-30), will receive $708,692 this year and $690,000 annually in subsequent years.

LEAD: Frank L. Haynes Jr., vice president and assistant general counsel at the Prudential Insurance Company in Newark, died on Monday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan.
He was 45 years old and lived in Manhattan.


California Execution Stayed: State Is Appealing to High Court
LEAD: California's first execution in 23 years was blocked today when a Federal appeals court judge said Robert Alton Harris, convicted in 1979 of the murder of two teen-age boys, might not have had adequate psychiatric help at his trial.

LEAD: Covering the annual town meeting here is a two-cameraman affair.
Richard Thodal, a machinist who is the technical director of Middlebury Community Television, keeps one camera trained on town officials in the front of the room and monitors the equipment deck while Louis Megyesi, a high-school teacher, pans the audience with the second camera.

Are Some Catholics More Equal Than Others?;   Like Supreme Court
LEAD: To the Editor:


Chemical Bank Pushing Cuts in Costs
LEAD: The Chemical Banking Corporation, in a push to bring its expenses down to levels comparable with other large banks, announced job cuts and other measures yesterday intended to save $60 million annually.
The changes, however, will cause a special $52 million reduction in first-quarter earnings.


King Gains Shore Lead
LEAD: Nancy Lopez missed the cut today for the first time in a major championship and only the third time in her 13-year career on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour.


Official Offers to Meet Critics
LEAD: Dr.
Woodrow A. Myers Jr. was sworn in yesterday as New York City's new Health Commissioner, and he made conciliatory overtures to critics of the appointment.
He promised ''to meet with those individuals and community groups that must have input into the decision-making process, including those who have been critical of me and of past Health Department efforts.


Nobel Industries And Gillette in Deal
LEAD: Reaching agreement on a plan announced in December, the Gillette Company said it would sell its European skin and hair-care operations to a unit of Nobel Industries of Sweden for $107 million.
The deal, expected to be completed within the next 60 days, includes such Gillette European brands as Silkience shampoo and Aapri skin care.

LEAD: The pay of the chairman of I.B.M., John F. Akers, was cut last year as the computer giant's profit tumbled, according to the annual proxy statement issued by the International Business Machines Corporation.

Telescope, Bugs Out, Is Put Aboard Shuttle
LEAD: A $2.1 billion telescope has been loaded into the space shuttle Discovery for an April flight after 40 mosquitoes that invaded a cargo shelter from a wildlife preserve were captured.

LEAD: Evelyn Dawson Winn, who as ''Suzy Perette'' designed women's clothes in the 1950's and early 1960's, died of a heart attack on Monday at Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck, N.J.
She was 81 years old and lived in Cliffside Park, N.J.

LEAD: Helen Hoke, who wrote nearly 100 children's books and set up and ran children's book divisions in five publishing companies, died of bronchial pneumonia on Monday in a nursing home in Bethesda, Md.
She was 86 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

Putting the National Interest First
LEAD: Could it be that a Congressman would say no to a multimillion-dollar military installation in his home district?
Meet Byron Dorgan, North Dakota's sole Representative, who has withdrawn his support for putting MX missiles on railroad cars.
Having backed research on the proposed rail system, he now opposes construction, despite the fact that the Pentagon proposes spending $70 million to put part of the system at Grand Forks Air Force Base.

LEAD: With a couple of initials tacked on to the end of it, the name on the brass plaque on the door in a nondescript office building in midtown Manhattan could be that of a dentist or an accountant.
The man who answers the door, in his staid blue suit, sensible tie and no-nonsense horn-rims, could easily be either of them, but there are no initials after the name.

Patents;   Alternative To Cortisone For the Skin
LEAD: The steroid cortisone rivals aspirin as one of the most widely used medications.
Thanks to its effectiveness in reducing inflammation, cortisone relieves a host of skin irritations, from poison oak to eczema and psoriasis.
Taken orally, it can relieve asthma and other forms of lung congestion.

Dow Off 20.49 After 'Buy' Programs End
LEAD: In another quiet session yesterday, stocks slid after traders turned off computerized ''buy'' programs that take advantage of momentary price swings.

LEAD: The Pentagon will no longer block exports of the least powerful American mainframes, leaving control to the Commerce Department.

Doctor Aboard Copter Is Hit by Ground Shots
LEAD: Gunshots fired from the ground struck a low-flying military helicopter on a medical mission yesterday, wounding a doctor on board and forcing the craft to make an emergency landing in northern New York, the authorities said.


Dakotas Lawmaker Retires
LEAD: Brynhild Haugland, the nation's longest serving state legislator, has announced that she is retiring after 52 years in the North Dakota House of Representatives.
Miss Haugland, an 84-year-old Republican from Minot, has been re-elected every two years since 1938.
She headed the Committee on Social Services and Veterans' Affairs for 22 sessions.

Loosely connected by the theme of American cities, their strongest link is the worthiness of their subjects and their unadventurous nature as films.

LEAD: It makes no difference if prosecutors go after criminals with indictments that use bad English, the state's highest court has ruled.

LEAD: Sonor, the chamber group that played on Wednesday night at the Kathryn Bache Miller Theater at Columbia University, is a major performing arm for the active music department at the University of California at San Diego.
Mostly, Sonor plays new music by American composers, many of whom are either affiliated with the school or have written music for performers who are.

LEAD: Veterinarians and public health officials are urging pet owners to have their pets vaccinated against rabies.
Even though the deadly virus has been virtually eliminated from pets in many parts of the country, officials warn that rabies remains prevalent among wild animals, especially raccoons and skunks.


J.A.L.-McDonnell
LEAD: Japan Air Lines has placed 10 orders and 10 options with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation to buy new MD-11 jetliners from the company.
The deal is worth about $2 billion.
The jets are scheduled to be delivered beginning in mid-1993.
J.A.L. is one of 30 customers that have placed a total of 340 orders and other commitments for the MD-11, which replaces McDonnell Douglas's DC-10.

Japan's Inflation Rises
LEAD: Japan's consumer price index climbed 3.6 percent in February from the period a year ago as a cold weather snap pushed up food prices and a weak yen caused a rise in wholesale prices, the Government said today.
It said February's year-to-year gain was the largest since November 1981, when consumer prices rose 3.8 percent.


Coping: With Spring Gardening
LEAD: The folk wisdom used to be that March would ''come in like a lion and go out like a lamb.'' But this year March appears to be going out like a lion across most of the country.
So far, spring snows, rainstorms, sudden dips in temperature and high winds have put outdoor gardening chores on hold.
Patient waiting is essential.

BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MARCH 31, 1990


Rival Lebanese Christians Battle Fiercely, Killing 26
LEAD: Rival Christian forces fought pitched battles for control of Lebanon's Christian heartland today, leaving at least 26 people dead, as a rickety truce between the factions finally fell apart, the police said.


Bulgaria Sets Election Dates
LEAD: Bulgaria's ruling Communists and opposition leaders said today that the country would hold its first free elections in 40 years in June, completing the sweep of East European countries moving to democracy.
Participants in round-table talks between Communists and the opposition said the elections would be held in two stages on June 10 and 17.


Sports People: PRO FOOTBALL;   Court Upholds Bonus
LEAD: A Federal judge in Philadelphia has ruled that Kelvin Bryant, a running back for the Washington Redskins of the National Football League for the last four seasons, is entitled to collect about $500,000, the remainder of a $1 million bonus he was promised for signing in 1983 with the Philadelphia Stars of the United States Football


Lockheed Missile Work
LEAD: The Lockheed Missiles and Space Company unit of the Lockheed Corporation has received a $352.2 million Defense Department contract for the Navy's Trident missile program, the department said today.

LEAD: On Thursday, the Brooklyn chapter of the American Red Cross gave Felipe Diaz a plaque for his heroism in rescuing a woman who fell from the Staten Island Ferry last August.


Redskins Let Williams Go; Sign Rutledge
LEAD: The Washington Redskins said yesterday they would not renew the contract of 34-year-old Doug Williams, the quarterback hero of their Super Bowl victory two years ago.


Fernandez Takes Greater Control in Local Districts
LEAD: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez moved yesterday to strengthen his authority over New York City's local school boards, appointing three trustees to take over the financial operations of one Brooklyn district and temporarily blocking the forced departure of the superintendent in another.


Bridge
LEAD: Two well-known New York bridge personalities found themselves sitting next to each other on a park bench a month ago and exchanged greetings. ''Hello, Tom.'' ''Hello, Bob.''


Upheaval in the East;   Kohl Emerging as Europe's Top Leader
LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany is becoming the dominant leader of the 12-nation European Community, something that seemed evident today in his confident mood and manner after two days of talks with the community's biggest skeptic, British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.


Nominee for Savings Post Admits Trying Drugs in 70's
LEAD: This morning, the Treasury thought its battle to get T. Timothy Ryan Jr. confirmed as the nation's top savings and loan regulator would be won or lost on the basis of whether he was a strong manager, a tough enforcer and a quick study of the savings and loan crisis.

LEAD: A Brooklyn grand jury indicted a police officer on a manslaughter charge yesterday in the fatal shooting of an unarmed 14-year-old robbery suspect on Jan. 31.

LEAD: The dollar rose sharply against the Japanese yen yesterday, recouping Thursday's loss of 2 yen in New York, but it finished mixed against other major currencies in hectic domestic trading.


Barbara Baer Capitman, 69, Dies; Created Miami Art Deco District
LEAD: Barbara Baer Capitman, whose vision and persistence helped to turn a rundown area of Miami Beach into a vibrant Art Deco historic district, died of congestive heart failure on Thursday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Miami Beach.
She was 69 years old and suffered from diabetes and heart tremors.


Hicks, Muse Buys 7 Insurers
LEAD: Hicks, Muse &amp; Company, a private investment group specializing in leveraged acquisitions, said today that it had completed the previously announced acquisition of seven insurance companies from the I.C.H.
Corporation for $530 million.


Lincoln Center Discussion
LEAD: Six new Lincoln Center administrators will take part in a round-table discussion at the Paul Recital Hall of the Juilliard School, 144 West 66th Street, on Monday at 6 P.M.
They are Christopher Keene, general director of the New York City Opera; Robert Lindgren, president of the School of American Ballet; Robert Marx, chief of the New York Public Library's Performing Arts Research Center; Richard Pena, program director of the Film Society of Lincoln Center; Fred Sherry, artistic director of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, and Hugh Southern, general manager of the Metropolitan


Corrections
LEAD: An entry in the Company Briefs listing of Business Day on Thursday about the Colorado-Ute Electric Association's intention to file for bankruptcy protection misstated its financial condition.
Colorado-Ute says its debt totals $819 million, of which $407 million is owed to the Federal Government.


Fitch Is in Foul Mood After Another Ejection
LEAD: Before tonight's game was over, Coach Bill Fitch and Purvis Short had been ejected, and two other Nets players had been called for technical fouls.
At least the Nets did not lose without a fight.


Vietnamese Officials Tour Vietnam War Memorial


Savings Post Nominee Clears Senate Panel
LEAD: After last-minute lobbying by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, the Senate Banking Committee voted today to send to the full Senate the nomination of T. Timothy Ryan Jr. as the nation's top savings and loan regulator.


F.D.A. panel urges AZT for children
LEAD: A Food and Drug Administration advisory committee voted overwhelmingly today to recommend that the agency approve the drug AZT for treatment of children with AIDS.


The Case for the Mentally Ill
LEAD: Under the budget cuts, whole mental health clinics would be closed.
What will happen to the people who depend on them for therapy?
The suicidal will become more suicidal.
Some will die.
The extremely irrational will become more irrational and even less able to cope.


Forecasts on Plantings
LEAD: Corn farmers intend to increase plantings this spring to 74.8 million acres, up 4 percent from last year, the Agriculture Department said today.
Soybean plantings are expected to drop 2 percent, to 59.4 million acres, it said.
Wheat plantings for 1990 were forecast at 77.6 million acres, up 1 percent from last year.

Pro-Democracy Protests in Nepal Turn Violent


Eastern Air Says Sale Is Unlikely
LEAD: Responding to a threat by some of its lenders, Eastern Airlines said liquidation of the airline was ''exceedingly remote.'' The creditors of Miami-based Eastern, which has been struggling to emerge from bankruptcy proceedings for a year, threatened this week to try to force a court-directed liquidation of the carrier.


81 Nations Seeking More Food Aid for Africa
LEAD: The United States and the representatives of more than 80 other countries appealed today for additional donations of food and money for Ethiopia, Angola, Mozambique and the Sudan.
They called existing pledges inadequate and said that without further aid hundreds of thousands of people could die of starvation this year.


A-Plant Broke Cleanup Vow, Ohio Charges
LEAD: The State of Ohio filed contempt charges against the Federal Department of Energy and the operator of the Fernald uranium processing plant today, accusing them of violating a cleanup agreement.

U.N. Investigating a Killing
LEAD: The recent killing of a Palestinian United Nations refugee official in the Israel-occupied West Bank appeared to be unrelated to his official duties and a fuller investigation is being carried out, a U.N. spokesman said today.
The refugee official, Yasser Qazmouz, was reportedly attacked during the night on Tuesday by masked assailants who suspected him of helping Israeli forces.


High Court to Rule Quickly on Flag-Burning Law
LEAD: The Supreme Court agreed today to a Bush Administration request to rule on the constitutionality of the new law against flag burning and to do so under an accelerated timetable.
The Justices set May 14 for argument, making a decision by early summer highly likely.


4 Hurt When a Taxi Crashes Into a Bank
LEAD: A taxi crashed into the front of a Citibank branch at the Avenue of the Americas and 23d Street yesterday morning, seriously injuring the driver and slightly injuring three pedestrians.


Mississippi River Gaming Venture
LEAD: International Game Technology agreed to a venture with the Connelly Group to develop and run riverboat gambling operations on the Mississippi River at Davenport, Iowa.
The Reno-based International Game, which designs and produces gaming products and systems, said it would invest $100 million in hotel and riverboat centers and hold a 45 percent stake in the partnership.


Sports People: PRO HOCKEY;   Gretzky May Be Out
LEAD: Wayne Gretzky's back problem is more serious than first thought and could sideline the Los Angeles Kings' star for the beginning of the National Hockey League playoffs, which start next week.


MOSCOW'S FORCES SEIZE 2 KEY SITES FROM LITHUANIANS
LEAD: Soviet forces took over the State Prosecutor's Office in the Lithuanian capital today and seized the printing plant where the republic's main independence newspapers are printed, Lithuanian officials said.


Nonunion Workers And UAL Buyout
LEAD: The UAL Corporation's nonunion employees are seeking legal advice after failing to arrange discussions with union workers who are trying to put together an employee buyout of the airline.
An internal UAL newsletter said representatives of the nonunion workers had authorized their financial adviser, the First Chicago


A Reminder
LEAD: Daylight saving time resumes at 2 A.M. tomorrow. Clocks are set ahead one hour.


Simpler Plan Sought in Congress To Identify All Eligible for Work
LEAD: Leading members of Congress said today that the nation should adopt a simpler, more secure method of identifying citizens and legal aliens in an effort to prevent job discrimination against Hispanic and other minority workers.


A Eurotunnel Director Quits
LEAD: Eurotunnel P.L.C., the British-French consortium building a rail tunnel under the English Channel, said on Thursday that Tony Ridley had resigned as a director.


Ralph M. Freeman, Federal Judge, 87
LEAD: Ralph McKenzie Freeman, a senior Federal district judge, died Thursday after undergoing surgery for a ruptured aorta at William Beaumont Hospital in Royal Oak, Mich.
He was 87 years old.


For Mexico, It's No Fad
LEAD: This week's announcement that Mexico and the United States would seek to negotiate a bilateral trade agreement appears to be part of a trend.
Last year the United States and Canada signed such a pact, and now Senator Phil Gramm has called for offering similar agreements to the struggling countries of Eastern


Grand Jury Votes to Indict Suspect in Social Club Fire
LEAD: The man accused of setting the fire at the social club that killed 87 people on Sunday in the Bronx, was indicted yesterday on 178 counts, including murder, attempted murder and arson.


Korda Steps In And Stuns Gilbert
LEAD: The plan was to use him only in an emergency, and no one really expected anything like that.
But as Czechoslovakia's second-round Davis Cup match against the United States approached and it became evident that Miroslav Mecir's injured back would prevent him from playing, Petr Korda got his chance.

Suspect Is Arrested In Sex-Abuse Case
LEAD: A transit police detective posing as a parochial school student in Brooklyn pulled a badge from her high school uniform yesterday and arrested a man on charges of sexual abuse, the police said.


Costs of Oil War Cited
LEAD: An oil research specialist was quoted this week as saying that OPEC states lost more than $200 billion in revenue because of their price war in the mid-1980's.
Quoted in a United Arab Emirates oil journal, Nicolas Sarkis, head of the Paris-based Arab Center for Oil Studies, said the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries could have avoided the oil price collapse if they had not started undercutting each other.


Talks Held on Sale Of Child World
LEAD: Jeffrey A. Cole, the chairman of the Cole National Corporation, said he had held talks with third parties interested in acquiring Cole's entire 82 percent interest in Child World Inc., a toy retail chain based in Avon, Mass.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr.
Cole said he was considering a sale of the shares and expects the talks with the third parties to continue.


Strike and Shortage Fears Lift Copper Prices to Highs
LEAD: Prices of copper futures jumped to new life-of-contract highs yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York amid fears of a strike by miners in Papua New Guinea and perceptions of a sharp drop in deliverable supplies of copper in London.

Review/Music;   From Subway to the Concert Stage
LEAD: James Graseck began playing his violin in the New York City subways and on the street when he was a student at the Juilliard School, in the 1970's.
And although he completed his master's degree and gave a well-received debut recital, he has decided not to climb the career ladder in the usual way.
Apart from a few years of teaching, in Georgia, he has continued playing in the subways, these days under the auspices of the Metropolitan Transit Authority's ''Music Under the City'' program.


CHRONICLE
LEAD: The DUKE AND DUCHESS OF YORK have named their week-old daughter PRINCESS EUGENIE VICTORIA HELENA.
She left Portland Hospital in London yesterday with her parents.


Patents;   A Device to Keep Autos Constantly Tuned Up
LEAD: Two physics professors at Syracuse University patented a circuit this week that might one day make it possible for an automobile to keep itself constantly tuned up.


Liberation Leader and 10 Others Slain in Kashmir
LEAD: A leading pro-independence militant was killed in fighting in Jammu and Kashmir today and 10 other people died in a separate incident, the authorities said.
The deaths struck a blow against the powerful movement that has swept the region for more than four months.


Lawyers Bring Poindexter Trial To a Heated End
LEAD: In an impassioned closing argument, the chief prosecutor in the trial of John M. Poindexter said today that the Government had presented ''overwhelming evidence'' against the former national security adviser, justifying a verdict of guilty on all five criminal charges.
